headline: Far to the East of Moscow, A Brazen Rush to Capitalism
abstract: LEAD: The islanders call their beloved outsider ''E. T.,'' for Valentin Fyodorov has proved to be a boon-producing alien, rocking the governance of Sakhalin Island with strange events in defiance of the law to make people imagine themselves more and more in a free-market world apart from the rest of the Soviet Union.

headline: Many Buyers, but No Saturns to Sell
abstract: The scene inside the showroom at Saturn of Schaumburg, which has been open for only six weeks, is a car dealer's nightmare: flocks of eager buyers, but no cars to sell.    While assembly of the much-awaited Saturn car, a product of the General Motors Corporation, began four months ago at a new plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., manufacturing problems have limited output to just 2,162 cars -- about the number that could be produced in three days if the factory was operating at full speed.

headline: Ford to Get Unit Of Marine Midland
abstract: The Ford Motor Credit Company will acquire a subsidiary of Marine Midland Banks Inc. to develop non-Ford business, the companies announced. The new business will continue for now as the Marine Midland Automotive Financial Corporation. Later, its name will be changed and headquarters will be established in Nashville. The acquisition price was not released.   Ford Motor Credit provides financing help for dealers selling vehicles made by the Ford Motor Company and its subsidiaries and customers of those dealers. Marine Midland Banks, with headquarters in Buffalo, will continue handling Marine Midland Automotive's consumer loans.

headline: Israeli General to Return Millions in Bribes
abstract: Prosecutors said today that they had agreed to a plea bargain by a senior Israeli Air Force officer accused of accepting millions of dollars in bribes while purchasing United States-made military equipment.   The agreement, signed last week, calls for Brig. Gen. Rami Dotan to return $10 million in bribes and kickbacks he is charged with having accepted while heading the Defense Ministry's department of military acquisitions in New York in 1984-85. General Dotan was arrested in October.    He also agreed to supply investigators with the names of other people involved in the scheme, Israel radio said. In exchange, it said, no charges will be brought against General Dotan's wife, who was also accused of involvement.   The scandal startled Israel's military establishment and raised concern that it might jeopardize the $1.8 billion in United States military aid that Israel receives each year.    In announcing the plea bargain, the chief military prosecutor, Brig. Gen. Amnon Strashnov, dismissed suggestions that it could limit full disclosure of the corruption.   "There is no attempt to hide or to cover up anything here," he said.

headline: Airline Woe: More Seats Than Fliers
abstract: As many as half the nation's airline seats could be on carriers operating under the protection of bankruptcy courts within a few months if high fuel costs, falling revenues and fare discounting persist, according to Robert L. Crandall, chairman and chief executive of American Airlines.    "The airline industry in the United States today is literally going broke," Mr. Crandall, who heads the nation's largest airline, told reporters Thursday night at a dinner meeting in Dallas. "We have too many seats chasing too few customers."

headline: Profits Down At Hewlett
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company Friday reported declining earnings for the quarter and year that ended on Oct. 31. Revenues and orders increased for the period, but operating expenses and the cost of goods that were sold grew more rapidly.   For the fourth quarter, Hewlett-Packard had earnings of $202 million, or 83 cents a share, down 17.9 percent from $246 million, or $1.04 a share, in the comparable 1989 period. Revenues rose 5.9 percent, to $3.58 billion from $3.38 billion.    For the year, Hewlett-Packard had earnings of $739 million, or $3.06 a share, down 10.8 percent from $829 million, or $3.52 a share, in the previous fiscal year. Revenues rose 11.1 percent, to $13.23 billion from $11.9 billion a year earlier.   Despite the declines, Hewlett-Packard shares rose $1.375 Friday, to $28.375, on volume of 1.25 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts' estimates for the quarter covered a broad range, and the actual results fell in the middle.

headline: Yugoslav Merger Planned by SPI
abstract: Yugoslavia's largest pharmaceutical company has agreed to merge with the California-based SPI Pharmaceuticals Inc. in one of the biggest East-West transactions in Yugoslavia since World War II.   Under the agreement, which was announced on Thursday in Belgrade, the assets of Galenika Pharmaceuticals will be transferred to a new joint company, to be called ICN Galenika. The combined company is expected to have annual sales of $370 million.

headline: Judge Calls 22 Keating Charges Too Vague
abstract: A state judge ruled today that more than half of the 42 fraud charges filed in September against Charles H. Keating Jr. and three other former executives of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association were too vague to be brought to trial.    But the judge, Lance Ito of California Superior Court in Los Angeles, stopped short of dismissing the charges, as lawyers for Mr. Keating and the other defendants had sought. He gave prosecutors an opportunity to make the charges more specific and to refile them by Nov. 19.

headline: Patents; Old-Style Pencil Editing On a Computer Screen
abstract: Three researchers at the International Business Machines Corporation have patented a word-processing program that lets people do the equivalent of old-fashioned pencil editing.    The software program allows a person to scribble proposed changes in a document displayed on the computer screen. The idea is that people with secretaries can scribble proposed changes and store them with the document without having to make a printout.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: A chart on Nov. 4 headed "Wall Street, Tokyo," with an article about American securities firms in Japan, mislabeled figures for the flow of long-term capital from Japan. The figures were worldwide, not just for the United States.

headline: Sudan's Famine Denials Take Anti-West Tone
abstract: Officials of the Islamic fundamentalist junta here continue to deny that the Sudan faces the possibility of a severe famine, with a strong anti-Western theme as their underlying message.    Dr. Hassan al-Turabi, head of the National Islamic Front, the main financial and political backer of the Government, said in a recent interview in a Government newspaper, "It is a blessing in disguise when people seek to withdraw financial and food supplies to the Sudan."

headline: North Fork Set To Add Eastchester
abstract: LEAD: The North Fork Bancorp Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Eastchester Financial Corporation of White Plains for $15.50 a share, or a total of about $62 million. The agreement resurrects at a lower price an earlier agreement.

headline: Prices of Treasury Securities Decline
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday and interest rates rose in light but persistent selling throughout the trading session. Dealers said that because many institutional investment managers had closed their books for the year, relatively light offerings were more than sufficient to cause prices to be marked down.   In late trading, for example, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue that will mature in August 2020, were being offered at 105 7/32, down 17/32, while the yield rose to 8.27 percent, from 8.22 percent the day before and 8.18 percent a week ago.   Yield on Long Notes Down     The Treasury's long notes, the 8.5's of November 2000, fell by 11/32, to 102 24/32, to yield 8.08 percent. The yield on the long notes, which are competitive with Japanese and German "long bonds," was 8.01 percent a week ago. During the week, the yield on Japan's 10-year long bonds eased to 7.12 percent from 7.14 percent, while that on their German counterpart soared to 8.95 percent from 8.62 percent.

headline: Relief, Tears and Hope At the Hostages' Hotel
abstract: First the armed guards disappeared from the lobby. Then the plainclothes secret policemen abandoned their checkpoint in front of the elevators.    Baghdad's hostage hotel, the transit camp for the human shields President Saddam Hussein sought to place between his military-industrial installations and the threat from America's strategic bomber force, was suddenly transformed this week into an emancipation hall after Mr. Hussein announced on Thursday that he had decided to set all foreign hostages free.

headline: With Few Planes, Kuwaitis Try to Revive an Airline Without a Country
abstract: LEAD: At the well-appointed Park Avenue offices of Kuwait Airways in Manhattan, reservation agents wait with little to do, and computer screens once brimming with information are blank. But executives say they are ready to revive the only national airline without a nation.

headline: Bankruptcy Filing by Laventhol
abstract: Attributing its problems to a litigious society, changes in the tax law, a soft economy and negative publicity, Laventhol & Horwath, once the nation's seventh-largest accounting firm, filed for protection from creditors yesterday in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York.    The Chapter 11 filing is believed to be the largest by a professional-services firm. At its peak, the Philadelphia-based Laventhol had 318 partners in 52 offices and earned $350 million in annual revenues.

headline: Managing; Putting Women on the Fast Track
abstract: James L. Ketelsen, Tenneco Inc.'s chief executive, was frustrated. For a decade, he had been telling his people to promote more women, with little effect.    So in 1988, Mr. Ketelsen tried the grass-roots approach. He established eight women-only advisory councils -- a central one at Houston headquarters, and satellites at each of the divisions -- and charged    them    with helping him help women get ahead.

headline: New York Times Co. Posts 43.9% Drop in Operating Net
abstract: LEAD: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that income from current operations fell 43.9 percent in the third quarter, to $9.2 million, or 12 cents a share. That compared with operating income of $16.4 million, or 21 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year.

headline: EARLIER HARM SEEN IN GLOBAL WARMING
abstract: LEAD: After two years of study, an international group of scientists working under United Nations auspices has found that global warming could cause serious environmental damage starting in the early years of the next century, long before the maximum temperature levels predicted by many scientists are reached.

headline: The Gulf Crisis Forces a Diminished OPEC to Face Reality
abstract: Gathering just months after one of its members invaded another, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries managed last week to hold one of its shortest -- and least quarrelsome -- meetings in its 30-year history.    Behind the show of cooperation, industry experts said, was a painful truth driven home anew by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August: OPEC no longer controls the world oil market the way it did in its heyday. The group's diminished role can be seen in oil's wild price gyrations since the invasion in a market now fueled by speculators' bets on the prospects for war or peace and often indifferent to OPEC's successful efforts at maintaining world supplies.

headline: Sales Softened in September at the Nation's Largest Retailers
abstract: LEAD: Providing further evidence of economic weakness, the nation's largest retailers yesterday reported generally soft sales for September, mostly below the year-to-date pace and with especially disappointing results in stores that were open at least a year.

headline: Licensing Fee Suit Against Microsoft
abstract: The Z-Nix Company, a personal computer supplier, filed a $4.5 million lawsuit against the Microsoft Corporation, the giant software company, charging restraint of trade and breach of contract. The suit, filed in United States District Court, says Microsoft agreed to license its popular Windows software to Z-Nix for $27.50 a copy. But Microsoft is said to have sought to double the fee when Z-Nix wanted to pair Windows with a device it produces that points out material on computer screens.   The fee increase effectively priced the Z-Nix product out of the market, Z-Nix contends. A spokesman for Microsoft said the company had no comment on the suit.

headline: U.S. Suppliers Get a Toyota Lecture
abstract: Two hundred executives of North American automobile parts makers fell into a stony silence here the other day when Osamu Obata, a Toyota Motor Company official with little use for traditional Japanese indirection, made it clear that what was good enough for Detroit would not cut it in Toyota City.    "Unfortunately, there is still a relatively big gap between the quality of parts we buy domestically for Toyota cars and the parts we import," Mr. Obata said, pointing to a graph that showed defect rates 100 times higher for components supplied by 75 American and European companies than those supplied by 147 Japanese companies.

headline: Severed German Families, Starting Now to Mend
abstract: LEAD: For 40 years, the border that divided East Germany from West Germany cruelly divided thousands of German families.

headline: Air France Account To TBWA Advertising
abstract: TBWA Advertising has created advertising for French water and cheese, and now it will try to sell French airline services to American consumers. The agency's New York office has won the $5 million account for Air France.    Air France chose TBWA to replace Lawrence Charles Free & Lawson after reviewing six agencies. "We're aware that TBWA has one of the best creative reputations in the advertising business," said Bernard Morel, vice president and general manager of Air France U.S.A. "I am looking forward to a long and productive relationship."    TBWA, too, is ready to fly. "It's a leap of faith for an airline client to realize that we can do the work, being that we've never done work for an airline," said William G. Tragos, TBWA's chairman. Nevertheless, he called it "a smart, brave decision."

headline: Embassy Deputy in Iraq, Unschooled as Diplomat, Plays the Top U.S. Role
abstract: Two weeks ago, the United States deputy chief of mission here, Joseph C. Wilson 4th, received an urgent telephone call from the State Department informing him that "the balloon is going up -- this is no drill."    The Iraqis were preparing to fire, or had just fired, two Soviet-made Scud-B missiles, and Western intelligence feared that President Saddam Hussein was launching a strike either against the international force assembled in Saudi Arabia or against Israel.

headline: UKRAINIANS RALLY AGAINST MOSCOW
abstract: LEAD: Tens of thousands of Ukrainian nationalists marched today through Kiev, the republic's capital, calling for greater independence from the central government in Moscow.

headline: Vehicle Sales Up 12.6% in Midmonth
abstract: Propelled by rebates, sales of vehicles made in the United States rose by 12.6 percent in mid-November, compared with sluggish demand in the period last year.    Several analysts said they were at a loss to explain why vehicle sales continued at a fairly steady pace despite a weakening economy.

headline: Exxon Net Unchanged; Unocal Up
abstract: The Exxon Corporation said today that its net income in the third quarter was unchanged from the period a year ago. Higher oil prices depressed profits in refining, marketing and chemical operations and increased profits in worldwide crude production.    The Unocal Corporation said earnings in the quarter increased by 53.2 percent, with its production unit benefiting from higher oil prices and its refining, marketing and chemical operations recording modest declines.

headline: Britons Said to Train Khmer Rouge Forces
abstract: LEAD: A television documentary has reported that British soldiers have been training the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas of Cambodia.

headline: New U.S. Ambassador Reopens Embassy in a More Secure Lebanon
abstract: In a sign of improved security conditions in Lebanon, the new United States Ambassador, Ryan Crocker, arrived here today to reopen the embassy, closed for more than a year.   Lebanese Government officials said Mr. Crocker was expected to submit his credentials to President Elias Hrawi on Thursday. An American military helicopter flew him from Cyprus to a Lebanese Army base near the Christian port of Junieh, 13 miles north of here. Junieh is only a few miles from Auker, where the United States Embassy compound is situated.

headline: Plea Agreement Said to Include Testimony in Milken Case
abstract: Richard J. Grassgreen, the former president of Kinder-Care, a national child-care operation once recommended in Drexel Burnham Lambert advertisements as a beneficiary of high-yield "junk bonds," has agreed to plead guilty to two felonies involving securities transactions with Drexel, a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.   The prosecutor, John K. Carroll, said that as part of the plea agreement Mr. Grassgreen would testify in the pre-sentencing hearing of Michael R. Milken, the former head of Drexel's junk bond department. Mr. Milken agreed in April to plead guilty to six felonies.

headline: Volvo Appointments
abstract: LEAD: Volvo A.B.'s president, Christer Zetterberg, today was appointed chief executive of the Swedish vehicle maker effective Oct. 15, Volvo's chairman and current chief executive, Pehr Gyllenhammar, will have the title of executive chairman, Volvo said. The company said Mr. Gyllenhammar would devote his time to Volvo's alliance with Renault, the French auto maker, and to Volvo's strategic development.

headline: Burrell the Big Winner Of Black Ad Awards
abstract: Burrell Advertising, Chicago, walked away from the C.E.B.A. (Communications Excellence to Black Audiences) awards ceremony with its hands full. The agency won 18 awards, five of them for excellence, the highest of three categories. Burrell's winning ads included its campaign for McDonald's.    Uniworld Group Inc., New York, last year's top winner, picked up three excellence awards and nine in the other categories. Executives from Time Warner Inc. were honored for "a distignuished record of service to new African-American owned companies," said Quincy Jones, who presented the award at the 13th annual C.E.B.A. ceremony this week in New York.

abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.57   7.57   8.43        3-MO. TREAS. headline: People
abstract: * William P. Daily, a senior vice president at Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, Chicago, will join the Quaker Oats Company as director of sports marketing.  * Jimmy E. Manis, vice president and general manager of the Pittsburgh Press Company, and Dennis Stoakes, vice president and director of media for North America for Hiram Walker-Allied Vintners, Toronto, were named directors of the board for the Audit Bureau of Circulation.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Drackett Co., Cincinnati, a subsidiary of Bristol-Myers Squibb, to Bozell Inc., New York, for a new product with undisclosed bilings. * Home Box Office, a unit of Time Warner Inc., to Block Everett Nardizzi, Stamford, Conn., for on-air retention promotion programs. The agency has also picked up new business from Sealy Inc. and Lincoln Technical Institute with combined billings of $3.5 million. * H. P. Hood Inc., Boston, to Ketchum Communications, New York, for its ice cream division. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Decking the Desert With Good Cheer
abstract: In all of the United States Marine Corps this Christmas Eve, Sgt. Rodney Pigford may have had the most demanding job: to somehow spread holiday cheer among hundreds of young marines spending their Christmas in the Arabian desert, thousands of miles from home.    "That's my assignment" said Sergeant Pigford, 25 years old, the morale welfare noncommissioned officer at a sprawling Marine supply camp here known as Northstar. His plans for Christmas Eve include a screening of the film "Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles" and Christmas caroling in the recreation tent.

headline: Toy Chain To Suspend Paying Bills
abstract: Child World Inc., the nation's No. 2 chain of toy stores, said yesterday that it would stop paying its old bills for six weeks, seeking to conserve cash to buy toys that it needed for the crucial Christmas season.   "It is our goal to avoid a Chapter 11 filing," said Jeffrey Cole, the chairman of CNC Holdings, which controls the 182-store chain of toy supermarkets. "We don't think it is necessary." But he said the company might still be forced into Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

headline: USE FORCE IN GULF, 14 EX-AIDES URGE
abstract: Fourteen former senior Government officials, most of whom worked on national security affairs, urged today that the Administration use military force shortly after the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait.    The form of their message was a letter to Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, that was made public today with the intent of countering recent testimony by two former Chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. William J. Crowe and Gen. David Jones. In comments before a Congressional committee the two men and others pressed the Administration to postpone military action against Iraq and give economic sanctions a year or more to work.

headline: Del Monte President Gets Chief's Post, Too
abstract: LEAD: Del Monte Foods said yesterday that it had promoted its president, A. Ewan Macdonald, to the additional position of chief executive. He succeeds Robert J. Carbonell, 63, who will continue as chairman.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                  Nov. 2   Oct. 26   Nov. 3        1990   1990   1989        Gasoline production, daily   6.8   6.8   6.9        Distillate production, daily   2.9   2.9   3.0        Gasoline stocks   221.2   220.4   222.8        Distillate stocks   138.2   138.1   120.6        Crude imports, daily   5.9   5.1   6.0        Product imports, daily   1.6   1.7   2.3        Crude stocks   344.5   339.5   344.4        Crude production, daily   7.1   7.1   7.4        Refinery utilization (%)   84.5   82.5   87.1       Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: U.N. Council Returns to Israel Issue Today
abstract: The Security Council is to resume discussions Monday on a resolution on Palestinians living in territories occupied by Israel. The United States narrowly succeeded in delaying a vote on the measure over the weekend.   The delay has given Washington more time to try to change the proposed resolution. American diplomats oppose it because they believe its passage would weaken their demand that President Saddam Hussein unconditionally withdraw his troops from Kuwait; at the same time, American efforts to resist the measure are complicated by a reluctance to allow a wedge to be driven between Washington and its Arab allies in the gulf crisis.     In its current form, the resolution would give United Nations protection to Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied territories. It also endorses a plan to convene an international Middle East peace conference to resolve the region's problems at an unspecified future date. Passage of such a resolution now, the United States says, could be seen by President Hussein as a weakening of the American insistence that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait without any linkage of its withdrawal to other issues.

headline: Vietnam Says 38 Expatriates Tried to Topple Government
abstract: LEAD: Vietnam charged 38 men with treason or other acts of subversion in Supreme Court today. Prosecutors said that they got help from Thai intelligence and Vietnamese in the United States to try to overthrow the Government.

headline: Gorbachev and Yeltsin Confer on Economy
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met today at the Kremlin with Boris N. Yeltsin, the president of the Russian republic, and one report said the two rivals discussed special measures to feed Soviet and rescue the crumbling economy.   Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin met for two hours, an independent news agency, Interfax, reported. The conversation between the two leaders was conducted in a "businesslike, principled atmosphere," Interfax said, without quoting any officials.   It was their first substantive meeting since an attempt at reconciliation over economic policy broke down late last summer. Mr. Yeltsin, whom Mr. Gorbachev ousted from the Communist Party Politburo in 1986, has criticized the Soviet President for the Government's slow pace of economic change.    Among the issues discussed today by the two leaders were the Russian republic's role in possible radical economic reforms and "urgent measures" to provide food and consumer goods, Interfax said.    After their private meeting, Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin were joined by the Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, and two officials from the Russian republic, Vice President Ruslan I. Khasbulatov and Prime Minister Ivan S. Silayev, Interfax said.

abstract: Net Income   Percent       July-Sept.   Change       1990   From '89              Anheuser-Busch Companies   $ 260,700,000   +   9.4        Armco Inc. headline: The Breakdown of 'Junk'
abstract: Michael R. Milken was sentenced to 10 years in prison not for his role in a "decade of greed," but for crimes that were aimed at enriching himself and his clients, Federal Judge Kimba M. Wood said yesterday.    But Mr. Milken's legacy nonetheless will be his role in the 1980's, and much of the vilification he is now receiving stems from worries that the financial excesses of the decade will lead to disaster in the 1990's.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., said its Paper Corp. of America subsidiary would acquire Sloan Paper Co. of Atlanta. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. * British Gas P.L.C., London, said it had acquired 97 percent of the outstanding common shares of Consumers' Gas Co. Ltd., Toronto. British Gas's $34-a-share (Canadian) offer for Consumers' Gas expires Thursday.  * W. R. Grace & Co., New York, an industrial, chemicals and natural resources concern, will purchase a 25 percent interest in Grace Cocoa from Berisford International P.L.C. Terms were not disclosed. Grace will own 100 percent of Grace Cocoa when the deal is completed early next year. * Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., London, a food and drinks company, has purchased Jus-Rol Ltd., a British frozen pastry products company, from Booker P.L.C., a British farming and food concern, for $:46.5 million, or about $91 million. * Hotel Investors Trust, Los Angeles, said Park Plaza Inc.'s agreement to purchase 27 of its hotels had been terminated. No reason was given, but Hotel Investors said it would receive about $4 million placed in escrow by Park Plaza as a result of the termination. * Jetborne International Inc., Miami, an aircraft parts purchasing, repair and supply company, has sold its Aircraft Modular Products unit to RTE Acquisition Corp., a company headed by Aircraft Modular's president, for $9.6 million. * McDonald & Co. Investments, Cleveland, said its McDonald & Co. Securities subsidiary would acquire certain assets of S. J. Wolfe & Co., Dayton, Ohio, a stock brokerage firm. Terms were not disclosed. * Nycor Inc., Peapack N.J., a maker of air-conditioners, said it would create a new class of stock to help the company make larger acquisitions. The new class A stock is expected to begin trading on the Nasdaq market within the next 10 days. * Sanifill Inc. said it would acquire three disposal operations consisting of four disposal sites. * Textron Inc., Providence, R.I., an aerospace, commercial products and financial services company, said its board had approved the additional buyback of five million of its 89 million shares outstanding. * Westport Bancorp Inc., Westport, Conn., said it would not object to David A. and Jean D. Rostow's efforts to acquire up to 16 percent of the company's common stock. Mr. and Mrs. Rostow currently hold 9.67 percent of the common stock.

headline: A Data General Founder Will Leave Company
abstract: At the board's request, Edson D. de Castro, a founder of the Data General Corporation, agreed yesterday to step down as chairman. Mr. de Castro, 52, will leave on Dec. 31 and will not seek re-election to the board.    "I guess the board just decided it was time," Mr. de Castro said in a telephone interview. "I certainly wouldn't have initiated it, but if they feel it's time, then that's not the kind of situation you should remain in." He declined to discuss what differences had arisen between himself and the board, and said he had no firm plans. "I'm ready to get back to work," he said. "I'm looking for challenges and opportunities."

headline: Saudi Women Disciplined
abstract: At least 6 of the 50 Saudi women who took to the road to protest Saudi Arabia's enforcement of customs that prohibit women from driving have been suspended from their jobs, Saudi academics said today.    The six women were suspended from the Social Sciences Department of the all-female campus at King Saud University in Riyadh, the academics said today.

headline: Business and Health;   Giving the Poor Private Insurance
abstract: LEAD: SUPPORT is growing in Washington and a number of states for taxpayer-supported subsidies to help buy private health insurance for low-income people. In a provision in last week's defeated budget proposal, which Congressional aides say is being retained, the Bush Administration said the states should help low-income families pay for insurance premiums so they would not need direct assistance from

headline: Rumsfeld Becomes Chief At General Instrument
abstract: LEAD: Donald H. Rumsfeld signed on again yesterday as a chief executive, taking the reins at the General Instrument Corporation, a supplier to the cable television industry that was bought in August by Forstmann Little & Company for $1.6 billion.

headline: Car Loans Back Chrysler Offering
abstract: A $1.3 billion offering of certificates backed by Chrysler car loans was priced yesterday through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.   The certificates are being sold through United States Auto Receivables Trust 1990-4, a financing vehicle established by the Chrysler Corporation solely for that purpose.    Underwriters gave the asset-backed certifcates an 8.65 percent coupon and priced them at 99.7656 to yield 8.743 percent, or about 110 basis points more than the Treasury's two-year note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. These asset-backed certificates have an average life of 1.78 years and a legal maturity date of Nov. 15, 1995.    The financing is rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S.& P.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: Companies    General Motors is sharply cutting back its production for the rest of the year because of the weakening American economy. Detroit's pessimistic sales outlook has been made worse by the Persian Gulf crisis and dwindling consumer confidence.  [ Page A1. ]   Paine Webber plans to cut up to 9 percent of its investment banking staff next week, Wall Street executives said. At least 25 to 30 people could join the 34 dismissed three months ago.  [ D8. ]   Nestle and Coca-Cola are negotiating a joint venture to make and market coffee and tea drinks under Nestle brand names.  [ D5. ]   Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is said to be seeking bank agreement to defer $5 billion debt payments for three years.  [ D7. ]   CBS stock climbed for the third straight day after a published report that the company was considering a stock buyback.  [ D7. ]   The Daily News filed a new lawsuit against its striking unions, accusing them of a violent conspiracy to harm the newspaper.  [ B1. ]   North Point Press said it would stop publishing new titles after its spring 1991 list, but would continue its backlist.  [ D7. ]   Matsushita said it would not become involved in decisions regarding the content of creative products at MCA.  [ D5. ] The Economy    Savings and loans institutions could convert to state-chartered savings banks under a proposal made by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and supported by the industry.  [ D1. ]   Consumer spending in October was unchanged at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.73 trillion, the Commerce Department said, and personal incomes rose just 0.1 percent, to a $4.71 trillion rate, far below the 0.6 percent inflation rate.  [ D1. ]   President Bush reiterated his confidence that the economy would improve soon in a brief speech to a banking group.  [ D2. ]   A fund to protect the global environment would be established within the World Bank under an agreement between industrial and developing countries in Paris this week.  [ D2. ]   Twelve men from several countries were indicted on charges of taking part in an international conspiracy to distribute more than $550 million worth of stolen securities.  [ D8. ]   Senator Alan Cranston conceded to the Senate Ethics Committee in a deposition that his involvement with Charles H. Keating Jr. was "politically stupid and unwise," but denied wrongdoing.  [ A23. ] Markets    The dollar surged more than 2 percent against the yen and more than 1 percent against the German mark. The rally is the first significant break upward for the dollar in months.  [ D1. ]   Oil prices slipped in volatile trading, easing 37 cents a barrel, to $32.91, as traders sold hours before the U.N. Security Council authorized the use of military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.  [ D2. ]   An innovative electronic auction was bypassed when U S West Financial sold its bonds through Merrill Lynch, rather than Capitalink, whose backers include J. P. Morgan Securities.  [ D5. ]   The Dow Jones average fell 16.34, to 2,518.81, because of rising interest rates and renewed war jitters.  [ D8. ]   Treasury securities prices fell and yields rose on rumors of shooting in the Middle East, later denied.  [ D15. ]   Corn and soybean futures prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade on new signs of Soviet buying interest.  [ D16. ] Today's Columns    Mutual fund investors are buying stock funds at a record pace, even though the year is shaping up as the worst one in a decade for the stock market. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D1. ]   The economy's "meaningful downturn" will not lead to depression because the Fed stands ready to rescue leading banks threatened with sudden insolvency. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene.  [ D2. ]   As advertisers cut back spending, black-owned media are worried that they will be the first to be frozen out. Advertising.  [ D7. ]

headline: Tough Gulf Talk Lifts Gold; Energy Prices Show Rises
abstract: Responding to tough talk from both sides in the Persian Gulf crisis, prices of gold futures rallied yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, erasing almost half of last week's big losses.   Gold futures settled $3.50 to $3.90 higher, with the contract for delivery in December at $374.20 an ounce; silver finished 0.5 cent to 0.9 cent lower, with December at $4.05 an ounce.

headline: Salvadoran Company Wins Peace of Its Own
abstract: LEAD: In an echo of the explosive labor relations that fuel this country's civil war, a 1977 strike at a snack-food company here erupted into violence in which one employee was killed and several were wounded. An owner was also shot and wounded.

headline: Both Kabul and Rebels Report Battle Gains
abstract: LEAD: Muslim guerrillas said today that they had captured strategic security outposts and killed more than 200 Afghan troops in their latest attempt to capture the capital, Kabul.

headline: Leverage on Pretoria: Mandela's Group Turns to a Mass Protest Campaign
abstract: As it maneuvers for advantage before negotiations proposed by President F. W. de Klerk on the nation's future, the African National Congress has replaced its former at least rhetorical commitment to armed struggle against white minority rule with a strategy of coordinated protest marches, strikes, consumer boycotts and work stayaways.   Though protests against apartheid are not new and Mr. de Klerk has tolerated peaceful dissent since taking office, mass action, as the Congress's current policy is called, has become a key point of contention, delaying talks between black and white leaders on a new national constitution.

headline: He Took The Journal in New Directions
abstract: LEAD: Slim, dapper and understated, Warren H. Phillips presided for 33 years over a sharp expansion of both The Wall Street Journal and its parent, Dow Jones & Company, while insisting that the company remain true to the principles with which the newspaper was founded 101 years ago.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday  None Tuesday  Industrial Production . . . Oct.  Capacity Utilization . . . Oct. Wednesday  Retail Sales . . . Oct. Thursday  Inventory Sales . . . Sept. Friday  Consumer Price Index . . . Oct.  Balance of Trade . . . Sept.

headline: For an HBO Thrill, You Can Call Roseanne
abstract: Home Box Office has developed the kind of wacky sense of humor in its promotional ads that helped make MTV a success.    A new spot for a Roseanne Barr comedy special on HBO features the sharp-tongued television star posed seductively on top of a grand piano. Packed into a glittering gown, Ms. Barr urges viewers: "Call Rose, where your fantasies come to life. Call Rose, if you want a good time."   Created by BBDO, the spoof of ads commonly used for telephone sex lines is intended to promote a special HBO comedy show, "Roseanne Barr Live from Trump Castle," which will be broadcast early in January.    It also features a toll-free telephone number fans can call to talk to Ms. Barr and hear her wise-crack live during a special call-in promotion immediately after her HBO show.   Presumably, callers lucky enough to be connected to Ms. Barr will get the kind of unexpurgated tongue-lashing they had only dreamed about before.

headline: Business People;   A President Is Named By Morrison Knudsen
abstract: LEAD: Gunnar E. Sarsten, known for diversifying and tripling the size of the engineering company he headed, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation.

headline: South African Blacks Meet to End Strife
abstract: Leaders representing most of the spectrum of black politics in South Africa met today under the auspices of the Anglican Archbishop, Desmond M. Tutu, to try to promote mutual tolerance and end the factional violence afflicting black South Africans.   Those present included Nelson Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress. But Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the head of the Inkatha Freedom Party, refused to come, contending that the leaders of the congress were not serious about making peace with Inkatha, a predominantly Zulu political movement. Supporters of Inkatha and the congress have been engaged in fierce factional clashes in Natal Province and around Johannesburg that have killed up to 5,000 people in little more than four years.

headline: Economic Scene; 'Tax Bubbles,' One More Time
abstract: CONGRESSIONAL incumbents take heart: those who make it through the November elections are home free. According to the official 30-Day Rule of Political Amnesia, Americans are too bored with politics and too distracted by personal problems to remember a month from now who voted to raise taxes and who did not.    What the public may longer remember, though, is that 1990 was the year of the "tax bubble" -- the year Congress discovered a new inequity in the tax code, then failed to root it out. That perception would be a pity, says Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat who led the fight for the 1986 Tax Reform Act. For while bubbles fit nobody's ideal income tax, they are no invention of the devil.

headline: A Lack of Ads Shuts Monthly
abstract: Just three years short of its centennial, Business Month magazine suspended publication yesterday. It called itself the oldest business magazine in the country.    Jay C. MacDonald, the publisher, said the magazine, a member of the Goldhirsh Group, fell victim to the bleak advertising climate.

headline: Bhutto Campaign Is Reeling Under Foes' Attacks in Court
abstract: LEAD: As a bitter election campaign enters its final two weeks, Benazir Bhutto's effort to regain leadership of the country is reeling under a Government onslaught in which her husband has been arrested on kidnapping charges while a special tribunal is weighing whether or not to disqualify her from running in the elections or holding public office.

headline: Discount Brand Promotion Likely if Beer Taxes Rise
abstract: LEAD: IF Congress raises the excise tax on beer, which appears likely, that means brewers may be pushed into uncharted territory and forced to promote discount brands with more advertising.

headline: U. S. Trade Plan Criticized
abstract: LEAD: A top European Community official today criticized as unrealistic an American trade proposal for sharp cuts in Government payments to farmers.

headline: World Markets; The Dollar in Germany's Future
abstract: DURING the rush to unity that culminated with the creation of a single German state on Oct. 3, the dollar's steady slide to one record low after another was largely ignored by the nation's eight stock exchanges. Investors and stock experts were focused on the potential for profits in building the Eastern Europe of the future, rather than on problems stemming from currency rate fluctuations of the moment.  In fact, the German attitude toward the mark's waxing strength against the dollar was reminiscent of a comment often heard when the dollar soared during the heyday of the Reagan Administration: a strong mark reflects a strong economy.

headline: Food Donors' Squabbles Imperil Aid to Sudan
abstract: As famine threatens to engulf the Sudan and Western donors try to persuade its Government that food aid is needed, fierce squabbling over where and how food should be delivered has erupted among the donors.   Western officials say the infighting poses a new obstacle to delivering up to a million tons of food needed in the coming months in the underdeveloped country, which is torn by civil war.

headline: A World in Flux Means Steady Work for Risk Analysts
abstract: JUDGING by the number of crises in the world lately, profits must be soaring in the political-risk business.   From the Soviet Union to Eastern Europe to Kuwait, the geopolitical map has been stretched, ripped and tossed on its side during the past 18 months. New markets have been created while existing business ventures have been shaken. Eager to get their bearings, American companies have been turning with increasing frequency to consultants who assess the potential risks and rewards abroad by analyzing the political, social and economic conditions of a particular country or region.

headline: Trade Deficit Up in Quarter
abstract: The deficit in the broadest measure of foreign trade widened sharply in the July-September quarter to $25.59 billion, the worst showing since late last year, the Government reported today.   The 13.9 percent jump was attributed to the Persian Gulf crisis, which drove up the price Americans pay for imported oil and also increased the country's spending on overseas military operations.

headline: For Some Cars, 'Clean' Gas Is Found to Raise Emissions
abstract: Some "reformulated" gasolines may be a mixed blessing. While several changes made by oil companies do make new cars run cleaner, they make 1983 through 1985 models run dirtier, according to a comprehensive study sponsored by 14 oil companies and the Big Three domestic auto makers.    It is "a riddle," one researcher said. The main difference in the cars' emissions appears to be whether the vehicle has a carburetor or a fuel injector; carburetors used to predominate, but fuel injection is almost universal in new cars.

headline: Home Building Plummets; Level Is Lowest Since 1982
abstract: Home building plunged by 6 percent in October, the Commerce Department said today, extending the longest construction slide on record and sinking housing starts to their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession.   Industry analysts cited shrinking consumer confidence and the growing inability of builders to get credit as causes of the nine-month drop, the longest since the Government began keeping track in 1959. Many analysts expect the slide to continue into mid-1991, especially in light of a broader weakening of the economy.

headline: P.L.O. Alone and Troubled After Its Efforts in Gulf Fail
abstract: LEAD: Ten weeks after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the Palestine Liberation Organization is in turmoil, unable to show any results for its mediation effort, isolated from Western governments and its former Persian Gulf benefactors and angry over new violence against its followers in the Israeli-occupied territories.

headline: 4th-Quarter CBS Loss Is Expected
abstract: In a sign of the deepening economic crisis facing the broadcast networks, CBS said yesterday that it expected a loss in the fourth quarter and lower 1991 earnings.   John Reidy, a media analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, estimated that the loss would be about $35 million. CBS reported a $60.1 million profit in the fourth quarter of 1989.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * H. F. Ahmanson & Co., Los Angeles, a savings and loan holding company, said it would complete the acquisition of Home Savings Bank, Brooklyn, on Monday.  * General Mills Inc., Minneapolis, expects its restaurant business to be a big growth area, chairman, Bruce Atwater, said in an interview. He said revenues from General Mills' Olive Garden and Red Lobster restaurants were good, despite a generally poor economy. "Our restaurants continue to act just as they did in the first quarter," when sales grew 18 percent, he said. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, has cut ties to six health maintenance organizations and has frozen membership in 20 others in an annual review aimed at reducing its $3 billion annual bill for health care. The cuts have not been opposed by the United Automobile Workers union. * Leaf Inc., Bannockburn, Ill. the maker of the Clark candy bar, announced it would close the Pittsburgh plant where the bars are made and put the 104-year-old Clark name up for sale. Prospective buyers are looking at the plant. Leaf, owned by Huhtamaeki Oy of Finland, operates 11 candy and gum plants in the United States and Canada. * Norfolk Southern Corp., Norfolk, Va., a railroad operator, has acquired the assets of an Ohio River terminal near Wheelersburg, Ohio, from an affiliate of Island Creek Corp., Lexington, Ky., a coal company. Terms were not disclosed. * Rank Organization P.L.C., London, a communications and entertainment concern, said it had decided not to sell its Clermont Casino to Bally Manufacturing Corp., Chicago, a gaming company. * Reading Co., Philadelphia, a real estate and emergency services company, completed the sale of several properties in Philadelphia for $18.4 million. * Textron Inc., Providence, R.I., an aerospace and technology company, said it would integrate its Bell Aerospace unit into its Textron Defense Systems division.

headline: What Will Pan Am Deal Mean for T.W.A. Bondholders?
abstract: THE proposed sale last week of Pan American World Airways' core London routes raised some intriguing issues for investors in the bonds of Carl Icahn's Trans World Airlines, which have taken a beating in the marketplace.   If United Airlines completes its deal for the routes, as expected, it will emerge as a much heftier competitor for the less robust T.W.A., notes John Clair, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. But that might also leave American Airlines, which has expressed interest in Pan Am's routes, looking for other London connections -- and T.W.A. has them, and might sell them.   "This both increases T.W.A.'s opportunities and its risks," Mr. Clair said. While he gives Mr. Icahn high marks for handling such situations deftly, he added, "What is good for T.W.A. may not be good for bondholders." One thing, at least, can be said for the bonds: Somebody at T.W.A. likes them. T.W.A. disclosed it bought up various bonds with a face value of $213 million in the second quarter.

headline: Thatcher Critic Makes His Move to Take Her Job
abstract: Eleven and a half years as Prime Minister, battling against "socialism" and for the British national interest have worn out scores of Margaret Thatcher's own appointees, her popularity and her European partners. Today all that came back to haunt her, with a bitter political challenge from Michael Heseltine, a pro-European figure she had driven out of her Cabinet in 1986.   A handsome, leonine 57-year-old who has been planning to be Prime Minister ever since his student days at Oxford, Mr. Heseltine openly called upon the 372 Conservative members of Parliament to overthrow Mrs. Thatcher as party leader and Prime Minister in a closed ballot set for next Tuesday. He had parted ways with Mrs. Thatcher in 1986, when he abruptly left her Cabinet.  Britain's Role in Europe     On the surface, the issue is the two-decades-long British argument over whether to be a full-fledged partner in the European Community, driving ahead toward political and monetary union as Mr. Heseltine and other "Europeanists" want, or to slow the process down to preserve the centuries-old hard-won prerogatives of parliamentary democracy, as Mrs. Thatcher insists.

headline: Roosevelt Aide Called an Unwitting Spy
abstract: LEAD: A new book by a prominent Soviet K.G.B. defector names Harry L. Hopkins, an architect of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal and his closest personal adviser, as an unwitting ''agent of major significance'' for the Soviet Union.

headline: Small Drop In Rates Predicted
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board will probably respond to the passage of the new Federal budget by reducing short-term interest rates, but credit market analysts said neither Congress nor the Bush Administration should expect a substantial reduction as a glittering prize for what the tortuous, confidence-shaking exercise has produced.    "The new budget is a step, but I don't think fiscal discipline has been re-established at all," said William H. Gross, a managing director of the Pacific Investment Management Company, a Newport Beach, Calif., money management firm with a portfolio of more than $16 billion in fixed-income investments. "Unless we can exert some discipline on spending, rather than taxation, we are probably not going to make much headway in reducing the deficit."   No Comment From Fed     As is their wont, neither the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, nor other officials of the nation's central bank would speak on or off the record about their intentions on interest rates. Telephone calls to Mr. Greenspan and governors of the Federal Reserve on Friday found no one who would comment on Federal Reserve policies and how the budget agreement might affect them.    But through the summer and into the fall, Mr. Greenspan had offered Congress a carrot -- a drop in short-term interest rates -- if the credit markets responded positively to a budget package.    The message struck a chord with market participants, and in the last week short-term money market interest rates moved down in anticipation of a budget agreement and a subsequent reduction in the overnight Federal funds rate, the market rate controlled most directly by the Fed. The funds rate -- the overnight rate on bank loans-- has hovered around 8 percent since July.   Drop in Prime Rate Unlikely     While welcome, a minor cut in the funds rate would probably not lead to a decline in the prime lending rate charged by commercial banks, or in other prime-based consumer borrowing rates. With poor balance sheets, analysts said, commercial banks were not likely to consider lowering the prime rate, currently at 10 percent, until the funds rate fell to 7 1/2 percent.    Yet, even as short-term rates slipped, bond yields, which are the ultimate indicator of how a long-term budget package is judged by market participants, have not budged.    By the end of last week, yields on 8 1/8 percent two-year Treasury notes, securities which are very sensitive to changes in Fed policy, had fallen to 7.76 percent, well under the funds rate. But yields on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds were stuck at 8.76 percent.    "The Fed might be able to cut the Federal funds rate by one-quarter of a percentage point without upsetting the market," said Jerry L. Jordan, a senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "But people who think there will be a big payoff on interest rates based on this budget package are in for a disappointment."    The Fed will be reluctant to move faster because market participants, especially long-term investors, see little reason to believe the budget package will generate the advertised $500 billion in savings over the next five years.    Moreover, with the dollar under pressure and fears about inflation still strong, the Fed would be running a substantial risk of pushing up long-term rates if it quickly cut short-term rates by more than a quarter of a percentage point, the analysts argued.   Economic Reports Awaited     A signal from the Fed that it has moved the funds rate lower may come almost immediately, but in order to calm nerves in the long-term bond market, analysts said, the Fed might well delay its move until after a string of important economic reports are released this week.    Those reports, coupled with the announcement late last week that a key measure of consumer confidence had plummeted in October, are likely to reassure bond investors that an easing of Fed policy is justified on economic grounds.    This week will provide a preliminary reading on how the economy fared in the third quarter and reports from the naton's purchasing managers and the Labor Department on how the fourth quarter began.   Rise in Consumption Spending     The Commerce Department's preliminary report on third-quarter growth could well show growth that is considerably above the increase of four-tenths of a percent recorded in the second quarter. But most analysts said a rise in third-quarter output should not be interpreted as a sign that the economy was regaining momentum. Much of the increase will probably be from a rise in consumption expenditures, a figure that tends to increase in the third quarter.   "I would hope people will look past the consumption number in the third quarter G.N.P. report," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "Consumption was stronger than it was in the second quarter, but on a year-over-year basis it continues to weaken."    Dimming the outlook for the fourth quarter was the announcement late last week of a record drop in the Conference Board's monthly survey of consumer confidence, which in October fell to its lowest level since the 1982 recession.   Gayle Fosler, chief economist at the Conference Board and an analyst who says the economy will avoid a recession, acknowledged that the results of the survey were troubling. "I would now be inclined to reduce my estimates on consumer spending somewhat," she said, "but I think this number has more to do with disenchantment over the budget negotiations than with economics."  Manufacturers and Jobs     Other analysts are not so sure. A report, due Thursday, from the nation's purchasing managers, will probably show that conditions among large manufacturers deteriorated further in October. October employment data from the Labor Department, expected the following day, will probably be weak, too.    "The data will show that the fourth quarter started off on a very weak note," Mr. Fine said. "I have no problem with a forecast which shows economic output declining in the fourth quarter."    Mr. Jordan of First Interstate said that weakness in the economy would ultimately lead to an aggressive easing in policy by the Federal Reserve. But constraints on the Fed will not be lifted until the crisis in the Middle East is resolved, he added, and the dollar regains some bouyancy.    "If they were not constrained by the Middle East crisis, the Fed would have already done more to help the economy," he said. "Assuming there is a solution, we think the funds rate will come down to 7 percent next year."

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: An article last Sunday about political risk analysis misidentified two companies. Business International is the London-based subsidiary of the Economist Group; Business Risk International Inc. is based in Nashville. They are not connected.

headline: U.S. HELPS QUELL REVOLT IN PANAMA
abstract: United States troops helped quell a rebellion in Panama today by a former chief of the country's national police, Pentagon and State Department officials said.    A year after the United States invaded Panama and ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, about 500 American troops were called in by the Panamanian national police to help capture the former police official, Col. Eduardo Herrera Hassan, the officials said.

headline: ITT Financial Rating Cuts
abstract: The rating on about $5 billion of debt issued by the ITT Financial Corporation has been lowered, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.   The senior debt was lowered to A, from A+, and subordinated debt to A-, from A.    According to the rating agency, the change in rating reflects the increasing delinquencies in the company's receivables portfolio, especially in the consumer and commercial real estate divisions. As a result, ITT Financial has had to increase its provisions for loan loss, which in turn is affecting the company's profits, S.&P. noted.    "This trend, coupled with the current recessionary environment, should continue to constrain the ITT Financial's profitability and financial flexibility over the next few years," S.&P. said.    On the plus side of these difficulties, the rating agency notes, is the company's strong inventory finance unit, adequate capital cushion and continued support from its parent, the ITT Corporation.

headline: Bulgaria and Neighbors In East Bloc Are Reeling After Cuts in Soviet Oil
abstract: At Gasoline Station 31 in northern Sofia, Georgi Georgiev finally neared the pumps after four hours of waiting in a line that was 90 cars long behind him.    Not bad, he said. Five weeks ago, he waited 24 hours.

headline: Chrysler Deal For Studio Was Sought
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian, the Los Angeles financier who has bought 9.8 percent of the Chrysler Corporation for $277 million, first proposed in 1989 that Chrysler buy the MGM/UA Communications Company in a transaction that would have made him a big investor in the nation's No. 3 auto maker, it was disclosed today.   But Chrysler's top executives rejected the acquisition because they could see no reason to join automotive and entertainment properties, said one person with knowledge of the talks who insisted on anonymity. Mr. Kerkorian had told Chrysler he would accept the company's stock as payment for MGM/UA.

headline: Data Bank/December 30, 1990
abstract: New Orders for Durable Goods   Nov.   Oct.   Sept.        Monthly percent change   --10.5   3.6   --1.6        Index of Leading Indicators                Monthly percent change   --1.2   --1.3   0.8       Gasoline Prices (retail)   Dec. 28   Dec. 21   Dec. 14        Per gallon    $127.3   $1.371   $1.371        Cash Wheat Price                No. 1 K.C., per bushel   $2.74   $2.77   $2.72        Crude Oil, W. Texas Intermediate                Friday spot price, per barrel   $27.57   $27.12   $26.60       3-month Treasury Bills                Yield in percent   6.44   6.52   6.82        Electric Power Production   Dec. 21   Dec. 14   Dec. 7        Milions of kilowatt hours, weekly total   55,887   55,507   55,739        Coal Production (Bituminous)                Thousands of net tons, weekly total   21,332   21,730   21,182

headline: Visitors for Enthronement Press Japan for Support
abstract: After a day of celebration for the enthronement of Emperor Akihito, diplomats and representatives from 158 countries plunged into another round of parties and diplomatic activities today, including discussions with Japan seeking economic aid for their countries.    Visiting leaders from Southeast Asia are expected to press Japan for aid and for support of the peace process in Cambodia, and Eastern European leaders told the Japanese press that they needed help to get through the economic problems resulting from thePersian Gulf crisis.

headline: Pretoria Journal; A Spy's Sorry Story: Espionage Wasn't Her Forte
abstract: She was South Africa's own little drummer girl, n idealistic, poignantly unqualified amateur enticed into the underworld of espionage and exploited by her handlers to infiltrate the African National Congress.   But Odile Harington, unlike the heroine of John le Carre's novel, proved so clumsy a spy that she promptly got caught. She spent four hard years in Zimbabwean prisons, and today she blames herself for having agreed to serve South African intelligence.

headline: Iran, Gulf States in Deal
abstract: Iran has agreed to buy petroleum products directly from several Persian Gulf states, the National Iranian Oil Company said today. The company, which imports about 200,000 barrels a day of gas oil and kerosene, will buy those products from refineries in Bahrain, Qatar and Abu Dhabi, which is part of the United Arab Emirates. Many Persian Gulf states had banned the sale of oil products to Iran because of their support for Iraq in its 1980-88 war with Iran. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has reversed that situation.

headline: Busch Profit Grows 9.4%
abstract: The Anheuser-Busch Companies today reported a 9.4 percent increase in third-quarter profits.   Profits in the quarter were $260.7 million, or 91 cents a share, up from $238.3 million, or 83 cents a share, last year. Revenue jumped 15.5 percent, to $3.12 billion, from $2.70 billion for the third quarter last year. It was the 55th straight quarter of record sales and earnings at the world's largest brewery.    August Busch 3d, chairman and president, said beer sales had been helped by the introduction of two brands, Bud Dry and Busch Light, in the early part of the year.   "We continue to be extremely pleased with our beer company's performance during 1990," Mr. Busch said. Sales of beer to wholesalers were up 4.8 percent from last year's third quarter, the highest volume gain in the industry, the company said.   Mr. Busch said higher profits at two other Busch companies -- Campbell Taggart bakery and the Metal Container Corporation -- also helped profits in the quarter.   But he cautioned that the weak economy, higher gasoline prices and tougher competition have resulted in lower 1990 attendance at the company's Busch Gardens and Sea World theme parks. The low attendance and lower profits will probably continue into 1991, Mr. Busch said.   The company's stock slipped 62.5 cents today, to $38, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: BLACK HOMELAND REPORTS UPRISING
abstract: A band of white and black rebel army troops mounted a coup attempt today in Transkei, a black homeland, and 17 people were reported killed in the fighting with loyalist forces.   The military ruler, Maj. Gen. Bantu Holomisa, said at a a rally late today in Transkei's capital, Umtata, that the coup attempt had been put down, the independent South African Press Association reported. General Holomisa said the leader of the uprising, Craig Duli, a former Holomisa aide, was dead, the agency said.

headline: HUSSEIN OFFERING TO TALK WITH U.S.
abstract: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said today that he was ready for negotiations with the United States, although he again refused to accept a withdrawal of his troops from Kuwait as a condition for talks to avert war in the Persian Gulf.    In an interview with ABC News in Baghdad, Mr. Hussein appeared confident but unusually conciliatory, and seemed to suggest that Iraq might eventually consider removing its forces from Kuwait.

headline: BURMESE MILITARY CRUSHES PROTEST
abstract: The Burmese military Government has crushed resistance among the country's Buddhist monks and has moved swiftly to eliminate most other visible signs of opposition, senior diplomats based in the Burmese capital said today.   In the last two days, the military authorities of Myanmar, formerly Burma, have combined raids on political offices with arrests of party leaders and ultimatums to other opposition parties to cooperate with the military, the diplomats said in telephone interviews from Yangon, the capital, formerly Rangoon.

headline: Europeans Near Pact With Japan
abstract: LEAD: The European Community's executive branch is close to reaching an agreement with Tokyo to restrict Japanese car imports for five years, but Europe's auto makers are battling to scuttle the accord because they think it is not nearly tough enough.

headline: All About/Maps; With Computers, Mapmakers Are Redrawing the World
abstract: Since the days of Amerigo Vespucci, the explorer whose name graces two continents and one nation, map makers have been romanticized as adventurers returning to painstakingly record the twists and turns of coastlines and borders.     Modern map-making has become corporate, the domain of computer wizards, marketing experts and board room warriors embroiled in legal debates over tax status and copyrights. The International Map Dealers Association estimates that commercial sales in the United States have reached $200 million annually.

headline: Split Into 3 Units Set By Santa Fe Pacific
abstract: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it would split into three independent units as of Dec. 4 in an effort to enhance the company's value for stockholders.   The main businesses of the three companies will be real estate, petroleum and rail service.   "In our view, the values of our significant and diversified assets, especially our real estate and petroleum properties, have not been reflected fully in Santa Fe Pacific's stock price," said Robert Krebs, the chairman of the company.   He said that separation into three companies, which had been under consideration since April, would "place a spotlight on the values inherent in those companies."    However, Graeme Lidgerwood, a railroad analyst for First Boston, said that in the near term the total value of the three pieces could end up trading at about $12, which would be lower than the company's current stock price.    Santa Fe closed yesterday at $13 a share, down 25 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.    Ms. Lidgerwood said that the minerals subsidiary had made significant gold discoveries and that the railroad had some valuable track it could sell and was taking steps to increase operating efficiency and cut costs.    The main problem, she said, was with the real estate company, the Catellus Development Corporation, which has a land portfolio of two million acres.   The spinoffs were put into place by the Santa Fe board, which yesterday approved a special dividend to common stockholders consisting of Santa Fe's interests in the company's real estate and energy subsidiaries.   Holders of Santa Fe common stock as of Nov. 29 will get one share of common stock of Santa Fe Energy Resources for every 3.3 shares of Santa Fe common stock, and one share of Catellus for every four shares of Santa Fe common stock.    The value of Santa Fe Pacific's stock has dropped considerably since June, when it was trading at $23.    Ms. Lidgerwood said the spinoffs were the culmination of a long effort by Mr. Krebs to keep the company from being taken over after it was put in play by an offer from the Henley Group in 1987.    After a series of steps to ward off takeovers and placate shareholders, which included a $30-a-share special dividend, Santa Fe has had to carry considerable debt and make large interest payments.

headline: Economic Scene; Let Them Eat Bread
abstract: ITEM: In yet another bid to prevent the Soviet Union from disintegrating in its winter of discontent, Mikhail Gorbachev reorganizes his Government and hints that full-blown rationing will be needed to feed the nation.   Item: World trade negotiations are on the verge of collapse because European leaders cannot bring themselves to say no to their subsidy-addicted, overproducing farmers.

headline: McDonald's Expected to Drop Plastic Burger Box
abstract: The plastic McDonald's hamburger box may be on its way out, a packaging dinosaur that could not survive in a less wasteful age.    The rugged little box, which was a design innovation that became one of the nation's best-known packages before turning into a symbol of the garbage crisis, will be phased out by the McDonald's Corporation, according to people informed of the decision.

headline: U.N. COUNCIL HOLDS THE IRAQIS LIABLE ON KUWAIT DAMAGE
abstract: The United Nations Security Council overwhelmingly approved a resolution today laying the groundwork for a seizure of impounded Iraqi assets.   The latest resolution, intended to increase pressure on Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, warned that if the Iraqis continued to disregard Council demands, the world organization would take "further measures under the Charter." This could include the use of military force, but this was not explicitly mentioned.  [ Text, page A12. ]

headline: New Aggressiveness at Times Mirror
abstract: When Thomas Plate left New York Newsday last year to become editorial page editor of The Los Angeles Times, the meeting to announce his arrival turned into a fiasco. A member of The Times's editorial staff abruptly stood up, asked, "Is this a meeting or an announcement?" and then embarked on a fiery 15-minute diatribe against the appointment of somebody from outside the paper.   This unusual outburst, which stunned the editors and executives present, reflected uneasiness about change at the Times Mirror Company, the diversified media giant that owns The Los Angeles Times and Newsday on Long Island. It is a company unused to upheaval. Indeed, The Times was once dubbed "the velvet coffin" because of its reputation for stability and paternalism.

headline: Bush, Meeting Foreign Minister, Lauds Beijing Stand Against Iraq
abstract: In the most substantial step to improve relations with China since the crackdown on democracy demonstrators around Tiananmen Square, President Bush met here today with the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, and declared that Beijing and Washington had "made common ground in terms of standing up against aggression" by Iraq.    Earlier this month, Chinese officials led the Administration to believe that they would support a United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force to expel Iraq from Kuwait. China abstained when the Security Council approved the resolution Thursday by a vote of 12 to 2.

headline: U.S. Suppliers Cut Workers
abstract: Litton Industries and the Rockwell International Corporation have joined the list of military contractors that have pared work forces.   Litton said this week that it had eliminated 600 of its 6,000 jobs in Southern California from October 1989 to September. Operations in Woodland Hills and Van Nuys were hit the hardest, losing 550 of 4,400 jobs, said Robert Knapp, a Litton spokesman.   Also this week, Rockwell officials said the company had cut 161 union employees at its Rocketdyne division in Canoga Park, Calif. Rocketdyne's union membership accounts for about one-fifth of its 9,100-employee work force.   A week ago, TRW Inc.'s space and military operations, which are based in Redondo Beach, Calif., acknowledged eliminating 1,600 jobs, about one-tenth of the work force, through attrition and layoffs, mostly in California.   The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the Lockheed Corporation and the Northrop Corporation have announced plans in the last year to reduce their Southern California work forces by 22,000.

headline: More Women Own Concerns
abstract: LEAD: The number of United States businesses owned by women climbed by 57 percent between 1982 and 1987, the Census Bureau reported last week.

headline: Sundstrand Fraud Case
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge today acquitted three former Sundstrand Corporation executives of wrongdoing in a scheme by the aerospace contractor to defraud the Pentagon.

headline: Polly Peck Stock Halt
abstract: LEAD: The steering committee of London's Stock Exchange said today that it would remove the shares of Polly Peck International P.L.C. from The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index. Trading in Polly Peck has been suspended since Sept. 20, when the company asked for a halt in trading after the shares fell 55 percent within hours.

headline: Bush Will Visit the Troops In Desert on Thanksgiving
abstract: President Bush will spend Thanksgiving with American troops in Saudi Arabia during an eight-day trip to review the Persian Gulf crisis and other matters with European and Middle Eastern allies, the White House said today.   The announcement came as Iraq formally notified the State Department that it would free four American hostages, including one man held as a so-called human shield at an Iraqi military or industrial site.

headline: Reports Are in Conflict on a Hostage Release
abstract: LEAD: Contradicting Western and Syrian assessments, Lebanese newspapers reported over the weekend that the release of some Western hostages may be imminent. One newspaper said today that an Anglican Church envoy held in Lebanon, Terry Waite, would be freed ''in the next few days.''

headline: Srinagar Journal;   In Kashmir's Enchanted Valley, War Breaks Spell
abstract: LEAD: Just before 4 P.M., traffic in the center of this tormented city comes to a standstill for about 20 minutes to let a few buses pass. The buses take Hindu government employees from their sandbagged offices to their safe dormitories, separated from Muslim Kashmir by troops in battle gear.

headline: A Shantytown of 30,000 Bulldozed in Nairobi
abstract: Peres Wamboi, her two grandchildren playing at her feet, sat on the remains of her shanty for the last 20 years -- bulldozed along with thousands of others by armed security men and zealous young members of this country's sole political party.   For the last week, since the demolition of Kibagare shanty village on the fringe of one of Nairobi's upscale, tree- and flower-laden suburbs, Mrs. Wamboi said she and many of her neighbors had been sleeping in cardboard hovels hastily patched together up the hill. "Ihave nowhere to go," she said simply.

headline: Far to the East of Moscow, A Brazen Rush to Capitalism
abstract: LEAD: The islanders call their beloved outsider ''E. T.,'' for Valentin Fyodorov has proved to be a boon-producing alien, rocking the governance of Sakhalin Island with strange events in defiance of the law to make people imagine themselves more and more in a free-market world apart from the rest of the Soviet Union.

headline: Many Buyers, but No Saturns to Sell
abstract: The scene inside the showroom at Saturn of Schaumburg, which has been open for only six weeks, is a car dealer's nightmare: flocks of eager buyers, but no cars to sell.    While assembly of the much-awaited Saturn car, a product of the General Motors Corporation, began four months ago at a new plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., manufacturing problems have limited output to just 2,162 cars -- about the number that could be produced in three days if the factory was operating at full speed.

headline: Ford to Get Unit Of Marine Midland
abstract: The Ford Motor Credit Company will acquire a subsidiary of Marine Midland Banks Inc. to develop non-Ford business, the companies announced. The new business will continue for now as the Marine Midland Automotive Financial Corporation. Later, its name will be changed and headquarters will be established in Nashville. The acquisition price was not released.   Ford Motor Credit provides financing help for dealers selling vehicles made by the Ford Motor Company and its subsidiaries and customers of those dealers. Marine Midland Banks, with headquarters in Buffalo, will continue handling Marine Midland Automotive's consumer loans.

headline: Israeli General to Return Millions in Bribes
abstract: Prosecutors said today that they had agreed to a plea bargain by a senior Israeli Air Force officer accused of accepting millions of dollars in bribes while purchasing United States-made military equipment.   The agreement, signed last week, calls for Brig. Gen. Rami Dotan to return $10 million in bribes and kickbacks he is charged with having accepted while heading the Defense Ministry's department of military acquisitions in New York in 1984-85. General Dotan was arrested in October.    He also agreed to supply investigators with the names of other people involved in the scheme, Israel radio said. In exchange, it said, no charges will be brought against General Dotan's wife, who was also accused of involvement.   The scandal startled Israel's military establishment and raised concern that it might jeopardize the $1.8 billion in United States military aid that Israel receives each year.    In announcing the plea bargain, the chief military prosecutor, Brig. Gen. Amnon Strashnov, dismissed suggestions that it could limit full disclosure of the corruption.   "There is no attempt to hide or to cover up anything here," he said.

headline: Airline Woe: More Seats Than Fliers
abstract: As many as half the nation's airline seats could be on carriers operating under the protection of bankruptcy courts within a few months if high fuel costs, falling revenues and fare discounting persist, according to Robert L. Crandall, chairman and chief executive of American Airlines.    "The airline industry in the United States today is literally going broke," Mr. Crandall, who heads the nation's largest airline, told reporters Thursday night at a dinner meeting in Dallas. "We have too many seats chasing too few customers."

headline: Profits Down At Hewlett
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company Friday reported declining earnings for the quarter and year that ended on Oct. 31. Revenues and orders increased for the period, but operating expenses and the cost of goods that were sold grew more rapidly.   For the fourth quarter, Hewlett-Packard had earnings of $202 million, or 83 cents a share, down 17.9 percent from $246 million, or $1.04 a share, in the comparable 1989 period. Revenues rose 5.9 percent, to $3.58 billion from $3.38 billion.    For the year, Hewlett-Packard had earnings of $739 million, or $3.06 a share, down 10.8 percent from $829 million, or $3.52 a share, in the previous fiscal year. Revenues rose 11.1 percent, to $13.23 billion from $11.9 billion a year earlier.   Despite the declines, Hewlett-Packard shares rose $1.375 Friday, to $28.375, on volume of 1.25 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts' estimates for the quarter covered a broad range, and the actual results fell in the middle.
