headline: Yugoslav Merger Planned by SPI
abstract: Yugoslavia's largest pharmaceutical company has agreed to merge with the California-based SPI Pharmaceuticals Inc. in one of the biggest East-West transactions in Yugoslavia since World War II.   Under the agreement, which was announced on Thursday in Belgrade, the assets of Galenika Pharmaceuticals will be transferred to a new joint company, to be called ICN Galenika. The combined company is expected to have annual sales of $370 million.

headline: Judge Calls 22 Keating Charges Too Vague
abstract: A state judge ruled today that more than half of the 42 fraud charges filed in September against Charles H. Keating Jr. and three other former executives of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association were too vague to be brought to trial.    But the judge, Lance Ito of California Superior Court in Los Angeles, stopped short of dismissing the charges, as lawyers for Mr. Keating and the other defendants had sought. He gave prosecutors an opportunity to make the charges more specific and to refile them by Nov. 19.

headline: Patents; Old-Style Pencil Editing On a Computer Screen
abstract: Three researchers at the International Business Machines Corporation have patented a word-processing program that lets people do the equivalent of old-fashioned pencil editing.    The software program allows a person to scribble proposed changes in a document displayed on the computer screen. The idea is that people with secretaries can scribble proposed changes and store them with the document without having to make a printout.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: A chart on Nov. 4 headed "Wall Street, Tokyo," with an article about American securities firms in Japan, mislabeled figures for the flow of long-term capital from Japan. The figures were worldwide, not just for the United States.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Miller Brewing Company, Milwaukee, a unit of Philip Morris Companies, will introduce a new low-calorie beer, Miller Reserve Light, with an ad campaign designed by the Milwaukee-based agency Frankenberry, Laughlin & Constable. The agency handles other accounts for Miller, as do Backer, Spielvogel Bates, New York, and Leo Burnett, Chicago.

headline: Oil Surge Disrupts Southeast Asia Economies
abstract: The increase in oil prices since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has taken some of the heat out of Southeast Asia's booming economies, while significantly adding to political stresses in the Philippines, which has no indigenous energy sources and a faltering economy.    But for Southeast Asia's oil producers -- especially Indonesia, the only Asian member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, and Malaysia -- price increases related to the Persian Gulf crisis promise a significant windfall.Indonesia based its budget through March 1991 on oil at $16.50 a barrel, but it will get an unforeseen profit of over $2 billion in this fiscal year alone. At current production levels, every increase of a dollar in world prices means an extra $500 million a year. For Malaysia, such an increase means an extra $160 million.

headline: Ex-Kennedy Aides Ask Release of '62 Crisis Papers
abstract: LEAD: Nine former Kennedy Administration officials have joined in a legal challenge to the State Department over the department's refusal to release nearly 700 documents about the 1962 Cuban missile crisis.

headline: BATTLE AT THE U.N.
abstract: LEAD: The Palestine Liberation Organization is straining the American-led international coalition against Iraq by pressing ahead with its own Security Council resolution condemning Israel.

headline: Semi-Gas Systems
abstract: The Justice Department said it planned to file a civil lawsuit challenging the proposed acquisition of Semi-Gas Systems of San Jose, Calif., by Nippon Sanso, based in Tokyo. The department said the transaction would combine the world's two leading suppliers of gas distribution and control systems to computer chip makers and would substantially increase Semi-Gas's dominant position in the American market. Nippon Sanso produces gas systems in the United States through a subsidiary, Matheson Gas Products of Secaucus, N.J.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Smith Barney Mortgage Capital Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $720 million in collateralized mortgage obligations through CMO Mortgage Investors Trust. The finance company's three-part offering will be underwritten by its parent, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., a subsidiary of Primerica Corp.  Ratings  * JPS Textile Group Inc.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to Ca, from Caa, by Moody's Investors Service. The textile producer is based in Greenville, S.C. * Tucson Electric Power Co.'s senior debt rating has been reduced to B-3, from B-2, by Moody's.

headline: Grey New York Wins T.C.B.Y.
abstract: LEAD: Grey Advertising, New York, was awarded the business for T.C.B.Y. Systems Inc., a yogurt franchise company.

headline: Facing More Losses, BBC To End 61-Year-Old Weekly
abstract: When the British Broadcasting Corporation decided to stop publishing The Listener, its 61-year-old weekly television, radio and literary journal, it demonstrated its increasing attention to the bottom line.   "The magazine's official budget for 1990-91 predicted a loss of about $:1 million, and sales have been falling sharply," said James Saynor, The Listener's deputy editor. And the magazine has lost money for years.

headline: Kenyan Party Votes Changes Without Imperiling Its Grip
abstract: While a number of African nations have moved toward multiparty political systems this year, the sole political party in Kenya has rejected such democratization and instead made some changes that may broaden the party's base but will unquestionably keep it in power.    Addressing a two-day convention of the governing party, the Kenya African National Union, President Daniel arap Moi said Kenya need not copy what was being done elsewhere. He called on the delegates to make "our political system relevant to the needs and aspirations of our people."

headline: New President At Northwest
abstract: Northwest Airlines named John H. Dasburg president and chief executive Friday to succeed Frederick B. Rentschler, who has resigned.   Mr. Rentschler, who will remain a director of NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest, has been president of the nation's fourth-largest carrier since June. He said his reasons for leaving were personal.   Mr. Dasburg, who is 47 years old, will begin his new duties immediately. He has been Northwest's executive vice president of finance and administration,   He joined Northwest in November 1989 after nine years at the Marriott Corporation.

headline: Banks Rush to Sell Assets by End of Year
abstract: Department stores are not alone in having end-of-the-year holiday sales.    Many of the nation's largest commercial banks, hurt by losses on real estate loans, are trying to sell big chunks of their businesses, like credit card operations, business loans and even branches.

headline: Cuts in Jobs Are Reported At Kidder
abstract: Kidder, Peabody & Company has joined the ranks of investment houses dismissing employees, with a reduction in its investment banking division of as much as 10 percent, Wall Street executives said yesterday.   Although the dimissals were focused in the investment banking division, which Kidder has been building up since the beginning of the year, they were part of a firm-wide cutback. As many as 70 people, or a little less than 2 percent of the firm's total staff of 5,000 were let go.

headline: INVESTORS DECLINE GOVERNMENT DEALS FOR FAILED S.& L.'S
abstract: When Congress passed the savings industry bailout legislation more than a year ago, it had high hopes that new money from private investors would pour in to strengthen the beleaguered industry. But today, even though Wall Street pledged nearly $2 billion for the effort, only a trickle of private money has been invested.    The Government has found it almost impossible to sell failed savings institutions to private investors. As a result, taxpayers are having to shoulder the entire burden of the industry rescue, and those costs are mounting daily.

headline: Economic Scene; The Case Offered By the Optimists
abstract: THE Government's report that the American economy expanded at an annual rate of 1.8 percent in the third quarter startled economists who have been saying a recession has already started or soon will.    Many doubting economists said the official numbers must be wrong, because the Commerce Department had underestimated the rate of inflation and therefore overestimated the rate of real economic growth. They rejected the data, saying, "Wait for the next revision!"

headline: Bhutto's Foes Win a Strong Majority
abstract: When final results were tallied today in an election that former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto had hoped to win to vindicate herself after her dismissal in August, her opponents in the Islamic Democratic Alliance had claimed a clear majority, with 105 seats in the National Assembly.    Up to 50 more seats in the 217-member lower house of Parliament will be held by partners of the alliance.

headline: U.S. Issues Off in Foreign Trading
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped and interest rates rose slightly in thin trading overseas yesterday, as market participants in the United States took Columbus Day off.

headline: First Fidelity Profit Up 29%
abstract: LEAD: The First Fidelity Bancorporation, the largest banking company in New Jersey, yesterday announced profits of $70.1 million in the third quarter, its most profitable quarter in two years.

headline: British Steel Sets Deal in Alabama
abstract: British Steel P.L.C. said it had agreed to buy the 90.4 percent of the Tuscaloosa Steel Corporation that it did not own from the Alabama-based company's other shareholders. British Steel refused to disclose the price.   Tuscaloosa, which produces plate and hot-strip steel, was formed in 1984 as a venture by British Steel, Tippins International, O'Neal Steel Inc. and the American Cast Iron Pipe Company. British Steel is the primary supplier of semifinished steel slabs to the Tuscaloosa mill. Tuscaloosa has annual sales of about $150 million and net assets of about $21 million, British Steel said.

headline: Pennzoil Backed on Chevron Stock
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission has cleared the Pennzoil Company to proceed with previously announced plans to increase its 8.8 percent stake in the Chevron Corporation, Pennzoil said today.   In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Pennzoil said the trade commission had removed a delay imposed in August on its the plans to buy 3.9 million more shares of Chevron stock from time to time.

headline: Agricultural Trade Snag
abstract: LEAD: The United States is not alone in its determination to walk away from global trade talks if the European Community continues to block a broad agreement to cut farm subsidies, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Signature, Memphis, a printing company, named Thomas P. Nelson senior vice president of corporate planning and development. * Cosmair Inc., New York, a cosmetic holding company, appointed Jean-Pierre Jabart vice president and general manager of its Biotherm division, replacing Margaret M. Sharkey, who was named deputy general manager and senior vice president in charge of marketing in its Lancome division. * Republic Health Corp., Dallas, named H. Neil Campbell vice president, finance, replacing Craig R. Clark, who becomes vice president and chief accounting officer. * Timberland Co., Hampton, N.H., manufacturer of footwear and outdoor gear, appointed Ron Tise vice president of retail. * Universal Foods Corp., Milwaukee, producers of yeast products, named Jacqueline M. Beuadry vice president of human resources, John T. Pool president of the frozen foods division and Mark W. Hayden vice president of sales in the frozen foods division. * Warrantech Corp., Stamford, Conn., sellers of service contracts covering consumer electronics, appointed Richard Rodriguez vice president of operations and Steven M. Thomas vice president of sales in its consumer product services unit. * Weigh-Tronik Inc., Fairmont, Ill., manufacturers of industrial electronic scales, named Salvatore Vinciguerra president and chief executive, succeeding Richard Bradley, who retired. * West Point-Pepperell Inc., West Point, Ga., a subsidiary of Farley Inc., Chicago, that manufactures bed linens, appointed Edgar E. Davis president and chief operating officer.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Balfour Maclaine Capital Markets, New York, a banking and bond trading firm that was formerly a part of Balfour Maclaine Corp., was acquired by a private investor for undisclosed terms. The company's name has been changed to Whitehall Capital Inc. * Chevron Chemical Co., a subsidiary of Chevron Corp., San Francisco, said it was seeking offers for its fertilizer business. * Crawford & Co., Atlanta, a claims adjusting firm, has acquired Graham Miller Group, London, a loss-adjusting organization, for undisclosed terms. * Domtar Inc., Montreal, a paper products and chemicals company, will cut about 300 jobs as part of a restructuring. * E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Wilmington, Del., predicted earnings growth for 1990 because of the strong performance of its European and petroleum operations. * General Dynamics Corp., St. Louis, the military contractor, said its Atlas IIAS launch vehicle would be used to launch two American Telephone and Telegraph Co. Telestar 4 communications satellites. * General Motors of Canada Ltd. said it would extend its regular Christmas shutdown at two Ontario plants. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, the aircraft company, said it had talks with Malaysia Airlines on a possible sale of MD-11 aircraft. * Montedison S.p.A., the Italian chemicals and pharmaceuticals company, purchased an undisclosed stake in ACX S.A. of France, a supplier of industrial components. * Raytheon Co., Lexington, Mass., a technology and services company, said it had been awarded a $635.4 million contract for the Army's Patriot missile system.   * U S West Inc., Englewood, Colo., a telecommunications company, said it had pulled out of a consortium set up to provide cable television service in Hong Kong. Miller, GrahamA.T.& T.Du Pont

headline: People
abstract: * Mary C. Churchill has resigned as director of corporate communications at J. Walter Thompson, New York, to start a public relations and consulting firm. Jennifer Walker will handle corporate communications for the agency on a special-assignment basis. * Joy McBride was been promoted to senior vice president and director of media services at McCann-Erickson, San Francisco. * Yvonne J. Furth has been named executive vice president and general manager of Kobs & Draft Advertising, Chicago. * Bruce Duffey has been appointed executive creative director at DDB Needham Worldwide, Detroit. * Molly Hudson has been named executive vice president of account management at Lintas, New York. * Sean F. Orr has been appointed vice president and controller for the Reader's Digest Association.

headline: In Cities of Iraq, Food Abounds, Not Spare Parts
abstract: LEAD: More than two months after the United Nations imposed a trade embargo on Iraq, Baghdad and other large cities are enjoying an unexpected bounty of fruit, vegetables and canned goods. As a result, diplomats here believe it will be many months, perhaps a year or more, before food shortages begin to put pressure on the Government of President Saddam Hussein.

headline: LAYOFFS ARE RISING EVEN AT COMPANIES IN GOOD CONDITION
abstract: Many American companies are laying off workers now, rather than waiting to be hit by hard times as they have in the past. Some economists warn that this outburst of corporate preventive medicine increases the odds of a steep recession.    The number of people laid off in the United States has increased sharply since June, reaching the levels of the early months of the 1981-82 recession. While some companies, including Citicorp, Digital Equipment and McDonnell Douglas, are acting because sales and profits have already begun to shrink, many others, including General Electric's appliance division and Nordstrom department stores, are only anticipating such a downturn.

headline: BAKER TRIP SHOWS COALITION DISCORD ON WAR WITH IRAQ
abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's weeklong talks with America's main partners in the coalition against Iraq has demonstrated that there are some very obvious differences over when, and even if, a military operation should be carried out against Iraq, senior Administration officials said today.    Indeed, if there is one overarching lesson from Mr. Baker's eight-country tour, it is that the coalition against Iraq remains solid -- as long as the military option is not imminent. But the closer Washington edges toward using military force, the more the small differences that now exist between coalition partners could develop into major cracks.   Administration officials say they do not think President Bush has decided whether or not to go to war. But his decision to send more than 150,000 more troops to the Arabian Peninsula was interpreted by American marines in Saudi Arabia today as a strong signal that an offensive was growing nearer.  [ Page 14. ] Making 'All Options Credible'     Mr. Baker in effect acknowledged the problems of maintaining the coalition at his closing news conference in Paris, after his talks with President Francois Mitterrand, when he said, "As we wrap up this trip, I feel that we have a very strong consensus on our collective aims, and on the need particularly to resist partial solutions and on the need to work together and stay together in this coalition and on the need to make all of our options credible, if we are to succeed."

headline: KING OF MOROCCO ASKS ARAB SUMMIT
abstract: King Hassan II of Morocco called today for an emergency Arab summit meeting to avert a war in the Persian Gulf.    In a speech broadcast on the Moroccan radio, King Hassan, whose deployment of 1,200 troops was among the first Arab commitments to defend Saudi Arabia, warned that a conflict was drawing near and that he was willing to be the host of an Arab summit meeting within the next week "to give peace a last chance."

headline: Bush Sees a Firm Coalition Even if Iraq Attacks Israel
abstract: The Bush Administration said today that it had reached an arrangement with its allies in the Persian Gulf to keep the coalition against Iraq from falling apart if Baghdad attacks Israel and draws that country into fighting in the Middle East.   The specter of an attack on Israel has been especially troubling to American policy makers as they prepare for the possibility of war with Iraq. Washington's concern has been that the historic enmity between Israel and its Arab neighbors would resurface and break apart the international coalition if Israeli were involved.

headline: Macy Units To Be Sold In G.E. Deal
abstract: LEAD: R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its consumer credit business to the General Electric Company, allowing the department store chain to erase about $1.5 billion in debt from its balance sheet. Macy remains heavily in debt from a management buyout in 1986.

headline: Telerate: A Burden for Dow Jones
abstract: When Dow Jones & Company bought a 32 percent share of Telerate Inc. in 1985, its flagship, The Wall Street Journal, its other business publications and its newer electronic news services were flourishing. Telerate was doing even better, as sizzling demand for its computerized price quotes on United States Government bonds and other financial instruments had allowed it to report annual earnings growth of more than 50 percent for five straight years.   "We believe that Telerate has outstanding potential for future growth, and we want to share in that," Warren H. Phillips, Dow Jones's chairman and chief executive, said at the time.

headline: Barclays Cutbacks
abstract: Barclays Bank P.L.C. said it planned to streamline its domestic retail branch operations in the next five years by closing 110 offices and trimming 1,800 employees through attrition. The office cuts, mostly in urban centers, amount to slightly more than 4 percent of Barclays's network of 2,600 retail bank branches in Britain, while the staff cuts represent 1.5 percent of its total domestic work force of 87,000. Barclays said 1,300 of the jobs would be cut from clerical staff and the rest from management.

headline: Fraud Alleged in Vote for Gorbachev Aide
abstract: Opposition members of the Congress of People's Deputies today produced what they called clear evidence of voting irregularities in the second-round election of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Vice President on Thursday.    Brandishing a smoking gun that consisted of two apparently excess ballots, the opposition legislators charged that the voting in the Congress had been falsified to insure the victory of Mr. Gorbachev's candidate, Gennadi I. Yanayev.

headline: Suzuki in China Deal
abstract: A Japanese car maker said today that it was providing technical assistance in a venture with China. The Suzuki Motor Company, Japan's top mini-car maker, plans to assist in production of a version of its Alto model, a five-door hatchback, a Suzuki spokesman said. Production is to start Tuesday in China. The China Changan Machine Building plant now manufactures Suzuki's Carry model, a lightweight commercial vehicle, with technical assistance from Japan, he said.

headline: Walesa's Rival to Open His 'Black Bag'
abstract: For the last week, Stanislaw Tyminski has been coyly hinting about documents in his "black bag" that would harm Lech Walesa, his rival in the Polish presidential race.   Tonight, he called a crush of Polish and foreign reporters to his headquarters for a news conference, kept them waiting an a hour and half, and then announced that he would make his purported evidence public on Friday, shortly before the noon deadline set by Polish law for all campaigning to come to a halt. Under the rules, Mr. Walesa will not be permitted to respond before the voting begins on Sunday at 6 A.M.

headline: Refinancing Move at Saks
abstract: Investcorp International Inc., the owner of the Saks Fifth Avenue chain, is seeking to raise $500 million by selling or refinancing the retail company's real estate holdings, Crain's New York Business reported in this week's issue.   Investcorp, which wants to use the proceeds of any such transaction to reduce the $775 million of debt it assumed when it bought Saks, will focus its efforts on the 13 stores that Saks owns, company officials told Crain's.    Investcorp is a partnership of Arab investors that last spring outbid several of the world's biggest retailers to pay $1.6 billion for the 48-store chain.   Among the options that Investcorp is considering are a mortgage on the properties, floating some form of securitized debt or doing a sale-leaseback transaction.   Saks, which recently reduced its staff by 700 employees, may have a difficult time raising the amount of financing it is seeking because of the weak commercial real estate markets around the country. The retail chain, which reported operating profits of $110.5 million for 1989, said last month that its 1990 profit was expected to be higher.   Investcorp is being advised on a possible transaction by Jones Lang Wootton, an international commercial real estate brokerage and consulting company. Merrill Lynch & Company has been retained to underwrite the sale of securitized mortgages if that method is used.

headline: Fighting Erupts in the Salvadoran Capital
abstract: LEAD: Fighting broke out between leftist guerrillas and Government troops in San Salvador tonight and loud explosions were heard in several sections of the city.

headline: Iraqi Leader Talks of Freeing Hostages by Spring
abstract: President Saddam Hussein will release all Western hostages held in Iraq by late March "unless something would take place that mars the atmosphere of peace," the official Iraqi press agency announced today.    In what appeared to be a move to pre-empt an American military attack on Iraqi forces at least through the winter, President Hussein said through a spokesman that the hostages would be freed in stages beginning Christmas Day.

headline: A.T.&T. Strained by a Success
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Universal card has been a bigger success than the company ever anticipated -- and that is exactly the problem.    Consumer demand for the card was so heavy after its introduction in March that A.T.& T. was unprepared to handle the millions of applications. The result was delays, billing errors and other problems that irritated some customers and led some to cancel their cards.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Walkers Shortbread Ltd., Aberlour-on-Spey, Scotland, to Cox Landey & Partners, with an undetermined budget.

headline: U.S. Aides Say Move by Israel Hampers Relations
abstract: LEAD: Administration officials say they are deeply concerned that Israel's decision to reject a United Nations inquiry into the shooting of 21 Palestinians in Jerusalem last week could worsen already tense American-Israeli relations and continue to divert attention from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

headline: Baker and Shevardnadze Plan Talks in Houston
abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, announced today that they would hold a ministerial meeting on Dec. 10 and 11 in Houston, Mr. Baker's hometown, apparently to pave the way for a summit meeting in Moscow this winter.   Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze made the announcement after a two-and-a-half-hour meeting at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations in New York, where the two men discussed last-minute details before Thursday's Security Council vote. It is expected to authorize the use of force against Iraq if Iraq continues to refuse to withdraw from Kuwait.

headline: Prescription for Growth: Books on Health
abstract: LEAD: As the cold and flu season approaches, many book buyers may seek relief in the ''Mayo Clinic Family Health Book.''

headline: DDB to Work On McDonald's
abstract: The McDonald's Corporation, has returned to DDB Needham with part of its reported $300 million account, giving the agency a reported $55 million chunk of the business that had been handled by Leo Burnett. The agency handled McDonald's entire account until 1981, and it will rejoin the fast-food chain with various promotional work aimed at young audiences.   The Leo Burnett Company, which took the account away from DDD Needham, continues as McDonald's main agency. "We don't like to lose any assignments, but over all our win/loss record is pretty good," said Hall (Cap) Adams Jr., chairman of Leo Burnett. "It's not the first time and it probably won't be the last." Mr. Adams said he did not anticipate that most dreaded and common result of a big account loss: layoffs.    "It's a matter of workload," said Charles Rubner, vice president of communications for McDonald's, explaining why DDB was chosen. "We're simply saying that we'd like some additional creative resources and diversity."    Mr. Rubner denied industry speculation that McDonald's was reacting to the lukewarm reception of Burnett's recent "Food, Folks and Fun" campaign. Some viewed it as an anticlimactic follow to the popular "Good Times, Great Taste" theme of the earlier Burnett days. "Not at all," Mr. Rubner insisted. "We are pleased with all the work Leo Burnett is doing."

headline: Two Cheers for the Root Canal
abstract: To the Editor:   I read "The Public Equivalent of a Root Canal" (Dec. 2) with interest. I take strong exception to the root-canal metaphor. Root-canal therapy as it is practiced today is one of the least painful dental procedures. It is an important part of modern dentistry and saves thousands of teeth every year. The procedure quickly alleviates the acute pain associated with an infected tooth. The bad press modern root-canal therapy receives is a disservice to dental health professionals, and creates a fear in the public that is unwarranted. DAVID M. GALLIN, D.D.S.  Clinical Professor of Endodontics College of Dentistry New York University  New York, Dec. 3

headline: Fed Stance on Rates Still Unclear
abstract: A big drop in commodity prices yesterday helped to lift Treasury securities and lower long-term interest rates a bit more.    But a clear signal from the Federal Reserve Board that it had decided to lower interest rates -- a move that many analysts had expected as soon as yesterday -- did not materialize.

headline: Bush's Remarks on Aid to Kremlin and Plans for Summit
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Bush's remarks today on aid to the Soviet Union and plans for a summit meeting in Moscow in February:    I have just had an opportunity to discuss with Foreign Minister Shevardnadze a number of issues of U.S.-Soviet relations, including cooperation in the gulf, and I'm pleased with the great progress we've made on Start and hopeful that we'll be ready to sign a treaty at a summit in Moscow on Feb. 11 through 13.   We also talked at length about the situation in the Soviet Union and the response of the United States to the economic problems there. I asked Minister Shevardnadze to convey to President Gorbachev my desire to respond both to the short-term needs of the Soviet Union and to contribute to fundamental economic reform. I've long supported perestroika and continue to.   We discussed frankly the relationship of economic change in the Soviet Union to the critical task of democratization and I reiterated our strong desire to see both political and economic reform continue because they are inextricably linked. I outlined specific and important steps that we're willing to take in support of reform, and after consulting closely with Secretary Yeutter as well as Secretaries Brady and Baker, I told Minister Shevardnadze that I am prepared to respond to a Soviet request for credit guarantees for purchase of agricultural commodities through a waiver of the Jackson-Vanik amendment.    While I've taken this step, I still look forward to a passage of the Soviet immigration law codifying the generally excellent practices of the past year. And this then will permit us to make further progress toward the normalization of the U.S.-Soviet economic relationship. Long-Term I.M.F. Role    In addition, we have proposed to the Soviets a special technical assistance project to help in assessing their food-distribution problem and to support market reforms.   I will also authorize a joint public-private medical-assistance effort to help the Soviet Union cope with immediate shortages of pharmaceuticals and basic medical supplies.   In the longer term, only steps that the Soviet Union itself takes can assure the economic health there. Thus to promote fundamental economic reform, I will propose that the World Bank and the I.M.F. work out with the Soviet Union a special association to give the U.S.S.R. access to the considerable financial and economic expertise of those institutions.   I have asked Secretary of the Treasury Nick Brady, as U.S. governor of both institutions, to pursue this proposal with them and also with our other allies, who I'm sure will be in accord.    As I've said before, I want perestroika to succeed. The Soviet Union is facing tough times, difficult times. But I believe that this is a good reason to act now in order to help the Soviet Union stay the course of democratization and to undertake market reforms. The United States has an interest in a Soviet Union able to play a role as a full and prosperous member of the international community of states. And I'm hopeful that these initiatives will further that goal.

headline: 200 on Verge of Soviet Exit Are Stalled
abstract: More than 200 Christian fundamentalists who were supposed to inaugurate a new refugee system to America were trapped in a bureaucratic limbo at the airport today, having sundered all ties to the Soviet Union after years of religious persecution, but then finding departure denied to them at literally the last exit.    "I had said farewell to this place -- but now look at us," Pavel Boyko said desperately of the group camped in a tangle of baggage and sleeping babies at passpor control.

headline: Rwandan Army Says Rebels Were Defeated in Northeast
abstract: LEAD: The Rwandan Army ousted rebels from a district center in the northeast in fierce fighting over the weekend, an army spokesman said today.

headline: Strategies in the A.T.&T. Offer
abstract: The NCR Corporation's stock jumped $24.75, or 43.6 percent, to $81.50 a share yesterday, as investors concluded that the company had little chance of remaining independent after receiving an unsolicited bid of $90 a share from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on Sunday.    NCR's chairman and chief executive, Charles E. Exley Jr., said: "It is our strong preference to remain independent and get on with the job. We want to be left alone." But investors brushed aside such statements, contending that Mr. Exley was seeking to obtain a higher price.

headline: Review of Matsushita Debt Rating
abstract: The rating of about $2.4 billion in senior debt issued by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Matsushita Electric Trading Finance N.V., the Panasonic Capital Corporation, and Panasonic Finance (Netherlands) B.V. is under review for a possible downgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday. The agency said Mastushita senior debt was currently rated Aaa.    Standard & Poor's cited Matsushita Electric's agreement to acquire MCA Inc. for $6.8 billionas its reason for placing the Japanese company under review.    The rating agency said the acquisition would affect Matsushita's capital structure by increasing new debt or reducing liquid assets to finance the purchase, besides adding MCA's existing debt. While the acquisition should provide benefits, S.&P. said, the addition of MCA's less predictable movie and record operations to Matsushita's consumer electronics business would increase the company's overall risk.

headline: Paris Futures Market Starts New Contract
abstract: Seeking to expand its base overseas and to bolster its challenge to London as Europe's leading futures market, the futures and options market here began trading a contract last week that is linked to the European Currency Unit.   The futures market, the Marche a Terme International de France, or Matif, is banking on the new long-term bond contract to increase its international allure and give it an edge over London in a running battle to become Europe's main futures market.

headline: Less-Costly Apple Line To Be Presented Today
abstract: LEAD: Answering criticism that its products are overpriced, Apple Computer Inc. will introduce three new versions of its Macintosh today, with the least expensive carrying a list price of $999.

headline: Blast in Ireland Kills Soldier
abstract: A bomb hidden in a car killed a part-time soldier today, and the police said they were looking for a woman who had driven it into the garage where the victim worked. The police said the slain man was 34-year-old Albert Cooper, a member of the Ulster Defense Regiment, a locally recruited army unit. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but Ulster Defense Regiment members have been frequent targets of the Irish Republican Army, which is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.25   8.12   9.08        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.18   7.13   7.87        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.21   7.16   7.92        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.60   8.68   8.34        30-YR.

headline: La Quinta Inns And Bass at Odds
abstract: LEAD: An investment group that includes members of the Bass family of Fort Worth requested that the board of La Quinta Motor Inns Inc. allow its shareholders to vote on the company's ''poison pill'' anti-takeover plan. The Bass group controls 14.9 percent of the La Quinta's shares. They are stymied from buying additional shares of the San

headline: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Are Mixed
abstract: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were narrowly mixed for the week that ended yesterday.    The postponement of the Treasury Department's regular bill auction on Monday of three-month and six-month Treasury bills because of Congress's failure to raise the debt limit meant many interest-rate watchers who follow the bill auctions had to watch trading in the secondary market instead for some indication of movement in short-term rates.

headline: Buyer Sought By Highland
abstract: Highland Superstores Inc. said this week that it would seek a buyer or merger partner for its 92 consumer electronics and appliance stores.    Highland, based in Plymouth, Mich., also reported a fourth consecutive quarterly deficit on Tuesday. It lost $4.8 million in the third quarter on $193.1 million in revenue. The company said that fourth-quarter sales "continue to be weak" and that it "does not anticipate significant improvement."   Highland said it had retained Shearson Lehman Brothers to find partners or buyers and to explore raising new capital.    Highland is also in negotiations with lenders to extend until April 30 a deadline for reducing short-term debt to $33 million, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company faces a Jan. 1 deadline to reduce its $52 million of short- term borrowings.   The company blamed weak demand and intense competition for its losses. It said it would close stores if it could not find a buyer or partner.   Highland employs 5,400 people and operates stores in New York, Texas and the Midwest.

headline: Hong Kong Bank Move
abstract: The largest bank in Hong Kong announced today that it was transferring all assets offshore, a move that could damage confidence in the British colony, which is scheduled to revert to Chinese rule in 1997.   The chairman of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, William Purves, said the decision reflected the bank's global reach and did not signal abandonment of the territory where it has flourished for 125 years.   One broker speaking on condition of anonymity said the action, which transfers the bank's assets to a British holding company, "leaves the impression that the British are pulling out." The Chinese authorities had no immediate comment on the move.    Under the plan, the bank will rename its Silom Ltd. subsdiary as HSBC Holdings Ltd. HSBC Holdings will then be transformed into an umbrella company, owning Hongkong and Shanghai Bank and all its holdings.

headline: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
abstract: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with tomorrow's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, rescheduled from today because of the Veterans Day holiday. On Thursday the Government will auction a record $11.75 billion of one-year bills.   By late Friday the outstanding three-month and six-month bills were bid at 7.05 percent and 7.03 percent, respectively, with the outstanding one-year bill at 6.85 percent.   The following fixed-income issues are scheduled this week: TAXABLE ONE DAY DURING THE WEEK      Source: McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc.   Ratings: MCM/Moody's/Standard & Poor's. TAX-EXEMPT TUESDAY    Illinois, $120 million in Build Illinois sales tax revenue bonds. Competitive.  New York State, $303 million in general obligation bonds. Competitive.  TENTATIVE OFFERINGS THIS WEEK    Boston, $170 million in revenue bonds for Boston City Hospital. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.  Chicago, $200 million in Chicago-O'Hare International Airport special facilities revenue bonds (American Airlines). Goldman, Sachs & Co.  Connecticut Health and Education Facilities Authority, $124.7 million in Yale-New Haven Hospital revenue bonds. Goldman, Sachs.  Corpus Christi, Tex., $63.4 million in utility revenue bonds. Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.  Fayetteville, N.C., $60 million in revenue bonds. Paine Webber Inc.  New Jersey Health Care Facilities Authority, $55 million in debt securities for the Medical Center of Ocean County. Ryan, Beck & Co.  Redevelopment Agency of Sacramento, Calif., $86 million in tax allocation bonds for merged downtown redevelopment project. Paine Webber.

headline: Economic Scene; Simulating Competition
abstract: DO consumers still benefit from the regulation of long-distance phone rates? Not so long ago the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was almost universally regarded as a puma amidst newborn kittens -- a powerful beast, whose predatory instincts made it untrustworthy out of sight of its Government keepers.    But in the last few years A.T.&T.'s rivals, notably the MCI Communications Corporation and U S Sprint, have grown claws of their own. And with the support of the Bush Administration, the Federal Communications Commission is proposing to lengthen A.T.&T.'s leash, with the thought of one day letting free markets rather than regulation protect consumers' interests.

headline: Keeping Track Of Defaulted Debt
abstract: AS more and more corporations default on their "junk bonds," the temptation to search for bargains has become greater. But so far, the pickings among defaulted bonds have been poor.   A new index that measures the performance of bonds only after they go into default fell almost 11 percent in the first 10 months of the year, worse than the performance of all junk bonds.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * AFG Industries, Fort Worth, a flat glass company, said its chairman, R. D. Hubbard, had started a proxy contest and consent solicitation seeking to replace the management of Hollywood Park Operating Co., Inglewood, Calif., a horse racing track. Mr. Hubbard owns 9.9 percent of Hollywood Park's shares. * Baker Hughes Inc., Houston, an energy services company, has purchased Elder Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Energy Ventures Inc., Houston, an oilfield services and equipment company. * Ball Corp., Muncie, Ind., a maker of packaging, industrial and consumer products, acquired the remaining 50 percent interest in its Ball-InCon Glass Packaging Corp. joint venture from Holland-American Investment Corp. The purchase price was $65 million. * Calvary Holdings, San Diego, said it would offer $5.25 a share for all common shares of Diceon Electronics Inc., Irvine, Calif., a maker of multi-layered printed circuit boards for the computer industry. * Celutel Inc., Philadelphia, a cellular telephone systems company, entered an agreement for a group led by Continental Bank Corp., Chicago, to buy $22.5 million of a new class of Celutel preferred stock and class A stock purchase warrants. * Hotel Investors Trust, Woodland Hills, Calif., and Hotel Investors Corp., San Diego, said that because of deteriorating international finance markets, EIE International Corp.'s Park Plaza Inc. was unlikely to get financing for its proposed purchase of 27 Hotel Investors properties for $152 million. * Xerox Corp., Stamford, Conn., said it and Computer Sciences Corp., El Segundo, Calif., had been selected by the Army to continue to compete to be prime contractor for the Army's Computer-aided Acquisition and Logistics Support program. The four-phase, 15-year program is worth about $400 million.

headline: The Hole in Hollywood's Pocket
abstract: While many American industries are retrenching in the face of a recession, Hollywood is on a spending spree. The studios are paying unprecedented prices for scripts, stars, directors and other talent required to produce feature films.   The theatrical, video and pay television businesses have exploded abroad, setting off bidding wars among the studios for the handful of talent believed to have the greatest global appeal. Artists involved in action films, which consistently play well worldwide, have seen the most spectacular increases.  High Industry Benchmarks    And rates like the following are beginning to serve as benchmarks for the entire industry:

headline: CONFLICTS DEFUSED IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
abstract: Czechoslovakia's Parliament enacted legislation today outlining the powers of the Czech and Slovak regional governments after weeks of sometimes bitter debate.    Supporters of the legislation, which was approved by an overwhelming majority, called it a positive step toward defusing the smoldering conflicts in this federated state.

headline: Amoco Begins the Sale of Cleaner Fuels
abstract: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that it had begun selling a cleaner gasoline in all three grades in Washington, Baltimore, Richmond and Roanoke, Va., and that together the fuels meet the 1992 standards of the Clean Air Act passed by Congress last month.   The company said it was the first to claim to meet the new standards, and spokesmen for other companies said that they knew of no others. But Amoco said, as have its competitors, that meeting the second phase, in 1995, presented a big challenge.

headline: Hussein, in U.S. TV Interview, Rejects a Kuwait Withdrawal
abstract: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said today that he had no intention of withdrawing his troops from Kuwait, despite the forces mounting against him.   "If an embargo would force the American people to withdraw from the last state that was linked to the United States -- say Hawaii -- then the same standards, if they were to be applied, would probably lead the Iraqis to consider withdrawal from Kuwait," he said.  Expresses Confidence     In a wide-ranging interview with correspondents of the Cable News Network in Baghdad, Mr. Hussein said that Iraq was seeking to avoid war, but that he was "confident of victory in the end" if hostilities broke out.

headline: Salvadoran Rebel Fire Kills 2 As Shells Fall Short of Target
abstract: A 9-year-old boy and his 20-year-old brother were killed this evening when two mortar rounds fired by rebels fell short of their apparent target and landed on a civilian neighborhood next to the Salvadoran military headquarters.   The homemade mortars, which also wounded two civilians, appeared to have been aimed at the Salvadoran high command. The explosions collapsed several steel-reinforced roofs and cracked the concrete walls of a United States Embassy house half a block from the point of impact.    The attack follows the bombardment last week by a rebel unit of the main air force base on the eastern outskirts of the capital.

headline: Drexel Deal Is Described By Witness
abstract: A former salesman of high-yield "junk bonds" with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. testified yesterday that Michael R. Milken once told him that securities owned by the firm were sometimes secretly held by the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, one of Drexel's largest clients.    The testimony by the salesman, James Dahl, came in the pre-sentencing hearing for Mr. Milken and was the first public evidence that Columbia may have "parked" securities for Drexel.

headline: Bolivians Clash Over Impeachment of Justices
abstract: In a crisis over separation of powers that severely challenges Bolivia's effort to build a stable democracy, 8 of the 12 members of the Supreme Court are being subjected to interrogation and confessional almost daily on live television.    The governing coalition behind President Jaime Paz Zamora says the impeachment proceedings in Congress are intended to make possible the creation of an independent judiciary with the naming of replacement justices who have no political affiliation. The leading opposition force charges that the impeachment is a kangaroo court intended to concentrate all three state powers in the hands of Mr. Paz Zamora and his political partners.

headline: Inflation Fear Is Said To Subside
abstract: Many credit market analysts say inflationary pressures have begun to ease significantly, even though oil prices remain substantially above the levels before Iraq invaded Kuwait and could go higher still if war erupts in the Persian Gulf.    The moderating trend has come as a welcome surprise to many credit market participants, who feared that rapidly rising oil prices would in turn push up the prices of other goods and services.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Companies    Exxon's net income was unchanged, while Unocal's rose 53.2 percent. At Exxon, higher oil prices depressed profits in refining, marketing and chemical operations.  [ Page D1. ]   Sears's earnings showed faint signs of improvement from a deep slump in its core retailing operation.  [ D1. ]   Even as Continental Air appears to be overcoming a reputation for bad service, financial problems are catching up with it.  [ D1. ]   A small software supplier involved in a dispute with Revlon disabled some of Revlon's software.  [ D1. ]   Procter & Gamble reported a profit of $555 million, or $1.57 a share. On an operating basis, that was up nearly 15 percent.  [ D4. ]   Goodyear said it lost $61.4 million, citing intense price competition, higher costs and huge debt.  [ D5. ]   The board of the Financial News Network and Infotechnology announced a new management team.  [ D21. ]   Times Mirror earnings dropped 40.2 percent, while Knight-Ridder said its profit slipped 3.2 percent from 1989 results.  [ D21. ]    The Big Board halted trading in MCA twice on reports of troubled buyout talks. The stock lost $8.875, to $50.  [ D21. ]    Warren E. Buffett and companies he controls have acquired 9.8 percent of Wells Fargo.  [ D4. ]  The Economy     A compromise on taxes believed to have the support of the White House and of a majority in the Senate and House was struck by Congressional leaders.  [ A1. ]    A sweeping bill to curtail disease-prevention claims on food packages was approved by Congress.  [ A1. ]    The decision to hold hearings on Senators linked to Keating marks a triumph of politics over process. News analysis.  [ A18. ]    The Transportation Dept. issued standards for auto safety intended to protect occupants of cars struck from the side.  [ A23. ]    The high dividend Citicorp was forced to pay on a preferred stock issue served as a reminder that many investors are skeptical about the strength of large banks.  [ D2. ]    Orders to factories for "big ticket" durable goods fell 1.7 percent in September from August, the Government said.  [ D6. ]    Sales of domestic vehicles rose 10.9 percent in mid-October, in sharp contrast to other signs of a softening economy.  [ D7. ]  International    A U.S. Treasury official told Brazil's central bank president he was worried about more than $8 billion in unpaid interest.  [ D2. ]    Markets Oil prices rebounded as the market sensed it might have been overly optimistic on the Gulf. Crude added $1.71, to $31.08.  [ D1. ]    Stock prices were mixed, although a sharp rise in Compaq's profits gave several high-tech stocks a lift. The Dow rose 10.15, to 2,504.21.  [ D10. ]    Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher and interest rates dipped in light trading.  [ D18. ]    The dollar fell sharply against leading foreign currencies.  [ D19. ]  Copper futures prices fell sharply.  [ D19. ]  Today's Columns    Citicorp agreed to pay a high rate on a preferred stock issue, another sign of investor concern about big banks. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D1. ]    When Philips and Du Pont ended their optical disk venture, it reflected a divergence within the disk market. Talking Deals.  [ D2. ]    T.W.A., dumped by Young & Rubicam and spurned by other big agencies, is looking at small ones. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D21. ]

headline: A NARROW ESCAPE FOR I.R.A. CAPTIVE
abstract: A Roman Catholic man said today that he thought he was driving to his death when gunmen of the Irish Republican Army strapped him into a van loaded with explosives and tailed him to a military base near Omagh.   But Gerry Kelly was lucky: He wriggled free and the bomb failed to go off.

headline: Japan Offers Adults New Electronic Toys For Holiday Season
abstract: Few countries celebrate the holidays as intensely as Japan does. As the end of the year nears, droves of blue-suited office workers take fellow employees, their best customers and their bosses on endless celebrations, often ending up in one of thousands of "snack bars" and "hostess clubs." As part of the ritual, a big-screen television set showing a music video with lyrics printed on the screen is flipped on, a microphone is passed around, and after sake and beer overwhelm traditional Japanese reticence, people begin to sing along. All night.   Now, with an enthusiasm born of long and noisy nights, Japan's industrial giants think the outside world is ready for large numbers of yet another export: those same "laser karaoke" systems that combine music, video images and lyrics in scrolling captions.

headline: Northern Telecom Is Under Review
abstract: The proposed acquisition by Northern Telecom Ltd. of the remaining 73 percent of the outstanding shares of STC P.L.C. for about $2.6 billion has prompted Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation to place the senior debt rating of Northern Telecom under review with negative implications.    The review, which affects up to $1 billion in debt, was prompted by the concerns of both rating agencies over the added debt burden that will result from the purchase of the STC shares. Both rating agencies will also be examining the potential benefits of combining the two companies' product lines.   The purchase is expected to be made with bank debt and proceeds from the sale of STC's computer business, STC International Computers Ltd., to Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan.    Northern Telecom, based in Mississauga, Ontario, is one of the largest suppliers of telecommunications equipment in North America, while STC, based in London, is one of the United Kingdom's leading telecommunications companies.   Northern Telecom's senior debt is currently rated Aa-3 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P.

headline: U.S. to Rent Cruise Ship for Gulf G.I. Furloughs
abstract: The Pentagon said today that it would pay the Cunard Line of Britain $31 million to divert a luxury cruise ship to the Persian Gulf so American soldiers and marines can enjoy brief furloughs from duty in the parched Saudi desert.   The 800-passenger ocean liner, the Cunard Princess, has canceled its bookings for the next six months so it can begin gulf duty, Cunard said in a statement today.

headline: Shevardnadze Move Bolsters Bills
abstract: Money poured into short-term Treasury bills yesterday after the sudden resignation of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Meanwhile, the year-end cashing in continued in the Treasury bond market, where prices fell and yields rose for the second straight session.    The threat to Soviet political stability from Mr. Shevardnadze's departure rattled European financial markets early in the day, and pushed German, French and British interest rates up sharply. The news also generated a strong rally in the dollar, particularly against the German mark. Analysts said at least some of the money that fled into dollars was invested in Treasury bills.

headline: Fed Acts To Lower Key Rate
abstract: Honoring a pledge it indicated would be fulfilled once Congress passed a new Federal budget, the Federal Reserve Board yesterday sent a clear signal that it had lowered interest rates.   Analysts, however, said the drop was modest would do little to spur an economy many contend has fallen into recession. Additional evidence of economic weakness will be needed before the Fed acts again, they said.

headline: Mexico Features Its Culture In New Tourism Campaign
abstract: MEXICO is trying to change its image, and to do so has enlisted the singer Linda Ronstadt in a campaign for the Ministry of Tourism estimated to cost $10 million.   In an effort to attract more sophisticated travelers, Mexico is turning its focus away from beach resorts like Cancun and instead is trying to appeal to visitors seeking the kind of cultural experience to be found in Europe or the Middle East.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: International    For much of Eastern Europe, 1991 is certain to be a year of swift economic change, one that aims to keep pace with the monumental political changes in the region. So far, with the first year of Eastern Europe's post-Communist era drawing to a close, the region's economies, except for Poland's, have moved only a few steps down the road to capitalism.  [ Page 1. ]   Officials of the U.S., Canada and Mexico say they are fast sweeping away obstacles to Canadian participation in free-trade talks expected to open in 1991 between the U.S. and Mexico. The three countries are expected to begin shaping an agreement that would create a North American common market.  [ 29. ]   World stock markets begin 1991 facing the threat of war, recessions or economic slowdowns, and dismal earnings. Yet many people expect a better year than the one that ends today.  [ 29. ] The Economy    A law that took effect on April 1 allows employers to hire teen-agers at less than the minimum wage of $3.80 an hour. But few companies have elected to go below this level, a survey has found.  [ 1. ]   The F.T.C. has subpoenaed records of the leading manufacturers of infant formula, suspecting that they collaborated to raise prices. The formula is a key ingredient of packages given to low-income families under the WIC supplemental food program.  [ 1. ]   Orders for machine tools dropped 24.1 percent in November from the October level, as concerns about the weakening economy and fear of war dampened demand for factory machinery.  [ 29. ] The Media Business    A year after the merger of Time and Warner created the world's largest communications company, Time Warner Inc. is finding that the combination adds up to a lot less than three, but something more than two.  [ 29. ]   One publication remains happily aloof from controversy over ads in children's magazines. Sesame Street Magazine, about to celebrate its 20th birthday, has never accepted advertising.  [ 34. ]   The U.S. may be poised to give Europeans a peculiarly American broadcast innovation: the plug.  [ 34. ]   Remarks by a Cuban-American television commentator about Puerto Rican women have enraged Puerto Ricans in many cities and embroiled the nation's largest Spanish-language network in a dispute that threatens its advertising and its base of viewers.  [ 1. ]   The World Paper covers topics ranging from nuclear proliferation to fundamentalism from a foreign perspective. Press.  [ 34. ]   Thompson Medical will begin new commercials for its Slim-Fast diet aid, intended to serve as an umbrella campaign for a new line of reduced-calorie foods. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ 35. ] Companies    Best Buy has converted nearly half of its 70 consumer electronics stores to warehouse-style operations. The move has proved popular with consumers but has angered Japanese suppliers.  [ 36. ]   CS Holding says the decision of a Swiss court will make business more difficult. The court stated that CS Holding is subject to the capital requirements of Swiss banking law.  [ 33. ]  Today's Columns    The old reliable consumer growth stocks again led the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average in 1990. Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola and Phillip Morris were the top three stocks again this year, as they were in 1989. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ 29. ]   The personal computer is a breakthrough technology that should be revamping the lives of millions of Americans and making them wealthier. But so far, the great payoff has not materialized. And if history is a guide, the payoff will probably not occur until the 21st century. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene.  [ 30. ]   One bright spot in the gloom that has hung over Wall Street this year was the financial performance of the 41 primary dealers of Government securities. The trading profits of these firms are likely to be higher than in any year since 1986. Credit Markets.  [ 33. ]

headline: Bell Atlantic Plans Earnings Charge
abstract: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said it would take a one-time charge against its fourth-quarter earnings of about $40 million, or 10 cents a share. The charge will reduce the value on Bell Atlantic's books of the company's non-telephone financial services, which include equipment leasing and lending to other companies and real estate projects.   Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, said that the businesses were doing well and had no credit problems but that their market value had fallen. Marion M. Boucher, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., said Bell Atlantic's investments outside the telephone industry now appeared more vulnerable to an economic downturn than many investors had thought. Bell Atlantic's stock fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $50.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: All-Sports Radio Format Arrives on the West Coast
abstract: Thirty years after major league baseball reached the West Coast, all-sports radio has made the journey, with a powerful San Diego-based radio station adopting the format pioneered by New York's WFAN-AM.    The fresh convert to all-sports programming is XTRA-AM, which has studios here and its powerful transmitter across the border in Tijuana. XTRA's signal can be heard throughout the San Diego-Los Angeles area. It recently added the broadcast rights to Los Angeles Kings hockey games, and it also carries San Diego Chargers football games.

headline: Farm Credit Unit Prices 3 Issues
abstract: The Federal Farm Credit Funding Corporation yesterday priced three bond issues totaling $2.33 billion through a nationwide group of securities dealers and dealer banks.    A $1.12 billion of consolidated systemwide bonds due April 1, 1991, was given a 7 percent coupon and priced at 100, to yield about 23 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, while an $45 million bond issue due July 1, 1991, was also given a 7 percent coupon and similarly priced at 100, to yield about 14 basis points more than Treasury issues. For $365 million of one-year bonds due Jan. 2, 1992, the coupon was 7.05 percent and price of 100, or more than 15 basis points over Treasury issues.

headline: American Cyanamid Names New President
abstract: The American Cyanamid Company, the chemical and pharmaceutical concern that recently divested itself of consumer lines, named a new president yesterday and made two other top appointments to strengthen its management.   The chairman and chief executive, George J. Sella Jr., gave up the president's post to Albert J. Costello, 55 years old, who was named a director as well.

headline: Korea Talks Resume; Seoul Sees Reasons for Caution
abstract: LEAD: The Prime Ministers of North and South Korea today formally began their second round of negotiations to reduce tensions as South Koreans cautioned against expecting any sort of breakthrough on the military and political issues dividing them.

headline: People
abstract: * Una Barden and John Marchese have been named senior vice presidents of BBDO New York. * Chris DeMoulin, Frani Pisano and John Cannon were named vice presidents of DDB Needham, New York. * Jonathan Giles Daly was promoted to vice president and director of strategic planning of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York. Cheryl L. Brenner was named an account manager in the St. Louis office. * Kathleen Foley has been named to the new position of senior vice president and group direcor at Young & Rubicam, San Francisco.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MONDAY: Stock markets close two hours early for Christmas Eve. Most commodities markets closed or closing early. TUESDAY: Christmas Day. Markets, banks, government offices and almost every business is closed. WEDNESDAY: Treasury auctions two-year notes. THURSDAY: Treasury auctions four-year notes. * Durable goods orders for November. FRIDAYLeading economic indicators for November.

headline: Debt and Democracy
abstract: President Bush has started his five-nation tour of South America speaking of democracy. His Latin hosts, all democratically elected presidents, are talking of debt.     "To fulfill the New World's destiny, all of the Americas and the Caribbean must embark on a venture for the coming century: to create the first fully democratic hemisphere in the history of mankind," Mr. Bush said on Monday as he began the first tour of South America by an American president in eight years.

headline: Technology; The Coming Switch on Switching
abstract: Consider the classical telephone connection: a "twisted pair" of copper wires stretching between two telephones, which are usually linked through some kind of central switch to form a closed-loop circuit. Despite enormous advances in technology, from optical fibers to cellular telephones, the underlying idea of the closed-loop circuit has endured.   But it may not endure much longer. In a growing holy war between rival manufacturers of telecommunications network equipment, proponents of a fundamentally different technology say it is time to write an obituary for the switched-circuit network and replace it with newer, faster technology.

headline: Guatemala Arrests Five in Killing of an American
abstract: LEAD: At least five soldiers have been detained in the killing of an American innkeeper, a case the Bush Administration has called an important test of the justice system of Guatemala and its relations with the United States.

headline: Foreign Workers Leaving Eastern Germany
abstract: LEAD: When she thinks back to her days in Dresden in the 1970's as an electrical-engineering student, Nguyen Lien's eyes glow.

headline: Wary Enthusiasm at GATT
abstract: The European Community's agreement on the terms of a proposal for cutting barriers to farm trade was greeted with cautious enthusiasm tonight at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 105-nation organization that is responsible for the Uruguay Round of world trade liberalization talks.   A GATT spokesman said there would "certainly be some relief" that all the major negotiating groups now have an offer on the table. But the spokesman added there would be a need to look at the fine print in some detail. There would also need to be an assurance that there was some room for negotiation, he said.    A large gap remains to be bridged between the American proposal, submitted three weeks ago, for 90 percent cuts in export subsidies and 75 percent in other farm supports, and the community proposal for 30 percent cuts.    The news came from Brussels as five days of crisis meetings at the Geneva headquarters of GATT and among some of the main participants had ended without any clear sign of progress. The four-year-long Uruguay Round is scheduled to end in Brussels Dec. 7.   GATT's Director General, Arthur Dunkel of Switzerland, said with evident disappointment that there were not many signs of movement.    Rubens Ricupero of Brazil, speaking for the developing countries, also said there had been no real negotiating effort in Geneva, and no progress in areas like agriculture and textiles that are of particular importance to developing countries.    He warned that these countries would not accept a package worked out by other nations that is presented on a "take it or leave it" basis.    The chief United States negotiator, Warren Lavorel, told the meeting: "I came here to strike deals, not to make speeches. So let's get on with it."

headline: Moscow to Get Trading Help
abstract: The Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the world's biggest commodities exchanges, said last week that they would help to develop a Soviet commodity market.   The Moscow Commodity Exchange is a rudimentary trading forum for goods from  paint brushes to computers.   An agreement signed here by the Board of Trade and the Merc follows a similar accord last month between the New York Stock Exchange and its planned Soviet counterpart.   Leo Melamed, chairman of the Merc's executive committee, said the assistance would be largely educational. "We also plan to give them a great deal of published information, which will be translated into Russian," he said.   The agreement calls for regular assistance and a swap of market research findings.   Mr. Melamed warned the Soviet organizers not to expect too much too soon from their new exchange, which is one of two that have sprung up in Moscow in the last six weeks. An exchange in Leningrad is also expected to open shortly.   He said the Moscow exchange would deal in physical commodities, as opposed to Chicago's standardized paper contracts that call for deliveries at a future date.

headline: Don't Blame the Rules, Learn the Game
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Tokyo, Irritated by U.S. Rebuke, Says Furor Over Slur Seems Racist
abstract: After weeks of issuing apologies, Japanese officials have reacted with irritation to a resolution approved by a Congressional committee in Washington that reprimands Japan's Justice Minister for comparing foreign prostitutes here with blacks who move into white American neighborhoods and "ruin the atmosphere."    The House Foreign Affairs Committee passed the resolution late Thursday after dropping an earlier version that had called on the Justice Minister, Seiroku Kajiyama, to resign. The committee changed the text of the resolution after lobbying from Japan's Ambassador, who suggested that the demand for Mr. Kajiyama's resignation amounted to interference in Japan's domestic affairs.

headline: Digital Model Has Problems
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation has found some problems in its new line of mainframe computers, prompting the company to retrofit the machines to make them more reliable, a spokesman said today.   Digital introduced its VAX 9000 machines last year, entering the mainframe market, which has been dominated by I.B.M.   Some customers have reported troubles with the machines, which are designed to handle large amounts of information. Digital said the problems had caused the machines to crash every few days in certain applications.   Mark Steinkrauss, director of investor relations for Digital, said the problems arose among a handful of customers who run the machines for long periods.    David Lynch, a Digital spokesman, said the enhancement was being made on all VAX 9000's. He said Digital did not consider the situation a serious problem.   The company has been looking to the VAX 9000 to help bolster weak revenues that led to Digital's first quarterly loss earlier in the year.   Digital's stock rose $2.125 today, to $59.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: A.T.& T. Offers New PC Chip
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company introduced an inexpensive chip today designed to give personal computers new capabilities for speech, music processing and graphics.

headline: Discover Card Certificates Are Priced by Dean Witter
abstract: A $500 million issue of pass-through certificates backed by Discover credit card receivables was priced yesterday through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Discover Card Services Inc. and Dean Witter are both units of Sears, Roebuck & Company.    The pass-through certificates are being offered through Discover Card Trust 1990-D and carry a coupon of 8.85 percent. They are priced at 99.643 to yield 9.02 percent, or about 108 basis points more than three-year Treasury notes. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.   Underwriters expect the financing to be rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation based on the underlying quality of the receivables and an issue of subordinated debt equal to about 10 percent of the senior securities.    The legal final maturity of the certificates is May 16, 1996, and the expected final maturity is May 15, 1994. Payments on the principal will be in 12 equal installments beginning June 15, 1993.

headline: Eurotunnel Share Offer
abstract: Eurotunnel, the British-French consortium that is digging a rail tunnel beneath the English Channel, said Friday that it hoped to raise $:532 million, or about $1.04 billion, through the sale of new shares to existing shareholders.   The company set the price at 285 pence a share, equal to about $5.56. It plans to offer nearly 200 million new shares, in addtion to the 332.4 million shares already outstanding.   The proposed sale price is 34 percent below Eurotunnel's current price of 430 pence on London's stock market. The new shares will begin trading on Nov. 12, the company said.   Current shareholders will be eligible to buy three new shares for every five they already own, Eurotunnel said.    The tunnel is scheduled to open in 1993, but the company expects to pay no dividends until 1999.

headline: Economic Scene; Is the Deficit Cut A Serious Error?
abstract: AFTER failing time and again to work out a plan to eliminate the budget deficit during the years when the economy was climbing, the White House and Congress finally made a deal to cut the deficit by an estimated $40 billion in the next fiscal year and by $490 billion or so over the next five years -- just when most economists believe the economy is weak and falling into recession.    Is this, as some economists are saying, a horrendous blunder, comparable to the decision made by President Herbert Hoover to put through a huge tax rise, nearly doubling rates, as the economy was falling into the depths of the Depression in 1932?      Mr. Hoover's aim was to prevent inflation by closing the budget deficit when businesses were failing, unemployment rising and incomes falling, and the real threat was deflation. Fear of inflation, during a time of falling employment and prices, also greatly restricted the efforts of the Federal Reserve to make more money and credit available and to reduce interest rates. The perverse Hoover fiscal policy and timid Fed monetary policy, which allowed the money supply to shrink by one-third, as banks slashed their lending to business, deepened the Depression.    Are national leaders about to make the same mistakes and thrust the weakened American economy into depression? Should they just forget about reducing the structural budget deficit, regarded as a cause of big trade deficits, savings shortfalls, low capital formation and productivity growth, as well as weakened American competitiveness -- and instead focus on the short-run necessity of fighting recession by increasing the deficit through lower taxes and higher spending? C. Eugene Steuerle, who was Deputy Assistant Secretary for tax analysis at the Treasury Department before joining the Urban Institute in Washington in 1989, contends it would be a serious mistake to forget about reducing the debt burden, which has been growing faster, even in good times, than the national income, for the sake of using short-term fiscal policy to combat the recession.    Indeed, he maintains it is possible to achieve a fiscal policy that will meet both the objectives of short-term economic stabilization and long-term deficit reduction aimed at strengthening national economic growth. To get both, he calls for "automatic fiscal stabilization through the tax and transfer system" within the context of long-run fiscal balance.    To get greater fiscal responsiveness to short-run cyclical swings without sacrificing long-term economic stability, he calls for improving public insurance programs. The unemployment compensation system, traditionally the Government's chief weapon for providing anti-recessionary expenditures and insurance, has, he says become a "timebomb," because the system is so inadequately financed that a recession could make many state programs insolvent. Less than one-third of the jobless have received benefits in the last decade.    He would provide financing to unemployment compensation that would make it one of the strongest automatic stabilizers, increasing total demand when the economy slumps and decreasing it when the economy booms.    While improving the automatic stabilizers for short-term fiscal responses, he supports a long-run deficit-reduction target and would stick to it over the course of the business cycle. Negotiators of the recent budget deal, in Mr. Steuerle's view, "score fairly high marks on their overall deficit-reduction strategy, but score less well on their choice of specific cuts."      But if one relies only on the automatic stabilizers, rather than on discretionary changes in taxes or spending, to check a recession, will the economy fall into a depression?    Hyman P. Minsky, a visiting professor at Bard College of Columbia University and author of "Can 'It' Happen Again?" answers no -- because today's economy is far less vulnerable to deep depression. In 1929 the Federal Government constituted a mere 3 percent of the total United States economy; it now accounts for 25 percent, and its spending will be stable throughout the business cycle.    In addition, the Federal Reserve, in the event of crisis, would move in, as Professor Minsky says, "to flood the economy with reserves and to prevent a collapse of asset values."    After the New York stock market crash of October 1987, which swiftly spread to markets around the world, the central banks behaved as a close fraternity, and they are likely to do so in any future crisis. As the former Fed Chairman, Paul A. Volcker, put it in his 1990 Per Jacobson Lecture before the International Monetary Fund: "In a turbulent world, the importance of restoring a sense of stability is more clearly recognized."

headline: Airlines Curbing Passengers Who Skirt Rules to Cut Fare
abstract: Like thousands of savvy fliers, Ronald Gelfuso knows that in the topsy-turvy world of air fares a longer flight can be cheaper than a shorter one. The New York fashion executive regularly saved $500 round trip by buying a ticket to San Antonio when he was going only as far as the first stop on the route, Dallas.    But last month American Airlines stopped Mr. Gelfuso in his tracks. A ticket agent in New York, noticing that Mr. Gelfuso's bags were checked to Dallas, insisted that he buy a new ticket. A dispute ensued, and when the dust settled Mr. Gelfuso had missed his original flight and was forced to buy another ticket for $519. "I ran into a brick wall," he said.  Travel Agents Sued

headline: BRIEFS
