abstract: * Abbott Laboratories Inc., North Chicago, Ill., said its directors had authorized the repurchase of up to six million of its 436.9 million shares outstanding.      * Blockbuster Entertainment Corp., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., an operator of video rental stores, agreed to acquire Erol's Inc., a videocassette rental and sales concern, for roughly $40 million in cash, a note, shares of Blockbuster's common stock and debt assumption.      * General Cinema Inc., Chestnut Hill, Mass., a motion picture theater company, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 10 million of the company's common shares.      * Graphic Scanning Corp., Englewood, N.J., a telecommunications service company, said it was negotiating with a third party about the acquisition for cash of all of Graphic Scanning's shares.      * Integrated Resources Inc., an investment company, agreed to sell its subsidiaries' general partnership interests in four American Insured Mortgage Investors limited partnerships to AIM Acquisition Corp., a new company that includes Goldman, Sachs & Co. and Broad Inc. for about $32.5 million.      * Louisiana Land and Exploration Co., New Orleans, an oil and gas company, said it would spend $291 million on capital and exploration projects in 1991.      * Nestle S.A., Zurich, a food company, agreed to buy Drumstick Co., an ice cream company, from Alco Standard Corp. Terms were not disclosed.      * OIS Optical Imaging Systems Inc., signed a letter of intent with Guardian Industries Inc., Northville, Mich., and William Manning, Rochester, under which Guardian will invest $10.5 million for a 29 percent equity stake in OIS.      * PS Group Inc., San Diego, an aviation holding company, said it had amended its shareholder rights plan to permit Warren Buffett to buy up to 45 percent of its outstanding common shares. He now holds a 22.1 percent stake.      * Washington Water Power Co., Spokane, Wash., an electricity and gas company, said Alltel Corp., Hudson, Ohio, a telephone utility holding company, had formally accepted Washington Water's $85 million bid for all natural gas distributuion assets of CP National Corp., an Alltel unit.

headline: Dollar Rises On Soviet Turmoil
abstract: Last   Prior   Year       Week   Week   Ago               Japanese Yen   135.55   132.94   142.35       per Dollar       German Mark   1.5289   1.4815   1.7070       per Dollar       Canadian Dollar   1.1600   1.1582   1.1592       per U.S. Dollar       British Pound   1.8860   1.9375   1.6205       U.S. Dollar per British Pound       Gold   $381.25   $375.75   $413.75       Republic National Bank       Currency: Friday NY Close

headline: Liberian Rebel Faction Is Ousted From Capital
abstract: LEAD: The West African peacekeeping force in Liberia pushed Charles Taylor's rebels out of central Monrovia today in a drive to capture the capital's downtown airfield.

headline: Demystifying Stanford's Stats
abstract: To the Editor:   The excellent article, "Coaxing the Stanford Elephant to Dance," (Nov. 11), demonstrates the problems facing large academic medical centers throughout the country. Nevertheless, there is a major fallacy in the chart intending to compare charges at Stanford and two competing hospitals. Statistics represent variation -- the reported averages are not comparable unless the data distributions of charges are symmetrical.   Quantitative data have three main characteristics -- central tendency (the average), variability (the spread) and shape (the symmetry, or lack thereof). Your chart focused only on central tendency. Stanford's measure was the arithmetic mean -- the average cost of all operations for a given procedure. El Camino's measure was the midrange -- the average of the lowest and the highest cost out of all operations for a given procedure. Sequoia's measure was either the trimmed mean (an average of the midmost 50 percent of all charges for each operation) or the midhinge (the average of the most costly and least costly operations for a given procedure). It is impossible to tell from the chart's key.    As data distributions become more and more asymmetrical, the midrange and the mean become less and less useful because these measures are too highly influenced by extreme values (i.e., unusually high charges will pull the measures up while atypically low charges will pull the measures down). The measure used at Sequoia -- whether trimmed mean or midhinge -- is resistant to extreme values and would clearly be the preferred indicator of average charges if symmetry in the data distributions were lacking. Thus it may well be true that Stanford is the most expensive of the three hospitals with respect to the three procedures selected -- but one simply cannot tell from this chart. Other outcome measures for comparing the three hospitals, such as the proportions of indigent, Medicaid and Medicare patients as well as morbidity indexes to indicate the severity and complexity of illness would be needed to make Stanford's case. MARK L. BERENSON, Ph.D.  New York, Nov. 13  The writer is chairman of the Baruch-Mount Sinai M.B.A. Program in health-care administration.

headline: Postal Service Starts Campaign on 'L.A. Law'
abstract: The United States Postal Service will appeal to the sentiments of viewers of the NBC program "L.A. Law" tonight when it screens its new network campaign for the first time.    The spot, which uses the old adage about sleet and rain, intercuts images of loyal postal workers battleing bad weather with pictures of the main Post Office branch in New York City. The idea is to focus on the side of the building, where the famous postal poem is carved. It is questionable, however, whether the carved words are legible enough for the spot's intent.   The ad, created by Young & Rubicam, New York, also emphasizes the postal service's technology, and calls on people to help enhance service by using a complete address.    "The objective is to communicate that the postal service is doing everything it can to improve itself," said Rich Kahn, senior vice president and group director at Young & Rubicam.

headline: JAPANESE TO HEAD U.N. REFUGEE UNIT
abstract: A Japanese professor of international relations and expert on human rights was nominated today to take charge of the world's 15 million refugees, at a time when the relief agency she is to head faces a severe financial crisis.    The United Nations Secretary General named Sadako Ogata, who teaches at Sophia University in Tokyo, to be the next United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, replacing Thorvald Stoltenberg of Norway.

headline: Excerpts From Gorbachev's Speech Proposing a Revamped Government
abstract: Following are excerpts from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech today to the Supreme Soviet proposing a new structure for the Soviet Government, as translated by The Associated Press:

headline: First Chicago Stake By Crown Family
abstract: The family of the late billionare Henry Crown disclosed that it had acquired a 5.5 percent stake in the First Chicago Corporation, the commercial bank based in Chicago. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Crown family said the shares had been purchased for investment purposes.    A spokesman for First Chicago said the company welcomed the investment as a sign of confidence. The Crown family controls 3.64 million First Chicago shares. The shares are held by 65 family members and trusts. Henry Crown was the honorary chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation and owned the Empire State Building in the 1960's.

headline: To Many Britons, Major Is Unknown
abstract: If Government leaders around the world are not too sure who John Major, Britain's new Prime Minister, is, they shouldn't feel too bad. A lot of people in Lambeth, the working-class borough in south London where he grew up and began his political career, aren't too sure either.   "I didn't have a clue who he was until last week," when he stepped into the spotlight as a contender to succeed Margaret Thatcher," said Tony Kelly, a 33-year-old construction worker.

headline: Bonds Rally on Weak Output Data
abstract: The rally in the Government bond market continued yesterday, as traders pushed up prices of some Treasury securities as much as a point and long-term interest rates fell to their lowest levels since the Persian Gulf crisis began.   The catalyst behind yesterday's move was a Federal Reserve report that industrial output had dropped eight-tenths of a percent in October, the first decline since April.

headline: Coke's Net Up 9.1%; Sales Overseas Cited
abstract: LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink company, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose to a record $394.2 million, or 58 cents a share. The 9.1 percent rise slightly exceeded analysts' expectations.

headline: Survey Sees Recession
abstract: The majority of top economists in a monthly survey believe a recession will begin before the end of the year, but most predict it will be brief and relatively mild, a prominent economic newsletter reports.   The publication, Blue Chip Economic Indicators, said in its latest report that 80 percent of the 55 economists in its survey thought a downturn would start before the end of 1990. Another 5 percent said the slump would start in 1991.   "It now seems very likely that America's longest peacetime expansion is about to come to an end," wrote the Blue Chip editor, Robert J. Eggert of Eggert Economic Enterprises Inc. in Sedona, Ariz.   The Blue Chip survey found three-fourths of the respondents expected any downturn to last no more than two or three quarters. "An even larger majority -- 82 percent -- anticipate that the recession will be relatively mild," the newsletter said.   The survey participants represent many of the nation's top banks, brokerage companies, corporations, economic forecasting organizations and universities.

headline: The Executive Computer; An Incentive in Multimedia Software
abstract: After years of talk but little action, some of the nation's most influential personal computer companies finally agreed last week to adopt a set of common hardware and software standards for multimedia computers -- machines that can produce high-quality sound and animation as well as text and conventional graphics.   The agreement set a standard that is surprisingly modest for hardware performance. Indeed, the standards seem to have been selected to provide software companies with an incentive to develop programs that take advantage of Windows and the OS/2 operating system for such multimedia computers.

headline: MNC May Offer Stock to Sell Unit
abstract: MNC Financial Inc., a Maryland banking company that has been trying to sell its credit card business for more than six weeks, said it might sell the business through a public offering of stock in the unit. With $6.8 billion of credit card loans outstanding, MNC's credit card operation is the fourth largest in the country among commercial banks.   According to a document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, MNC is proposing to sell 45 million shares of the MBNA Corporation, which would own the credit card business. The sale would be handled by underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. At a public price that could be as high as $25 a share but might be changed depending on market conditions, the sale could raise $8.5 billion.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    Many U.S. companies are laying off workers now, rather than waiting to be hit by hard times as they have in the past. Some economists warn that this outburst of corporate preventive medicine increases the odds of a steep recession. Since June, the number of people laid off in the United States has increased sharply, reaching the levels of the early months of the 1981-82 recession.  [ Page A1. ]   The Federal Reserve will probably respond to the new budget by reducing short-term interest rates, but credit market analysts say neither Congress nor the Bush Administration should expect a substantial reduction.  [ D1. ]   Congress has approved a three-way attack on taxes. The intent is to get that money from the upper class and upper-middle class through higher taxes for Medicare, a variety of income tax changes and additional excise taxes.  [ D1. ]   Washington is losing some of its enthusiasm for liberalizing its trade policies. The reason is political: some American industries are unhappy about giving up protection.  [ D1. ]   Why won't Michael Milken testify? That question resounded throughout the former financier's presentencing hearing, in which the prosecution and defense both indicated last week that they had called all of their witnesses.  [ D2. ]   Orders for U.S.-made machine tools dipped 4.6 percent in September, rate, according to a report to be released today.  [ D7. ]  Companies    Merrill Lynch is expected to announce a reorganization as soon as today that dissolves the firm's separate consumer and capital markets groups. The reorganization is expected to result in hundreds of layoffs.  [ D1. ]   Government and corporate documents appear to support a whistleblower's accusations that Hughes Aircraft overcharged the Pentagon on programs to develop in-flight radar systems.  [ D2. ]   The Daily News is encountering serious problems as its management tries to produce and distribute the New York paper three days into a strike.  [ B4. ]  The Media Business    Simon & Schuster has been a model of relative stability amid the recent turmoil in publishing. That low-profile approach seems to have paid off: with sales of $1.3 billion last year, six times those of 1983, Simon & Schuster is the largest U.S. publisher.  [ D1. ]   Newsstands are disappearing in many cities as single-copy magazine sales decline. But a few well-stocked newsstands are bucking the trend.  [ D8. ]   Publishers are taking a serious look at increasing book prices to bring their revenues in line with rising costs. Publishing.  [ D8. ]   The People's Weekly World, a U.S. paper, is trying to revive its sagging Communist fortunes with some decidedly capitalist initiatives: aggressive marketing and prudent cost-cutting.  [ D8. ]   J. Walter Thompson has created a commercial version of the hit television show "America's Funniest Home Videos" for Toys "R" Us. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D9. ]  International    The new leaders of Jaguar Cars are hoping to turn the antiquated British company into one of the world's biggest, most efficient makers of luxury cars.  [ D1. ]   Poland has yet to turn a single large state-owned enterprise into a private company, even though it is 10 months into a crash economic program.  [ D4. ]  Today's Columns    The Treasury Department is finally moving towards adopting regulations governing the electronic transfers of money. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law.  [ D2. ]   The cellular phone market is beginning to resemble the real estate market. Both are depressed. Market Place.  [ D6. ]

headline: Iraq Says It Is Still Seeking 'Deep Dialogue' With U.S.
abstract: Iraq's Minister of Information said tonight that his country still wanted a "deep dialogue" with the United States to solve the Persian Gulf crisis, despite differences over the dates for direct talks in Washington and Baghdad.   The minister, Latif Nassif al-Jassem, also said the Bush Administration must allow President Saddam Hussein to chose the date for high-level talks in Baghdad with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, while the White House could set the date for the meeting in Washington with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz.

headline: Salvador Aide Denies Ouster of Prosecutors
abstract: A spokesman for the Attorney General today denied a report that the two principal prosecutors in the case against eight military men charged in the slaying of six Jesuit priests had been dismissed.    The spokesman, Eduardo Pineda, chief of the Attorney General's human rights unit, said the two prosecutors remained on the case and that his office was committed to bringing the defendants to justice.    But a local newspaper, El Mundo, had quoted the two prosecutors, Edward Sidney Blanco Reyes and Alvaro Henry Campos Solorzano, as saying they had been dismissed by the Attorney General, Roberto Antonio Mendoza Jerez.  The two men, could not be reached for comment. In the past, they have complained about interference in the case by superiors.     The six priests, their housekeeper and her daughter were slain here in November 1989 at a time when the Salvadoran Army was battling a rebel offensive in the capital.    Eight military men were eventually arrested.  But human rights monitors now say they doubt that there will ever be a trial.

headline: Kahane's Followers in Israel Bury Him and Vent Anger
abstract: As mourners wept or angrily shouted "Death to the Arabs!" and masses of policemen looked on, Rabbi Meir Kahane's coffin was carried today from the yeshiva he founded in an impoverished neighborhood to a hilltop cemetery on the edge of Jerusalem.   Despite intense security, a mile before reaching the graveyard about 100 mourners beat and stabbed four Palestinians, threw rocks at journalists and Arabs' cars, smashed store windows and tried to storm the Israeli television studios. Mounted policemen charged the crowd and two policemen were injured in the melee. The four Palestinians were hospitalized, and the police said 13 mourners were arrested.

headline: Mixed Views On NEC Computer
abstract: The performance of the NEC Corporation's newest SX-3 supercomputer, far outstrips its nearest American and Japanese competitors for speeds attained by a single processor system, according to a leading American computer expert.   But other American experts said yesterday that they were skeptical about the potential of the new machine and that the Japanese still trailed American supercomputer makers significantly in harnessing many processors in parallel to perform dramatically faster.

headline: Market Place; Kay Deal Hurts Shares of Ratners
abstract: GERALD RATNER has wrought a revolution in the British retail jewelry market, and now he is trying to prosper in the American market with a company that was on the verge of financial failure before he took it over. Share buyers in both London and New York are dubious.   Ratners Group, by far the largest jewelry retailer in Britain, has completed the acquisition of Kay Jewelers Inc., this country's second-largest chain of jewelry stores after the Zale Corporation.    But Kay was encountering growing financial problems before the acquisition. To succeed, Ratners must accomplish the tricky goals of sharply raising Kay's profit margins and sales while toughening its credit terms.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Lifetime Television, a venture of Hearst Corp., ABC and Viacom Inc., New York, appointed Kristin Dean FitzGerald senior vice president in charge of sales. * Moore Handley Inc., Birmingham, Ala., a maker of industrial supplies, named Gordon K. Johnston vice president of merchandising. James A. Tucker was named vice president, overseeing major and corporate accounts. * Paramount Communications Inc., New York, appointed Alan Cole-Ford vice president of corporate development. * RJR Nabisco Inc., New York, named Robert S. Roath vice president and corporate controller. * Sonoco Products Co., Hartsville, S.C., producers of cones and containers, appointed Alexander Watson senior vice president. * TRW Space and Technology Group, Redondo Beach, Calif., a unit of TRW Inc., Cleveland, appointed Dr. George Gleghorn vice president and chief engineer. * U S West Inc., Englewood, Colo., named Tracie A. Muesing vice president of quality.

headline: Mortgage Rates Dip
abstract: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.13 percent this week, down from 10.17 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.15 percent, down from 8.17 percent last week.

headline: Safeway Net Rises Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Safeway Inc., the Oakland, Calif., supermarket chain, today reported strong gains in earnings despite only moderate growth in sales in its third quarter.

headline: MAI Systems' Chief Resigns
abstract: The MAI Systems Corporation, the computer company controlled by the investor Bennett S. LeBow, said today that William Weksel, the chairman and chief executive, has resigned "to pursue other business interests." Mr LeBow will replace Mr. Weksel as chairman and chief executive.    Mr. Weksel, a longtime busness partner of Mr. LeBow, resigned in July as chairman of the tobacco maker Liggett Group Inc., another venture controlled by Mr. LeBow. Liggett is now called Brooke Group Ltd.    Bert Weidberg, MAI's general counsel, declined to comment on the circumstances of the resignation and referred questions to Mr. LeBow and Mr. Weksel at their Brooke office in New York. Calls there were not answered.

headline: Xerox Profit Down 14.8%
abstract: The Xerox Corporation today reported a 14.8 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, partly because of a weak performance by the company's insurance and financial services businesses.   For the period that ended on Sept. 30, profits totaled $132 million, or $1.16 a share, on revenue of $4.5 billion. That compared with earnings of $155 million, or $1.41 a share, on revenue of $4.4 billion in the 1989 period.   Income from continuing operations in Xerox's insurance and other financial services fell 98 percent, to $1 million, from $50 million in the 1989 quarter. Pretax capital gains totaled $4 million in the period, compared with $207 million a year earlier.    Income at Crum & Forster's property and casualty and life insurance operations dropped 64.5 percent, to $27 million, in the third quarter from $76 million a year ago.    Xerox's stock slipped by 12 1/2 cents today, to $30.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: 7 Reported Killed in India in Hindu-Muslim Strife
abstract: New Hindu-Muslim fighting left at least seven people dead in the capital Wednesday night, as Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar prepared for a parliamentary vote of confidence in his five-day-old minority Government Friday.    Mr. Shekhar started to confront the problem of violence that has troubled his predecessors, as a curfew was ordered today in parts of the crowded old city of Delhi after the riots between a Muslim-Sikh alliance and Hindus. Reports of arson and other attacks, including rocks being hurled at buses,continued today.

headline: Tech Notes;   Fitting a PC's Circuitry on One Thumbnail-Sized Chip
abstract: LEAD: When the International Business Machines Corporation introduced its PC/AT personal computer in 1983 - incorporating Intel's powerful new 80286 computer chip - the machine was the sensation of the rapidly growing desktop computer business. The AT was expensive and powerful, but it was also bulky. The 80286 chip, which functions as the computer's brain, resided on one large circuit board about the size of a dinner plate.

headline: A Restraint on Bush
abstract: The failure of the United States and the Soviet Union to agree on if and when to use military force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait has undercut the Bush Administration's Persian Gulf strategy, at least temporarily,     When President Bush announced his decision two weeks ago to double the number of American troops in the Persian Gulf, he expected that it would be quickly followed by a United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing the use of military means to drive Iraq out of Kuwait if sanctions proved ineffective.

headline: Aggressive Campaign For the Amex
abstract: RESPONDING to a slowdown in business and increasing competition from rival markets, the American Stock Exchange will soon begin an aggressive $1 million print campaign boasting about itself and belittling its much bigger competitor, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs the Nasdaq over-the-counter market.   With the ads, the American Exchange will join an advertising battle that has been raging between Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange for listings of publicly traded companies. Companies that in the past might have gone from the over-the-counter market to the Amex are now going directly to the Big Board, which has gained a number of listings. The Amex hopes to start gaining listings, as well as win investor favor in its new campaign.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9.5-10   9.5-10   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   6.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.25   6.25   9.50        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.47   6.54   7.70        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.58   6.63   7.59        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.03   8.09   7.97        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Legislating Competence
abstract: To the Editor:   After reading "The Case for a New Civil Rights Bill" (Nov. 11), regarding the veto of the recent civil rights legislation, the same question kept running through my mind: At what point in terms of time and numbers would minority members of corporations feel they would be able to trust white managers? Could a new series of new civil right bills assure that at some future date all managers of corporations will be black or women?   If that were the case, would the new managers have arrived via legislation or talent? If by legislation, I think we might slip faster in world competitiveness than this country is now doing. MARIO A. DeMATTEO  Vero Beach, Fla., Nov. 21

headline: Some Debt of CBS Put Under Review
abstract: The quality ratings on about $1.5 billion of debt of CBS Inc. were put under review yesterday for possible downgrading by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.   The ratings agencies cited as among the reasons for the review a plan announced Wednesday by CBS to spend about $2 billion to repurchase about 44 percent of its common stock; the company's recently reported lower earnings, and the opinon of analysts that CBS profits would continue to be weak.   Standard & Poor's mentioned CBS's plan to reduce fourth-quarter earnings by $115 million because of losses in the $1.06 billion contract to televise Major League Baseball.    Moody's said it was concerned that the large amount being spent to buy back stock in a non-income-producing transaction would weaken bondholders' protection.   Moody's now has the senior debt rated at A-3, while Standard & Poor's rates it A+.

headline: U.S. Troops and Saudis: A Silent Clash of Cultures
abstract: As the military deployment here lengthens and President Bush arrives to celebrate Thanksgiving, the cultural gap dividing American troops from their Saudi hosts appears to be widening, leaving each staring at the other across a chasm neither can easily bridge.    "The other day, I realized that none of us has gone into the desert and said thank you to the American soldiers for coming here to save us," a Saudi Government official said.

headline: U.S.-Pakistan Bone of Contention: Narcotics
abstract: With talks just beginning between the United States and Pakistan over a nuclear program that has led to a suspension of American aid to this country, officials of both nations are already engrossed in the next explosive policy issue: narcotics.   The United States Congress is demanding that Pakistan be able to demonstrate by March 1 that it is acting to curtail the cultivation of opium poppies and the production of heroin in up to 100 laboratories in the mountainous areas near the frontier with Afghanistan. Inability to provide convincing evidence of progress against narcotics production and trafficking would create another bar to American aid.

headline: Air France to Buy 2 French Airlines
abstract: The European Community's competition commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, cleared the takeover of two French airlines by Air France after negotiating a deal to increase industry competition in France. The settlement to allow Air France's purchase of UTA and Air Inter, uniting France's biggest airlines, would end months of bitter legal wrangling between the commission, Air France, and the French Government.   The accord will guarantee rivals of state-controlled Air France takeoff and landing slots on key domestic and international routes. The European Community's Executive Commission has the power to block mergers if it determines that the deals would endanger competition in the 12-nation trade bloc.

headline: Ames to Reduce Corporate Staff
abstract: LEAD: Ames Department Stores Inc., the ailing discount chain that filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year, said it would lay off 250 corporate employees and close offices in West Hartford and Syracuse. The company said it had eliminated 200 corporate positions through attrition over the last four months.

headline: As Korean Leaders Meet, North Seems Increasingly Isolated
abstract: LEAD: Six weeks after the start of a new high-level discussion between North and South Korea, a senior South Korean delegation traveled to the North this morning amid signs that Seoul was prepared to offer some limited new concessions to its longtime Communist enemy.

headline: Pentagon Seeks to Diminish Effects of Officer's Remarks
abstract: The Pentagon sought today to limit the political damage caused by a senior American commander who said on Wednesday that the United States would not be ready to fight Iraq by Jan. 15, the deadline the United Nations has set for Baghdad to withdraw its forces from Kuwait.   The remarks by the officer, Lieut. Gen. Calvin A. H. Waller, deputy commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, drew sharp criticism from Administration officials in Washington who said the comments undercut their gulf strategy to persuade President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to pull out peacefully or face imminent attack.

headline: European Push by Haagen-Dazs
abstract: Now that the Haagen-Dazs Company has won over many American taste buds, it is taking on the land of napoleons, creme caramels and eclairs.   As part of a $50 million campaign to expand European sales, Haagen-Dazs, which is based in Teaneck, N.J., opened four slick shops in fashionable districts of Paris last summer and is now beginning large-scale distribution in French supermarkets.

headline: Bank Yields Are Lower For 3d Week
abstract: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts for the week ended yesterday were lower for the third consecutive week.    The lower short-term interest rates make it more likely that depositors will be attracted toward the longer maturity certificates of deposit, which are offering higher yields. Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, expects the continuing decline in yields to be slow. "The weakening economy has resulted in less borrowing, and the banks are not under any pressure to replenish the cash by offering higher rates," he said. "Look for the decline in bank rates to extend into 1991."

headline: 88 U.S. Citizens Held as 'Shields'
abstract: About 88 Americans are still being held as so-called "human shields" at strategic sites in Iraq after the release of 15 others over the weekend, the State Department says.   The 88 are among about 1,000 Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, the department said.   The Americans include staff members at the United States embassies in Baghdad and Kuwait, people in hiding and those who are being held at the Iraqi military and industrial installations to deter a military attack.   The 15 Americans freed over the weekend left Iraq with Muhammed Ali, the former boxing champion, who had flown there to seek their release.   Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said Monday that 10 of the 15 Americans who flew out of Baghdad on Saturday had special medical problems.

headline: Jordan King to Meet With Iraqi
abstract: LEAD: King Hussein said today that he would meet here on Saturday with Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, to discuss the latest peace efforts in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Patents;   New Methods To Improve Hair Care
abstract: LEAD: The quest for better beauty products has always produced a steady stream of new chemicals and devices as interest regularly shifts with the winds of fashion and changing circumstances. In the last few weeks, inventors have patented products intended to help cope with acid rain, air pollution and the growing pressures on women with fast-moving careers.

headline: TV Rerun Ownership In Review
abstract: LEAD: The Government is moving toward loosening, and perhaps scrapping, longstanding rules that limit ownership by the three major television networks of programs they broadcast.

headline: Gulf Quiet, Oil Falls by $1.74 a Barrel
abstract: LEAD: The oil market, which alternates between believing that no news is good news and fearing that silence is ominous, took the former tack yesterday, and oil fell nearly $2 a barrel on world markets.

headline: Douglas Aircraft Cutting 1,200 Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The Douglas Aircraft Company will lay off 1,200 workers at its Long Beach and Torrance, Calif., operations this year. An executive of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation unit said the company also wants to cut its work force by an additional 1,500 workers in 1991.

headline: Bond Prices Slip as Books Are Closed
abstract: A spurt of selling pushed down prices of Treasury securities yesterday, as dealers made final bookkeeping preparations for the end of 1990.    The decline came even though the economic data released yesterday were generally favorable for the fixed-income market. The numbers included a report that the Government's index of leading economic indicators fell by 1.2 percent in November, the fifth straight month that the forecasting gauge has shown a decline.

headline: War Effect On Energy Minimized
abstract: Bush Administration officials contend that if war erupted in the Persian Gulf, it would pose few disruptions to energy supplies, even though the region holds two-thirds of the world's oil.   Government and industry planners say the risk of damage to oilfields there is only minimal. They say that even some loss of output from Saudi Arabia could be sustained with little effect on consumers or the world economy.   By drawing upon strategic and commercial stockpiles and buying oil already aboard tankers and awaiting customers, these analysts say, it should be possible to avoid any oil shortage, as well as to keep prices from rising, as they did after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August.

headline: G.M. Plans To Cut Cost Of Saturn
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation announced an ''aggressive pricing and warranty'' strategy today for its Saturn line of compact cars, which will be shown publicly for the first time next week.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    MARKETS       Oil prices soared to record levels, closing for the first time above $40 a barrel on renewed fears of war. [Page A1.]      Stocks fell sharply, with the Dow plunging 78.22, to 2,445.54. It was the sharpest decline in more than two months. [D1.]      Prices of Treasury securities plummeted.

headline: People
abstract: * Barry R. Linsky has joined the Interpublic Group of Companies, New York, as senior vice president of plannning and business development, replacing Arthur E. Wilen, who is retiring. * Nancy Axthelm has been promoted to senior vice president and deputy director of broadcast production at Grey Advertising, New York. * Lynn Guthrie Heiler has been promoted to associate publisher of The New Yorker magazine. Lance J. O. Ford was named advertising director. * Ralph John Cuomo was named controller ot the Time Inc. Magazine Co., New York.

headline: Pathe and MGM Delay Deal Again
abstract: The MGM/UA Communications Corporation and the Pathe Communications Corporation said today that they had again delayed the closing of Pathe's $1.3 billion deal to acquire MGM.   The companies said in a statement that the closing would be delayed until Tuesday "to complete the transfer of funds necessary to consummate the merger and to permit finalization of the closing documentation."   The companies had previously said the deal would close today, after extending the initial deadline from last Tuesday.   Both companies have said in recent days that there are no big roadblocks to completing the deal, which has been plagued for months by Pathe's inability to raise all the necessary financing.Pathe, which is controlled by Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian investor, said Monday that all the financing was in place.   Pathe has announced that it is raising $325 million by selling television and home video rights to MGM and United Artists movies, and that it has raised an additional $600 million from foreign affiliates of Pathe. Pathe said the remaining money would come from a series of as-yet-unannounced deals involving MGM/ UA's assets, but it did not give details of those arrangements.   "We are confident the funds will be in place and the merger will close by Tuesday," said Craig Parsons, a spokesman for Pathe. Mary Hardy, a spokeswoman for MGM/UA, did not return a phone call.

headline: Dairy Queen Bracing for a Battle
abstract: Dairy Queen, whose Dillybar and Peanut Buster Parfait frozen desserts and Brazier Burgers have become staples of small-town America, is about to learn if it can withstand an onslaught from the Big Mac.    For years, Dairy Queen restaurants have prospered by operating in small towns, often ignored by the giants of fast food -- McDonald's, Burger King and Wendy's. In fact, even though many of its outlets offer only desserts, no sandwiches or burgers, the Dairy Queen chain has been among the most successful in the fast-food industry, producing double-digit sales and profit gains year after year. This has held true even in the last 12 months, when overall fast-food results have slumped.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Fujisankei Communications International Inc., New York, to Deutsch, New York for the Ultima Exodus and Ultima Quest video games accounts. The total budget is $2.5 million.

headline: Capital Cities/ABC Net Off; Weak Ad Market Blamed
abstract: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. reported lower earnings for the third quarter yesterday, blaming a weakened advertising market and losses on sports programming.   The company also predicted that it would report a loss in the fourth quarter because demand for television commercial time by advertisers has declined further since Labor Day.

headline: USF&G's Chairman Had Same Job at Heller
abstract: Norman P. Blake Jr. was appointed chairman and chief executive yesterday by the USF&G Corporation, the troubled insurance and financial services company.   Mr. Blake, 49 years old, has been chairman since 1984 of the Heller International Corporation, a Chicago-based financial unit of the Fuji Bank Ltd., of Tokyo. He succeeds Jack Moseley, 59, who retired after 37 years with USF&G.

headline: Farm Credit Banks
abstract: The Federal Farm Credit Banks yesterday priced $100 million notes due Dec. 27, 1993, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. Underwriters said the noncallable issue had a 7 3/8 percent coupon and was priced at 99.801, to yield 7.45 percent, or about 11 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Wall Street Job Cuts Spread As 2 Firms Disclose Layoffs
abstract: Job cutbacks continued to spread on Wall Street yesterday. Prudential-Bache Securities said it was abandoning the risk-arbitrage business for its own account, and the First Boston Corporation dismissed about 9 percent of its fixed-income operation.    The moves were further signs of the weakness affecting many top Wall Street firms. Faced with a dearth of deals and a dwindling trading volume, firms have been cutting jobs and getting out of business areas at a rapid clip.

headline: Hawaiian Group May Buy Ameron
abstract: A Hawaiian investment group said it was considering the purchase of Ameron Inc., a Monterey Park, Calif., construction products manufacturer. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the investment group said that it had talked with third parties about financing an acquisition but that no agreements had been reached.    The investment group already controls 8.5 percent of Ameron's 3.7 million shares outstanding. The group is led by two Hawaiian businessmen, Jay H. Shidler and James C. Reynolds. Ameron's stock rose 25 cents today, to $35.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Chemical Leads Bank Group Aiding Hostile A.T.&T. Bid
abstract: The gritty details of a takeover battle began to unfold yesterday after A.T.& T. began its $6.12 billion hostile bid for the NCR Corporation.   In its formal tender offer, filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said Chemical Bank would lead a syndicate trying to raise $6 billion to finance the acquisition of the computer maker. Chemical said it would provide $600 million of that amount.

headline: Britain's Foreign Secretary Urges Israel to Make Peace
abstract: LEAD: The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, urged Israel today to negotiate a Middle East peace should Iraq withdraw from Kuwait.

headline: Borrowing Growth Dips
abstract: LEAD: Americans cut the growth of their installment credit in half in August, the Government said today.

headline: Matsushita Shifts Stance On MCA
abstract: Attempting to quell political concerns surrounding its acquisition of MCA Inc., one of the largest entertainment companies in the United States, the president of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said this morning that the giant consumer electronics manufacturer "has no intention of becoming involved in decisions regarding the subject or content of creative products at MCA."    The statement by Akio Tanii appears to alter significantly what he told reporters at a news conference in Osaka on Monday night, minutes after Matsushita signed a $6.13 billion agreement to acquire MCA.

headline: Thousands Rally in Prague to Denounce Communists
abstract: LEAD: Tens of thousands of demonstrators jammed the Old Town Square here today to denounce the Communist Party, which has begun to reassert itself politically for the first time in a year.

headline: Bush Concerned Over Shevardnadze
abstract: President Bush said today that he was concerned about Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's warnings of the threat of dictatorship in the Soviet Union and said he hoped that any political change in the Kremlin would be peaceful.   In his first comment on Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation, Mr. Bush tried to make the best of the upheaval in Moscow, saying that "life goes on" and that he expected that Soviet foreign policy would not change, especially in the Persian Gulf.

headline: As Folksy Replaces Trendy, Wigwag Magazine Thrives
abstract: TRENDY, caustic magazines like Spy and Details that chronicle and criticize the lives of powerful, or often merely glamorous, people were the rage in the late 1980's -- but now it is hip to be square.   Media analysts say one of the few successful new magazines this year is Wigwag, a folksy publication that takes a serious look at politics, issues and life in America.

headline: Wave of Gloom Over War Peril Covers Baghdad
abstract: A wave of national gloom is settling over the Iraqi capital at the prospect that this nation may be sliding toward a destructive military confrontation with the United States and its allies.    With diplomacy deadlocked, food prices soaring under the pressure of United Nations trade sanctions, medicines in short supply and a whole generation of young men going back into uniform after eight years of brutal combat against Iran, many of those Iraqis who answered a Westerner's questions, in more than a week of interviews, said they were living day to day, hoarding money and searching for mental distraction from the harsh realities of life.

headline: Swissair Alliance
abstract: Swissair and Singapore Airlines will buy equity stakes in each other starting next June as part of a program to expand their existing links, the Swiss carrier said. The two airlines established an alliance last December that allows cross-holdings of up to 5 percent by each carrier. Swissair, Switzerland's shareholder-owned national airline, will buy an initial 0.62 percent stake in Singapore Airlines, while Singapore will obtain a 2.77 percent holding in Swissair.

headline: U.S.-Italian Airline Pact
abstract: LEAD: After 20 years of negotiations, Italy and the United States signed a memorandum last week that would allow Italy's flagship airline to land in additional American cities. The Government-owned Alitalia airline will offer year-round service to Boston, Miami, Chicago, Washington and Philadelphia with the option to add four destinations soon.

headline: Greeks Squabbling Over U.S. Cold War Plan
abstract: Greece's political parties have been dredging up the cold war again this week, with leftists protesting over the discovered existence of "Red Sheepskin," a American-Greek contingency plan aimed at resisting Warsaw Pact occupation forces.   Despite the conservative Government's assurances to the contrary, the left is describing the plan as an American intelligence guise for the domestic subversion of Greece and the supression of leftists.

headline: Greece Is Warning Albania On Killing of 2 Ethnic Greeks
abstract: LEAD: Greece's Government today strongly protested an incident in which two Albanians of Greek origin were said to have been shot while trying to escape Albania and their bodies put on public display.

headline: Business Diary/December 23-28
abstract: THE ECONOMY Singing the Ever-Deepening Recession Blues Economists and Government officials who earlier said they expected light showers stepped outside last week and got drenched.  Many said that the most recent figures pointed to a recession deeper and more prolonged than they had expected. New factory orders for durable goods in November fell 10.5 percent, matching January's record decline. These include the orders for aircraft, automobiles, machinery, metals and computers that nourish the economy for months, or sometimes years. A broader forward-looking index, the leading economic indicators, dropped for the fifth straight month in November, falling 1.2 percent; three straight declines are usually enough to signal a recession. The National Bureau of Economic Research, the official arbiter of business cycles, confirmed that a recession probably began between June and September. Economists are watching the Middle East, the banks and consumers to see how severe the slump will be. High consumer debt and low confidence are likely to aggravate the slowdown, many say. "If Sam Kahan doesn't know whether he's going to have a job in 1991, he's going to tell the kids 'No more Nintendo games,' " Mr. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities, said. Middle East peace would give consumers heart, he said, adding that his children remain optimistic that at least one economist will do all right. "They figure dad is always good for another buck," he said.  More Taxes on the Toast  The party's over on Dec. 31 as far as the Government and the liquor stores are concerned. A one-time tax, expected to generate $300 million, is being imposed on wholesale and retail liquor inventories held on that date. Higher excise taxes take effect with the New Year. The excise taxes should add only pennies to the price of a bottle or can of beer, wine or spirits; the tax on a bottle of 80-proof whiskey goes from $1.98 to $2.14. But just as every tremor in the Middle East seems to produce an earthquake at the local filling station, the liquor tax hikes might be amplified and redoubled. Many big American brewers and French and Italian winemakers are seizing the chance to raise prices. Wholesalers and retailers will then add their own markups. Some merchants say a $2 tax increase per case could mean $10 more in the store. Less Action At the Stores  For the nation's retailers, it was almost as if the doldrums and discounts of July had arrived in December. A chronically optimistic bunch, they were nevertheless frankly downcast about this year's Christmas results -- the worst season in years, they said. Some retailers reported last week that sales had dropped from the year before; factoring in inflation, most appeared to have suffered real declines. Shoppers neglected to swarm into the stores at the last minute, as they had done in previous years. The stores usually earn about half their annual profits between Thanksgiving and Christmas. Analysts say that price-cutting, continuing slack sales and weak balance sheets might force more chains into bankruptcy court. A few privileged retailers did report higher sales from customers who were rushing to beat the new 10 percent Federal luxury tax. That levy takes effect on New Year's Day, making very expensive cars, boats, jewelry, furs and private planes that much more difficult to afford. Trouble in the California Freeze  When the parade floats for the Tournament of Roses can't get enough flowers, California must really be in trouble. The state's worst winter freeze in more than half a century has wilted the flower crop and also promised to raise fruit and vegetable prices around the nation. A box of California navel oranges at local produce markets shot up to $22 last week from $12 the week before. Considerably higher prices are likely to spread toward the East over the coming days and weeks. COMPANIES   Drexel Still Pays  The patient might be in a terminal coma, at best a vegetative state, but the continuing treatment remains excruciatingly expensive. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection May 29, but it is still paying two officers $1.45 million a year each, and $21.1 million to the 73 officers still on the payroll. Frederick H. Joseph, the firm's former chief executive and now vice chairman, has to make do with $450,000. Drexel executives speak of the need to pay competitive rates to keep talented people with the firm; creditors say Drexel is depleting its estate with no chance of being revived. Icahn Moves In on Pan Am  The letters and news leaks and telephone calls flew thicker than the Northeast's snow between Carl C. Icahn and Pan Am last week.  Mr. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines, added more tangles and twists to his offer to buy Pan American World Airways. First, he sent a tough letter warning Thomas G. Plaskett, the Pan Am chairman, not to sell his Northeast shuttle. Then, through an anonymous but talkative aide, he demanded Mr. Plaskett's ouster. Mr. Icahn, who proposed buying Pan Am for $375 million in mid-December, is expected to make a formal offer in the next several days. Pan Am is desperately searching for help as the slow winter season arrives and its cash supplies dwindle. Japan's Protective Instincts  Maybe, as the United States Treasury Department insists, the Japanese Government really does give unfair breaks to domestic banks and brokerages. Japan's Finance Ministry has quietly begun investigating whether Japanese investment firms pressured two Japanese companies into dropping their deal for Salomon Brothers to issue bonds. A leading executive at Nomura Securities, Japan's largest broker, compared Salomon's entry to "exporting AIDS from Wall Street." INTERNATIONAL   Russia's Latest Split  Gorbachev is veering to the right, Yeltsin is staying on the left and a chasm opened last week in the middle. The Russian republic's Parliament, urged on by its President, Boris N. Yeltsin, voted Wednesday night to reduce its contribution to the central Soviet budget by more than 90 percent. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told his own legislature that the confrontation threatens economic collapse. "This would mean the breakup not only of the economy, but of the Soviet Union," he said. Meanwhile, Mr. Gorbachev won the lawmakers' approval of Gennadi I. Yanayev as Vice President only after they initially turned the nomination down. Michael Mandelbaum, director of the Project on East-West relations for the Council on Foreign Relations, called the split inevitable once the republic adopted a free-market plan that Mr. Gorbachev spurned. "There is no way to have serious economic reform in the Russian republic without a constitutional confrontation," Dr. Mandelbaum said. " What they are saying is, 'We the Russian people are not going to let this corrupt machine take our money anymore.' " Vineyards Safe and Sound  As 1990 ends, the French village of Chateauneuf-du-Pape can raise a glass of its earthy red wine to one of the most successful examples of government regulation to encourage commerce. In 1954, the village council passed a law forbidding flying saucers -- flying cigars in French parlance -- from landing, fearing they would crush precious grapes. Any that did arrive were to be immediately impounded. Again this year, no saucers or cigars touched down in Chateauneuf-du-Pape, and the vineyards were safe. No word on whether, come 1992, saucers from within the European Community will be allowed in.

headline: London Betting on Itself And on Canary Wharf
abstract: When Olympia & York Developments Ltd. decided in 1987 to undertake Canary Wharf, the biggest real estate development project in Europe, Paul Reichmann, the president of the family-owned company, said he was prepared to live through at least two downturns in the real estate market here.   The Toronto-based developer, which is staking nearly $:4 billion ($7.86 billion) on Canary Wharf, is now going through the first slump -- and without too much difficulty considering that London is in the grips of the worst real estate downturn since the mid-1970's.

headline: UAL Deal For Routes To London
abstract: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire one of the most prized assets in the airline industry, the routes of Pan American World Airways between five cities in the United States and London.   The $400 million acquisition pact was a coup for Stephen M. Wolf, chairman of UAL. Indeed, the all-cash transaction could give United a substantial lead over its competitors, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines, in the race to Europe. At the same time it strips Pan Am of the core of its European route system.

headline: Foreign Leaders Say They Hope Iraqi Gesture Will Lead to a Pullout From Kuwait
abstract: Governments around the world expressed hope today that President Saddam Hussein's plan to release all foreign hostages by year's end could be the first step toward a peaceful withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait.   The British Prime Minister, John Major, said confirmation that the hostages were being released would be "wonderful news." More than 1,100 Britons are in Iraq.

headline: PRETORIA PONDERS U.S. CONSTITUTION
abstract: LEAD: The American Constitution is being examined by the Government of President F. W. de Klerk as a possible model to carry South Africa beyond the end of apartheid.

headline: For War of the Re-Runs: Lights, Camera, Action!
abstract: It was a day of soaring rhetoric, sarcastic barbs and occasionally bizarre imagery, as top Hollywood executives squared off against the nation's television networks in the fiercest regulatory battle now confronting the entertainment industry.    At issue, in a packed hearing at the Federal Communications Commission, was the seemingly technical question of whether to repeal rules that now block the networks from buying re-run rights to the shows they broadcast. But to hear the arguments, it was a battle over nothing less than the future of television or even the soul of creative freedom.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Del Monte Tropical Fruit Co., Coral Gables, Fla., to Harris & Drury, Fort Lauderdale, for its $2 million account.

headline: Professors With Influence Far Beyond Their Schools
abstract: LEAD:    Harry M. Markowitz    City University of New York

headline: On the Danube, Unbuilt Dams but Pent-Up Anger
abstract: Last year, with the fall of Communism, the mammoth Gabcikovo-Nagymaros hydroelectric dam on the Danube River seemed doomed.    Prompted by nationwide protests, Hungary struck the first blow in October 1989 with a unilateral decision to stop work at Nagymaros, one of the project's two main sites.

headline: Lehman Brothers Said To Weigh Partner Plan
abstract: Senior executives of Lehman Brothers plan to change their compensation system in a way that would make the subsidiary of the American Express Company resemble a partnership, Wall Street executives said yesterday.   The move would be one of several that have been taken over the last six months to re-create the culture of the old Lehman Brothers firm, an institution that has become something of legend on Wall Street.

headline: Cuba Flirts With Capitalism to Stave Off Collapse
abstract: Even as a severe oil shortage brings oxen back to agriculture and darkens many office buildings by midafternoon, the Cuban Government is forging ahead with a crash effort to create world-class industries in tourism and biotechnology.   With trade and aid from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union quickly drying up, Cuban leaders say the country has frozen social investments and is concentrating on these two industries in the hope that they can quickly generate enough income to stave off economic collapse.

headline: Airbus May Develop Jet
abstract: Airbus Industrie said Friday that it might develop a large commercial jet to compete with the Boeing Company in the lucrative United States market. The Airbus plane, tentatively dubbed the A350, would be able to carry up to 700 passengers with a range of at least 7,000 miles. It would be intended to compete with Boeing's 747, which has given the Seattle-based plane maker a monopoly in the high-capacity commercial jet market since it was first put into service 20 years ago.

headline: NCR Seeks Senator's Help To Fend Off A.T.&T.'s Bid
abstract: NCR took its case for independence to Washington yesterday, but Wall Street professionals said such efforts would be unlikely to help it ward off A.T.& T.   A delegation from the NCR Corporation met with staff members of Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Subcommitte on Monopolies and Business Rights. The Senator has already said the $6 billion offer by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to buy the computer maker does not appear to violate antitrust law. Still, such meetings could put public pressure on A.T.& T.

headline: Europeans Ask North Africa Aid on Hostages
abstract: The foreign ministers of the European Community asked their counterparts in the Muslim countries of North Africa today to help win the release of the thousands of hostages held by Iraq.   The foreign ministers of the 12 members of the community were consulting for the first time with the foreign ministers of the countries on the Mediterranean coast of Africa.

headline: Crisis in the Kremlin; Reading Tea Leaves of Soviet Fate: U.S. Experts Look Ahead
abstract: Gorbachev classically tries to balance the right and the left in exercising domestic control within the U.S.S.R. But there are times when one must choose a path for the future. His indecision and his drift for most of this year into alliance with reactionary forces are very disquieting and may move him on the path toward becoming a Russian Jaruzelski. Jaruzelski thought of himself as a patriot restoring order and avoiding bloodshed. But objectively speaking, what he did was to repress the grass-roots reformist element represented in the Solidarity movement and to set democratization back a decade.   One would have expected that Gorbachev, as a pragmatic politician who unleashed glasnost and the reform impulse, would have found opportunities to work more boldly with reform-minded officials who received popular electoral mandates in the past year -- or at least to adopt the economic measures his own economists have been recommending. The reform movements in the dominant Russian republic have been generally nonviolent and have shown tremendous vitality this year and opened up a real possibility for relegitimizing civil authority from the bottom up.

headline: Bigger Note Issue By Security Pacific
abstract: The Security Pacific Corporation is offering $150 million in subordinated notes through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Originally, the size of the issue by the Los Angeles-based bank holding company was $100 million, but because of good investor demand it was increased, underwriters said.    The subordinated issue is due in 2000 and has a 11 1/2 percent coupon. It is priced at 99.766 to yield 11.540 percent, or about 305 basis points more than the Treasury's when-issued 10-year note.    Noncallable through maturity, the notes are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Leningrad Journal;   Capitalism Checks In, Marxist Ghosts Check Out
abstract: LEAD: Out damned Marxist chintz! Begone you dozing doorman of a bemedaled hero of the great patriotic war!

headline: Mandela Sees Western Bias In Outrage at Iraqi Invasion
abstract: Nelson Mandela accused the West today of hypocrisy and prejudice in responding to Kuwait's occupation, saying Iraq is being singled out because its people are "brown-skinned."   Mr. Mandela, the black nationalist leader in South Africa, said Western governments had made no objections when United States forces invaded Grenada or Panama and had tolerated the Israeli occupation of Arab land.   "But now, the whole of the West is screaming and sending armies," Mr. Mandela said. He emphasized that he did not condone Iraq's actions.

headline: Kuwaiti Envoy Says Baker Vowed 'No Concessions' to Iraqis
abstract: Kuwait's Ambassador to the United States said today that the Bush Administration had assured his Government in exile that the United States would make "absolutely no concessions" when it meets with Iraqi officials in Washington and Baghdad.   The Ambassador, Sheik Saud Nasir al-Sabah, said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d gave the assurance during a meeting on Monday evening at the State Department with him and Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, Kuwait's Foreign Minister. His account of much of the meeting was confirmed by an Administration official.

headline: Iraqis' Christmas: Joy and a 'Weight'
abstract: With the end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988, the Rev. Kamal Bidawid thought he had passed his last Christmas with death and destruction hanging over his 250-family congregation of Chaldean Catholics.    During the eight brutal years of that conflict, Father Bidawid said the requiem Mass for most of the 15 men who had died in combat and were buried in the congregation cemetery donated by the Iraqi Government 25 miles outside the city. He thought he had put the pain of those years behind him.

headline: General Cinema Sells Cadbury Stake
abstract: LEAD: The General Cinema Corporation sold its stake in Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the British candy and soft-drink company, and said the sale would result in an after-tax gain of more than $80 million, or about $1.10 a share, in its fourth quarter. General Cinema said it had sold its entire investment in Cadbury except for 13.2 million shares being held in escrow in connection with its outstanding 5 percent exchangeable debentures that are due in 2002.

headline: Immunex Plans Job Shift At Crucial Time for Drug
abstract: Michael L. Kranda will be named president of the Immunex Corporation today, the Seattle-based biotechnology company said yesterday. Immunex is on the threshold of manufacturing and selling its first major drug product.    Mr. Kranda, who is 37, will continue as the company's operating officer; he has also been executive vice president. The president has been Stephen A. Duzan, the chairman and chief executive who was one of the company's founders in 1981.

headline: Bank Acts on Rumors
abstract: LEAD: An Australian bank today offered a reward of 10,000 Australian dollars (about $8,300) for information on the source of rumors that the bank was near collapse. A spokesman for the Metway Bank, based in Brisbane, said he thought the bank had been the target of a deliberate and malicious campaign, which should not go unpunished.

headline: Soviets Renew Bid for Peace By a Negotiated Settlement
abstract: Moscow renewed its effort today to find a negotiated settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis, with a special envoy to Arab nations saying there was still hope for peace.   Yevgeny M. Primakov, a personal envoy of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, addressed the issue when he arrived in Cairo at the start of a journey expected to take him to Saudi Arabia, Syria and Iraq.

headline: M.I.T. Vice President To Head Harvard Coop
abstract: LEAD: The Harvard Cooperative Society, which with six stores is the largest college bookstore operation in the nation, has named William R. Dickson as its new chairman and chief executive. Mr. Dickson, 55, is senior vice president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline: Rig Count Off in Week
abstract: LEAD: The number of American rigs drilling for oil and natural gas fell by 8 last week, to 1,047, compared with 978 a year ago, Baker Hughes Inc., an oilfield services company, said on Monday. The weekly rig count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and gas, not those producing oil and gas.

headline: Executive With Trump Joins Housing Company
abstract: Anthony B. Gliedman is leaving the big-city real estate aura of the Trump Organization to become chief executive-designate of the Amrep Corporation, which builds moderate-priced housing in New Mexico and Florida land developments.    Mr. Gliedman, 48, is executive vice president of the Trump Organization, where he most recently has been in charge of the long-stalled Trump City project proposed for abandoned railyards on the West Side of Manhattan. Mr. Gliedman joined Trump in 1986 after a 19-year career with the City of New York. From 1979 to 1986, he was commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

headline: Islam's Influence Weighed Differently Since Crisis
abstract: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 3 - As Islamic envoys ended an abortive mission to secure peace in the gulf crisis this week, their voyaging between Baghdad and Riyadh seemed to mark a shift in the way their faith has come to be weighed in the region's crises since the fervor of the Islamic revolution a decade ago.   At that time, the fear of pan-Islamic upheaval gnawed at secular governments and conservative monarchies across the region. It also served to unite much of the Arab world behind secular Iraq as its champion against Iran's avowed desire to export Islamic revolution and topple those regimes that did not subscribe to its absolutism.   "There was a fear of this Islamic monolith that threatened the entire Arab political order," said a senior Western diplomat in Cairo. "That is no longer the case," despite the passions and uncertainties aroused by the vision of foreign, mainly American, soldiers on the conceptual Arab homeland.   The current crisis, by contrast, has laid bare fissures in the one-time perception of Islam's power as a universal rallying point. While virtually all Muslims oppose the deployment of American troops in Saudi Arabia - the land that houses their holiest shrines -many others remain privately wary of association with Saddam Hussein's secular leadership.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.00   8.00   8.75        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.06   7.12   7.73        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.03   7.11   7.52        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.38   8.48   7.84        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.67   8.75   7.86        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.75   9.92   9.12        MUNICIPAL BONDS*   7.67   7.71   7.36       *Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: People
abstract: * Diane Tipsword has been named senior vice president of Ogilvy & Mather, Chicago. * Deirdre Cavanagh, Beth Green, Marc Rappin and Tony Stanol have been promoted to management directors at F.C.B./Leber Katz Partners, New York. * Jeffrey Sharlach has been promoted to executive vice president of Rowland Worldwide, based in New York. * Richard Beckman has joind Conde Nast Traveler, New York, as advertising director. * Dusty Bricker has joined Vanity Fair magazine, a Conde Nast publication, as director of marketing services. * Megan Bueschel has been appointed director of public relations at Tribune Broadcasting Co., Chicago. * T. R. Shepard 3d has been promoted to publisher of Country Living, a Hearst magazine in New York, replacing Richard J. Sarno, who retired.

headline: Male Journal; 1,190 Islands in Danger: Sea Could Drown Them
abstract: Even before the first hint of dawn outlines the offshore islands rimmed with white sand, the chugging motors of dhoni boats have announced a new day to this town.   The all-purpose craft, adapted for fishing, ferrying people or hauling freight, are rarely at rest. The Indian Ocean is everything and everywhere in the Maldives, a nation of 1,190 low-lying islands whose cowrie shells were the currency of ancient trade routes.

headline: Cable Concern Shows a Loss
abstract: The giant cable television company Tele-Communications Inc. this week reported a loss of $44 million in the third quarter, as improved operating results were offset by higher interest expenses and other costs.   The results compared with a loss of $74 million in the corresponding quarter last year.   Total revenues for the three months were $942 million, up 13.9 percent from $827 million last year. Tele-Communications said its cable television revenue increased 17 percent in the third quarter.   Operating income before depreciation and amortization amounted to $357 million in the third quarter, compared with $312 million last year. But interest expense increased to $239 million, from $217 million in the 1989 period.

headline: For Christians, Holidays Gain an Indian Feel
abstract: At the end of a year of almost unbroken strife between Hindu-dominated India and two of its religious minorities, Muslims and Sikhs, the Christmas season has brought a quiet time for Indians to reflect on the Christians in their midst.   Christmas Day is a holiday in India, as are the major festivals of most religions represented in this constitutionally secular country. But unlike the situation in other Asian nations, where Christmas has become a commercialized season for giving gifts and sending cards, its celebration here is still limited mostly to Christian churches and communities, where the holy day retains its strictly religious character.

headline: Wal-Mart Stores For New England
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. will make its first foray into New England with five discount stores planned in New Hampshire. The stores will be near the borders of Massachusetts and Maine to take advantage of shoppers from those states who come to New Hampshire to avoid their states' sales taxes.    Wal-Mart will also open a Sam's Wholesale Club in Scarborough, Me. Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., operates largely in the Sun Belt and the Midwest. It operates 1,527 discount stores in 35 states, including 146 Sam's Wholesale Clubs and four Hypermart-USA stores.

headline: Partial Acquittals In Sundstrand Case
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge acquitted three former executives of the Sundstrand Corporation on charges of lying to the Government in connection with the military contractor's admitted Pentagon fraud scheme. The judge is expected to rule on the remaining charges of conspiracy and scheming to conceal the conspiracy next week.

headline: Haitian Victor Reported Ready to Soften Stands
abstract: Haiti's President-elect, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has privately told American officials that he is ready to work with the Haitian Army he has long opposed and moderate much of his leftist platform, Administration officials said today.   The officials pledged cautious support for Father Aristide, saying that their main concern now was to help assure that the army and supporters of the old Duvalier dictatorship refrain from disrupting or even preventing his scheduled Feb. 7 inauguration.

headline: DUTCH TO BATTLE POLLUTION ABROAD
abstract: Reaching far beyond the bad breath of their smokestacks at home, Dutch power stations have begun an ambitious cleanup project that involves replanting thousands of acres of forests in the tropics and helping to clear Eastern Europe's choking air.    The power companies argue that they can achieve much faster and more impressive results by combating air pollution in poorer or less developed countries than they can by spending huge sums to yield small improvements in the Netherlands.

headline: Your Money Some Tax Breaks On Falling Stocks
abstract: LEAD: For many investors, it may be time to trim the sails. Since stocks and bonds have taken a pounding in recent weeks, many portfolios have losers. While the sentiment may be to hold on, what can be salvaged represents a tax loss.

headline: House Leaders Tell President Not to Call Special Iraq Session
abstract: As the United Nations Security Council gave its approval today to the use of military force against Iraq, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the House told President Bush they could not guarantee strong bipartisan support for a similar resolution in Congress.   The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, and the House Republican Leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, told Mr. Bush at a private White House luncheon that he might prevail in Congress if he pressed for a vote now, but could fall short of a clear-cut mandate to use force against Iraq this winter and might well set off a divisive debate among lawmakers. They advised Mr. Bush not to call a special session of Congress on the Persian Gulf.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Air Midwest Inc., Wichita, Kan., an air transportation company, said it would sell 23 aircraft and related assets used in its Trans World Express operations in St. Louis to Trans States Airlines Inc., another Trans World Express operator, for slightly more than $16 million. * Black Clawson Co., New York, a maker of paper recycling systems, has acquired Zimpro-Passavant Inc., Rothschild, Wis., a maker of high technology pollution control and sludge disposal systems. Terms were not disclosed. * Blount Inc., Montgomery, Ala., a construction manufacturing company, said its Omark Material Handling division had entered a manufacturing and marketing agreement with Oy Norcar A.B. of Finland, a maker of forest harvesting equipment. Terms were not disclosed. * CAE-Link Corp., a part of CAE Industries, Toronto, a maker of transportation control devices, said its Link Flight Simulation division was offering an enhanced retirement program to about 425 employees and expected to announce further staff reductions next month. * Cabot Corp., Waltham, Mass., a specialty chemicals and energy company, said it would offer its shareholders the opportunity to exchange Cabot common stock for shares of the Cabot Oil and Gas Corp. common stock that it owns. The exchange rate for the offer will be announced in December. * Corning Inc., Corning, N.Y., a supplier of optical fiber and fiber-optic components, said it would invest more than $100 million to increase the capacity of its optical fiber manufacturing facility by more than 50 percent. * DeSoto Inc., Des Plaines, Ill., a maker of chemical coating and specialty products, closed the sales of its consumer paint business to Sherwin-Williams Co., Cleveland, a paints and finishes company, for $80 million and its coatings business to Courtaulds P.L.C., London, for $135 million. * Dow Chemical Co., Midland, Mich., said it and its wholly owned subsidiary, RH Acquisition Corp., had bought an additional 1,013,505 common shares of Marion Merrell Dow Inc., giving it a 68.5 percent stake in Marion Merrell. * Honeywell Inc., Minneapolis, announced a computer system that will allow companies to combine control of manufacturing with their air-conditioning and heating systems. The company said the new system could reduce energy costs, cut waste and improve efficiency.  * Tenneco Inc., Houston, a diversified industrial corporation, said its Packaging Corp. of America subsidiary had acquired Dixie Container Corp., Richmond, a corrugated container company. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: 472 of the Rich Avoided Taxes
abstract: Some wealthy Americans are still able to scrape together enough deductions to avoid paying any Federal income tax, the Internal Revenue Service said today.    Of 557,848 couples and individuals who reported income of $200,000 or more on returns filed in 1988, 472 with total income of $211 million paid no income tax. Two of them, both unidentified, even reported receiving unemployment compensation.   Of the high-income people who paid taxes, about 9,300 paid less than 5 percent. Another 17,082 reduced their liability to less than 10 percent, which is about the same as that paid by the average $35,000- a-year family.   In its annual report on the tax liabilities of high-income people, the I.R.S. said two- thirds of those with income of $200,000 and up reported capital gains -- profits from the sale of investments -- that averaged $284,814. By comparison, salaries averaged $264,331.   The study, prepared by the Treasury Department's Office of Tax Analysis, is based on raw tax returns. Some of the nontaxpayers could be moved onto the tax rolls following I.R.S. audits.

headline: Pan Am May Seek Extension
abstract: Pan American World Airways, facing perhaps its most serious cash squeeze yet, is expected to ask for an extension of a Friday deadline for payment to creditors, officials of the airline and of its creditors said yesterday.   The deadline for payment of $32 million comes at a precarious time for the ailing carrier. Pan Am is entering the slow winter travel season, and the airline has yet to receive payment from a $400 million route sale to United Airlines. "This could be quite serious," said an official of Airbus Industrie, a Pan Am creditor, who insisted on anonymity.

headline: Coke Bottler Move
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. said it had finished one stock buyback and was starting another. The company said it had repurchased about 1.5 million shares from public shareholders and the Coca-Cola Company in the fourth quarter, completing a two-year program to buy back 25 million shares. The bottling company, which is 49 percent owned by the Coca-Cola Company, said its board had also approved a new program to repurchase up to 15 million common shares. It said Coca-Cola would participate in the repurchase program to maintain its ownership at 49 percent.

headline: A Priest to the Very Poor at the Pinnacle in Haiti
abstract: When he emerged as the apparent overwhelming victor yesterday from a brief but intense race for the Haitian presidency, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide was given sweet popular vindication against two of his most bitter foes.   The object of several assassination attempts, and a longtime foe of a military he has denounced as brutal and corrupt, Father Aristide will soon become the armed forces' Commander in Chief.

headline: Cigarette Makers Try To Brake a Slide
