abstract: LEAD: Here in tobacco country, the notion that Washington is almost certain to raise Federal taxes on cigarettes has some people smiling.

headline: South African Clerics Meet; Tutu Raises Issue of Restitution
abstract: The largest assembly of black and white churches in the history of South Africa convened here today to determine ecumenical guidelines for a future beyond apartheid.    But the prospect of promoting reconciliation between black and white Christians after years of apartheid looked far from assured at the conference, the first concrete attempt in 30 years to create unity among churches divided by apartheid. The Anglican Archbishop, Desmond M. Tutu, and some other black clerics contended that repentance by whites for their past support of apartheid should include restitution for injustices inflicted on blacks.

headline: Taipei Journal; War on Crime Makes a Hero of a Hated General
abstract: Just a few months ago, Hau Pei-tsun seemed one of the most unpopular men in Taiwan. When he was appointed Prime Minister, protesters rallied in the streets and warned that his selection would threaten Taiwan's emerging democracy.   But these days most people here approve of Mr. Hau, a former general and military Chief of Staff, for one reason: they want social order.

headline: Campbell Net Sets a Record
abstract: The Campbell Soup Company said today that higher sales and a worldwide revamping had increased its first-quarter earnings by 27 percent, making it the best quarter in the company's 121- year history.   For the quarter that ended on Oct. 28, earnings climbed to $105.1 million, or 82 cents a share, from $83 million, or 64 cents a share, in the first quarter a year ago. Its revenues increased almost 5 percent, to $1.59 billion, from $1.52 billion a year ago.    "We are pleased with the progress we have made during this first quarter and remain confident about the rest of the year," Campbell's chief executive, David W. Johnson, said at a shareholders meeting.   John M. McMillin, a food industry analyst with Prudential- Bache Securities, said: "The quarter was better than expected. They certainly got their fiscal year off to a good start."   Last year, Campbell's profits dropped sharply as the company continued a two-year restructuring and corporate makeover. Earnings for the year were $4.4 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with a profit of $13 million, or 10 cents a share, the previous year.   The higher earnings were seen as a first step toward pacifying disgruntled members of the founding Dorrance family, who own a large stake in Campbell's and have urged that the company be sold.

headline: Sales of New Homes Lowest in Eight Years
abstract: Sales of new homes dropped by 3.5 percent in October to the lowest level in eight years, the Government reported today. But analysts said the free fall might be bottoming out and sales should begin rebounding by spring.   "Sales should be leveling off at this number in the fourth quarter and the first quarter of next year," assuming mortgage rates continue to fall and the gulf crisis is resolved, said David G. Seiders, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Decline Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Japanese stocks dropped sharply today.

headline: Gorbachev Urged to Consider Crackdown in Republics
abstract: A galaxy of top Soviet military officers joined prominent figures from industry, the arts and the church today in urging President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to consider direct Kremlin rule in rebellious regions of the country.    "If constitutional methods prove ineffective against separatists, criminal speculators and the paramilitary forces that are continuing to spill the blood of the people, we suggest instituting a state of emergency and presidential rule in zones of major conflicts," said the open letter to Mr. Gorbachev, circulated at the Congress of People's Deputies.

headline: Net Jumps at B.P. and Shell
abstract: British Petroleum and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group today announced dramatically higher third-quarter profits, after riding a sharp rise in oil prices prompted by the Persian Gulf crisis.   B.P. said its profits totaled $:822 million, or about $1.5 billion, in the quarter, nearly a three-fold increase from the $:211 million earned in the corresponding period last year. B.P. said the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 sent the average crude price to $26 a barrel in three months, $10 higher than in the 1989 quarter.    Earlier in the day, the British-Dutch company Shell said its third-quarter profits rose 68 percent, to $:1.09 billion, from $:652 million.    Shell also said its profits were helped by higher exploration and production earnings, which were largely attributable to higher oil prices.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Labatt Breweries of Canada to J. Walter Thompson, Toronto, with billings between $15 million and $20 million. * Minolta Corp., Ramsey, N.J., to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, for its business equipment dealers account, with a reported $4.5 million in billings. * El Conquistador Resort & Cuntry Club, Fajardo, P.R., a unit of Williams Hospitality Management Corp., San Juan, to AC&R Advertising, with a budget of $2 million. * H. P. Hood Inc., Boston, distributors of dairy, citrus and cheese products, has consolidated all its advertising for its dairy and ice cream accounts in Ketchum Advertising, New York. Part of the account, which has a budget of $5 million, was previously handled by Leonard Monahan Lubars & Partners, Providence, R.I.

headline: East German Plant Reprieved
abstract: The factory that produces East Germany's Trabant car was given a last-minute reprieve today when the German Economics Ministry said it had approved the export of 10,000 Trabants to Poland.   The ministry said in a statement the Polish order had given the plant enough work to survive until February instead of having to shut down next month.

headline: Drexel Faces Claims by S.& L. Regulators
abstract: Federal savings regulators plan to file claims expected to reach billions of dollars against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., former employees and related entities, people with direct knowledge of the plans said yesterday.    The claims are expected to run as high as $5 billion to $10 billion for substantial losses the agencies say were incurred by a number of the nation's largest savings and loans that had invested in high-yield "junk bonds."

headline: Unrest Fills Somalia's Capital as Rebel Groups Press Drive to City
abstract: After several years of increasingly brutal civil war in Somalia, the situation has taken a sharp turn, with near anarchy in Mogadishu, the capital, and rebel groups on the outskirts pressing in on the city, diplomats and people who have just fled the country say.    The United Nations has ordered the evacuation of all its personnel after the shooting in the head of a United Nations official, and the United States has advised all dependents and nonessential personnel to leave.

headline: Manischewitz Agrees To Pact on Buyout
abstract: LEAD: The B. Manischewitz Company, the maker of matzohs and other kosher foods, agreed yesterday to a buyout led by Kohlberg & Company and Manischewitz's management.

headline: Corral Journal;   Chile's Woodmen Fret at Cry 'Spare That Forest!'
abstract: LEAD: When the aging motor launch that links Corral to the outside world pulled into the harbor on its midday stop, most of those going aboard were men carrying bedrolls.

headline: Dow Up 2.73 Points Despite Opening Slump
abstract: The surprise resignation of Eduard A. Shevardnadze as Soviet Foreign Minister pushed stocks down sharply early yesterday, but prices recovered almost immediately as investors concluded that they had severely overreacted.    Hugh Johnson, chief strategist for the investment firm First Albany Corporation, called it "the scare at the opening" with traders fearing that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union might be weakened.

headline: 5 Israeli Soldiers Killed in a Guerrilla Clash in Southern Lebanon
abstract: Five Israeli soldiers were killed and a sixth was wounded early this morning during a firefight with Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon.    The deaths came just as Israel finished burying its dead from the terrorist incident on the southern border Sunday in which an Egyptian border policeman opened fire on vehicles passing on a highway, killing four people and wounding 26.

headline: Excerpts From President's News Conference on Crisis in Gulf
abstract: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:                    OPENING STATEMENT         I have a statement -- an opening statement -- that is a little longer than normal and I'd ask your indulgence, and then I will be glad to respond to questions.    We're in the gulf because the world must not and cannot reward aggression. And we're there because our vital interests are at stake. And we're in the gulf because of the brutality of Saddam Hussein.    We're dealing with a dangerous dictator all too willing to use force, who has weapons of mass destruction and is seeking new ones and who desires to control one of the world's key resources -- all at a time in history when the rules of the post-cold-war world are being written.   Objectives of U.S.     Our objectives remain what they were since the outset. We seek Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. We seek the restoration of Kuwait's legitimate Government. We seek the release of all hostages and the free functioning of all embassies. And we seek the stability and security of this critical region of the world.    We are not alone in these goals and objectives. The United Nations, invigorated with a new sense of purpose, is in full agreement. The United Nations Security Council has endorsed 12 resolutions to condemn Iraq's unprovoked invasion and occupation of Kuwait, implement tough economic sanctions to stop all trade in and out of Iraq and authorize the use of force to compel Saddam to comply.    Saddam Hussein has tried every way he knows how to make this a fight between Iraq and the United States, and clearly he has failed.    Forces of 26 other nations are standing shoulder-to-shoulder with our troops in the gulf. The fact is that it is not the United States against Iraq. It is Iraq against the world. And there's never been a clearer demonstration of a world united against appeasement and aggression.    Yesterday's United Nations Security Council resolution was historic. Once again the Security Council has enhanced the legitimate peacekeeping function of the United Nations. Until yesterday, Saddam may not have understood what he's up against in terms of world opinion. And I'm hopeful that now he will realize that he must leave Kuwait immediately.    I'm continually asked how effective are the U.N. sanctions -- those put into effect on Aug. 6. And I don't know the answer to that question. Clearly the sanctions are having some effect. But I can't tell you that the sanctions alone will get the job done. And thus I welcome yesterday's United Nations action.    The fledgling democracies in Eastern Europe are being severely damaged by the economic effects of Saddam's actions. The developing countries of Africa and in our hemisphere are being victimized by this dictator's rape of his neighbor Kuwait.   Fragile Economies in Trouble     Those who feel that there is no downside to waiting months and months must consider the devastating damage being done every day to the fragile economies of those countries that can afford it the least.    As chairman Alan Greenspan  [ of the Federal Reserve Board ]  testified just the other day, the increase in oil prices resulting directly from Saddam's invasion is hurting our country too. And our economy, as I said the other day, is at best in a serious slowdown, and if uncertainty remains in the energy markets, the slowdown will get worse.    I've spelled out once again our reasons for sending troops to the gulf. Let me tell you the things that concern me most:   First, I put the immorality of the invasion of Kuwait itself. No nation should rape, pillage and brutalize its neighbor. No nation should be able to wipe a member state of the United Nations and the Arab League off the face of the earth.    And I'm deeply concerned about all the hostages, innocent people held against their will in direct contravention of international law. And then there's this cynical and brutal policy of forcing people to beg for their release, parceling out human lives to families and traveling emissaries like so much chattel.    And I'm deeply concerned about our own Embassy in Kuwait. The flag is still flying there. A handful of beleaguered Americans remain inside the Embassy unable to come and go. This treatment of our Embassy violates every civilized principle of diplomacy. And it demeans our people. It demeans our country. And I am determined that this Embassy, as called for under Security Council Resolution 674, be fully replenished and our people free to come home. What kind of precedent will these actions set for the future if Saddam's violation of international law goes unchallenged?    I'm also deeply concerned about the future of Kuwait itself. The tales of rape and assassination, of cold-blooded murder and rampant looting, are almost beyond belief. The whole civilized world must unite and say this kind of treatmet of people must end and those who violated the Kuwaiti people must be brought to justice.  Potential Nuclear Threat     I'm deeply concerned about Saddam's efforts to acquire nuclear weapons. Imagine his ability to blackmail his neighbors should he possess a nuclear device. We've seen him use chemical weapons on his own people. We've seen him take his own country -- one that should be wealthy and prosperous -- and turn it into a poor country, all because of insatiable appetite for military equipment and conquest.    I've been asked why I ordered more troops to the gulf. I remain hopeful that we can achieve a peaceful solution to this crisis, but if force is required, we and the other 26 countries who have troops in the area will have enough power to get the job done.   In our country, I know that there are fears about another Vietnam. Let me assure you: should military action be required, this will not be another Vietnam; this will not be a protracted, drawn-out war. The forces arrayed are different, the opposition is different, the resupply of Saddam's military would be very different, the countries united against him in the United Nations are different, the topography of Kuwait is different and the motivation of our all-volunteer force is superb.    I want peace. I want peace, not war. But if there must be war, we will not permit our troops to have their hands tied behind their backs, and I pledge to you there will not be any murky ending. If one American soldier has to go into battle, that soldier will have enough force behind him to win, and then get out as soon as possible, as soon as the U.N. objectives have been achieved.   I will never, ever agree to a halfway effort. Let me repeat: we have no argument with the people of Iraq. Indeed, we've only friendship for the people there. And further, I repeat that we have no desire to keep one single American soldier in the gulf a single day longer than is necessary to achieve the objectives set out above.    No one wants to see a peaceful solution to this crisis more than I do, and at the same time, no one is more determined than I am to see Saddam's aggression reversed.  'Time Is Running Out'     And lastly, people now caution patience. The United States and the entire world have been patient. I will continue to be patient. But yesterday's U.N. resolution, the 13th by the Security Council, properly says to Saddam Hussein: time is running out. You must leave Kuwait, and we've given you time to do just exactly that.   Many people have talked directly to Saddam Hussein, and to his Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz. All have been frustrated by Iraq's ironclad insistence that it will not leave Kuwait. However, to go the extra mile for peace, I will issue an invitation to Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to come to Washington, at a mutually convenient time during the latter part of the week of Dec. 10, to meet with me. And I'll invite ambassadors of several of our coalition partners in the gulf to join me at that meeting.   In addition, I'm asking Secretary Jim Baker to go to Baghdad to see Saddam Hussein, and I will suggest to Iraq's President that he receive the Secretary of State at a mutually convenient time between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15 of next year. Within the mandate -- within the mandate of the United Nations resolutions -- I will be prepared, and so will Secretary Baker, to discuss all aspects of the gulf crisis.   However, to be very clear about these efforts to exhaust all means for achieving a political and diplomatic solution, I am not suggesting discussions that will result in anything less than Iraq's complete withdrawal from Kuwait, restoration of Kuwait's legitimate Government and freedom for all hostages.    Thank you very much, and I will be glad to respond to a few questions.                    QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS       A Deadline for War?     Q. Mr. President, now that you have the clear-cut U.N. resolution on use of force, doesn't that force you into a position -- if these talks between the Secretary of State break down, doesn't this force you into the position of having to use force on Jan. 15 if Saddam Hussein hasn't left, and if not, won't we be seen as the one that blinked first?    A. No, the date was not a date at which point force had to be used.    Q. If I could just follow up with another question. Are you going to ask Congress for approval of this resolution? Would you like to see Congress pass the same kind of resolution as the U.N.?   A. I'd love to see Congress pass a resolution enthusiastically endorsing what the United Nations has done, yes. We're in consultation on that and I have no plans to call a special session. I'm not opposed to it, but we're involved in consultations right now. I've talked to several members of Congress, I've talked to leaders in the House, I've talked to several on the Republican side and Democratic side in the Senate. And I want to be sure that these consultations are complete.   Some feel a lame-duck session is not good, that the new members should have a right to have a say. Others feel that we ought to move right now. The Congress, as you know, in their adjournment resolution, had a provision in there that they could come back and take this up. They are a coequal branch of government, they can do that if they want to. But I -- we will continue our consultations. . . .   Price of Victory    Q. Mr. President, you say you're confident that American troops will prevail against Saddam if called upon.    A. Oh, absolutely.   Q. At what price? I mean --   A. Well, I can't give you that. I can't give you that, any figures, of course. But I can say that the movement of this additional force safeguards the lives of every American and every one of our allies in the gulf.    Q. Mr. President, in recent days, senior members of the Administration have emphatically rejected the idea of any special emissaries or diplomatic envoys to or from Iraq to discuss this, on your part. What changed your mind, sir?   A. The United Nations resolution, I think, has a good chance of making Saddam Hussein understand what it is he's up against. I have not felt that he got the message. I hope this will do it. But I am convinced that these two direct meetings that I've discussed here will guarantee to all the people of the world -- certainly to the American people -- that Saddam Hussein not misunderstand, not misinterpret.  .  .  .     Q. You indicate that this date is not actually a deadline for the use of force, merely a date after which force would be permissible. How do you avoid the impression, should that day come and go without military action, that the U.S.-led coalition has in fact blinked?   A. Well, we've got to look at events at the time. But I don't think there will ever be a perception that the United States is going to blink in this situation. That's why I had some of the words in this statement that I had. Yes?  Quest for Mideast Stability    Q. Mr. President, you've just spoken about the weapons of mass destruction and nuclear weapons, and also that one of your goals is to try to reach stability in the region. Can you reach stability in the region with Saddam Hussein in power?   A. I think most countries, members of the United Nations, feel that there have to be some safeguards put into effect in terms of guaranteeing the security and stability of the gulf. And so I would think that the status quo ante will not be enough, and I think there will be -- there are sanctions in place now, and I think it would be very proper to discuss what those safeguards should be after there has been a total compliance with the United Nations resolutions.  .  .  .     Q. Mr. President, I want to ask if your comments about the Kuwaiti Embassy -- whether it's fair to conclude, based on those, that you will neither close the Embassy nor permit those Americans to be starved out?    A. I will not say exactly what I will do or exactly what I won't do. There is a very interesting report that we got in this morning saying that some Iraqis showed up at the Kuwaiti Embassy -- our Embassy in Kuwait -- and had delivered fruit, vegetables and a case of Iraqi cigarettes to Embassy Kuwait. And apparently there's going to be another delivery tomorrow, including soda pop. And they asked what medical supplies were required. And it doesn't say that. And the Embassy will apparently provide a list tomorrow. And the electricity is still cut off. So this is kind of an interesting little development. But I -- somebody said to me: Well, hy, what about if there's some provocation? They asked me in the leadership meeting. I said consider me provoked when it comes to the United States Embassy. Consider me provoked when I see Americans without proper food and medical equipment.    Q. May I follow up? Do you take it from that communique that you received there that the Iraqis have the message and want to eliminate that as a potential tripwire?    A. I don't know. It's too early -- it's the best question, right on target, one that we were discussing inside. And I -- let's try to be optimistic and say this is -- this could be a positive sign. But it's so far short of compliance with international law that I can't be rejoicing. But it is a very interesting development. . . .   Criticism in Congress    Q. You've been getting some pretty negative comments up on the Hill at these hearings that have been held this week. Now this morning you said this would not be a long, protracted, Vietnam-type war. However, General Odom, the former head of the N.S.A., testified just this morning at the Senate Armed Services that in fact you have to be there for decades. Now presumably he means even after military combat. We'd have to have people in place there as part of a peacekeeping force. Do you see our commitment there extend that far?    A. No I don't.    Q. May I ask something else? Al Gore, yesterday, takes issue with your comments and the comments of some of your aides, such as Brent Scowcroft, about Saddam being able to churn out a nuclear weapon in a matter of months. Gore, who's had some private briefings, apparently, from some of your people, indicates that your Administration statements are misleading.    A. I disagree with the Senator. And if he wants to gamble on the future about the construction of atomic weapons by Saddam Hussein, I don't. And I know what the intelligence says. Every bit of it. And I can't share it, obviously, because we don't comment on intelligence matters. But I am concerned. . . .   Dependability of Allies    Q. Of those 26 nations that you list in the area, how many of those are equally committed to offensive action other than just defensive action?   A. I can't give you the answer to that, because I don't really know. But I'd expect that there is enthusiasm in all quarters of those countries for the U.N. action that was taken yesterday.    Q. With all respect, shouldn't you know how many would follow your troops into battle?    A. I know that what I said is true about the -- if we have to go into battle, and I'm satisfied I know enough about that. I went over in detail -- as you might well imagine a President should, because I have the responsibility as commander in chief -- what might happen if we have to use force. I repeat, I hope we'll never have to have one single shot fired in anger. Yes?   Q. Iraq has been constantly calling for dialogue. Aren't you concerned that those two missions, Tariq Aziz and James Baker, will lead Saddam Hussein to claim that the U.S. is showing signs of weakness?  .  .  .     A. No, I'm not. I'm concerned some might say this is an ultimatum, in which -- all it is is an effort to make sure that he understands the commitment of the United States, that he understands that anything that is done must be done inside the confines of the United Nations resolutions that have been passed, that there will be no contingency, there can be no face-saving. This is not what this is about. This is to be sure that he understands how strongly the President of the United States feels about implementing to a T, without concession, the United Nations position.    And some have told me that he's not getting the message of how determined we are. And I can't think of any better way to do it, at this juncture, in the wake of the U.N. resolution, than this face-to-face meeting. I'm not sure he'll agree to it. . . .    Q. The Soviet Union did indeed vote on our side as far as the resolution, allowing force if it's necessary. Are we going to offer the Soviet Union any compromise on export credits? As you know, there's some concern that they think there's a de facto grain embargo going on because we won't offer export credits in their very needy time.   A. The matters are totally separate and unrelated, but I am concerned about this. And I've talked about, with Mr. Gorbachev, of a willingness to entertain proposals for food -- particularly if the reports prove to be accurate in terms of the severe winter and the hardship that this will inflict on the Soviet people.   Conference on Mideast    Q. Mr. President, you -- Arab experts suggest that Saddam Hussein has hinted in his remarks that he would like to have some sort of deal, but he wouldn't necessarily hold to his demands. Now you're saying you're willing to meet with him. Are you willing to offer him anything in these meetings in return for a pullout, such as a conference on the Middle East?   A. No. Those two items are totally separate. We've made that very very clear. And what I have said is that this will be -- these discussions will be done within the U.N. mandate. . . .    Q. Mr. President, you mentioned the damage that higher oil prices are doing to the world economy. Should Saudi Arabia and other producers share more of their windfall?    A. I think they're doing a pretty good job in underwriting the costs to various countries and helping third-party countries that are -- that have been hurt by all of this. But I think everybody should go the extra mile to help others. . . .   Q. . . . Should Saudi Arabia have a military draft?    A. That's for the Saudi Arabians to decide. I don't think the United States needs one, incidentally. . . .   Risking American Lives    Q. Mr. President, if you ultimately feel that you have to ask Americans to support the use of force, what that, of course, means is that you have to ask some parents to give up the lives of their children.    A. I know it.    Q. And what I was wondering was, we all know how important your children are to you. Do you feel that this issue is important enough to you that you could conceive of giving up one of their lives for it?    A. You know, Maureen, you've put your -- you put your finger on a very difficult question. People say to me: How many lives? How many lives can you expend? Each one's precious. And I don't want to reminisce, but I've been there. I know what it's like to have fallen comrades and see young kids die in battle. And it's only the President that should be asked to make the decision. Is it worth it? How many lives is it worth? Is it worth it to commit one life -- put one life in harm's way -- to achieve these objectives? And that's why I want to get a peaceful resolution to this question. You ought to read my mail. It is so heart-moving. Supportive and yet: "Please bring my kid home. Please bring my husband home." And it's a tough question. But a President has to make the right decision. And these are worldwide principles of moral importance. And I will do my level best to bring those kids home without one single shot fired in anger. And if a shot is fired in anger, I want to guarantee each person that their kid, whose life is in harm's way, will have the maximum support, will have the best chance to come home alive and will be backed up to the hilt. And that's why -- it's because of that question that weighs on my mind I added that language this morning about how this will not be a Vietnam. They can criticize me for moving force, and if we got one kid that's apt to be in harm's way, I want him backed up to the hilt by American firepower and others as well. And that's why I'm working as hard as I am, not only to hold this coalition together but to strengthen it. . . . And if force has to be used, the best way to safeguard lives is to see that you got the best and you're willing to use it. . . .

headline: Hearing Held on Length Of Jail Time for Milken
abstract: Legal wrangling continued yesterday about recommendations for the prison term Michael R. Milken will actually serve as lawyers for the Government and for the former financier tried to make their cases to the court about the financial impact of his crimes on individuals.    The information is important because it would have great influence on when the former head of the "junk bond" division would be released from prison. Under rulings that have been made in the case, Mr. Milken, who was sentenced last month to 10 years in prison, is eligible for parole at any time.

headline: Government Cleanup Effort Is Set Back Again in Japan
abstract: In a setback to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's efforts to clean up the image of corruption in government, a former Cabinet minister was indicted this week on charges that he made more than $21 million from insider stock tips and then evaded taxes on the income.    The indictment of Toshiyuki Inamura, a former state minister in charge of the Environmental Protection Agency, on Thursday shook Japan's political establishment just as Mr. Kaifu was presiding over a bitter tug of war within his party over demands for a Cabinet reshuffling.

headline: Martin Marietta's Big U.S. Contract
abstract: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said it had awarded a $525.9 million contract to the Martin Marietta Corporation. In the next 30 months, the company will replace all of the department's mainframe computers, work station computers and the equipment that ties desktop computers together to form local networks. Martin Marietta will also consolidate the department's automated data-processing operations in Lanham, Md., and create a national data communications network linking the department's 81 offices.   Over 10 years, Martin Marietta will manage and upgrade the department's computer systems and data-transmission equipment. The company will also keep about three-fifths of the contract's revenues and pass on the rest to subcontractors, mostly equipment manufacturers, said Peter A. Bracken, a Martin Marietta vice president who manages the program.

headline: KLM Airlines To Cut 500 Jobs
abstract: LEAD: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines announced it was cutting 500 jobs and warned that rising jet fuel prices and a weak dollar could wipe out profits this year. The company may also cut part of its foreign network as part of a $231 million cost-cutting plan in the next three years, a KLM spokesman, Hugo Baas, said.

headline: The Nub Is Timing No Major U.S.-Soviet Rupture Seen, But Separate Focuses on Gulf Persist
abstract: Like so many things, it appears to be mostly a matter of timing, this question of whether the United Nations Security Council ought to authorize the use of military force against Saddam Hussein, and if so, when it should act.     If senior diplomats of half a dozen major countries are to be believed, including those of the United States, there has been no major rupture in the solid front that most of the world has maintained for almost three months against the Iraqi President's invasion and occupation of Kuwait. Agreement on tactics for the next few months is not coming as quickly as President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would like, but that does not mean that it will not come.

headline: People
abstract: * D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Detroit, has named three new executives. Alex Morton was appointed executive vice president and group account director, Mark Gjovik was named management supervisor and Robin Carr was appointed senior vice president and account director. * Dan Weeks has been named an art director at Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago.

headline: A Giant That Takes No Giant Steps
abstract: Over the last five years, the Tribune Company of Chicago has faced a persistent question from some investment bankers: With the powerful base of its six television stations, why not emulate Fox Broadcasting and develop a new network?    In light of the strike at The Daily News, Tribune is now facing the most crucial long-term decisions since it went public in 1983. Its policy over the network question suggests that it will act cautiously, avoiding precipitous action.

headline: Arabs at U.N. to Seek Debate Over Kuwait
abstract: LEAD: Arab foreign ministers agreed at a meeting here today to support Kuwait's demand for a General Assembly debate on the Iraqi invasion during the current session.

headline: Ethnic Germans in Romania Dwindle
abstract: As Romania struggles to piece itself together socially and economically a year after the bloody downfall of Nicolae Ceausescu's Communist dictatorship, the country's centuries-old ethnic-German community is on the verge of extinction.    A half-million strong after World War II, Romania's ethnic Germans now number fewer than 100,000, said Hans Klein, who administers their main political organization, the German Democratic Forum.

headline: U.S. Flies Anti-Qaddafi Libyans Out of Chad in a Secretive Airlift
abstract: The United States has begun a secretive airlift of several hundred Libyan dissidents who oppose the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, American diplomats and other officials said tonight.    The dissidents are former Libyan soldiers who had been captured by Chadian Government forces and later joined the army of former President Hissen Habre of Chad, said the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.     When the Habre Government fell last week to rebel forces, the Libyan dissidents asked for protection and the United States agreed to help them find refuge elsewhere, the officials said. Diplomats here have said they are convinced that Colonel Qaddafi backed the Chadian rebels.

headline: Having Helped a Friend, Bush Leaves Mexico
abstract: It ended today with the requisite joint statements of Mexican-American solidarity on everything from drugs to the Persian Gulf. But the 28-hour visit to northern Mexico by President Bush seemed primarily a demonstration of the lengths to which he will go to indulge his favorite pastime, high-level diplomacy, and reward a political ally.   Mr. Bush and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico reaffirmed their commitment to negotiating a free-trade agreement, opened the door a little farther for Canada to join thearrangement, and renewed their demands that Iraq withdraw from occupied Kuwait.

headline: K.G.B. CHIEF WARNS AGAINST WEST'S AID TO SOVIET ECONOMY
abstract: The chairman of the K.G.B. today warned the Soviet Congress to be wary of foreigners offering to help the Soviet economy, suggesting that Western businesses and governments represent a hidden danger to the country's security.    The K.G.B. chief, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, charged that economic contacts were often a pretext for compiling strategic information about Soviet industry and resources, for cheating unwitting Soviet partners, and for imposing an alien capitalist outlook.

headline: YELTSIN PROPOSES MOSCOW COALITION
abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic said today that he had urged President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to share power in a "coalition government of national unity" and that Mr. Gorbachev agreed "in principle" to consider the idea.    Mr. Yeltsin, stepping up the ante in the looming contest over redrawing the nation's lines of authority, drew laughter from the Parliament of his Russian federated republic as he described how he "did not ask for many posts" in challenging Mr. Gorbachev to share power in the national government.

headline: U.S. Wine Exports Up
abstract: United States wine exports are booming and Japan is the best customer, the Agriculture Department said in the December issue of Agexporter, an official monthly publication. In the first six months of this year, wine exports topped $51 million, up 19 percent over the period last year. Japanese wine drinkers took one bottle out of every four. Since 1985, American wine sales have more than quadrupled.

headline: Small Budget, Small Star, Big Hit
abstract: In a year that has been unkind to action movies with big names and big budgets, one movie with neither, "Marked for Death," seems marked for success. Made for a mere $12 million by two independent producers, this violent tale of vengeance has earned $29 million since its release on Oct. 5, including an opening weekend at the box office that was the second best ever for a fall film release.   As a movie, "Marked for Death"is little more than a cavalcade of shooting, stabbing, beheading and bone-cracking. Starring Steven Seagal, a martial arts expert with meager acting experience, the movie has received largely negative reviews. But as a commodity and an exercise in successful formula film making, the movie has quickly earned the admiration and the envy of studio executives here, all of whom are acutely aware they could not possibly have made the movie for the same price.

headline: Rise in Oil Production Fails to Blunt Price Increase
abstract: Global oil production is running 200,000 barrels a day higher now than it was before the Kuwaiti crisis began, but even so, prices will not fall until there is an easing of tension in the Middle East, W. Henson Moore, the Deputy Secretary of Energy, said at the American Petoleum Institute's annual convention here this morning.    When calm returns, he said, prices will drop to the low $20's, roughly what they were before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.

headline: G.E.'s Net Rises 9% In Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Although its performance was hampered by the weakening of the economy, the General Electric Company said yesterday that its net income climbed 9 percent in the third quarter, to $1.03 billion, from $945 million in the 1989 period.

headline: RJR Nabisco Trims Loss To $86 Million
abstract: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the maker of Camel cigarettes and Oreo cookies, said yesterday that it had narrowed the loss in its third quarter, to $86 million, from $447 million the previous year.   Its sales rose by nearly 18 percent, to $3.53 billion from $3 billion.    Analysts said that the results were in line with expectations and that they were pleased with strong operating earnings that more than covered interest expenses. "These are excellent figures," said John C. Maxwell Jr., an analyst at Wheat First Securities Inc. in Richmond.  Free Cash Flow

headline: Castle Harlan Gets Sharon Steel
abstract: Castle Harlan Inc., a New York merchant bank, said it had completed the acquisition of the steel assets of the Sharon Steel Corporation for more than $300 million.   Sharon Steel, based in Farrell, Pa., had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April 1987. The plan by Castle Harlan, together with Quantum Overseas N.V., a $2 billion investment fund, to bring Sharon Steel out of bankruptcy had been confirmed in November by a Federal bankruptcy judge. The assets acquired by Castle Harlan will continue to be called the Sharon Steel Corporation.

headline: Philip Morris's Ratings Raised
abstract: Citing the Philip Morris Companies' ability to maintain interest and principal payments while expanding operations internally and through acquisition, Moody's Investors Service yesterday raised the company's senior debt rating to A-2, from A-3, and commercial paper rating to Prime-1, from Prime-2.   The senior debt ratings of all subsidiaries, historically higher than the parent company's, were also increased, to A-1 from A-2.    The rating changes affect about $16 billion in long-term debt and should result in more favorable interest rates when the company enters the debt market to raise cash.   Moody's said the upgrading had taken into account the likelihood that Philip Morris would continue to invest heavily to achieve international expansion of its food operations. The rating agency said it expects the company's large cash flow to provide adequate support for debt incurred to finance further diversification.

headline: Market Place; Investors Seeking Safety in Foods
abstract: AS economists argue over whether the nation is in a recession or about to enter one, more investors are seeking safety. Regardless of the state of the economy, they reason, people still eat every day. As a result, the normally stodgy food sector of the market has again become attractive.   Thanks to abundant harvests of basic farm products and growing consumer acceptance of a variety of new products, many food manufacturers have been able to increase their dividends by double-digit percentages this year.

headline: 12 Found Dead After Religious Rite in Mexico
abstract: Twelve people who had taken part in a ceremony to call up spirits were found dead today in a house in this border city, the police said.   Seven others were found sprawled on the floor in a circle formed by rope and were listed in serious condition, a Baja California police spokeswoman said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; Global Vision Gets Readers, but Not in U.S.
abstract: TWELVE years ago, Crocker Snow Jr. -- then a rising star at The Boston Globe -- left the paper to become the founding editor of The World Paper, a monthly newspaper supplement focusing on global issues.    And therein lies a tale of nimble entrepreneurship, an increasing appetite for an international perspective in much of the world and a curious inability of The World Paper to find an audience in its home country.

headline: Waiting for the Zapping of Nintendo
abstract: Will Nintendo, the world's biggest maker of computer games, be zapped this increasingly bleak Christmas? Many stock analysts think so. Nintendo competitors hope so.   Nintendo says, dream on.

headline: Congress Party to Begin Its Turn on Sidelines
abstract: The Congress Party, which led India to independence in 1947, will be sidelined in Parliament this week for the first time, without a formal role in government or the opposition.    When the Parliament is called into full session on Thursday, the leader of the militantly pro-Hindu political party that brought down the Government of V. P. Singh will be installed as leader of the opposition, the speaker of the lower house announced Monday. The Congress Party of Rajiv Gandhi, nevertheless, holds the largest bloc of seats in the Parliament.

headline: McDonald's Hurt By Price Report
abstract: Stock of the McDonald's Corporation dropped $1.125 a share, to 28, on the New York Stock Exchange after an analyst said the fast-food chain was considering permanent price cuts on most basic menu items. But Jack M. Greenberg, McDonald's chief financial officer, disputed the report. He said the company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., was testing "a variety of value strategies" in local markets but had not settled on a systemwide plan.   He said the report, distributed late Wednesday by Caroline Levy, an analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., was "factually inaccurate." Ms. Levy was reported to be out of her office and did not return telephone calls. Most analysts believe McDonald's will announce some price cuts early next year. Wendy's International Inc., a rival chain, recently did so. "They're going to want to reduce prices permanently on items that can still stimulate additional sales of other items," said Leslie Steppel, an analyst at Prudential Bache Securities Inc., referring to McDonald's.

headline: Argentina Asks Death for 2 Army Rebels
abstract: Seeking to demonstrate that military rebellions will no longer be tolerated, the Government and the armed forces are seeking the death penalty for at least two leaders of the army revolt that broke out nearly three weeks ago.   The rebellion by the army dissidents, the fourth in less than four years, was quickly put down by loyalist troops. But it took 21 lives and turned the heart of Buenos Aires into a series of battlegrounds just two days before a visit by President Bush.

headline: Sorting Out Legal War Concerning Real War
abstract: As the prospect of armed conflict in the Persian Gulf stirs increasing discussion, President Bush finds himself challenged by legal questions about his ability to wage war.   The calls in recent days by lawmakers for a special Congressional session to debate Persian Gulf policy have provided new urgency to a 200-year-old debate over how much of a role Congress should have in the President's decision to use combat troops abroad.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    As many as one of every four Americans who bought homes with adjustable-rate mortgages may be paying too much or too little each month because of bank errors in calculating interest rates.  [ Page A1. ]  The F.D.I.C. chairman said the fund that insures deposits would probably lose $4 billion or more this year.  [ D1. ]   About 50 auto insurers that had balked at cutting rates to comply with a rate-rollback law in Pennsylvania have now done so, the state insurance commissioner said.  [ D1. ]  The officers of a group of Southern businesses were charged with defrauding several thousand people by failing to pay $1.9 million in medical claims.  [ A20. ]   President Bush decided to reappoint Robert L. Clarke as the nation's top regulator of nationally chartered banks.  [ D1. ]  Senator Cranston's chief banking aide testified that she did not warn her boss against dealing closely with Charles H. Keating Jr.  [ B10. ]   A Senate survey says drug companies have spent more than $165 million a year on gifts, trips and payments for doctors.  [ B13. ]   Purchasing executives predicted in a survey that the manufacturing economy will be in a recession for the first half of 1991.  [ D2. ] Companies    The chairman of Occidental Petroleum died at age 92. Armand Hammer had long sought peace between the U.S. and the Soviet Union and financed research for a cancer cure.  [ D20. ]  In the 33 years he headed the company, Mr. Hammer shaped Occidental in his own image, pushing it into diverse interests. The new chairman, Ray R. Irani, is expected shift the company's focus.  [ D1. ]   Equitable said it planned to become a publicly owned company. The move is intended to raise much-needed capital.  [ D1. ]   The Daily News will keep publishing as long as it shows progress in overcoming a strike, its publisher said.  [ B1. ]   Pan Am is expected to ask for an extension of a Friday deadline for a payment to creditors.  [ D3. ]   I.B.M. has decided to build its own child-care centers for employees.  [ A20. ]  Texas Instruments said it had reached a new patent cross-licensing agreement with Toshiba.  [ D3. ] International    The Treasury said foreign banks and securities firms are still blocked from competing on equal terms in Japan because of a host of legal and informal hurdles.  [ D18. ] Business Technology    Advances in manufacturing computer chips promise to allow the existing technique to be used for many more years.  [ D1. ] Markets    Weakness in G.M.'s stock helped push the market lower in slow trading. The Dow industrials fell 10.64, to 2,586.14. G.M. fell 1 1/8 after an analyst lowered his earnings estimate for the company.  [ D6. ]  Crude oil for January delivery fell 49 cents a barrel, to $26.41.  [ D4. ]   Treasury bond yields continued their downward march toward 8 percent.  [ D13. ]  Yields on C.D.'s and money market accounts were down again for the week ended yesterday.  [ D11. ]   Gold prices retreated on the Comex, erasing most of the gains made on Monday.  [ D14. ]  The dollar strengthened on news that the Group of Seven countries planned to meet to halt its decline.  [ D14. ] Today's Columns    Orley Ashenfelter is up to his old tricks. The Princeton econometrician and nemesis of wine raters is already predicting that the 1990 French red wines are likely to become the most coveted since the 1961's. Peter Passell: Economic Scene.  [ D2. ]   One of the last big British privatizations took effect, and those who bought shares in 12 regional electric utilities at the initial prices showed big profits. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D6. ]   W. B. Doner won its second big recent victory, gaining a new promotional account for Conagra. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D4. ]

headline: FORUM; Foreign Cures for Ailing Airlines
abstract: SCANDINAVIAN Airlines System's plan to invest $52 million in Continental Airlines is likely to have important implications for the future of many heavily indebted American carriers. The investment, which will nearly double S.A.S.'s stake in Continental, may infuse new vitality into a troubled domestic carrier that lost almost $2 billion during the last three years.  This transaction illustrates how foreign investment can help American aviation cope with some of the undesirable consequences of deregulation and the wave of airline mergers and acquisitions. However, for that to occur, Federal policy makers must relax the longstanding restrictions on foreign investment in United States airlines.

headline: Factory Pact By Compucom
abstract: In a move that would create the nation's second-largest personal computer dealer, after Businessland, Compucom Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Computer Factory Inc., a financially troubled chain of computer retailers with headquarters in Elmsford, N.Y., for $4.50 a share, or $39 million over all.   "Properly handled, they could be a potent factor in the business," said Seymour Merrin, a computer industry analyst at Merrin Information Services.

headline: Article 004090 -- No Title
abstract: The New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency is offering $54.4 million in tax-exempt project revenue bonds for the Beth Israel Medical Center's main campus in Manhattan.    Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company said the maximum yield was 7.585 percent for a bond due in 2010 that carried a coupon of 7.50 percent and was priced at about 98.125.

headline: Patents; Patent Fees Go Up
abstract: The Federal budget measure approved by Congress last week imposes a 69 percent increase in the fees charged by the Patent and Trademark Office for processing patent applications. Large corporations will have to pay $370 for filing an application and $1,050 at the time the patent is issued. Individuals, small businesses and universities will pay $185 and $525, respectively. The increases are expected to generate an additional $100 million, which is intended to make the office essentially self-financing.

headline: Simmons Move On Lockheed
abstract: LEAD: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons said today that he was considering seeking control of the Lockheed Corporation but cautioned that he had not made a final decision.

headline: Officer Shifts At Salomon
abstract: Deryck C. Maughan, who was named vice chairman of Salomon Brothers Inc. last week, will relocate to New York from Tokyo to become co-head of investment banking.   Mr. Maughan, who will become Salomon's fifth vice chairman effective Jan. 1, is expected to take on the investment banking post in New York in mid-1991. He will work with Leo I. Higdon, who is also co-head of investment banking.   Mr. Maughan had been chairman of Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd., and the firm said yesterday that it expected to announce a replacement for that post early next year.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Karlyn Armstrong has been appointed vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago.

headline: 257 Kuwait Evacuees Land at Raleigh Airport
abstract: LEAD: Evacuees from Kuwait arrived here today telling of the continued availability of food in spite of the embargo and a harrowing bus ride at the beginning of their journey home in which Iraqi soldiers tried to ''break us down mentally.''

headline: The Credit Markets;   Treasuries Drop in Volatile Day
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities fell again in volatile trading yesterday, pushed lower by the same unsettling melange of factors that have dominated trading for some time.

headline: And Now a Blast From the Past: Stagflation!
abstract: LEAD: Pornography, like beauty, may be in the eye of the beholder. If so, what is happening to the Federal deficit is patently obscene, says Mark L. Melcher, the director of Washington research for Prudential-Bache Securities.

headline: The Executive Computer; The Latest Convert to Network Religion? Big Blue
abstract: IN what it described as its most significant announcement since the PS/2 family was rolled out in 1987, the International Business Machines Corporation last month introduced two machines at the high end of its personal computer line. Both are based on the powerful 486 microprocessor from the Intel Corporation and use a high-resolution display system designed to show to best advantage all the new graphic-based software. At the same time, I.B.M. came out with an updated version of its OS/2 operating system software.   The new computers are the desktop PS/2 Model 90, with a base price of $12,495, and the floor-standing PS/2 Model 95, which starts at $14,145. Each comes in 25- and 33-megahertz versions. These computers are significant not just for their computational muscle -- there are many other 486-based computers on the market these days, most of which cost far less -- but because they are designed to be upgraded easily to keep pace with future technology.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * British Aerospace P.L.C., London, and Rolls-Royce P.L.C., London, have received a contract to build seven Hawk two-seater training jets for the Finnish Air Force. Terms were not disclosed. * C-Tec Corp., Wilkes-Barre, Pa., a telecommunications company, said it would sell the assets of C-Tec Information Services Co. and C-Tec Management Information Services Inc. to Systematics Inc., Little Rock, Ark., a provider of software and outsourcing services. The purchase price was $12 million, plus a minimum royalty of an additional $3.6 million. * First Western Financial Corp., Las Vegas, Nev., a financial services company, has rescheduled its annual meeting to Feb. 14, from Nov. 29, because it is negotiating the potential sale of the company. * Equifax Inc., Atlanta, a provider of financial data, and Telecredit Inc., Los Angeles, a provider of check authorization and credit card processing, said their shareholders had approved the acquisition of Telecredit by Equifax in a tax-free exchange of 2.8625 shares of Equifax for each share of Telecredit. * Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., Providence, R.I., said it would combine its Norstar Bank of Central New York unit in Syracuse with its Norstar Bank of Upstate New York unit in Albany. * Georgia-Pacific Corp., Atlanta, a paper products company, has completed the sale of 77,000 acres of timberland in Washington to John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co., Boston, for undisclosed terms. * Guinness P.L.C., London, an alcoholic beverage company, said its United Distillers Ltd. unit in Australia would acquire the spirits business of Carlton and United Breweries Ltd. Terms were not disclosed. * Hadson Energy Resources Corp., Oklahoma City, an oil and gas company, and Baruch-Foster Corp., Dallas, an oil and gas company, said the shareholders of Baruch-Foster had approved the merger of Baruch-Foster with a subsidiary of Hanson for $16.9 million. * Inflight Phone Corp., Oak Brook, Ill., a provider of phone service on airplanes, has received Federal Communications Commission approval to provide nationwide air-to-ground radio telephone service. * Ivax Corp., Miami, a medical, chemical and pharmaceutical company, said its shareholders had approved the acquisition of Harris Pharmaceuticals Ltd., a pharmaceutical company in England and Ireland. Ivax issued 6,250,000 shares of common stock worth $73.4 million in exchange for all the outstanding equity securities of Harris. * Sealright Co., Kansas City, Mo., a supplier of packaging for frozen dairy desserts, has completed the purchase of Jaite Packaging, Akron, Ohio, a supplier of packaging for the food and beverage industry, for about $22.6 million and the assumption of $11 million in liabilities. * Youthland Inc., Columbus, Ohio, an owner and operator of children's clothing stores, has filed a voluntary petition of reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

headline: Market Place; Vacation Vehicles In a Steep Slump
abstract: THE sputtering recreational vehicle industry needs a vacation.   Sales of motor homes, travel trailers and plush vans, which are seen by some economists as a leading indicator of economic health, were already in bad shape when Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. That drove the price of oil sharply higher and caused sales to dry up even more. Share prices of publicly held makers of recreational vehicles went into a virtual free fall.   Two years of slumping demand have forced these companies to close plants and slash earnings projections, and some have been telling Wall Street analysts that sales are likely to continue dropping.

headline: World Markets; Bleak Days for British Banks
abstract: AS a group, British bank stocks have been among the world's best performers in the banking sector this year, far outstripping their counterparts in the United States. Five of the top 10 banks in S. G. Warburg Securities' index of world bank stocks are British. And five of the nine major banks in England have outperformed the British stock market.    But much of this performance was built on overly optimistic earnings forecasts earlier in the year and large dividend increases this summer. The bigger payouts look more than a little generous after the economic fallout from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and dividend cuts by several major American banks.

headline: CLASH SITE VISITED BY SOUTH AFRICANS
abstract: Within hours of each other, Nelson Mandela and Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi paid visits today to this black township, where at least 124 people have died in a week of factional fighting.   The fighting has been between residents who support Mr. Mandela's African National Congress and Zulu migrant workers loyal to Mr. Buthelezi's political movement, Inkatha.

headline: Pretoria Adopts Pact on Freeing Political Prisoners
abstract: The South African Government today adopted an agreement it had reached with the African National Congress on a phased release of political prisoners and the return of political exiles, though the two sides differed slightly over the details.    The accord, published in The Government Gazette, emerged from a joint working group authorized at talks in Pretoria between Government and congress officials in August to draft a mutually acceptable compromise for the return of political prisoners andexiles to civilian life. The resolution of their plight was among the conditions set by the African National Congress for its participation in negotiations proposed by President F. W. de Klerk. Timed to Progress

headline: Technology; A New Way to Carve Out Space For Ever-Expanding Piles of Trash
abstract: When John and Jane Q. Public drive by a sanitary landfill, they see no more than a neatened-up mountain of trash. But, oh, what a difference a vested interest makes!    Environmentalists and landfill operators see a rapidly depleting land resource that may soon be harder to find than a buyer for a high-priced apartment. Regulators and landfill neighbors see a potential source of blowing garbage, rats, insects, fires and unspeakable odors -- one reason that every state has a rule that landfill surfaces must be covered with six inches of soil a day.    Paul A. Kittle and Dale Kent see dollar signs.

headline: For Eastern Europe Now, a New Disillusion
abstract: A group of Czechoslovak students, veterans of the demonstrations a year ago that brought down the Communist Government, issued a statement recently urging that the anniversary not be marked this year, because "we don't want former Communist officials coming out cheering and laughing in our faces."    Complaining that the hopes and expectations of the student-led protests of a year ago had become mired in half-measures and disputes, and that old bureaucrats still held sway throughout the Government, they declared, "There's no reason to call our revolution a 'velvet' one."

headline: An Outsider Is Named To Top Steelcase Posts
abstract: Steelcase Inc., the big maker of office furniture, has reached out of its industry for a new president and chief executive, naming Jerry K. Myers to the positions.   Mr. Myers, 49, who comes from the auto-parts business, succeeds Frank H. Merlotti, 64, who has been president since 1980 and chief executive since 1988. Mr. Merlotti will continue as a director, will head the board's executive committee and will be active in international joint-venture operations, the company said.

headline: Drug Maker On L.I. Is Fined
abstract: LEAD: A drug company based on Long Island was fined $1 million today for making illegal cash payoffs to Federal drug reviewers and other law violations that were turned up in a two-year investigation of the generic drug industry.

headline: Baghdad Says It Will Free 78 of 305 Japanese Held
abstract: Stepping up its policy of using hostage releases to deter a war over Kuwait, Iraq announced today that it would reward the visit to Baghdad of Yasuhiro Nakasone, the former Japanese Prime Minister, by freeing 78 of the 305 Japanese citizens it has held since the Kuwait invasion.    The Iraqi announcement, after two meetings in Baghdad between Mr. Nakasone and President Saddam Hussein, meant that the former Japanese leader will be returning to Tokyo with the second largest group of male hostages yet released by Baghdad, after the 298 French citizens who were released and flown to Paris last week. But it appeared to fall short of the hopes of Mr. Nakasone, who arrived in Baghdad at the weekend aboard a chartered Boeing 747 with 350 seats.

headline: Final Chapter in Milken Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: The final chapter in the four-year investigation of Michael R. Milken begins today with a hearing to address a crucial question: Were the crimes of the former financier part of a wide scheme to manipulate markets illegally for his own gain, or were they simply isolated cases of going too far to help a client?

headline: Southwestern Bell Retirement Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Southwestern Bell Corporation's Southwestern Bell Telephone Company unit said it plans to offer incentives for up to 1,600 managers who voluntarily choose to retire or leave the company before the end of the year. Incentives will vary by length of employment, with a maximum payout of one year's salary to managers having more than 20 years of service, Southwestern

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.00   7.87   8.75        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.21   7.23   7.61        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.16   7.18   7.47        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.46   8.49   7.87        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.75   8.77   7.88        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.85   9.89   9.05        MUNICIPAL BONDS*   7.73   7.75   7.34       *Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Germans and Poles Agree to Pact on Oder Border
abstract: German leaders promised their Polish counterparts today that they would join them in signing a treaty this month that would formally establish the Oder and Neisse Rivers as the permanent border between the two countries.    The agreement was announced in this dreary town of 85,000 on the west bank of the river by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland after nearly five hours of talks marked by an unusual display of harmony and trust.

headline: Air Force Begins Calling Up Reservists for the Gulf
abstract: The Air Force has quietly begun calling to active duty hundreds of reservists and members of the National Guard to fly and maintain combat planes in the Persian Gulf.    The crews for attack and fighter jets would be among the first reserve units from any of the services to be sent to the gulf to perform combat missions rather than support jobs.

headline: Communist Paper in U.S. Feels Capitalist Pressure
abstract: The People's Daily World, the American Communist newspaper whose legacy extends back to the 1920's, is trying to revive its sagging fortunes with some decidedly capitalist initiatives: aggressive marketing and prudent cost-cutting.    After years of incurring heavy debts, which were only erased through fund raising, the newspaper's management in June reduced its publication schedule from four issues a week to one and began a campaign to increase circulation. To reflect the changes, the newspaper early this month was renamed The People's Weekly World.

headline: U.S. Said to Want Sanctions Kept After a Pullout
abstract: Seeking to increase the pressure on Iraq, a senior Administration official said today that the United States wants to keep some of the United Nations sanctions against Baghdad in force even if President Saddam Hussein withdraws his army from Kuwait.   The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the sanctions would be left in place to insure that Mr. Hussein "can't keep up his massive military machine," including the nuclear weapons capability that the United States contends Iraq is on the verge of developing.

headline: Suit Is Settled By MGM/UA
abstract: LEAD: MGM/UA has settled a $200 million shareholders' lawsuit for $35 million, and the troubled entertainment company said on Tuesday that it would file suit against insurers that it said had forced MGM/UA into the settlement.

headline: British Say Allies Must Erase Doubts
abstract: Britain's new Prime Minister, John Major, repeated his Government's strong support today for international demands that Iraq pull out of Kuwait by Jan. 15. But members of his Government warned that if Iraq balks, the allies must leave no doubt about their willingness to use military force.    One high-ranking Government official, referring to growing opposition in Congress to the use of force, said the United States would have to "fish or cut bait" soon after the United Nations deadline in mid-January.

headline: Bush Says Recession Is Possible
abstract: President Bush conceded for the first time tonight that the country might face a recession, but he said his economic advisers did not believe a long and severe one was in the offing.   In an interview broadcast on the Cable News Network, the President said, "Most seem to feel that if we have a recession, it will not be deep and that we'll come out of it relatively soon, six months at most, and I'd like to think that is true."

headline: Gold Prices Drop Sharply As Soviet Selloff Is Feared
abstract: LEAD: Gold prices declined sharply today on New York's Commodity Exchange because of fears of a huge Soviet gold selloff, analysts said.

headline: Net Off 4.5% At Gannett
abstract: LEAD: The Gannett Company today reported a 4.5 percent decline in earnings for the third quarter of 1990, primarily because of lower retail newspaper and classified advertising sales.

headline: OPPOSITION LEADER IN BULGARIA QUITS
abstract: Amid growing allegations that he once acted as a secret police informant, the leader of Bulgaria's main opposition political alliance has announced his intention to resign.    The opposition leader, Petar Beron, announced his resignation on Sunday at a meeting of his alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces. He said he would officially step down as of Thursday in order to devote full attention to his work as a zoologist, alliance leaders said in their weekly news conference today.

headline: Arabs Kill Israeli on Bus Near Tel Aviv, Police Say
abstract: One Israeli was killed and five were wounded today in a stabbing attack aboard a bus in Israel, officials said.    The police said three West Bank Palestinians climbed aboard the bus just outside Tel Aviv this morning, rode a few stops sitting in the back, then got up screaming "Allah Akhbar," or God is great, as they drew knives and stabbed four Jewish passengers.

headline: In a Failed Hungarian Factory, Jeans Succeed
abstract: The tall brick wall that slices through the textile factory here is a dividing line between Eastern Europe's dreary economic past and what people here hope will be a brighter economic future.   On one side is a recently closed state-owned sweater factory, where old sewing and knitting machines sit in a darkened room, eerily silent. This is what is left of the Texcoop plant which lost money from the day it opened, having been built not to meet consumer demand but as a favor to a local Communist chieftain who wanted to boast about a new factory.

headline: European Inquiry Is Ordered For Anti-Communist Groups
abstract: The European Parliament called today for an investigation into the activities of secret anti-Communist organizations that were set up in the 1950's to counter a possible Soviet invasion of Western Europe.   In a resolution passed by a vote of 65 to 41 with 13 abstentions, the Parliament also asked the 12 Governments of the European Community to look into possible links between the network of secret groups and right-wing terrorism in Europe over the last two decades.   It urged a "full investigation into the nature, structure, aims and all other aspects" of the clandestine groups.

headline: Playboy Magazine Takes Account In-House
abstract: Payboy magazine has decided to create its advertising in-house, taking it over from Chiat/Day/Mojo, Toronto, which was originally assigned the approximately $2 million account.   "Many changes in management and the distance just made it pretty inconvenient," said Cindy Rakowitz, vice president of public relations for the Chicago-based magazine. "The creative development wasn't going in the direction we thought it would."    The magazine has enlisted the help of a freelance creative director, Don Easdon, who was formerly with Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.   The new ad campaign is scheduled to begin in January.    Executives at Chiat/Day could not be reached for comment.

headline: Pope, in Christmas Message, Warns on a Gulf War
abstract: Pope John Paul II delivered a blunt admonition to world leaders today that war in the Persian Gulf would be "an adventure with no return."    In his annual Christmas message, "Urbi et Orbi" -- "To the City and the World" -- the Pope called for talks to resolve the crisis. But at the same time, he seemed to suggest that Iraq had to withdraw from Kuwait, saying "the inalienable rights of people and nations" must be respected.

headline: A Major Design Shift at Digital
abstract: Searching for a way out of its two-year financial stall, the Digital Equipment Corporation is continuing to move away from the computer design on which it based it business for more than a decade.   Digital became the nation's second-largest computer maker largely on the strength of software and hardware that was compatible from the top to the bottom of its product line. But last week, the company, which is based in Maynard, Mass., introduced its second fresh computer design in the last two years. The latest machines are small-business minicomputers based on a chip made by the Intel Corporation. Yielding to Unix

headline: Oil Down $1.71 After Big Swings
abstract: LEAD: Oil prices fell yesterday after bouncing up and down on war worries and then on rumors that Saddam Hussein had been assassinated.

headline: Maxicare Finishes Its Reorganization
abstract: Maxicare Health Plans Inc. said it had emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization profitable and at half its old size. The health maintenance organization said it made money in the quarter ended Sept. 30, its first profitable quarter in four years.   Maxicare operates in California, Indiana, Illinois, Louisiana, North Carolina, South Carolina and Wisconsin. It filed reorganization plans 21 months ago with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Santa Ana, Calif. Creditors and shareholders will receive about $130 million in cash, 10-year notes at 13.5 percent interest with a face value of about $67 million and common stock and options.

headline: Pressed, Premier Shuffles Japan's Cabinet Again
abstract: Bowing to pressure from his political patrons and underlings, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu today carried out a sweeping revision of his Cabinet but indicated that he expected no major shifts of policy in the 10 months left in his term of office.   Although the Cabinet shuffling was seen as having little substantive effect, it underscored the precarious hold that Mr. Kaifu continues to have on his job and offered a revealing glimpse into the feuding that rages in Japanese politics beneath the placid surface.

headline: Next: Artificial Bone To Repair Fractures
abstract: After years of uncertain progress, a handful of companies are closing in on one of the most exotic goals of orthopedic surgery: artificial bone, grown from proteins in a jar.    To be sure, most of the new compounds will not be commercially available for at least five years. Even then, doctors will not be able to heal fractures overnight. But an array of new technologies could strikingly simplify the task of repairing completely broken limbs. It could also make it easier to reconstruct jaws ravaged by cancer and improve the durability of artificial knees and hips.

headline: Baker and Shevardnadze: Link Breaks
abstract: When he was a lawyer in Houston, James A. Baker 3d was called "the panther" by some of his adversaries and even a few of his friends, who thought the nickname fitting for someone so skilled at pouncing on weakness in an opponent or an argument.    So perhaps it was fitting that his closest and most important relationship with a top foreign official during his first two years as Secretary of State was with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, who announced his resignation in Moscow today. In Georgian, the language of his native republic on the Soviet Union's border with Turkey, Mr. Shevardnadze's family name is related to the word meaning "falcon."

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Aeromexico, a subsidairy of Aerovias de Mexico C.V., Mexico City, appointed Guillermo Heredia president. * Discover Re Managers, Farmington, Conn., a reinsurance group, appointed Albert Collings executive vice president and chief financial officer; Gregory Berg executive vice president; Rhonda Miller a vice president, and Robert Schultz assistant vice president for underwriting and marketing. * Federal National Mortgage Association, Washington, known as Fannie Mae, named Martin D. Levine and Thomas W. White senior vice presidents. Appointed vice presidents were Violetta Kapsalis, Donna M. Callejon, Deborah L. Cohen, Bess Donaldson, Jane Orahood, Julie St. John, Daniel C. Smith and Paul R. Vergets. * Oracle Corp., Redwood Shores, Calif., a subsidiary of Oracle Systems Corp., Belmont, Calif., a software company, appointed Terence J. Garnett vice president of corporate marketing. * Sotheby's Inc., New York, a unit of Sotheby's Holdings Inc., Bloomfield Hills, Mich., the auction and realty concern, named Diana D. Brooks president and chief executive. * Three-Five Systems Inc., Phoenix, a maker of optical displays and keyboards, named James F. Bowser senior vice president for sales and marketing, and Frank A. Polimene vice president of operations.

headline: Union Leader in Brazil Slain After Defying Sugar Barons
abstract: A rural union leader who had defied powerful sugar barons in northeastern Brazil has been shot to death, the police said today.   They said Jose Helio da Silva had been shot down in a sugar cane field on Thursday near the Farm Workers Union headquarters in Palmares, a sugar-producing town in Pernambuco state, 1,600 miles northeast of here.   The Palmares police chief, Joaquim Donati, said Mr. da Silva and the union's treasurer, Jose Cicero Leite, had been driving along a highway when a car started chasing them.   "They stopped the car and hid in a cane field, but the gunmen found them," Mr. Donati said. He said Mr. Leite had been wounded in the left leg.   The slaying occurred on the second day of the trial of two ranchers accused of ambushing and killing an environmentalist and union leader, Chico Mendes, in Brazil's Amazon region in 1988. Mr. da Silva had recently received an anonymous letter warning that he would "end up like Chico Mendes," said the president of the Farm Workers Union, Joao Luca da Silva, who is not related.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Asea Brown Boveri Inc., Stamford, Conn., a unit of ABB-Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., Zurich, a provider of steam, gas and hydro turbines, appointed Richard J. Slember president of its United States power plant businesses and executive vice president of ABB Inc. * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., an advanced technology company, named Donald J. Redlinger senior vice president of human resources. * DPL Inc., Dayton, Ohio, a gas and electric holding company, appointed Thomas M. Jenkins group vice president and treasurer. * Definicon International Corp., a unit of Helionetics Inc., Irvine, Calif., which makes computers, named Joseph Z. Perry president and chief executive. * First Interstate Bank of California, a subsidiary of First Interstate Bankcorp, Los Angeles, appointed Susan Whipple vice president and manager of its South Anaheim office. * General Public Utilities Corp., Parsippany, N.J., named Susan S. Schepman vice president in charge of communications.  * Hansen Manufacturing Company,a subsidiary of IMC Magnetics Corp., Jericho, L.I., promoted William K. Poyner to president. * Kansas City Power and Light Co., Kansas City, Mo., said its president and chief executive, Drue Jennings, would take on the added post of chairman on Jan. 1, succeeding Arthur J. Doyle. * McDermott International Inc., New Orleans, a pipeline holding company, appointed M. E.
