Eagles vice president of marketing, engineering and its industrial groups. * Tultex Corp., Martinsville, Va., a clothing manufacturer, named Walter J. Caruba vice president of distribution and James M. Baker secretary and treasurer.

headline: United German Parliament Assembles
abstract: LEAD: Germany's united Parliament held its first session in the old Reichstag today, and after the ritual tributes to union, the politicians plunged into the next major stage of reunification, the campaign for the Dec. 2 national elections.

headline: Patents; Prolonging the Crunch And Freshness in Food
abstract: It may be a step away from natural foods, but the Procter & Gamble Company has patented a group of polyester food coatings. The company says the coatings provide a moisture barrier that can keep the crunch in rice cereals and saltine crackers, while preserving the moisture in fresh fruits, vegetables, meat and fish.   The coatings consist of sucrose fatty-acid polyesters and are somewhat similar to Olestra, the synthetic, nondigestible fat substitute that the company invented and that is awaiting approval by the Food and Drug Administration. According to the patent, the compounds have long been considered possible fat substitutes, but this is the first time researchers have described their ability to block the transmission of moisture.    According to the patent, the possible uses include keeping cereal from becoming soggy with milk; keeping raisins, prunes and other dried fruit from becoming sticky and clumped together; preventing frozen foods from drying out in frost-free freezers, and keeping bakery products from going stale.    The patent is silent on the key issue of how the coating affects the taste of food, and company officials refused to comment. P.&G. has not announced any plans to commercialize the technology.    Jeffrey J. Kester, Christian A. Bernhardt and three other researchers received patent 4,960,600.

headline: Beijing Journal; Chinese Cartoonist Is the Master of the Fine Line
abstract: In a country where bold is bad, artists sometimes think more about diplomacy -- about tiptoeing on a thread of silk -- than they do about drawing. Ding Cong is such a diplomat: he is a consummate political cartoonist who never raises the topic of politics.   At a time when people are thrown in jail for openly criticizing the Government, Mr. Ding's black and white drawings stand out because they dare to satirize the leadership and the tensions in Chinese society. But these days, Mr. Ding has mastered tact and subtlety, a far cry from his younger days when he would paint scrolls streaming with flashy evil-doers, distorted and contorted, to portray his views of the Chinese Nationalists.

headline: Cray Earnings Off 9.8%
abstract: Cray Research Inc., based in Minneapolis, yesterday reported declining earnings and revenues for the third quarter, which the company said had been expected. New orders fell. The company reported earnings of $27.6 million, or 99 cents a share, down 9.8 percent from $30.6 million, or $1.04 a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues fell 11.2 percent, to $186.6 million from $210.2 million. "While we continue to expect flat revenue this year, we see significant opportunities to improve 1990 earnings over last year," said John A. Rollwagen, the chairman and chief executive. Cray's stock jumped $2.25 a share yesterday, to $27.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: 582 Are Laid Off At Electric Boat
abstract: LEAD: The Electric Boat shipyards gave layoff notices to 582 employees in Groton and Quonset Point, R.I., citing declining military orders and uncertainty about Federal military expenditures. The layoffs, mainly of support personnel, represent less than 3 percent of the total work force of Electric Boat, a division of the General Dynamics Corporation.

headline: Taiwan Sees Trade Growth
abstract: LEAD: Taiwan expects to be among the world's 10 largest trading nations by 1996 when its foreign trade is expected to hit nearly $200 billion, the Board of Foreign Trade said Sunday.

headline: Pennzoil Net Drops 25%
abstract: The Pennzoil Company, an oil and gas concern, said today that third-quarter earnings dropped 25 percent, partly because higher crude oil prices cut into refining revenue. Profits of $26.4 million, or 66 cents a share, compared with earnings of $35.4 million, or 87 cents a share, in the quarter last year. Revenue rose 13.5 percent, to $615.4 million. "Motor oil sales in the third quarter were at an all-time high, but we were unable to adjust product prices to fully recover the surge in crude costs," said James L. Pate, president and chief executive.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Co., New York, appointed Bernie Hamilton to the new position of chief of staff in its travel related services group. * Hallmark Cards Inc., Kansas City, Mo., named Henry F. Frigon executive vice president of corporate development and strategy. He was also named chief financial officer. * Howtek Inc., Hudson, N.H., a maker of ink jet printers and copiers, appointed Paul R. White vice president of graphic arts in its colorscan division. * LTX Corp., a designer of computer-controlled equipment in Westwood, Mass., named Clyde M. Armstrong vice president. * Madison Square Garden Corp., a unit of Paramount Communications Inc., New York, appointed Bruce Moran vice president of its enterprises unit. * Merrill Lynch & Co., New York, named Patrick J. Walsh senior vice president of human resources. * Unisys Computer Systems Group, San Jose, Calif., promoted John Chen to vice president and general manager of its Unix systems group. * Vitalink Communications Corp., Fremont, Calif., which manufactures office network equipment, appointed Tony Banta, Art Klein, Maureen Lawrence and Paul Schaller vice presidents.

headline: Meeting of African National Congress Calls for Continued Sanctions Against Pretoria
abstract: The African National Congress appealed today for sanctions to be maintained against South Africa, rejecting warnings from within its leadership that they were eroding.    The call, made in a resolution adopted on the second day of the congress's consultative conference, came as leaders of the European Community nations, meeting in Rome, lifted a ban imposed in 1986 on new investments in South Africa, so as to reward the initiatives undertaken by President F. W. de Klerk to begin dismantling apartheid.

headline: Military Contractor Is Fined
abstract: LEAD: A manufacturer of the Army's main tactical field radio was ordered today to pay $3.8 million for conspiring to defraud the Government on military contracts by falsifying test results.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt * Clark County, Nev., is offering $15 million in tax-exempt 7.125 percent adjustable tender pollution-control revenue bonds, due in 2009, for Southern California Edison Co. projects, priced at about 97.25 to yield 7.40 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The bonds are expected to be rated AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and for some investors they are subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax. * Discover Receivables Financing Group Inc., a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Co., Chicago, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $500 million in Discover Card Trust 1990-E credit card pass-through certificates. The underwriting syndicate will be managed by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. * Clark Oil and Refining Corp., Toronto, a 60 percent owned subsidiary of the Horsham Corp., has established a two-year $150 million line of credit with a syndicate of international banks led by the Bankers Trust Co. * Nova Scotia Power Corp., which is a wholly owned corporation of the Province of Nova Scotia, has filed for up to $400 million in debentures. Ratings  * Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc.'s senior debt rating has been downgraded to Baa-2, from Baa-1, by Moody's Investors Service, which also lowered the commercial paper rating to Prime-3, from Prime-2. The bank holding company is based in Providence, R.I.

headline: Fannie Mae Will Provide $14.1 Billion for Mortgages
abstract: LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, announced yesterday that it had made separate agreements with six mortgage banking companies, whereby Fannie Mae would provide $14.1 billion in financing for about 170,000 single-family home mortgages throughout the United States.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: CONOMY    White House officials stormed out of budget negotiations at the Capitol, accusing Democrats of being unwilling to negotiate a fair tax compromise on the $145 billion package of new revenues over five years. Until the talks halted abruptly, the differences of the two sides appeared to be narrowing.  [ Page A1. ]   Congressional negotiators agreed on new air-quality rules to reduce damage to the environment caused by acid rain.  [ A1. ]     The big New York banks are considering which of their neighbors would make the best merger partners. The banks need to pool their resources to compete against stronger foreign rivals.  [ D1. ]     The nation's wildcatters are wary about the recent surge in oil prices. Most have turned from oil to gas and are skeptical that prices will stay high after the Middle East crisis is resolved.  [ D2. ]     The savings industry bailout could cost more because of conflict between Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and the chairman of the House Banking Committee, Henry Gonzalez.  [ D10. ] COMPANIES    Digital Equipment is moving away from the emphasis on compatibility for its hardware and software. Its new machines are based on an Intel chip and it is about to announce that its VAX line will be able to run Unix system programs.  [ D1. ]     Pathe Communications agreed to sell the exclusive rights to show some of Hollywood's most popular films to Turner Broadcasting if Pathe finally acquires MGM/UA Communications.  [ D1. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS    CBS was a big loser in the World Series. The Cincinnati Reds' four-game sweep could cost CBS $150 million in lost advertising, some television executives say. Television.  [ D1. ]     El Al Israel Airlines has begun a television campaign in the face of turmoil in the Middle East. The ads rely on historical footage about the Zionist movement, which laid the foundation for the creation of the state of Israel. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D1. ]     Many communications companies are running into a troubling fact: Selling magazines, book publishers and other media properties has suddenly become a very arduous task.  [ D12. ]     In troubled times, people turn to prophets and religion. So for authors, publishers and retailers of books on these topics, the Persian Gulf crisis has brought plenty of good news.  [ D12. ]     Music videos and cassette singles are booming in the music business. As it becomes more difficult to promote new music groups, record companies are expanding their product lines.  [ D12. ] INTERNATIONAL    Four years of talks on world trade are threatened with collapse as a result of the European Community's failure to accept even a modest plan to reduce farm subsidies.  [ D1. ]     Europe regained lost momentum in its push to create a single currency and central bank, when German Chancellor Helmut Kohl backed the start of a second stage in the process in 1994.  [ D8. ]     The Parisian futures exchange, the Matif, is challenging London's dominance of European trading.  [ D8. ]     U.S. officials are encountering stiff opposition to their efforts to crack the shell of secrecy surrounding Panama's banks.  [ A1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS    The U.S. economy no longer has the abundance of natural resources that formed the base for the country's industrial might. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene.  [ D2. ]     Occidental Petroleum stood to gain from the oil price surge, but it depends more on its chemical business than on its oil operations and has been badly hurt in the broad retreat in the chemical industry. Market Place.  [ D10. ]     American investors in bonds are following foreigners out of the country's financial markets, some economists and portfolio managers say. Credit Markets.  [ D11. ]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1990
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: Argentine Phone Sale Is Snagged
abstract: LEAD: Argentina's efforts to sell the outdated, deficit-ridden telephone company hit a snag when the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation failed to provide the $2.2 billion worth of foreign debt paper needed by the Thursday night deadline to finance the Bell Atlantic Corporation's purchase of half of the company.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Circle K Corp., Phoenix, a convenience-store chain operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, received approval from the bankruptcy court to sell the majority of its properties in Hawaii to Texaco Inc.'s refining and marketing unit for almost $22.3 million. * Eaton Corp., Cleveland, a maker of engineered products, acquired EAC Technologies Corp., Cary, Ill., a maker of electronic controls for appliances. Terms were not disclosed. * Furrari Inc., New York, a fur dealer, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. * General Dynamics Corp., St. Louis, was awarded a $765 million contract to build one Ohio class submarine for the Navy. The work is to be done in Groton, Conn., and Quonset Point, R.I. * Geritech Inc. will form an alliance with Marion Merrell Dow Inc., a pharmaceuticals company, to develop a new biomedical technology. * International Business Machines Corp., Armonk, N.Y., further delayed the release of its Officevision software that links computers. It said no date had been set for deliveries.  * Loral Corp., New York, an electronics concern, received a $202.4 million contract from Intelsat for two VII-A communications satellites. * Lufthansa A.G., the German airline, expects the Bonn Government to draw up a treaty to allow it to take over the former East German airline Interflug. * Nissan Motor Co., Tokyo, said it would build a component plant in northern Japan to increase its capacity to supply luxury vehicles. * Philips N.V., the troubled Dutch electronics company, might be broken up and sold in pieces if its cost-cutting plan fails, according to its president, Jan D. Timmer. * Sara Lee Corp., Chicago, a foods company, received approval from Hungary to acquire a significant interest in the Compack Trading and Packing Company, Hungary's third-largest food company. * Union Carbide Canada Ltd., Toronto, plans to sell its chemicals and plastics business for $120 million to its majority shareholder, the Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Company.  * UPSA Group, a French drug company, said Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, the pharmaceuticals and personal-care products company, had completed its acquistion of a significant minority interest in UPSA. * Westinghouse Electronic Systems Group, a unit of Westinghouse Electric Corp., will acquire Schlage Electronics, Santa Clara, Calif., a maker of electronic access-control systems.

headline: Dow Rises 14.11 in a Sharp Turnaround
abstract: The stock market came to life in the final half-hour of trading yesterday after unconfirmed reports that Iraq might be ready to leave Kuwait if certain conditions were met.   The Dow Jones industrial average had been moving sharply lower in slugglish trading for practically the entire day. But minutes after the Reuters news service carried the 3:28 P.M. report on Iraq, volume soared and the Dow bounced back sharply, ending the day at 2,579.70, up 14.11 points.

headline: The Danger of Short-Term Thinking
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: 28 Planes Leased By 10 Airlines
abstract: The International Lease Finance Corporation, a subsidiary of American International Group Inc., said it had leased 28 jet aircraft to 10 airlines. The aircraft have a combined value of $806 million.    Among the deals completed were the leasing of four new Airbus A320-200 jets to Canadian Airlines International. Canadian Airlines also leased three Boeing 737-200 aircraft on short-term sale leasebacks until the new A320's arrive. Iberia's Viva division, Madrid, also leased four used Boeing 737-300's on four-year leases through 1994.

headline: 6 Killed in Ethnic Violence in Moldavia
abstract: Weeks of nationalist tensions in Soviet Moldavia turned to violence today as 6 people were reported killed and 30 wounded after Moldavian vigilantes entered a predominantly Russian-speaking town in the republic's separatist eastern region.    Initial reports by Tass, the Soviet press agency, said the violence occurred near Dubossary in the republic's Dniester River region, where a minority of Russian speakers and Ukrainians have declared their own republic and independence from Moldavia.

headline: FORUM; Time for the Ex-Im Bank to Fade Away
abstract: CONGRESS struggled mightily to cut the deficit, yet one very large sacred cow still lives: the Export-Import Bank. Created in 1934 to subsidize trade with the Soviet Union, the bank since then has grown to subsidize exports to countries around the world.  In its budget plan for 1991, the Bush Administration proposed reducing the bank's loans to $500 million from $612 million, but Congress decided to   increase   the bank's lending, by nearly 23 percent to $750 million. Loan guarantees and insurance will also rise under the new budget reduction plan.

headline: Company News;   Enron Names New President
abstract: LEAD: The Enron Corporation, operator of the nation's largest natural gas transmission system, said yesterday that it had named Richard D. Kinder president and chief operating officer.

headline: A Lower Mortgage Rate
abstract: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.9 percent this week, down from 9.93 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.

headline: U.S. and Thailand in Trade Dispute
abstract: The Bush Administration has put Thailand on notice that it will consider imposing retaliatory tariffs unless the protection of American copyrights is improved.   The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, announced that she had begun an investigation into Thailand's copyright enforcement practices.   "We have repeatedly expressed our strong concern to Thai officials at all levels that the rights of U.S. copyright holders are not adequately safeguarded," Mrs. Hills said in a statement."Unfortunately, we have seen no improvement in Thailand's willingness to shut down the considerable illegal copying of U.S. movies, music, books and computer software or to insure that U.S. companies obtain prompt and effective redress through Thailand's legal system," she said.   Mrs. Hills acted after receiving a petition on Nov. 15 from the Motion Picture Association of America, the International Intellectual Property Alliance and the Recording Industry Association of America.

headline: Shearson Move To Chiat/Day
abstract: Chiat/Day/Mojo's New York office picked up the $20 million account for the Shearson Lehman Brothers division of the American Express Company. The agency currently handles the American Express Gold Card.    "We're very excited," said Bob Perkins, president and chief operating officer of Chiat/Day/Mojo New York. "It's a wonderful endorsement of our strategic capabilities."

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: LEAD:            Net      Percent       Income      Change                $      Net Income   Percent        July-Sept.   Change        1990   From '89        Archer-Daniels-Midland Co.   $ 107,700,000 -   8.1        Boise Cascade Corp.   13,900,000    -77.9        Bruno's Inc.   15,400,000    +20.3        Cooper Tire & Rubber Co.

headline: A Year After the Wall, Some Nostalgia
abstract: Like all Berliners, Jan Faktor and his wife, Annette Simon, were dumbfounded when the Berlin wall opened a year ago on Friday.    Now, mixed in with the euphoria aroused by the impending anniversary the couple admit to feelings of nostalgia for a time before the wall gave way when the lines between the East German Government and its opponents were clearly drawn, and when people could define themselves against the course set by the Communist Government.

headline: Bank of New York
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of New York has purchased Bank of New England Associates, the investment banking subsidiary of the Bank of New England, for an undisclosed price. The subsidiary will be renamed Bank of New York Associates and will act as an intermediary in arranging mergers, acquisitions, private placements of debt, equity securities and financial restructuring services.

headline: Market Place; Questions About First Chicago
abstract: WITH the shares of the First Chicago Corporation down more than 40 percent this year, some people might rate the stock of the big bank holding company a "buy." After all, if First Chicago traded at $35 a share in the last year on the strength of its leading market position in the Middle West, then at its current price below $20, the stock is surely a bargain.   That, at least, might be an argument on behalf of the company. But to hear most Wall Street analysts tell it, First Chicago is anything but a buy and should probably be sold short in anticipation of further price declines.

headline: Payment Plan at Shearson Aims to Keep Best Brokers
abstract: Wall Street firms are expanding the use of compensation programs to keep their best brokers. Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. told its employees yesterday that it was creating a two-tiered deferred compensation plan to reward the brokers who increased their production while keeping customer complaints low.    The plan will also reward many of the firm's 9,000 brokers for not having left during Shearson's recent years of financial trouble, which ended with the firm being repurchased earlier this year by the American Express Company. Follows Merrill Plan     The Shearson announcement came shortly after Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage, decided to restructure its broker compensation system. One aspect is rewarding brokers with $100,000 if they remain with the firm for 10 more years. The Merrill plan also puts newly hired brokers on salary instead of the traditional commission system.

headline: Investments in Korea
abstract: Faced with rising local wages and other problems, foreign corporate investors withdrew $110 million from South Korea in the first nine months of 1990, the Finance Ministry said today. Withdrawals of direct foreign investment from the country totaled $75 million in 1989 and $48 million in 1988. Approvals of new foreign capital investment from January to September totaled $632 million, down 26.9 percent from the corresponding period last year, ministry officials said.

headline: Censure Vote May Topple Government in France
abstract: France's Socialist Prime Minister, Michel Rocard, today faces the most serious political challenge since he took office 30 months ago -- a censure vote in the National Assembly in which conservatives and Communists are expected to combine against him.   If his opponents win a no-confidence vote related to a social security tax measure, Mr. Rocard's Government could fall. The situation also reflects strains in the relationship between Mr. Rocard and the Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand. The censure vote was put forward on Friday by conservative deputies who are supported by Communists.

headline: Bhutto's Trial Becomes Main Issue in Election
abstract: LEAD: In a country with problems of runaway population growth, environmental destruction, the abuse of women, child labor and a foundering economy, the principal issue in the national election campaign is none of these, but rather whether Benazir Bhutto is guilty of the Government's charges against her.

headline: Grand Met and Elders Blocked on Beer Deal
abstract: LEAD: Britain today blocked a venture between Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Elders IXL Ltd., but the Government gave the companies time to come up with a scaled-down proposal that would not threaten competition in the beer industry.

headline: S.E.C. Bill Is Passed By House
abstract: LEAD: The House of Representatives gave final approval today to changes in the laws governing violations of securities regulations, the second piece of major securities legislation to be passed in the last week.

headline: Four-Page Ad Glows And Sings 'Silver Bells'
abstract: While national holiday advertising campaigns have been decidedly ho- hum this season, an ad for a Houston shopping center is as festive and fun as they come.   The ad, created for Highland Village, is a four-page musical and electrical "greeting card." The first page shows a Christmas bulb, and when it is turned, a two-page spread is shown, with palm trees that light up while the carol "Silver Bells" plays. The back page gives details about the shopping center. The ad will run in Houston Metropolitan magazine.   "Our concept was to produce a very unique and memorable insertion that would appeal to the sophisticated shopper," said Stephen Rogers, executive vice president of Fogarty & Klein, the Houston agency that created the ad. "Everyone who sees it has the same reaction -- 'Wow!' "

headline: A Nuveen Fund's Tax-Exempt Issue
abstract: LEAD: John Nuveen & Company is offering $250 million in tax-exempt preferred stock from one of its sponsored funds, the Nuveen Investment Quality Municipal fund, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Each underwriter served as lead manager for two of the four series priced.

headline: President and the G.I.'s: He Will Get Respect
abstract: President Bush's Thanksgiving visit here, along with military exercises and steps in Middle East diplomacy, form part of what is shaping up as a major effort to show American resolve in the Persian Gulf.    White House and Pentagon advance teams are carefully planning Mr. Bush's visit, apparently determined to avoid the problems that marred recent visits by the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell, and by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.

headline: Very Weak Ad Sales Trouble TV Networks
abstract: LEAD: Coming on the heels of disappointing ratings at the start of the new television season, the broadcast networks now appear to be facing the weakest fourth-quarter market for advertising in at least the last decade.

headline: Fujitsu Introduces Portable Computer
abstract: LEAD: Fujitsu Ltd. displayed a notebook-sized personal computer that is the lightest ever made in Japan and that the company hopes will win it a prime spot in the computer industry's fast-growing portable market. The machine weighs 2.2 pounds. Fujitsu and the Poqet Computer Corporation of the United States, in which it has a majority stake, have developed a one-pound model for the American market, a

headline: BMW Lifts Prices
abstract: BMW of North America Inc. said its 1991 cars would cost an average 3.6 percent more than comparably equipped 1990 models. All of the West German-made luxury-performance cars will be covered by a four-year, 50,000-mile limited warranty, the company said. Prices for 1991 BMW cars range from $19,900 for the 318i to $73,600 for the 850i.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Quality Bakers of America Cooperative Inc., Greenwich, Conn., to GSD&M, Austin, Tex., for its Sunbeam and Sunbeam Lite breads business, with undisclosed billings. The account was previously handled by Buntin Advertising, Nashville.

headline: U.S. Envoy to China Has Quarrel With Rights Protestors in Seattle
abstract: The United States Ambassador to China, James Lilley, called demonstrators against Chinese human-rights abuses "cowards" when they confronted him here Saturday night, and he suggested that one man, a Tibetan, "go back to China and serve China."   But in a speech a few minutes later, Mr. Lilley said the United States wanted to see "concrete improvement on China's human rights record," and referred to the lifting of martial law in Tibet as "window dressing."

headline: American Buying Eastern Assets
abstract: American Airlines bought $10 million worth of Canadian routes and other assets from Eastern Airlines. Eastern sold its route authority for New York-Newark and Montreal-Ottawa along with 10 gates at La Guardia Airport in New York. The deal also includes gates at Montreal's Dorval Airport and at Orlando, Fla., Nashville and Hartford.   The transaction is subject to approval by the Government and the bankruptcy court. Eastern has been in bankruptcy reorganization since March 1989. The sale will leave Eastern with Miami-Toronto and Tampa-Toronto as its only Canadian service.

headline: Saatchi Says Hard Times Will Stay With It a While
abstract: FOR Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., the future looks even bleaker than the recent past.    The advertising giant yesterday reported a loss for the year ended Sept. 30 that was much greater than the loss in the previous year. And Saatchi executives stunned the financial community with an unusually grim forecast for next year.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;  Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * NBC and the Cablevision Systems Corp.'s pay-per-view account to DMB&B; Entertainment, Los Angeles, for all media planning and buying, with undetermined billings. Other agencies are handling the creative aspects of the account, which has a budget of more than $40 milion.

headline: Careers; Retainer Fees for Management Recruiters
abstract: MANY management recruiting firms have been developing a new way to stabilize their revenues, by encouraging client companies to pay retainer fees.   The firms have been doing this quietly in recent years for competitive reasons, but with recession concerns deepening, it is becoming more and more prevalent.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE FOR VOLUNTARY CONTRIBUTIONS TO PROGRAMS OF U.N.H.C.R.  -- 10 A.M.

headline: Secret-Police Scandals Outlive East Germany
abstract: On Oct. 3, the night of German unity, East Germany's police shed their drab gray suits and donned the bright green uniforms of West Germany. But shedding old ways of doing business is proving to be more difficult in the lingering presence of so many veterans of the defunct Communist police state.    The former Communist secret police, the Stasi, was one of the largest and most efficient political-police operations in East Europe. It had 85,000 full-time agents and, by some estimates, more than 500,000 part-time informants.

headline: 20 Million United Payment Aids Pan Am Cash Position
abstract: Pan American World Airways' cash position was strengthened yesterday by United Airlines, which paid ahead of time for assets that it had bought, making $20 million available.    The infusion, however, does not solve Pan Am's problem of how to survive a winter when traffic is low and fuel prices have been unusually high, as a result of the crisis in the Middle East.

headline: Natural Gas Use Slowed By Weather
abstract: Winter, or the lack of it, is sending a chill through the natural gas market. And after a string of mild winters in the Northeast, slack demand is starting to erode gas prices and squeeze drillers and pipeline operators.    It was not supposed to be this way. The invasion of Kuwait made oil, gas's big competitor, double in price, and was a reminder that a growing fraction of the nation's oil is imported, while nearly all gas comes from the United States and Canada. And geologists say that unlike oil, large quantities of natural gas almost certainly await discovery in North America.

headline: Woolrich to Lay Off Half of Work Force
abstract: LEAD: Woolrichi Inc., which primarily manufactures outdoor clothing, will lay off more than half its 2,600 employees nationwide because it has few orders for deliveries beyond December.

headline: Second Homes;  Vacation Communities Rise in Catskills
abstract: LEAD: Once known primarily for its huge resort hotels, New York's Sullivan County has been evolving into a prime site for second homes over the last seven years. Vacation communities are springing up in clusters within the open fields, hills and thick woodlands of the Catskill Mountains.

headline: Lebanese General Seeking Exile As Syria Tightens Grip on Beirut
abstract: LEAD: As thousands of Syrian troops tightened their grip on sectors of East Beirut that they entered on Saturday, the defeated Christian chief, Gen. Michel Aoun, remained stranded today at the French Embassy here, waiting while France negotiates with the Lebanese Government to allow the general safe passage into exile.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Common Stock * Comcast International L.P., Philadelphia, an affiliate of the Comcast Corp., announced on Friday the postponement of an offering of its units of limited partnership interest because of unfavorable market conditions. Ratings * Bank of Boston Corp.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to B-1, from Ba-2, by Moody's Investors Service. * CalFed Inc.'s subordinated debt rating has been reduced to B, from BB+, by Standard & Poor's. The financial services holding company is based in Los Angeles. * First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to BB-, from BBB-, and commerical paper rating to B, from A-3, by S.&P. The bank holding company is based in Houston. * Michigan National Corp.'s subordinated debt rating has been reduced to BBB-, from BBB+, by S.& P. The company is based in Farmington Hills, Mich. * Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia's power revenue and general power revenue bond rating has been increased to A-1, from A, and subordinated bond rating to A, from Baa-1, by Moody's.

headline: Jump in Oil Profits Is Expected
abstract: Many major oil companies will post sharply higher profits this quarter. Prices of crude oil and natural gas are far higher than they were last year, and fewer companies are likely to report big charges against earnings, as they did a year ago.   In fact, some companies may double their profits and touch off renewed charges of profiteering. But even with this strong fourth quarter, the industry will probably fall short of its expectations a year ago that it would increase earnings from operations by more than 10 percent in 1990.

headline: The Cartographic Underclass
abstract: To the Editor:   More accurate mapmaking via computers sounds fine ("With Computers, Mapmakers Are Redrawing the World," Dec. 2), but it is alarming to learn that one new projection claims "to better represent the shapes of third world countries that, some say, have been slighted by mainstream publishers." Just what is the underlying concept here? Are we to understand that the Horn of Africa has hitherto been maliciously made to look like a lumbering rhino instead of a graceful antelope?   In an already paranoid world, in which every race, ethnic group and gender considers itself "slighted," I hope we are not setting up a new category of victimhood: the cartographically disadvantaged. LOUIS JAY HERMAN  New York, Dec.5

headline: Paramaribo Journal; In Suriname's Racial Jumble, a Quest for Identity
abstract: At this country's largest mosque, a geaming white structure dominated by four towering minarets, Annette Ayub, a woman of Christian and Hindu parents who practices no religion, watches over the grounds. Her husband, the mosque's muezzin, who is of Pakistani descent, calls the faithful to prayer.   When asked if she is resented as an outsider by the Muslims who gather nearby for prayer, Mrs. Ayub said with surprise, "Never, this is Suriname and I am Surinamese."

headline: Bulgarian Premier Quits After 2 Weeks of Protests
abstract: Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov, a Socialist who was a Politburo member in the Communist Party that governed here for 45 years, resigned tonight after two weeks of loud but peaceful street protests and a four-day strike that paralyzed much of the country.   Mr. Lukanov, who had been head of Bulgaria's Government since February, announced his resignation to a national television audience as thousands of anti-Government demonstrators outside Bulgaria's Parliament building whistled and shouted "Down with the Reds!"

headline: Exemption to Rise $100
abstract: The personal tax exemption will increase by $100 next year, to $2,150, the Internal Revenue Service announced on Friday. The exemption is adjusted each year to account for inflation, as are the standard deductions. The standard deduction for couples filing joint returns, which is $5,450 this year, will go to $5,700. The deduction for single people, now $3,250, will rise to $3,400.

headline: Ratings Cut For News Corp.
abstract: The rating of debt securities issued by the News Corporation Ltd. has been lowered, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. The rating change affects about $1.7 billion (United States) in securities issued by the Australian media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch.   Moody's said its action stemmed from a weakening in the media and entertainment businesses in general.   The rating agency said News Corporation's aggressive expansion in the late 1980's, financed by borrowed money, was based on ready access to worldwide financial markets and the ability to quickly sell media assets when their market values were rising. Moody's said that because these conditions had changed, the company's financial flexibility had been hampered and its protections for debt holders had become strained.   Moody's said it expected that declining operating margins in the media and entertainment industries would put pressure on the company's earnings over the intermediate term.   The rating of the company's senior debt was lowered to B-1, from Ba-2, and that of the subordinated debt to B-3, from Ba- 3.

headline: Economic Scene;   Cleaner Air, Cooler Air
abstract: LEAD: COULD taxes on carbon dioxide emissions stop atmospheric warming that threatens to flood coastlines and turn farmland to desert? Perhaps, concludes a study released last month by the Congressional Budget Office. But even in the best of plausible worlds, taming the global economy's addiction to carbon fuels would cost trillions of dollars.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Gannett Co. formed a cross-media advertising network called Gannettwork, to allow advertisers to design special multimedia packages that could include advertising placed in Gannett's newspapers, billboards and radio and television stations. * Merchandising Corporation of America, a unit of MCA Inc., signed an agreement with New Age Pad and Paper, a division of Colad Group, that allows New Age to use the cartoon character Woody Woodpecker on a new line of environmentally safe school supplies.

headline: Britain Begins Selling Electricity Industry
abstract: The British Government today began the selloff of its electricity industry in its largest privatization in 10 years.   The Government expects to raise $10.2 billion in the stock offering. The 2.16 billion shares will sell for 240 pence, or about $4.73, each, or a total $:5.18 billion, the Government said.   The offering caps Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's privatization program, which has so far raised $65 billion through the sales of Britain's telephone, gas and water utilities, as well as British Airways P.L.C. and other companies.   Some nervousness has arisen about how successful the recent privatizations will be, with an uneasy stock market, the continuing Middle East crisis and the struggle for leadership within Britain's governing Conservative Party.   Investors also remember the sale of the Government's third of the British Petroleum Company, which flopped because it coincided with the October 1987 stock market crash.   But the Energy Secretary, John Wakeham, said 7.3 million people had registered an interest in buying the electric utility shares, second only to the record 7.5 million registrations for British Gas P.L.C.   The Government has also calmed jitters about the offering by saying that it would cancel the sale if war broke out in the Persian Gulf.   "I think in today's market conditions the offer will be a success," said Chris Rowland, an analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd.    The Government signaled its intention to sell 100 percent of each of the 12 regional electricity companies of England and Wales. It had been considering whether to scale back the offer to 60 percent if market conditions were poor.   The shares are expected to fetch a 20 percent premium when trading begins on Dec. 11. The application deadline is Dec. 5. Shareholders are to receive an average dividend return of 8.4 percent in the first year, Mr. Wakeham said.   The Government has sought to enhance the complex sale with an installment payment plan of nearly two years, the longest ever, and with bonus shares and discounts on electricity bills, the types of perquisites it has offered in the past.   The Government said at least 34 percent of the shares would be reserved for the general public in Britain, 20 percent would be available to foreign investors and the remaining 46 percent would go to British institutional investors. If heavy British demand for the shares occur, the 20 percent to be offered to foreign investors will be reduced, the Government said.

headline: Quebec Indians Ponder True Cost of Electricity
abstract: LEAD: Chief Robbie Dick has seen the future and he wants no part of it. Neither do most of the 500 Cree Indians he represents in this remote northern Quebec village on the eastern shore of Hudson Bay.

headline: Careers; An Emphasis On Training For the 1990's
abstract: Training programs for employees from the beginning level to top managers are likely to gain in importance in the 1990's.    Responding to a questionnaire from Heidrick & Struggles, a management recruiting firm, 62 percent of the chairmen of 264 big companies said "building and keeping a qualified work force" was the most important business issue of the decade.

headline: Poland Arrests 2 Police Generals In '84 Killing of Reformist Priest
abstract: LEAD: The police have arrested two Polish secret-police generals in connection with the slaying in 1984 of a well-known Solidarity priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, the Government said today.

headline: Albania Recognizes First Opposition Party
abstract: The Albanian authorities formally recognized the country's first opposition party today, paving the way for multiparty elections after decades of one-party Communist rule.   But the Government continued its clampdown on suspects accused of taking part in rioting last week. The official Albania press reported that courts had sentenced 18 people to prison terms of up to 12 years. More than 150 people were on trial for anti-Government acts after the violence last week in four provincial centers, the Albanian state radio reported.   Justice Minister Enver Halili issued a signed and stamped document recognizing the new Democratic Party of Albania exactly one week after its founding, said a party spokesman, Genc Pollo.   The approval came a day after the new party applied for registration and the parliamentary presidium passed a decree formalizing a Communist Party decision of last week to legalize independent political parties.   The decision appeared to reflect growing pressure on the authorities to speed up democratic reforms. After the democratic revolutions that swept the former Soviet bloc last year, Albania is the last country in Europe still under Stalinist rule.

headline: Account
abstract: * Brooklyn Bottling Corp., to the Zak Agency, Ridgefield, N.J., with a budget of $1.5 million to $2 million. The Brooklyn-based company makes a variety of drinks.

headline: Market Place; Pricing a Station In Biggest Market
abstract: JUST what is a television station worth in the New York market? That question will soon be answered, as investors get a chance to buy the first "pure play" available. WWOR-TV is being spun off from MCA Inc. as part of its deal to be acquired by Matsushita.   The figures bandied about yesterday covered a wide spectrum, reflecting questions about how much prices have fallen and whether any companies would step forward and try to buy the station.

headline: Iraq Children in Anti-Embargo March to Embassies
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of children carrying empty milk bottles marched to the United States and British Embassies today chanting ''Down with Bush! Long live Saddam!'' to protest the trade blockade against Iraq.

headline: Careers;   Shift Seen In Executive Benefit Plans
abstract: LEAD: ''GOLDEN parachutes'' for top managers are slowing in number, while stock options appear to be increasing, Towers Perrin, a benefits consulting firm, has found.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * California Commerce Bank, Los Angeles, a subsidiary of Banco Nacional de Mexico, Mexico City, appointed Jule Vargas senior vice president in charge of its retail banking division. * Figgie International Inc., Willoughby, Ohio, producers of fire protection products, named Joseph J. Skadra senior vice president of finance and controller. * Invacare Corp., Elyria, Ohio, a wheelchair manufacturer, promoted Hymie H. Pogir to vice president of marketing and rehabilitation products. * Loral Corp., New York, a producer of military computers, appointed Richard W. Koepke group vice president of four divisions of its newly formed products group. * MCI Communications Corp., Washington, appointed Edward G. Freitag vice president and assistant general counsel. * Maxtor Corp., San Jose, Calif., a maker of computer disk drives, named Mark Fischer-Colbrie to the new position of vice president of finance. * Mutual Life Insurance Co. of New York, known as MONY, promoted K. Rone Baldwin to senior vice president of corporate development and appointed Richard Daddario to chief financial officer. * NBI Inc., Boulder, Colo., word processing software manufacturers, appointed Gary R. Ensminger vice president of systems integration.

headline: Vaulx-en-Velin Journal;   Arab Youths of France: Their Anger Boils Over
abstract: LEAD: The Mas-du-Taureau section here, a predominantly North African neighborhood, has had quite a facelift: there are newly planted chestnut trees, a new library and day-care center and a fresh coat of salmon-colored paint on the six-story apartment buildings.

headline: Conde Nast Publications Get 3 New Publishers
abstract: In the latest round of executive musical chairs at his publishing empire, S. I. Newhouse Jr. named new publishers yesterday at Vogue, Vanity Fair and Conde Nast's Traveler.   With the changes came a broad domino-like reshuffling of top executives throughout Conde Nast Publications Inc., a unit of Advance Publications, which is owned by the Newhouse family. Such management housecleanings have become a trademark of Mr. Newhouse.

headline: Thompson Celebrates by Aiding the Needy
abstract: INSTEAD of the usual bash for the holidays, J. Walter Thompson has organized a strikingly different kind of event: The New York office will be closed today and most of the agency's 410 employees will be wielding hammers or wrapping presents as they donate an eight-hour work day to 30 charitable projects.    This is perhaps the first time in New York in recent years that an agency, or any large company, has donated an entire day to charitable work, said Kenneth Adams, the executive director of New York Cares, which works with businesses that want to help charities. "We need so much help," he said, "I hope this encourages other companies to do something similar."

headline: BUSH SENDS NEW UNITS TO GULF TO PROVIDE 'OFFENSIVE OPTION'; U.S. FORCE COULD REACH 380,000
abstract: President Bush today ordered more than 150,000 additional American ground, sea and air forces to the Persian Gulf area, saying they were needed to provide "an adequate offensive military option" to drive Iraqi troops from Kuwait.   The move would nearly double the size of the American land and naval combat units in the area and give the United States a numerical advantage over Iraq in the most up-to-date tanks.

headline: Profits Down at Digital and Apple
abstract: LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation and Apple Computer Inc. reported yesterday that their earnings had fallen in the latest quarter. Digital's earnings plunged nearly 83 percent, while Apple's were down just under 39 percent.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER, 17, 1990
abstract: The Economy    Consumer prices climbed 0.6 percent in October, less than in the preceding two months, the Labor Department said. About half of the increase stemmed from higher oil prices. Apparently persuaded that the risks of a serious slump now outweigh those of inflation, the Fed acted to cut a key short-term interest rate.  [ Page 1. ]  Fed policy makers agreed in early October to ease interest rates if a budget-cutting agreement was reached, and to allow further easing if economic conditions warranted.  [ 32. ]    The trade deficit narrowed slightly in September, the Commerce Department said. The U.S. bill for oil rose to the highest level in nine years, but imports of other products fell.  [ 31. ]    Four Senators forcefully defended their political integrity, insisting to their peers on the Senate Ethics Committee that they had done no special favors for Charles Keating.  [ 1. ]    About $780.7 million in unclaimed money was collected by state governments last year. The total could reach $1 billion in 1990.  [ 29. ] Companies    Donald Trump agreed to turn over half ownership of his crown-jewel casino to bondholders. On top of that, the flamboyant financier must make a brief detour to bankruptcy court, and could eventually lose control of the Taj Mahal.  [ 1. ]  For the first time, Trump is being forced to hand over a share of his real estate empire to creditors. It could happen again next month. News analysis.  [ 33. ]    Chase Manhattan said it expected increased losses on consumer and business loans in coming months, assuming that the economy continues to weaken.  [ 31. ]    Mexico reported three formal bids to buy control of Telmex, the national telephone company. The bids by two multinational consortiums and one Mexican group set the stage for what may be the largest sale ever of a government-held enterprise.  [ 31. ]    The Manville trust to compensate victims of asbestos poisoning is close to approving a proposal to give its senior executives a lucrative severance package, trust officials said.  [ 31. ]    Fred Allegretti doesn't like the price fluctuations he sees on his computer screen, and his customers don't like what they see on their bills. He heads a large heating oil delivery company.  [ 31. ]    Chrysler canceled plans to produce a "mini-Jeep" for lack of a joint-venture partner.  [ 33. ]    A top Daily News spokesman sallied out for the company's first head-to-head, out-in-the-open debate with some of the strikers.  [ 26. ]    U.P.I.'s union employees accepted a 35 percent pay cut for 90 days while its owners seek a buyer.  [ 26. ]  Markets    A barrel of oil cost less than $30 for the first time in more than three weeks. Traders reacted to conciliatory talk from Saddam Hussein and to the beginning of President Bush's trip abroad.  [ 31. ]    Signs that the Fed had begun to cut interest rates lifted the credit markets. Prices of long-term bonds rose sharply.  [ 34. ]    The stock market seesawed, then ended higher, despite a selloff of long-distance telephone issues. The Dow Jones industrials closed up 5.20 points, to 2,550.25, a gain of 61.64 points this week.  [ 34. ]    The dollar declined broadly and settled at a new low against the German mark as lower interest rates drove investors away.  [ 40. ]    Soybean prices were lifted by aggressive commercial and professional buying. Grain, meat and livestock futures climbed.  [ 40. ]  Today's Columns    The election defeat of Rep. Robert W. Kastenmeier was significant for inventors. The crusty Wisconsin Democrat spent 21 years as head of the subcommittee that oversees patents, trademarks and copyrights. Patents.  [ 32. ]    A Stradivarius will be auctioned on Wednesday, with the proceeds going to the donor and the UJA-Federation, in an example of the benefits of a charitable remainder trust. Your Money.  [ 32. ]

headline: Your Own Account; Changing Jobs in Tough Times
abstract: IF the economic slump is forcing you to reassess career prospects and job security with your current employer, don't wait to be laid off before you start looking for something else. Competition is fierce and it will take a long time to get the next job.  When Hewitt Associates ran an advertisement for a consultant in the Wall Street Journal last fall, the company received nearly 2,000 resumes, according to Robert P. Gandossy, a consultant in the Rowayton, Conn., office.

headline: Paper Ties Terrorist Group to Egypt Killing
abstract: LEAD: Six followers of the Palestinian terrorist group led by Abu Nidal were responsible for the killing of the Speaker of the Egyptian Parliament last week, the semiofficial Al Ahram newspaper reported today.

headline: Financial News Network Says It Faces Default
abstract: LEAD: Financial News Network Inc., the business news service that appears on many cable systems, announced yesterday that depending on how a dispute with auditors was resolved, it could be placed in default with banks on a $48.5 million line of credit.

headline: Fog Equipment Is Approved
abstract: LEAD: Alaska Airlines said today that it had received Federal Aviation Administration approval for new technology that will allow its planes to take off in dense fog. Alaska Airlines said it was the first carrier to receive such authorization.

headline: Greece to Investigate Plan for Guerrilla War
abstract: Greece's conservative Government has ordered an investigation into a 1955 agreement between the C.I.A. and the Greek military for the establishment of a guerrilla network to fight invading Warsaw Pact forces in the event of a war.   The plan was similar to those in other European member countries of NATO. Defense Minister Ioannis Varvitsiotis, countering charges by the opposition that previous conservative governments and the Americans had in fact set up a covert mechanism to impose a dictatorship if necessary, said on Monday that he had ordered the investigation "because the Government has nothing to fear or to conceal."   Early this month, the former Socialist Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, confirmed the existence of an American-Greek contingency plan for guerrilla warfare. Mr. Papandreou and his former ministers then disclosed that the plan had involved about 800 hiding places throughout the country, used to conceal weapons, communications equipment and medicines. They were to be used by specially trained commando forces that would go into action if the country was overrun by the Warsaw Pact.

headline: Traders in Milan Striking Over Capital Gains Tax Plan
abstract: For the last two business days, no trading has been conducted on the Milan Stock Exchange because of a strike by floor traders protesting a proposed new capital gains tax and the pace of market-reform plans winding slowly through the Italian Parliament.    The exchange's 700 or so traders threatened to shut down operations at least through Wednesday, when they expect to present their grievances to a parliamentary committee.

headline: Condominiums in Connecticut; With Sales Strong, a Greenwich Builder Raises Prices
abstract: At a time when many builders in the New York metropolitan area are cutting prices to attract buyers, a Greenwich, Conn., developer, Glenville Associates-Hawthorne, has been raising prices because its sales have been so strong.  The price increases at the 80-unit Hawthorne condominium have averaged less than 10 percent since sales began in March. Still, the increases indicate that there is still a strong market for housing that gives purchasers the features they want. The project, a mix of town houses and apartments, is being built on a six-acre site in Glenville, a section of Greenwich.

headline: In Soviet Union, Dizzying Disunion
abstract: It was a typical day's Babel of self-determination in the Soviet Union.    The Moldavian Republic was distracted from its own anti-Moscow separatist plans to face the determined rebellion of one of its parts, the Gagauz minority, who were beginning ad hoc independence elections.

headline: Crisis in the Kremlin; SOVIET AIDES WORK TO PLACATE FEARS OF ABRUPT CHANGE
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today sought to calm the aftershocks of his Foreign Minister's resignation, discounting fears that the event was a precursor of changes in the country's internal and foreign policies.    But critics among the democratic insurgents seized on Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's resignation as evidence that the country is inexorably sliding toward tyranny, and that Mr. Gorbachev is going along with it.

headline: Ukraine Introduces a Form of Currency
abstract: The Ukraine today became the first Soviet republic to introduce its own crude currency, official coupons that come in every resident's pay envelope and must be used with Soviet rubles to purchase most consumer goods.    The measure was described by officials in the second-largest Soviet republic as a remedy for inflation and empty shelves, and a step toward replacing the ruble with new Ukrainian money.

headline: Wall Street; The Dow and a Decade of Discount Rate Cuts
abstract: The conventional wisdom is that the Federal Reserve Board delivered a giant Christmas gift to Wall Street last week by cutting the discount rate a half-point, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent. And figures collected by the archivists at Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in New York, show how such assumptions arose.   Not counting this recent action, the Fed has cut the discount rate by a half-point or more on 25 occasions during the past decade. The Birinyi folks checked to see where the Dow Jones industrial average stood three months after a major discount rate cut. And, in 18 of the 25 cases, the Dow was higher. Pretty reassuring, huh?   But before you uncork the champagne, look carefully at the record during the brief economic downturn in the first half of 1980 and the much deeper recession that began in July 1981 and continued through November 1982. Despite a lot of pushing and shoving from the Fed, the market didn't start to rebound until the recession was nearly over. Aspirin, anyone?

headline: Thomson Layoffs
abstract: Thomson-CSF S.A., one of France's biggest military contractors, plans to lay off 3,800 to 4,000 employees because of declining demand for military products, union officials said. The sources, who spoke only on the condition that they not be identified, said the layoffs would involve more than 10 percent of the company's 37,800 employees. They said details would be announced on Thursday.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Ivan Lendl will be the official spokesman for Snapple brand beverages, through a multiyear, million-dollar contract. Mr. Lendl will be featured in all television spots and promotional materials, and will wear a Snapple patch on the sleeve of his shirt during all tennis tournaments.

headline: U.S. ARMY ADVISERS TRAINING KUWAITIS
abstract: In a particularly desolate stretch of desert here, a team of American special warfare advisers is helping the remnants of the Kuwaiti Army regroup, rearm and prepare to fight Iraq.    A visit to this frontline area offered what was believed to be the first look by reporters at the usually elusive American military trainers, including Army Special Forces advisers, who are working in Arab units and coordinating military operations with them in Saudi Arabia.

headline: France Denies Talking With Iraq Over Settlement of the Gulf Crisis
abstract: LEAD: France said today that it was not engaged in talks with Iraq, secret or otherwise, to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: Argentine Leader Sees Gulf Role As Best Way to Reverse Old Image
abstract: LEAD: President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina, the only Latin American leader to order forces to join the blockade against Iraq, says he did so in the hope of presenting a new image of his country as a reliable partner.

headline: Market Place; Drought May Hurt Some California Bonds
abstract: The drought afflicting California is starting to send an uneasy rumble through the municipal bond market, as some analysts and investors question whether the long dry spell will make it harder for thousands of local government units to repay billions of dollars worth of bonds they sold to the public.    These government units, including water districts, municipal utilities and public power projects, make money from selling water, treating waste water and generating hydroelectric power. Yet the markets have largely ignored the impact that nearly four years of below-average rainfall could have on the financial health of these borrowers.

headline: In Land of Big Bucks, Even Bigger Bucks
abstract: LEAD: NOT only has the cost of making movies risen sharply, but the budgets for advertising them have soared as well.

headline: Police Enforce an Angry Calm in Israel
abstract: LEAD: As clouds of tear gas and pillars of black smoke from burning tires hung in the air over much of Jerusalem, angry Palestinians protested and Israeli leaders held themselves blameless today in the Old City violence that took at least 19 and as many as 24 Arab lives on Monday.

headline: Bush Gives Czechs a Copy of Liberty Bell
abstract: President Bush rang a replica of the Liberty Bell in the Czechoslovak capital today to mark the first anniversary of this country's democratic revolution, and he evoked the memory of Czechoslovakia's subjugation by Hitler to appeal for support in his fight against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.   "There is right and there is wrong. There is good and there is evil. And there are sacrifices worth making," Mr. Bush told an enthusiastic crowd of more than 100,000 people in Wenceslas Square, the symbolic center of the 1989 overthrow of Communist rule here.

headline: Liberia Guerrillas Refuse to Sign Accord at Talks
abstract: The leading guerrilla army battling for control of Liberia refused to sign a cease-fire agreement at peace talks this week, but Bush Administration officials say they are cautiously optimistic that the accord will soon return to the bargaining table.   Three days of talks between the remnants of the late President Samuel K. Doe's army, two rebel factions and a West African peacekeeping force ended late Wednesday in the Gambian capital, Banjul. As the last session broke up, representatives of the rebelNational Patriotic Front of Liberia said they needed to consult with their leader, Charles Taylor, before agreeing to a cease-fire.

headline: MGM-Pathe To Postpone Bond Interest
abstract: The MGM-Pathe Communications Company, the Hollywood studio formed in early November from the merger of MGM/UA and Pathe, said today that it would delay for about a month making interest payments of about $25 million on "junk bonds."    Reflecting the announcement, Moody's Investors Service Inc., the debt-rating company, reduced some of MGM-Pathe's debt-quality ratings from middle grade to low grade.

headline: Kohl Pledges Help in Soviet Food Crisis
abstract: Germany will increase food shipments to the Soviet Union if an acute supply crisis develops this winter, Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today. He called on other Western nations to give more support to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic changes.    There are growing indications of a food crisis in the Soviet Union. Leningrad's City Council voted today to begin wide-scale food rationing on Dec. 1, the first in the city of five million people since the blockade by German armies from 1941 to 1945 that killed an estimated 600,000 people.

headline: Public Speaking Without the Pain
abstract: To the Editor:   As a communications consultant who coaches senior executives on effective public speaking techniques, I challenge the assumption that learning how to communicate better is painful ("The Public Equivalent of Root Canal," Dec. 2)   Too often, public speaking seminars emphasize style over substance -- and what a chillingly superficial style it can be. One participant finishes a practice speech in front of peers and receives this advice: "Button you jacket, Joe. You're a vice president, for God's sake." Imagine how anyone would feel if feedback about our public speaking skills started or stayed on this level.

headline: Vitamin A Said to Cut Childhood Death Rate
abstract: LEAD: Weekly vitamin A supplements can cut the childhood death rate in half in parts of the world where malnutrition is widespread, a study shows.

headline: A Clamor in Norway to Ban All Smoking
abstract: Norway, which already has the world's most expensive cigarettes, is trying to stop smoking everywhere indoors and wipe out the habit in a decade.   Even a smoker's home may not be his castle for long. Schools and day-care centers tell children about the dangers of passive smoking and encourage them to tell their parents to quit or smoke outside.   Norwegians with tobacco habits are responding by rolling their own cigarettes, using butts over again, taking snuff and smoking on balconies.

headline: Turbulence Is Expected For OPEC
abstract: As it prepares for its annual meeting in Vienna starting Wednesday, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is in disarray, perhaps more so than at any time in its 30-year history. And it faces a long period of uncertainty because of the consequences of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.   The OPEC system of country-by-country production quotas has been discarded by most of the 13 member states, which are pumping all the oil they can pull out of the ground. OPEC is producing much more than its production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day, even though exports of 4 million barrels a day from Iraq and Kuwait have been shut off since Baghdad invaded Kuwait in August.

headline: Shared Medical Is Asked to Merge
abstract: David J. Greene & Company, a New York broker-dealer with a 10.5 percent stake in Shared Medical Systems Corporation, said the company should consider a tender offer, merger or asset sale to increase its stock price. Shared Medical, based in Malvern, Pa., supplies software to hospitals and physicians. In a filing with the Securities and ExchangeCommission, Greene said that Shared Medical's stock was significantly undervalued.    Alan I. Greene, general partner of David J. Greene, said in a telephone interview that Shared Medical had a good niche business, but "changing conditions warrant that the company come under the wing of a larger company." Shared Medical's stock rose 62.5 cents today, to $15.875, in over-the-counter trading.

headline: Dissident in Filing On ASK Computer
abstract: James P. Lennane, a dissident shareholder of ASK Computer Systems Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he was reviewing his options after losing a proxy battle with the company and that he might seek control of the software concern, based in Los Altos, Calif. Mr. Lennane said he controlled 1.4 million ASK Computer shares, or 7.45 percent of those outstanding.   The stake is down from the 10 percent level Mr. Lennane held before ASK Computer increased the number of shares outstanding by selling $60 million in stock to the Hewlett-Packard Corporation and the E.D.S. Corporation unit of the General Motors Corporation. Mr. Lennane had fought to block the sale, which helped to finance ASK Computer's $100 million purchase of the Ingres Corporation. Between Oct. 23 and Oct. 25, Mr. Lennane bought 120,000 ASK Computer shares for $5.80 to $7.19 each.

headline: Ads Aimed At Children Restricted
abstract: LEAD: President Bush decided today to let a bill that limits television commercials on children's programming become law without his signature. He withheld his official seal of approval because of First Amendment concerns.

headline: Amid Gulf Crisis and Cold War End, Questions on U.S. and NATO Roles
abstract: The crisis in the Persian Gulf and the end of the cold war, despite political uncertainty in the Soviet Union, are adding fuel to a major debate about strengthening Western Europe's defenses and reducing its dependence on the United States.   Government officials in West Germany and Britain support the idea of building up the European defense pillar, something they hope would encourage the United States not to withdraw to the other side of the Atlantic. But others, even in Britain, argue that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization may no longer be the best way to insure that the United States keeps devoting resources to European defense.

headline: Polish Catholic Bishops Denounce Anti-Semitism
abstract: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops today issued a document condemning anti-Semitism in this country and acknowledged that some Poles helped Nazis kill Jews during World War II.    "We express our sincere regret over all cases of anti-Semitism which were committed at any time or by anyone on Polish soil," the bishops said in a four-page statement that is to be read during masses in Catholic churches here on Jan. 20. "All cases of anti-Semitism are against the spirit of the Gospel . . . and are contrary to the Christian vision of human dignity, the bishops said. The move follows Pope John Paul II's endorsement on Dec. 6 of an earlier statement forged by Catholic and Jewish leaders from Europe and the United States who met in Prague and called for an aggressive effort by the church to combat anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe.

headline: Kodak Plans For Desktop Publishing
abstract: Following on its effort to combine traditional picture taking with advanced electronics, the Eastman Kodak Company plans to announce today a group of technologies aimed at the desktop publishing market.    The company had said last month that in 1992 it would begin selling a system to allow snapshots to be stored on optical compact disks. Using a new player that can read both audio and photo disks, customers could view their pictures at home on television sets.

headline: The Cure for the Deficit Isn't More Taxes
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: S.& L. Chief Loses Round
abstract: The ousted chairman of Centrust, David Paul, who has come to symbolize the savings and loan crisis, lost his bid today to keep from paying $30.8 million in restitution sought by Federal regulators.   United States District Judge Edward Davis rejected Mr. Paul's motion for a temporary injunction to hold off the Office of Thrift Supervision. Mr. Paul's lawyer, Sanford Bohrer, promised an appeal, saying, "What O.T.S. did doesn't bear any resemblance to what the Constitution requires."   Judge Davis's ruling did not address a deadline for Mr. Paul to pay up, but Deborah Siegel, a lawyer for the thrift office, said, "Hypothetically, the order has always been in force and the bond is due."

headline: Tektronix Layoffs
abstract: LEAD: Tektronix Inc. said it would sell or shut down its unprofitable work-station business within 60 days, and the company gave layoff notices to about 175 employees. If it can find a buyer for the business, many of those workers would be re-employed, a company spokesman, Doug Babb, said. More than 2,000 other Tektronix employees have been laid off since the beginning of the year.

headline: Talks by I.B.M. and Motorola On Advanced Chip Collapse
abstract: LEAD: Negotiations between Motorola Inc. and the I.B.M. Corporation to license the computer maker's most advanced memory-chip technology have collapsed, dashing some people's hopes of an American alliance that would strengthen the nation's semiconductor industry.

headline: Merrill Lynch Moving To Trim Its Expenses
abstract: Reacting to the worsening market environment, Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage house, has taken a number of cost-cutting moves, including a hiring freeze and a freeze on salary increases based on merit.   The firm also plans to trim its spending for such things as conferences and entertainment events for clients. The firm is also limiting the number of temporary employees who can be hired.

headline: Banks in New Jersey and Georgia Adjust for Loan Woes
abstract: The Midlantic Corporation and the C&S/Sovran Corporation announced separately yesterday that they were having growing problems with defaulted commercial real estate loans.    Midlantic, based in Edison, N.J., said it was eliminating shareholder dividend payments to conserve cash and rebuild its financial strength. The company said it expected to earn a profit in the fourth quarter, following losses of $183.8 million the previous six months.

headline: The Droll European Ad
abstract: To the Editor:   European advertising sells the quality of a product in an ethical way and does not underestimate the intelligence of a potential buyer ("Why European Ads Are More Amusing," Oct. 7). American advertising is rather naive and might be considered somehow crude. Who really buys a car because pretty girls and boys perform some dances on and around it? It is a car you want to sell, not the dances.   Also, Europeans do not have fewer brands, but rather a selection of brands which promote quality a consumer can depend on.   The open question -- Which type of advertising will be successful? -- will be answered differently every year. As the world shrinks, we all are under various influences and so will advertising be. It is only a question of adjustability and flexibility for all of us. JAN J. MRAZEK  Spring Hill, Fla., Nov. 6

headline: Citing Violence, Bangladesh Declares State of Emergency
abstract: The Government declared a state of emergency today after weeks of violence by opposition forces demanding that President H. M. Ershad resign.   Mr. Ershad said in a televised speech that the decree was necessary to safeguard the country's internal security in the face of what he called a conspiracy to destroy the economy.   The proclamation suspended all civil rights and imposed press censorship. An indefinite curfew was imposed on the capital, Dhaka, and the Government arrested a top opposition leader.

headline: 2 Convicted of Killing Amazon Environmentalist
abstract: A rancher and his son have been convicted in the murder of a celebrated Amazon environmental leader, breaking a long tradition of impunity for pro-development forces in Brazil.   The rancher, 54-year-old Darly Alves da Silva, was convicted of planning the Dec. 22, 1988, murder of the Francisco (Chico) Mendes, leader of a rubber-tappers' union who became internationally known as a defender of the rain forest. The rancher's son, 23-year-old Darci Alves Pereira, was convicted of firing the shotgun blast that killed Mr.Mendes. Both were found guilty and received 19-year sentences late Saturday. The prosecution had sought 30-year sentences. Brazil has no death penalty.

headline: Money-Fund Yields Mixed
abstract: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.    Analysts at Donoghue's said investors appeared to be unwilling to invest until a Federal budget was wrapped up. Then, they said, investors will likely wait for some interest-rate direction from the Federal Reserve in the form of some action on short-term rates.

headline: Morgan Site In Stamford
abstract: Morgan Stanley & Company has taken an option to buy a piece of property in downtown Stamford, Conn., that could be the site of its future headquarters, a company spokesman said yesterday.   The investment bank, which is considering moving its offices out of New York City, has an option on a site near the Stamford train station and has begun seeking city and state zoning approvals that would allow it to build a large office tower on the property.   Morgan is also continuing its talks with New York City on keeping its nearly 4,000 employees in New York after its present lease expires in 1997, the spokesman said. It is widely expected that New York will offer Morgan incentives to keep the firm from leaving.   A move to Connecticut by Morgan Stanley would contribute to the erosion of New York's tax base at a time that the city faces severe budget problems.   Wall Street executives have said that other large financial- services companies are watching the Morgan negotiations carefully. If the company leaves New York, they say, it could signal the beginning of an exodus of Wall Street firms.

headline: Saudis to Give Free Hand to U.S. If Attack on the Iraqis Is Approved
abstract: The United States and Saudi Arabia tightened their pressure on Iraq today by agreeing on new command arrangements they would follow if they mounted an offensive strike, senior American and Saudi officials said.   In a step clearly intended to demonstrate the credibility of American military options, the two sides agreed that any offensive against Iraqi troops in Kuwait, or against Iraq, begun from Saudi territory would be undertaken only after President Bush and King Fahd both gave their approval.

headline: BANGLADESH PICKS AN INTERIM LEADER
abstract: Opposition parties nominated the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court today to head a caretaker government, the day after President H. M. Ershad announced his resignation.   The news that General Ershad would step down was greeted with noisy celebrations by thousands of people, many of whom ran from their homes in pajamas to dance in the streets and set off firecrackers.

headline: Business and Health; Cost Trade-Offs On Medical Care
abstract: PARTICIPANTS in the struggle with balloon ing health-care costs are under pressure to accept some kind of change. Congress is tightening regulation on physicians and considering new controls on private health insurance for the elderly. Many employers who provide health benefits for workers favor special taxes on businesses that do not do so. Advocates of publicly financed health insurance, meanwhile, blame the medical profession and private insurers for the system's problems.    Trying to shape the debate, and perhaps deflect some criticism along the way, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is sponsoring a survey of employers, union executives, health professionals, insurers and Government regulators. Representatives of each group were asked if they would be willing to make sacrifices "as part of a total plan in which everyone made some concessions."

headline: Keating Freed on $300,000 Bail Under Ruling by a Federal Judge
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge today reduced Charles H. Keating Jr.'s bail to $300,000, from $5 million, and hours later the former savings and loan official was freed, having spent a month in a county jail.

headline: NEW SOUTH AFRICA IS AT A ROADBLOCK
abstract: LEAD: Disagreement over whether right-wing whites inside South Africa's security apparatus are orchestrating the recent violence among blacks has strained the Government's working relationship with the African National Congress and slowed efforts to start full-scale negotiations on the nation's future.

headline: Dissent by Burmese Only Brings More Repression
abstract: Their heads shaved and bowed and their hands tied to a thick rope, about a dozen barefoot young men walked sullenly into the shabby, cavernous township jail.    A man who lives nearby watched the parade.
