"This is where they bring a lot of political prisoners," he said, suggesting that the forlorn group had been detained for their politics rather than for common crimes. The onlooker, who has close contacts in the military, spoke in a matter-of-fact tone, as if he were describing something as normal as the weather.

headline: Five Journalists to Receive Cabot Awards at Columbia
abstract: Five journalists specializing in Latin American or Caribbean affairs are to be presented with Maria Moors Cabot prizes tonight by Columbia University.   The awards, gold medals and honorariums of $1,000, have been given annually since 1939 to journalists living in the Western Hemisphere to honor their contributions to inter-American understanding and the freedom of information.    This year's recipients are Richard Boudreau, bureau chief in Managua, Nicaragua, of The Los Angeles Times; Marc Garcia and Elsie Etheart, editors and publishers of the weekly newspaper Haiti en Marche in Miami, and hosts of radio programs there; Alma Guillermoprieto of Mexico City, who writes for The New Yorker, and Huascar Cajias Kauffmann, founder of the daily newspaper Presencia in La Paz, Bolivia.    The Cabot prizes are awarded by the trustees of Columbia University on the recommendation of the dean of its Graduate School of Journalism.

headline: Northwest Air Net Falls 47%
abstract: Northwest Airlines said today that higher fuel costs associated with the Middle East crisis had caused a 47 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings and would result in a fourth-quarter loss.   The nation's fourth-largest airline reported net income of $91 million in the quarter that ended on Sept. 30, down from $134 million for the corresponding period in 1989. Revenues grew from $1.8 billion in the third quarter in 1989 to $2 billion in the third quarter this year, the airline said.   Northwest, which is owned by NWA Inc., said its fuel expense jumped 30.5 percent, to $338 million from $259 million in last year's third quarter.  The escalation in prices followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.   "We anticipate that continued high fuel expenses for the remainder of the year will result in a fourth-quarter net loss," said John Dasburg, Northwest's newly appointed president and chief executive.   Northwest said it has adopted a number of measures to deal with its soaring fuel bill, including fare increases, flight schedule reduction, deferral of non-essential expenses and a ceiling on the number of people it employs.

headline: 300 Are Laid Off By Burger King
abstract: LEAD: The Burger King Corporation has laid off 300 employees nationwide and plans to close more than a third of its field offices in a move to streamline the company and pay more attention to franchisees.

headline: Tense Talks at Chrysler
abstract: LEAD: Claiming the company has no money to meet union wage demands is a time-honored tactic of collective bargaining. But this time there seems to be little doubt that Chrysler Corporation management is telling autoworkers the truth about its precarious position.

headline: Czech Communists Gain Seats in Local Elections
abstract: Czechoslovak voters sent a warning today to Civic Forum, President Vaclav Havel's political movement, by giving an unexpected salute to the Communist Party in this country's first free municipal elections in 52 years.   Civic Forum retained the widest support of any group, winning 35 percent of the votes, according to preliminary estimates issued by the Government. The Communist Party, surprisingly, came in second in the large Czech region of the country, with 17 percent.

headline: All About/Movie Theaters; The Crunch Comes to Cinemas
abstract: WHEN movie ticket sales peaked seven years ago, the theater chains continued to expand. They added 4,000 screens, for a 1989 total of nearly 23,000. Only now are they retrenching, trying to sell their theaters as well as their tickets.   Average ticket prices have risen to $4.58 last year from $2.69 in 1980, but after inflation the increase is slight. "It is a nongrowth business that has become highly competitive," said Sumner Redstone, whose National Amusements Inc. owns nearly 700 screens. "Real growth does not come from raising your admission prices year after year. With everyone fighting for market share, the question is: how well can companies manage what they own?"

headline: Mubarak's Party Far Ahead In Egyptian Legislative Vote
abstract: Incomplete returns today from general elections showed Egypt's ruling National Democratic Party maintaining an unassailable hold on Parliament amid controversy over how many people actually voted for it.   Officials said returns from 171 of the 444 seats contested in the voting on Thursday showed 144 parliamentary places going to supporters of President Hosni Mubarak and 27 to independents.

headline: Governador Valadares Journal; You Might Say, This Is the Town Uncle Sam Built
abstract: In the vast, arid interior of Minas Gerais State rises a tidy, thriving city that residents call "Brazil's best American town."    Lacking any visible source of income other than ranching, Governador Valadares is sprouting high-rise apartment buildings. The tallest, with an Art Deco motif, is called the Empire State Building. Around the central square, teen-age girls shop for outfits at Benetton. Boys sit on park benches, reading Mad magazine in Portuguese.

headline: NEW LEADER TAKES SINGAPORE'S HELM
abstract: In a brief, rather solemn ceremony, Goh Chok Tong became Singapore's second Prime Minister tonight, taking over from Lee Kuan Yew, the world's longest-serving Prime Minister, who has run Singapore for the last 31 years.   During the ceremony at Singapore's City Hall, where Mr. Lee was sworn in with his first Cabinet in 1959, Singaporean officials were still referring to him as "the P.M." It has been the habit of a lifetime. Mr. Lee, 67 years old, has been synonymous with Singapore, and he has fashioned this remarkable city-state in his own image: honest, combative, efficient and ruthless.

headline: Some Saudi Women Push Changes
abstract: Saudi women may have been officially banned from driving, but in many other ways at least some of them appear intent on stretching the narrow limits of this male-dominated Islamic society.    "I'm frustrated, but I still think change will come," said a Saudi professional woman who asked not to be named because of possible censure for public criticism. "I don't see how it can remain like this forever."

headline: Times to Sell 3 Papers
abstract: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell three of its regional newspapers to the American Publishing Company, based in West Frankfort, Ill.   Two of the papers are dailies in eastern Kentucky: The Middlesboro Daily News and The Harlan Daily Enterprise. The third, The Claiborne Progress, is a weekly in New Tazewell, Tenn.

headline: Kasparov to Play Under Russian, Not Soviet, Flag
abstract: LEAD: Gary Kasparov, the world chess champion, announced yesterday that when he defends his title in New York next Monday he will not play the match under the Soviet flag but rather under the white, blue and red colors of the Russian Republic.

headline: A South Africa Color Bar Falls Quietly
abstract: LEAD: Racial discrimination became illegal today in parks, swimming pools, libraries, toilets and other publicly owned places across South Africa.

headline: Soda Ash Makers Fined
abstract: The European Community's Executive Commission today fined three chemical companies a total $66.2 million for running a cartel in Western Europe for soda ash.   The action includes the largest antitrust fine ever imposed by the commission -- a fine of $41.4 million against Solvay, Belgium's largest chemical company. Solvay called the fine "utterly unreasonable" and said it would appeal.   The commission, the executive board of the 12-nation group, also fined Britain's Imperial Chemical Industries $23.5 million and Chemische Fabrik Kalk G.m.b.H., a unit of BASF A.G. of Germany, $1.38 million.   The commission said the companies had an agreement by which I.C.I. would not sell soda ash on the Continent if Solvay and Chemische Fabrik Kalk stayed out of Britain.   The commission said Solvay and I.C.I. had fixed the market so that companies looking for secondary sources of soda ash ended up buying from the group anyway.   Soda ash is used in the chemical industry as a neutralizing agent. It also accounts for up to 60 percent of the raw material costs of glass making. It is so widely used that the commission said the group's effect "is ultimately felt by millions of consumers."   The fine is the second blow to Solvay in three months. In October, the European Community withdrew all anti-dumping duties on soda ash imports from the American Natural Soda Ash Corporation.   Analysts say the end of the duties may hit Solvay's earnings severely. Soda ash and its derivatives represent 10 percent of Solvay's total sales.

headline: People
abstract: * Marianne Caponnetto has been appointed to the new position of director of corporate marketing for Dow Jones & Company. * Dean Bastian has been named vice president at J. Walter Thompson, Chicago.

headline: Technology;   Kodak's Hybrid: Compact Disks and Photographic Film
abstract: LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company is concerned that the all-electronic still cameras being introduced by Japanese consumer electronics companies could seriously erode its domination of the $15 billion film and photofinishing industry. It is rushing to bring out a system that uses traditional photographic film and allows consumers to retain their current cameras but also convert pictures to video images that can be manipulated electronically.

headline: Macy Says It Might Sell Sizable Stake to Trim Debt
abstract: R. H. Macy & Company told its investors yesterday that it might sell a more substantial stake in the debt-laden company than it had previously sold to other investors. Some speculation centered on a Hong Kong company as a possible buyer.    In a quarterly letter to investors in Macy's 1986 leveraged buyout, top management did not identify a potential buyer. The company did not say whether it was already negotiating with one buyer or was still exploring the field. But a Macy spokeswoman said, "This is not a veiled reference to a specific buyer, but it is stronger than merely exploring the possibility."

headline: Managua Dons High Heels and Has a Fling
abstract: Bourgeois is back.    It's hip to be rich here. And better yet to flaunt money it if you have it.    After a decade of revolutionary asceticism, lipstick and other cosmetics are fashionable again. Business suits are in, jungle fatigues out; Mercedes Benz cars in, souped-up jeeps out; flashing neon graphics in, murals of muscled workers out.

headline: 10-Day Sales: Chrysler Won't Tell
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation, whose financial results and share of the American automobile market have faltered in the last two years, announced today that it would no longer participate in the industry's widely followed reports of car and truck sales each 10 days.    Chrysler said it would stop publicly reporting its 10-day sales not only because of the cost and trouble of tabulating the numbers, but also because they exaggerate Japanese auto makers' gains in the American market.

headline: Dow Jumps 68.07 Points In 2d Big Rise
abstract: LEAD: Wall Street traders, investors and speculators were all smiles yesterday. A big drop in oil prices, bold new Iraqi peace feelers and strong signs of an imminent budget agreement combined to lift stocks sharply for the second consecutive day.

headline: Court in Romania Suspends Ex-Secret Police Chief's Trial
abstract: LEAD: A military court today decided to suspend the trial of the late Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's secret police chief because of insufficient evidence.

headline: Bankers Trust Picks Unit Chief
abstract: LEAD: C. Edward Midgley, a veteran of Wall Street and the corporate board room, has joined the Bankers Trust Company as head of its corporate finance group.

headline: U.S. DECIDES TO ADD AS MANY AS 100,000 TO ITS GULF FORCES
abstract: The Bush Administration has decided to expand the number of American forces in the Persian Gulf and may send as many as 100,000 more troops to the region, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today.    The United States has sent more than 210,000 troops to the gulf, as part of a planned deployment of 240,000 troops. In announcing that more forces would be sent, Mr. Cheney said the exact number had not been worked out, and he gave no date for completing the American military buildup in the region, the largest since the Vietnam War.

headline: Ross Roy Aims for Integrated Marketing
abstract: THE Ross Roy Group, one of the Midwest's largest agencies, is expected to announce in January the completion of a reorganization.   The Detroit-based agency has been shifting the responsibilities of its senior management and more closely aligning its divisions so it can offer clients what is known as integrated marketing, where marketing programs are coordinated to include promotional campaigns, direct marketing, public relations and advertising all done within the agency.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE ECONOMY    The National Security Agency wants to retain strict barriers to the export of coding devices, despite growing demand from companies and government agencies in the U.S. and abroad. Because of new technology, these devices are now small enough to be placed on computer chips, allowing even desktop computers to code and decode material at a relatively small cost. But the agency does not have a practical way of cracking the codes.  [ Page A1. ]     The slump in commercial real estate is likely to get worse before it gets better, real estate executives and bankers people say. Many of these experts say they think prices of commercial property will fall sharply in the next two to three years and will not recover for four to five years.  [ D1. ] COMPANIES    Partners of Laventhol & Horwath voted to disband the firm and seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, former partners said. The nation's seventh-largest accounting firm held a hastily arranged weekend meeting in Houston.  [ D1. ]     Dairy Queen is about to face heavy competition as McDonald's focuses on expanding into the smaller towns where Dairy Queen has been strong.  [ D1. ]     The $4.5 billion claim filed against Drexel Burnham Lambert by Columbia Savings and Loan of Beverly Hills, Calif., provides the first look at Drexel's purported manipulation of the securities markets through the eyes of a big "junk bond" customers.  [ D1. ]     MCA has enlisted some of Washington's heavy hitters to promote its possible sale to Matsushita Electric.  [ D1. ]     The failure of Freedom National Bank may cost some charities hundreds of thousands of dollars because they maintained separate large accounts in the bank and had thought the accounts were protected by Federal deposit insurance. The F.D.I.C. chairman said the insurance applies to aggregate deposits, not individual ones.  [ B1. ] INTERNATIONAL    Poland's program to replace Communism with capitalism has slashed inflation, stabilized the nation's currency and made food lines a thing of the past. But the program now faces one of its biggest tests: reversing a huge drop in economic output.  [ D6. ] MEDIA BUSINESS    The founder of Ebony and Jet magazines is a leading pioneer in black entrepreneurship. But at age 72, John H. Johnson is becoming less optimistic about the opportunities for blacks.  [ D8. ]     Reduced advertising and tough economic conditions at newspapers appear to be hurting the industrywide effort to hire more minority journalists.  [ D8. ]     Simon & Schuster touched on issues that publishers rarely address any more when it canceled the book "American Psycho." Edwin McDowell: Publishing.  [ D8. ]     Each of the four million copies of Time this week will have the name of an individual subscriber on the cover.  [ D8. ]     Anheuser-Busch plans a series of Super Bowl commercials, for the third consecutive year, depicting the Bud Bowl, a comical football game played by bottles of Budweiser beer. In a new twist, a new brand, Bud Dry, may make an appearance. Advertising.  [ D7. ]   TODAY'S COLUMNS    A.T.&T. has finally learned to throw its weight around effectively, battering the sales and the stocks of United Telecom and MCI. The latest evidence came on Friday when MCI's stock price plunged $7.375. Market Place.  [ D1. ]     The downturn in the economy has eased the labor shortage for entry-level and low-wage jobs. Job applications are rising and hourly wages, which had inched up to more than $6 an hour in some areas, have leveled off. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene.  [ D2. ]     The steep slide in interest rates in the last six weeks is probably over, analysts say. In the next breath, however, they say they expect further declines before the year's end. Credit Markets.  [ D5. ]

headline: Layoffs by Hasbro
abstract: LEAD: Hasbro Inc., the nation's largest toy maker, said it had laid off 90 workers. Hasbro said it had made the cuts because of the ailing economy and its need to remain competitive. The company, which employs 8,000 worldwide, said administrative costs had grown at a greater rate than sales. The layoffs affected workers in marketing, research and development, sales and administration.

headline: Sony to Help Make Times Square Brighter
abstract: LEAD: The Camel may puff and the neon signs may glow, but they will seem like faded soldiers in the world of display advertising come November when the Sony Corporation erects a two-story video screen at One Times Square as part of the continuing redevelopment effort.

headline: Airline Is Pursuing 2 Hubs on Continent
abstract: British Airways, concerned about the likelihood of stronger competition in its North Atlantic business, is also battling to establish two big hubs on the European Continent: in Brussels and Berlin.    It needs the new hubs if it is to fully take advantage of the opportunities created by the deregulation of the European airline industry, the transformation of the European Community into a single market and the opening of Eastern Europe.

headline: Australia Cuts Rates
abstract: LEAD: Australia's central bank moved today to cut official interest rates on the money markets by one percentage point, to 13 percent, in the fifth easing of monetary policy this year.

headline: Union Trust Halts Sale
abstract: Citing a glut of credit card businesses offered for sale by banks in the last few months, the Union Trust Company of New Haven yesterday withdrew its previously announced offer to sell its card business.    Soon after it announced plans to sell the card business in October, "other larger regional and national card portfolios also came on the market, which created a glut and would appear to have driven down prices," said Frank J. Kugler, chairman of Union Trust. He said none of the offers for the bank's 123,000 credit card accounts and $110 million of loans outstanding were high enough.   Like many other New England banks, Union Trust, which is owned by Northeast Bancorp of Stamford, Conn., has been hurt by losses on commercial real estate loans, and it was trying to improve its financial condition by selling one of the profitable parts of its business. Bank of New England, Bank of Boston and State Street Boston have all sold their credit card businesses this week.

headline: Thousands March in 16 Cities to Protest U.S. Intervention in Gulf
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of people rallied in New York and 15 other American cities yesterday to protest the United States' military buildup in the Persian Gulf. It was the largest demonstration against the American presence in the gulf since President Bush first sent troops after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

headline: India's Cabinet Falls as Premier Loses Confidence Vote, by 142-346, and Quits
abstract: The 11-month-old Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh collapsed tonight after losing a confidence vote by a wide margin.    Mr. Singh, India's seventh Prime Minister, immediately submitted his resignation to the President, Ramaswami Venkataraman.

headline: World Markets;   A Mixed Blessing for the Pound
abstract: LEAD: The British pound's entry last week into the European Monetary System has altered the outlook for equities in London. Investors, says Mark Brown, the chief United Kingdomstrategist for UBS Phillips & Drew in London, will be ''paying more for less.''

headline: Wall Street; Ah, the Weird Whimsy of It All
abstract: Generally speaking, Wall Street research is no laughing matter. Day in and day out, thousands of highly paid and (usually) hard-working men and women monitor the vital signs of thousands of public companies, alert for any development that might affect the market's view of a company's worth. Their findings flow from Wall Street with the force, if not always the clarity, of a mountain cataract seeking the sea.   Some of these reports make a real contribution to investors' understanding of some arcane corner of global finance, or identify a promising investment opportunity. A few even warn investors of a company's deteriorating prospects early enough for them to exit with a portion of their profits intact. (These accomplishments are even more notable given the increased workload that analysts are facing in these lean times. Barry Graubart of Nelson Publications points out that, since 1987, Wall Street firms have been paring research staffs while increasing the number of companies they monitor.)

headline: Ford's Truck Outlook
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company expects the United States market for commercial trucks, including medium- and heavy-duty models, will remain slow at least through the end of the year, a manufacturing executive said today. ''It looks as if we're still in a slow period that will last several more months, certainly through year-end,'' George Kormanis, manager of Ford's Kentucky truck plant, said in an interview.

headline: Delta Withdraws Moscow Proposal
abstract: Delta Air Lines asked to withdraw its proposal for a nonstop flight from Atlanta to Moscow and filed instead for a route with one stop in Germany. The Atlanta-based airline had previously asked the Department of Transportation for permission to operate three weekly nonstop flights between Atlanta and Moscow-Leningrad in 1991.    Delta cited increased fuel costs and economic conditions in the United States and the Soviet Union as reasons for the decision not to pursue nonstop service.

headline: Fuel for Saudi Debate: Opening Society Without Causing Strife
abstract: An adviser to the King of Saudi Arabia refers to it as "pre-crisis" and "post-crisis" in the way a historian might define the moment that broke a continuum and forced an opening toward a new era.   He was speaking of the shift in thinking here since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, a jolt that has spurred the small political and social elite of this insular Islamic monarchy into a debate in which one word is repeated time and again: change.

headline: Dollar Up on Mideast Worry; Election Hedging Also Cited
abstract: The dollar rose yesterday on worry about the Middle East and on technical buying by traders adjusting their positions in advance of the results of the day's elections.   The dollar rose more than a yen and a half against the Japanese currency and came off its lows against the German mark and the Swiss franc.

headline: Cuban Communist Party Is Moving to Slash Its Bureaucracy by Half
abstract: LEAD: Cuba's ruling Communist Party has moved to streamline its bloated bureaucracy, slashing national and provincial party posts by 50 percent and reorganizing the powerful Central Committee Secretariat.

headline: Campbell Consolidates
abstract: LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company is consolidating its worldwide biscuit and bakery operations into one organization and has named Richard A. Shea president of the new division. Campbell's United States biscuit and bakery operations were previously grouped under Pepperidge Farm, while the international biscuit and bakery businesses were a division of Campbell International.

headline: Serbian Voting Today Could Signal A Major Turn in Yugoslavia's Future
abstract: Voters will cast ballots on Sunday in Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, to deliver a verdict on a government whose raw blend of old-style one-party rule and aggressive nationalism has made it a central issue for the country's uncertain future.    The vote in Serbia completes a year of free elections held throughout Eastern Europe on the ruins of now-defunct Communist systems. With the exception of Albania, this Balkan republic of 9.5 million will be the last not only in the region but in Yugoslavia itself to undertake the initiation into democracy.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 519 money market mutual funds increased by $3.76 billion, to $415.11 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday. The Investment Company Institute said yesterday that the assets of the 159 institutional funds increased by $2.48 billion, to $102.33 billion. The assets of the 255 general-purpose funds were up by $625.4 million, to $146.78 billion.

headline: British to Prosecute 3 Detectives in I.R.A. Case
abstract: Three police detectives involved in the investigation of the Irish Republican Army bombing of an English bar in 1974 in which 5 people were killed and 65 were wounded were charged today with conspiracy to pervert the course of justice.    The decision to prosecute the three came nearly 13 months after a Court of Appeals quashed the murder convictions of three Roman Catholic men from Northern Ireland and an English woman who were blamed for the bombing in Guilford, which is in the County of Surrey, southwest of London. They were quashed after police investigators concluded that detectives in Surrey had rewritten, altered or suppressed important interviews with the defendants and then lied in court to secure the convictions. The four, who were serving life sentences, were freed after 15 years in prison.

headline: Europeans Reach Accord on Farm Aid; Tepid Reaction in U.S.
abstract: American trade officials said today the Brussels agreement should forestall an untimely collapse of the Uruguay Round, but they insisted it would have to be sweetened considerably to serve as a basis for future farm negotiations.   A Bush Administration trade official said the proposed cutback in the community's farm spending was "inadequate," but he added, "If it means they are ready to talk now, that's a good sign."

headline: 127 Killed in Jetliner Collision in China
abstract: HONG KONG, Wednesday, Oct. 3 -- The death toll in China's worst air disaster on record rose this morning to 127 people killed and 46 seriously injured, but there were conflicting accounts of how the hijacked aircraft happened to crash in the southern Chinese city of Canton.

headline: Bogota Journal; Was the Beautiful Anti-Drug Agent a Cartel Spy?
abstract: To her fellow agents in Colombia's anti-drug police force, Diana Margarita Fonseca was a chestnut-haired beauty who one year was elected the police organization's "Charm Queen."   But many Bogotanos suspect that the Charm Queen of Colombia's Administrative Department of Security may have led a double life as an operative of the Medellin drug cartel. Her story may say as much about Colombian press hyperbole and assumptions about feminine guile as about drug traffickers' infiltration of police agencies.

headline: Gas Prices Dip Nearly 6 Cents
abstract: Gasoline prices fell an average of nearly 6 cents a gallon during the last two weeks, the biggest drop since the Persian Gulf crisis began, according to a national survey released Sunday.    The average price for all grades of gasoline at full-service and self-service stations was $1.40 a gallon as of Friday, a drop of 5.79 cents from Dec. 7, according to the survey of 13,600 gasoline stations by an oil industry analyst, Trilby Lundberg.

headline: 6 Plus System, Visa in Deal
abstract: Plus System Inc. and Visa U.S.A. agreed today on a program providing their card holders with access to all United States based automated teller machines in the Plus and Visa networks.   In the next two years, the move will add 14,000 domestic sites to the Visa network and 6,000 sites to the Plus network.   Wesley C. Tallman, Visa's executive vice president for debit systems, estimated that financial institutions would see increased teller-machine volume from the 410 million cards from both networks.   Small technical changes will be required in the machines to permit the added access, executives said.   The announcement was made at the Bank Administration Institute's Retail Delivery Systems Conference. Plus is based in Denver, and Visa U.S.A. is based in San Mateo, Calif.

headline: A Scramble for New Bailout Funds
abstract: The Bush Administration began scrambling today for ways to finance the bailout of the savings and loan industry in the wake of Congress's decision in its waning hours over the weekend not to supply any more money to the limping rescue effort.   A senior Treasury official, Deputy Secretary John E. Robson, said in an interview today that the department was considering use of an ambiguous provision in last year's bailout legislation that could permit the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the bailout, to borrow an additional $18.8 billion. But he said it would probably be days or longer before a decision would be made as the Administration evaluated the political and practical consequences of borrowing without Congressional approval. He added that even if some funds were borrowed, the pace of the bailout would be forced to slow considerably.

headline: U.S. Receives Assurance
abstract: The Saudi Defense Minister's suggestion that Kuwait could make territorial concessions in exchange for an Iraqi withdrawal alarmed the Bush Administration, but the United States is now satisfied that the comment did not reflect Saudi Government policy, officials said today.   American officials hurriedly contacted the Saudi Ambassador in Washington, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, after the Minister, Prince Sultan, was quoted by Arab journalists in Riyadh on Sunday as saying Arab countries were ready to grant Iraq "all its rights."

abstract: For much of Eastern Europe, 1991 is certain to be a year of swift economic change, one that aims to keep pace with the monumental political changes the region has undergone.    So far, with the first year of Eastern Europe's post-Communist era drawing to a close, the region's economy has moved only a few steps on the road to capitalism, save for Poland.

headline: Soviet Economists Warn of Paralysis
abstract: A group of free-market economists, including two of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's top advisers, warned today that the Soviet leader's compromise economic program was pointing the country toward hyperinflation and political paralysis.    The public disavowal of Mr. Gorbachev's approach was a symptom of serious discord in the Kremlin, as the reformers in the inner circle begin to lose hope that the Soviet leader can get the economic crisis under control.

headline: U.S. Sales Of Vehicles Down 3.7%
abstract: LEAD: United States vehicle sales dropped 3.7 percent in late September compared with a strong period a year ago, but analysts said today that the results were surprisingly strong in light of recent negative economic developments.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Du Pont Co., Wilmington, Del., will sell its formaldehyde plant in Toledo, Ohio, to Perstorp Polyols Inc. of Sweden. * Fedders Corp., Peapack, N.J., a maker of air-conditioners, will buy the Emerson Quiet Kool division of the Jepson Corp., a unit of Great American Management and Investment Inc., for $56 million and assumption of some liabilities. * Gleason Corp., Rochester, said its board had decided not to sell the company despite overtures from G. S. Beckwith Gilbert and Field Point Capital Management Co. * International Business Machines Corp., Armonk, N.Y., will move the headquarters of its worldwide communications division to Britain from Somers, N.Y. * Reliance Financial Services Corp., a subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings Inc., a concern controlled by the family of Saul P. Steinberg, purchased 451,000 common shares in the UAL Corporation in the third quarter. UAL has about 21.9 million common shares outstanding. * Thorn EMI P.L.C., London, a telecommunications, electronics and entertainment conglomerate, will pay a maximum of $93.5 million for Filmtrax P.L.C., a British music publisher, and its U.S. subsidiary, Filmtrax Copyright Holdings Inc.

headline: East German Aides Ousted
abstract: LEAD: Control of East German industry was removed from officials appointed by the ousted Communist administration and handed over to Western businessmen on Thursday.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: All financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Christmas. Banks, government offices and most businesses were also closed.

headline: Hard Times? Not for These Stores
abstract: They conduct a no-frills business in cavernous warehouses on the outskirts of towns, shun advertising and limit access to those with memberships. But by offering a wide variety of goods at wholesale prices, membership warehouse clubs have quietly and firmly positioned themselves as a rare bright spot in the nation's dim retailing environment.   Moreover, in an economy certain to encourage even more bargain hunting by consumers and businesses alike, the huge stores that carry everything from mayonnaise to mattresses are expected to outperform mainstream retailers by a wide margin in the next several years.

headline: Allied-Signal Appoints Fibers Unit President
abstract: Allied-Signal Inc. yesterday named David C. Hill as president of its Allied Fibers division, a producer of nylon with annual sales of $1.1 billion.   Mr. Hill, 44 years old, succeeds Daniel Burnham, 43, who became president of the company's AiResearch division, part of its aerospace operations.

headline: Strong Demand Lowers Rate on One-Year Bills
abstract: The Treasury's delayed auction of one-year bills was greeted with strong demand yesterday, which caused the average discount rate on the $10.13 billion issue to drop to its lowest level in almost two and a half years.   With bids totaling almost five times the $10.13 billion being sold, and the Federal Reserve abstaining as a bidder, the average discount rate sank to 7.01 percent, from 7.25 percent at the last auction of one-year bills on Sept. 20, and was the lowest since May 5, 1988, when the average auction rate was 6.74 percent.

headline: Global-Lender Aid Is Seen For Debtors Hurt by Crisis
abstract: The International Monetary Fund is expected to move Friday toward getting more and faster financial aid to countries feeling the economic shock from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, American and other officials said today.    "The whole idea is to make the fund more flexible in dealing with members' requests for cash," said an international official who insisted on not being identified.

headline: Upstate Banks in Talks
abstract: LEAD: The National Savings Bank of Albany said today that it was holding talks with the Trustco Bank Corporation of Schenectady, N.Y., about a possible business combination. A National Savings Bank spokesman said the talks were preliminary and any proposal would have to be acted upon by the board, which will meet on Tuesday.

headline: Canada Closing Set By Kelsey-Hayes
abstract: LEAD: A Kelsey-Hayes Canada Ltd. steel wheel plant in Windsor, Ontario, will be closed by the end of the month, resulting in the loss of about 450 hourly and salaried jobs, the company said. The company cited ''grave operational problems and mounting losses due to significant overcapacity in the steel wheels manufacturing industry.

headline: MCA Goes Calling on Capitol Hill
abstract: MCA Inc., the parent company of Universal Studios and MCA Records, has enlisted some of Washington's heavy hitters to promote its possible sale to the Matsushita Electric Company, Japan's largest electronics company.   The entertainment company, known for its political connections, has a board that includes both Robert S. Strauss, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee and a United States trade representative, and former Senator Howard H. Baker, who served as Senate Republican leader and President Reagan's chief of staff. The company's lobbyists include Jody Powell, President Carter's press secretary, and Anne Wexler, the public liaison in the Carter White House. Taking Swift Action     Their mission is to overcome possible political objections to the MCA-Matsushita deal by critics who might argue that it involves the sale of a national resource to a foreign predator. The sales of CBS Records and, later, Columbia Studios to the Sony Corporation were criticized in some quarters on those grounds. MCA's strategy has been to act swiftly, portraying the proposal as a way of providing the money the company needs for global expansion.

headline: Four Nations to Send a Force to Supervise Truce in Rwanda
abstract: Central African nations have agreed to send a peacekeeping force to supervise a cease-fire in Rwanda, where civil war broke out last month after rebels invaded from Uganda.   The agreement by the four nations on Friday prompted the Belgian Government to announce today that it was withdrawing the 500 paratroopers that it sent to Rwanda on Oct. 4 to protect Belgians living there. Prime Minister Wilfried Martens said the troops would begin leaving the former Belgian colony on Thursday.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Advo-System Inc., Windsor, Conn., a direct mail concern, appointed Kay Knight Clarke senior vice president of business development. * J. I. Case, Racine, Wis., a unit of Tenneco Inc., Houston, named Gary L. Tessitore executive vice president and general manager of its agricultural equipment group; Richard L. Wambold executive vice president, and Edward McFadden senior vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Mr. Tessitore. * Federal National Mortgage Association, Washington, appointed William E. Kelvie senior vice president and chief information officer. * Lehman Brothers, a division of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., New York, appointed James M. Davin executive vice president and director of worldwide equity sales in its world equity division. * Viacom International Inc., a unit of Viacom Inc., New York, named Jill Newfield vice president of counsel and enterprises in its law department. * Ziff-Davis Publishing Co., a division of Ziff Communications Co., New York, appointed Frank Kelcz vice president of international operations.

headline: Chapter 11 Filing By a Van Maker
abstract: The Starcraft Corporation, a maker of recreational vehicles, filed for protection from creditors in Federal Bankruptcy Court, blaming high gasoline prices, the threat of war in the Middle East and a weakening economy. The company's chairman, J. Michael Bell, said he expected Starcraft and its units would pay off their debts and emerge from court-directed reorganization "in a healthy condition."   Van conversions, an important part of Starcraft's business, shrank at least 30 percent in September, a month after Iraq invaded Kuwait and gasoline prices began rising, according to the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation, the largest suppliers of van chassis to the conversion industry. Last month, Starcraft laid off 30 employees at its offices. The company employs about 400 people in Goshen, Ind., and about 300 in Topeka, Ind.

headline: Bankers Trust Posts Profit a Year After $1.42 Billion Loss
abstract: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that it earned $170 million, or $1.98 a share, in the third quarter, compared with a loss of $1.42 billion in the comparable 1989 period, when the company recorded a $1.6 billion addition to reserves to cover possible losses on loans to third-world nations.    Without the added reserves, quarterly earnings would have declined 5.6 percent, from $180 million, or $2.18 a share, a year ago.

headline: South Asian Nations, in Turmoil, Will Meet
abstract: The leaders of seven South Asian countries are to begin a meeting here on Wednesday, at a time of more widespread internal turmoil and greater uncertainty about the region's place in the world than those countries have known in decades.    Four of the seven regional nations -- India, Pakistan, Nepal and Sri Lanka -- have new Governments, all born of controversy and violence to one degree or another.

headline: Kenyan Bans a Journal That Upholds the Law
abstract: LEAD: The Government on Friday banned The Nairobi Law Monthly, a popular magazine, in a signal that President Daniel arap Moi is hardening his opposition to opening up the political system here.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Rust-Oleum Corp., Vernon Hills, Ill., to Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago, with a budget between $4 million and $5 million. The account was handled by Ketchum Advertising, Pittsburgh. * Doral Hotels Inc., New York, to Austin Kelley Advertising, Atlanta, with a budget of $4 million. * Swank Inc., New York, to Rubin Reid Noto & Ehrenthal Inc., New York, for its L'Aiglon men's accessories, Pierre Cardin men's accessories and Royal Copenhagen cologne accounts. Billings have not been determined.

headline: Bush, in Germany, Finds Kohl Cool to Gulf Policy, Stressing Talks Instead
abstract: As President Bush paid a brief visit to Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl offered only lukewarm support today for Mr. Bush's Persian Gulf strategy and referred repeatedly to the idea of conducting negotiations with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.    The Chancellor's remarks left White House officials trying to play down seeming differences between the two leaders over gulf policy.

headline: Japan's Ambiguous Economic News
abstract: LEAD: The latest economic news seems completely incongruous: the financial markets are reeling as stock prices continue their vicious yearlong plunge and interest rates soar to their highest levels in nearly a decade. In the meantime, the economy is so vigorous the policy makers' biggest worry is how to rein it in.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.62   7.62   8.37        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.05   7.10   7.72        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.03   7.06   7.58        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.32   8.41   7.85        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Turkey's Top Officer Quits, But Only Hints Why
abstract: The chief of Turkey's armed forces resigned unexpectedly today, possibly to protest President Turgut Ozal's personal management of Turkey's front-line stand against neighboring Iraq.    The military leader, Gen. Necip Torumtay, did not detail the reasons for his unusual action, the first of its kind in memory here.

headline: Egypt's Money Dealers: Victims of Gulf Crisis
abstract: Psst! Hey, mister, wanna change dollars?   That is the time-honored cry of Egypt's illegal money-dealers, the siren-call of the sharp-eyed men who sidle up to foreigners, offering a deal from a well-thumbed wad. Yet in recent days, the call has been reduced to a sibilant whisper, and it has become as rare as a songbird in a sandstorm -- yet one more victim of the crisis in the Persian Gulf.   With precipitate determination, the authorities here have clamped down on the black market, which offers the Egyptian currency, the pound, at a modest margin above its official rate in the banks, which is now 2.88 Egyptian pounds to the dollar.   At least 13 street dealers in currency have been arrested and "large amounts" of contraband dollars have been confiscated from them, Interior Ministry officials said. And the 16 legal dealers in the Port Said duty-free zone on the Suez Canal -- who are officially authorized to deal in free-market dollars -- have been told to close for a month to display their patriotism.   The reason is that, since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the parallel market has been starved of the dollarsthat usually flow from Egyptian expatriate workers returning home from the gulf with dollars to change at the highest available rate.   Responding to the laws of supply and demand, the rare dollars commanded ever higher local prices, and the parallel rate leapt from around 3 pounds to the dollar to 3.25 pounds, while the official rate languished at around 2.85 -- an unusually large gap.   The rate traditionally rises in December as people in business seek dollars to settle year-end accounts.   But the surge to 3.25 also meant that many people risked unlawful transactions to sell dollars for a high price,thereby diverting the American currency from official banking channels.   Dollars, German marks, British pounds, French francs or any other convertible currency are highly valued because Egyptians may not routinely buy them at the banks except for officially authorized transactions.   "We are Egyptians who love our country and wouldn't do anything to affect its economy," said Hassan Abu Reida, president of the Port Said association of legal currency dealers. "That is why we decided to stop our dealings in dollars for a whole month to prove to everyone that we are not the reason for the rising value of the dollar."   The authorities, apparently, did not fully share the assessment, charging that the money-changers had far exceeded the small margin above the official rate that they are allowed to offer. Thus, officials said, the dealers had been told to deposit their dollars at the bank and put up signs saying: "For the sake of Egypt, dealing in dollars has been stopped." The Port Said market was established three years ago as part of an earlier and much wider crackdown on rampant illegal currency dealing.   Even before the latest ban, the cut-off in remittances had caused problems. Official Egyptian estimates put the likely losses to the economy from lost remittances, fallen tourism and reduced Suez Canal transit fees at $4.5 billion a year.   And even before the gulf crisis, dollars could be a dicey business because Egyptians working in Iraq were supposed to await oft-delayed bank transfers from Baghdad for their earningsand were barred by the Iraqi authorities from carrying dollar bills out of the country.   That, in turn, led to undignified moments at Baghdad's airport as rigorous and unsmiling customs officials uncovered contraband dollars hidden in Egyptian workers' socks, shoes, hems and pockets -- and once even in the backing of a portrait of President Saddam Hussein carried by a homebound Egyptian worker.   Ezzat Sonbati, Assistant Interior Minister, said the newest crackdown had begun to take effect, with the street traders offering to change dollars at three Egyptian pounds while the official rate, set each day by a committee of bankers, had been increased to 2.88.    "If you find a single black market dollar in Cairo let me know," he told a reporter. "But you'll never find any."

headline: Sorbs of Germany Say Long Live the Difference
abstract: On the road map it says Dissen, but Hermann Jahn calls his village of 500, strung along a tree-lined road, Desno.   That is because Mr. Jahn, a 70-year-old carpenter, is one of the Sorbs, a small Slavic minority in southeastern Germany. Desno's sturdy cabins lie on the hilly wooded fault line where Czechs, Poles, Germans and Silesians historically have flowed one into the other.

headline: Suit on Mesa Bid For Phillips Settled
abstract: A Federal judge has approved a $6.7 million settlement involving Mesa Limited Partnership, headed by T. Boone Pickens; the Phillips Petroleum Company, and Phillips shareholders. Mesa, Phillips and other defendants agreed to settle the suit brought by Phillips shareholders unhappy with Phillips's use of "greenmail" to head off a takeover bid by Mr. Pickens in 1984. In greenmail a company pays a premium to acquire the shares of an unwelcome stockholder.    United States District Judge Murray M. Schwartz approved the settlement in Wilmington, Del., on Monday and dismissed the case with prejudice, which means it cannot be brought up again. Mesa will pay about 80 percent of the amount. The settlement stipulates that the defendants make the payment without conceding guilt or wrongdoing.

headline: Journal to Close Philadelphia News Bureau
abstract: The Wall Street Journal announced yesterday that it would close its bureau in Philadelphia at the end of the year as an economy move and that some of the 10 reporters and editors there would be dismissed.   Roger B. May, a Journal spokesman, said that to his knowledge it was the first time The Journal had laid off news personnel, and certainly the first time in many years.

headline: Dow Slides 5.69 on Poor Economic Reports
abstract: Stocks seesawed yesterday in quiet trading amid new signs that a recession could be on the way.    By the end of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen 5.69, to 2,442.33.

headline: U.N. Will Send Envoy to Israel as a Test
abstract: The United Nations has decided to send an envoy to Israel on a trip that is widely seen here as a test of Israel's desire to cooperate with the Security Council in dealing with the occupied territories, members of the Security Council said today.    After first refusing to cooperate with any United Nations investigation into the shootings of at least 17 Palestinians at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem in October, the Israeli Government changed position under American pressure earlier this week and agreed to invite Jean-Claude Aime, a senior United Nations official, to visit the country.

headline: Frequent-Flier Suit Is Allowed
abstract: The Appeals Court of Illinois decided yesterday that frequent fliers can bring suit against American Airlines over changes in the rules of its frequent-flier program that made it more difficult to get seats to desirable destinations.   The court said a group of frequent fliers was entitled to bring a class-action suit on behalf of the nine million members of American's Advantage program under the consumer fraud laws of Illinois.   The group said that American was guilty of breach of contract because of the changes it made in its frequent- flier rules on May 18, 1988, and contended that those who accumulated mileage before that date were subject to capacity controls when they sought to use the program.    Before May 1988, there were no limits on frequent-flier seats. Under the controls a limited number of seats are alloted for a certain types of fares and other restricted travel.   One the lawyers who handled the case, Gilbert Gordon of Marks, Marks & Kaplan of Chicago, said frequent fliers had found it difficult to get seats to highly desirable destinations like Hawaii because of the capacity controls.   He said the court had ruled that his clients could bring suit in a lower court to have American remove the capacity controls for those who want to cash in miles accumulated before May 1988. He said American had said it would appeal the decision to the Illinois Supreme Court.

headline: Indiana Housing Bonds in 2 Parts
abstract: The Indiana Housing Finance Authority is offering $45 million in single-family mortgage revenue bonds in two parts through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.   About $19 million of the financing includes debt securites with longer maturities, offering investors a yield of 7.45 percent for an issue due in 2011 and 7.50 percent for an issue due in 2016.    For certain investors, bonds in the remaining $25.6 million of the financing may be subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax. Yields on the short maturities range from 6.15 percent in 1993 to 7 percent in 2002, while a long-term issue due in 2022 is priced to yield 7.75 percent.    Underwriters said the financing, which was not rated by Standard & Poor's, was rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service

headline: Airlines Are Nervous About Rapid Spread Of 2-for-1 Fare Deal
abstract: What began as a small promotion offered by one airline to a small group of customers has grown into a nationwide giveaway that has delighted tens of thousands of passengers but is hurting the industry and infuriating travel agents.   Earlier this month, American Airlines mailed coupons to members of its frequent-flier plan in Chicago, offering them a chance, on certain routes, to buy a second ticket for $50 on flights for which they had purchased excursion fares. When other airlines learned of the offer, they matched the promotion, then went one better. Within days, the nation's large airlines were all offering a companion ticket without charge to people who bought a round-trip ticket at the most inexpensive advance-purchase fares.

headline: German Phone System Is Taxed by Unification
abstract: Concern that telecommunications shortcomings are hindering the economic and administrative fusing of the two Germanys has led to new pressure to radically change the telecommunications arm of Deutsche Bundespost, Germany's lumbering supplier of telephone and postal services.   When the Berlin wall fell a year ago, only 200 telephone lines carried calls from East Germany to West Germany, and only 1,100 in the other direction. While the Bundespost has moved to increase the number of lines, its pace has not been fast enough for many German businesses and Government offices trying to complete calls.

headline: Real Estate; Market Slow For Offices In Boston
abstract: NEWLY built office buildings in downtown Boston are struggling to find tenants amid a general downturn in development activity, which is related to the slowing New England economy.  At present, two major projects are under construction across the street from each other. One is known as 125 High Street, a $450 million development with 1.5 million square feet of space. The other is the 750,000-square-foot second phase of International Place, scheduled to open early in 1992. A 20-minute walk away in the Back Bay neighborhood, the 470,000-square-foot 222 Berkeley Street is also going up. With 2.72 million square feet of space in construction, the pace of building shows a decline from the heyday of the mid-80's.

headline: Trade-Talk Role Seen For Ottawa
abstract: Officials of the United States, Canada and Mexico say they are fast sweeping away obstacles to Canadian participation in the free-trade negotiations expected to open in 1991 between the United States and Mexico.   The three countries are expected to begin shaping a single agreement that would create a North American common market of 350 million people. "We're clearing away the underbrush and will start on the big trees very quickly," said Canada's Minister of International Trade, John C. Crosbie.

headline: China Ready to Try (and Forget) Dissidents
abstract: Perhaps what is most remarkable about Zhu Jianbin is not that he has spent the last nine years in prison for trying to promote democracy, but that he has been so totally forgotten in the labyrinth of the Chinese penal system.   Mr. Zhu is evidence that repression sometimes works, for the authorities have locked him up without attracting any significant criticism or tarnishing their image.

headline: Penthouse Publisher Is Aiding N.A.A.C.P.
abstract: Bob Guccione, the publisher of Penthouse magazine, will play host to a fund-raising party that will include the first showing of a public service campaign for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.    Paragon Cable, which serves upper Manhattan, has produced eight public service spots that will be shown to its customers. The ads, which feature N.A.A.C.P. members talking about the organization, use the theme "The struggle continues." The spots will get their first showing at the Manhattan apartment of Mr. Guccione and his wife, Kathy Keeton, during the party next week.    "We've always been interested in the N.A.A.C.P.," Mr. Guccione said in an interview. "It's been part of our editorial and publishing philosophy to help underprivileged groups. I was born in the city and what happens here is of concern to us."

headline: All About/The Spice Business;   Ancient Industry Catches Up With the Microwave Generation
abstract: LEAD: As 1992 nears and Americans prepare to celebrate 500 years since Columbus's voyage, they should prepare to pay tribute to spices. When he bumped into America, after all, Columbus was on a mission for the King and Queen of Spain to locate a new and speedier route to a place called the Spice Islands, now part of

headline: Freeport-McMoran
abstract: LEAD: Freeport-McMoran Inc. said it had agreed in principle to raise its payments to settle lawsuits challenging the merger with the Freeport-McMoran Oil and Gas Company. The original agreement was reached before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, which sent oil prices soaring. The company said it had agreed to increase the price for each Freeport-McMoran Oil and Gas share to $11 from $10.50.

headline: United Thrives Amid Turmoil
abstract: LEAD: Given the environment in which it has been operating, the UAL Corporation could have become a basket case long ago. As if four takeover bids and three chief executives in four years were not enough, the parent of United Airlines has recently been battered by the rising fuel prices and weakening traffic that have troubled the whole industry.

headline: Zale Jewelry Retailer Names Top Executive
abstract: The Zale Corporation, a jewelry chain owned by Canadian and Swiss  interests, yesterday named Dennis S. Bookshester, a former Chicago department store executive, to be president and chief executive.    Mr. Bookshester, 50 years old, succeeds Irving R. Gerstein, who is also president and chairman of Peoples Jewelers Ltd. of Toronto, which owns Zale with Swarovski International Holdings A.G. of Switzerland. The appointment is effective Dec. 1.

headline: Peru's Church Battles a Contraception Plan
abstract: In the Spanish Colonial central plaza of Lima, where the bell towers of the Roman Catholic cathedral face the Baroque spires of the Presidential Palace, a centuries-old calm between church and state has been shattered by a dispute over contraception.    The controversy is over an ambitious plan by Peru's new President, Alberto Fujimori, to extend free family planning advice and devices to all Peruvians who want them.

headline: NCR Terms A.T.&T. Bid Far Too Low
abstract: In announcing yesterday that its directors had unanimously rejected A.T.& T.'s $90-a-share tender offer, the NCR Corporation called the bid "grossly inadequate and unfair."   The announcement, included in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission, sets the stage for a complex proxy fight with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for control of the company's board.

headline: Business Diary/October 28-November 2
abstract: COMPANIES General Motors Scales Down, Ford and Chrysler Fall Back Alfred P. Sloan Jr.'s credo for turning General Motors into the world's largest company was simple: "Growth," he said, "is essential to the good health of an enterprise. Deliberately to stop growing is to suffocate." But size can be stifling as well, and last week G.M. gave up hope of regaining the immense portion of the market it has lost. The auto maker plans to shut nine plants, leaving it with a record quarterly loss of $1.98 billion G.M. executives want a company at least as trim and fit as Ford became after closing plants and cutting costs proved his company's decision to change course. "Any rigidity by an automobile manufacturer, no matter how large or how well established, is severly penalized by the market," he wrote. G.M. said its write-offs cover all foreseeable costs, but many analysts wonder whether G.M. will continue to shrivel. As James P. Womack, who studies the auto industry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said, "The real question is whether four years from now we'll just be repeating the process."    Ford and Chrysler, despite their efficiency campaigns, had a tough quarter too. The Ford Motor Company's third-quarter earnings fell 78.7 percent to $101.7 million on weak demand for cars and losses at its savings and loan subsidiary. The Chrysler Corporation blamed lower production of minivans and continuing sales incentives for a $214 million loss. Chrysler asked for special concessions from the United Automobile Workers, but the union said that a tentative contract settlement last week followed the pattern at Ford and G.M. Chrysler said on Friday that is has given up on arranging a European joint venture with the Fiat Group of Italy. The End Of the Clamshell Era  It was a landmark in the cluttered landscape of corporate images. The McDonald's plastic foam box completed an identity program that began with the arches and continued with proprietary names for variations on the hamburger. The package served several functions well, said Stewart Mosberg, senior director of the Walter Dorwin Teague Associates industrial design firm. "It retained heat, it was lightweight, and disposable," he said. "It's ubiquitous. It's everywhere." But the yellow clamshell boxes with the bold logos also became some of the nation's most visible refuse. Environmentalists faulted the company's plans for recycling packages that otherwise take decades to degrade. Last week, the company abruptly announced it would turn to paper and cellophane packaging instead. The technological challenge: using paper, not foam, to keep the lettuce and tomato cool and the hamburger separate and warm in wrapping a McDLT.   A Slide for Steel  Staying in the steel business has its costs. USX said last week that it plans to make its steel operations a wholly owned subsidiary -- easing the way for a sale of all or part of them, as Carl C. Icahn, the company's largest shareholder, demands. Lower steel earnings left the USX Corporation with a 6.8 percent drop, to $163 million, in third-quarter income, despite higher profits from energy. Bethlehem Steel, still relying almost entirely on its prime business, reported its quarterly profits fell 78 percent to $10.1 million. Even as the weaker dollar has helped American steelmakers fend off imports, overcapacity and a slack economy have tamped down their prices. Said Peter L. Anker, an analyst at First Boston, "This is the lowest-price market in the world today."   A Probe at New York Telephone  Prosecutors who have found widespread corruption in the buildings department of New York Telephone may seek criminal indictments, the company's president said on Friday. Frederic V. Salerno said as many as 80 of his employees, and some at other companies, are under investigation. In Brief  R.H. Macy & Co. plans to sell as much as $150 million in equity to help repay its debts. Britain's two satellite television networks, British Satellite Broadcasting and Rupert Murdoch's Sky Television, plan to merge. Harold Evans, the editor in chief of Conde Nast's Traveler magazine, took over as publisher at Random House. Having resigned as editor of The Times of London eight years ago in a dispute with its owner, Mr. Murdoch, Mr. Evans is now responsible for publishing Mr. Murdoch's memoirs. Federal regulators announced plans on Friday to sell 18 large savings and loan associations, including Lincoln Savings, the industry's most costly failure. INTERNATIONAL   A Moscow Currency Sale  Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev plies foreign companies with more blandishments, but too few to persuade them that his nation is truly open for business. Mr. Gorbachev has recently announced steps to help Western businesses take home their profits and manage their ventures without Soviet partners. Beginning in January, foreign businesses with ruble earnings will be able to bid at Government auctions of convertible currencies. Western companies doubt they will obtain enough hard currency to avoid the trouble of taking their profits in pickles, pianos and other local products. And these businesses might continue to depend on Soviet partners for office space and plant sites, since foreigners cannot own property and have difficulty renting it. Only a determined program to free prices and make the ruble convertible will allow liberalized business policies to succeed, said Michael Mandelbaum, director of the Project on East-West Relations at the Council on Foreign Relations. "The history of reform has been too little, too late," he said. "You really need a big bang."   The Value of a Dinar  It was becoming difficult to squeeze all the zeroes onto the currency. By the time Yugoslavia issued a million-dinar note, now worth less than $10, superscript exponents seemed like the next step. Instead, the Government of Prime Minister Ante Markovic has, in the last year, introduced a new, semi-convertible dinar, worth 10,000 of the old ones, and pegged its value to the German mark. Prices have been freed, import restrictions relaxed. Inflation fell from 2,500 percent last year to less than 1 percent in July and August before higher wages and energy prices caused a 7 percent jump in September. "It's a shock program," said Keith Crane, a senior economist at Planecon, a Washington consulting firm, "similar to that of Mexico or Poland." Yugoslavian industrial output fell by about 10 percent this year. But Mr. Markovic's popularity remains one of the few forces holding his fractious country together. THE ECONOMY   The Indicators Drop  A plunge in the leading economic indicators and continuing job losses left many economists debating only about the severity of a recession. The leading index fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in September, the second straight monthly decline. Nonagricultural employment shrank by 70,000 in October, the fourth monthly decline, according to a payroll survey. Although October unemployment remained at 5.7 percent, economists pointed to slow growth in the labor force rather than renewed hiring.  Gloom on Growth  Word that the gross national product grew at an annual rate of 1.8 percent in the third quarter caused no cheer. Several economists said that higher oil prices began doing damage only recently. Alan C. Lerner, of Bankers Trust, foresees just a short, mild recession. But he added that continued Federal borrowing and burdensome corporate debt will retard growth "for years to come." Reading the Fed's Signs  Was the Federal Reserve Board's reduction in interest rates last week just a beginning? Several observers say so. Neal M. Soss, chief economist at First Boston, predicts that, at its Nov. 13 meeting, the Fed will authorize another quarter-percent reduction in the short-term Federal funds rate -- "with more to come after the New Year." The cut last Monday, to 7.75 percent, fulfilled the Fed's pledge to ease interest rates after Congress agreed to reduce the budget deficit. Then came a cascade of disappointing reports likely to turn the Fed's attention from fighting inflation to softening a recession. As William V. Sullivan Jr., director of money market research at Dean Witter, said about the Federal Reserve's chairman, "I don't think Alan Greenspan wants to be the grinch that stole Christmas."  More Grim News  Much of last week's other economic news was sobering: weekly unemployment claims up 33,000 for the week ending Oct. 20; September new-home sales falling to their lowest level since the 1982 recession; the fourth consecutive monthly drop in the purchasing managers' index of economic activity. Consumer spending did bounce up 1.1 percent in September, and personal income rose as well. But the Federal Reserve said that business and consumer confidence was fading, with slower economic growth in most regions during September.

headline: President of Navistar Retiring This Month
abstract: Neil A. Springer, who was named president and chief operating officer of the Navistar International Corporation in March, plans to retire at the end of the month.   Mr. Springer, who is 52 years old, has spent more than 30 years with the company, which was formerly called the International Harvester Company. He is known as an operations man, while the company's chairman and chief executive, James C. Cotting, 57, came up on the financial side.

headline: High Pakistan Court Upholds Dismissal of Bhutto
abstract: LEAD: A high court in Lahore today upheld President Ghulam Ishaq Khan's dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Government on Aug. 6.

headline: With Nation in Turmoil, Bangladeshis Fear Strife
abstract: As politicians struggle to fill the vacuum left by the abrupt resignation of President H. M. Ershad a week ago, many Bangladeshis say they fear that economic collapse and widespread civil strife may be unavoidable.    "The ports are not functioning, and we are going to run out of food in the countryside," a businessman said, placing the blame for the situation on Mr. Ershad, who encouraged imports of basic commodities rather than increasing local production.

headline: Shigatse Journal;   Lamas Seek the Holy Child, but Politics Intrude
abstract: LEAD: Perhaps he is crawling about a remote village somewhere on the slopes of Mount Everest, perhaps he is not even born yet, but a small Tibetan boy will be plucked from his home sometime over the next few years and proclaimed the reincarnation of one of Buddhism's holiest figures - and thus be given the chance to help determine the future of

headline: War Talk Hurts Treasury Prices
abstract: Hawkish statements on the Middle East, a rise in oil prices and worrisome comments from a Federal Reserve Board governor combined to push down prices of Treasury securities and raise interest rates in rocky trading yesterday.    The session began placidly, with prices inching higher after news reports suggested that the Federal Reserve Board, concerned about weakness in the economy, might lower short-term interest rates again at a meeting next week.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: Economy    Bond traders say inflationary pressures have eased, even though oil prices remain significantly above levels seen before Iraq invaded Kuwait, and could go higher if war erupts.  [ Page D1. ]   Retailers are urging affluent consumers to buy expensive goods like cars, boats, jewelry and furs before the new Federal "luxury tax" takes effect on Jan. 1. The deficit-reduction bill established a 10 percent excise tax that applies to the portion of retail prices that exceeds $30,000 for automobiles, $100,000 for private boats and yachts, $10,000 for furs and jewelry, including watches, and $250,000 for private airplanes.  [ D1. ]   Many of the blacks who have taken a tenuous place in the middle class are scaling the economic ladder with one hand on the rung and the other outstretched to relatives who need them.  [ A1. ]   Cape Canaveral will not be able to fend off foreign competitors in the rocket-launching business unless the base in Florida is revamped. State officials have a plan involving Federal grants and tax incentives to commercial space ventures.  [ D1. ]   Machine tool orders increased nearly 1.9 percent in October from the September level, the industry's trade association said in its monthly survey.  [ D2. ] Companies    The deal for MCA, owner of Universal Studios, seems near, but the details of the takeover by Matsushita were not yet completed last night. One participant said no hurdle had arisen to block the deal, which is valued at almost almost $7 billion.  [ D2. ] The Media Business    Ninja Turtles have conquered yet another world: Saturday morning television ratings. With its "Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles," CBS seems likely to take the lead in the prime time for children for the first time in almost a decade.  [ D1. ]   A proposed category for mail would cost newspapers millions of dollars in lost business. The Postal Service wants to create a new third-class category that would give direct-mail companies, which compete with newspapers, a 20 percent discount.  [ D1. ]   Publishers like Farrar, Straus & Giroux see great potential in Eastern Europe. Edwin McDowell: Publishing.  [ D8. ]   Mirabella and Lear's magazines are succeeding in attracting sophisticated, affluent, middle-aged women.  [ D8. ]   Advertisers often feel their agencies ignore them, according to a survey conducted by a consulting firm. But many brand managers and marketing executives said they were not thinking of switching agencies. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D9. ]  International    Taiwan is trying to accomplish a new industrial revolution by becoming a high-technology manufacturer of computers instead of toys, and satellite equipment instead of gadgets.  [ D1. ]   Czechoslovakia's Kotva department store is a leader in the Eastern European drive to modernize. Its executives have overcome many obstacles, like the scarcity of hard currency, but they still struggle to keep the shelves stocked.  [ D7. ]   Caribbean banana farmers are worried that the economic changes in Europe could kill their industry by ending the preferences they rely upon to compete with Latin American rivals.  [ D7. ] Today's Columns    Faster, prepackaged bankruptcies are becoming more popular, as more overleveraged companies admit that they cannot make the interest payments on high-yield securities they issued in the 1980's. Some troubled corporations are trying to cut both the time and expense of reorganizations. Business and the Law.  [ D2. ]   Supermarkets General wants to unleverage the company it took private before the stock market crash in 1987. It is trying buy back some of the securities it issued but says the refinancing is not a sign of distress. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D4. ]

headline: Heinz's Focus On the Family
abstract: The H. J. Heinz Company is spending more than $10 million in sponsorship to build on the image of ketchup and gravy as being as American as baseball and apple pie. The company is sponsoring "Family Works!" -- a nationally syndicated series of television programs that will focus on family issues.   The Hearst Corporation will produce and distribute the series, to begin in January in Boston. The periodic installments are expected to run for two years. Although Heinz is to be the only national advertiser, air time will be open to local advertisers.   The series would include star-studded dramas, documentaries and other features, dealing with the "stresses and challenges" of American family life in the 90's.    "When people buy a product, their choice goes beyond the performance of that product; they are buying a company," said Brian Ruder, the vice president of consumer products for Heinz U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Pittsburgh-based H. J. Heinz. "We want to build an emotional bond with our consumers without being judgmental. That bond will be the tie-breaker at the grocery store shelf."

headline: Appointment At Chiat/Day
abstract: Don Peppers has been appointed president and chief executive of Perkins/Butler Direct Marketing Inc., a subsidiary of Chiat/Day/Mojo, New York, where he is now executive vice president for business development. He replaces Robert Perkins, who was recently named president and chief executive of Chiat/Day's flagging New York office.   New business has been a concern for the agency. The New York office has lost several key accounts in the last year, most recently, the Royal Carribean Cruise Lines business.    Jay Chiat, the agency's chairman, denied that the shift of Mr. Peppers was related to the decline of billings. "The reverse is actually true," Mr. Chiat said. "His background on the client level and in agency business makes him the best possible candidate."   Mr. Peppers said that he was "ecstatic" about the new positon. "I feel it's the job I've been in training for all my adult life," he said.

headline: American Building Ends Stock Talks
abstract: LEAD: The stock of American Building Maintenance Industries plunged after the company said its two principal shareholders, Theodore and Sydney Rosenberg, had ended talks with a potential buyer for their American Building shares. The shares fell $4.875 today, to $25.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where the company's 16.1 percent decline was the second worst of the day.

headline: The Tumbling Dollar Hits A Low Against the Mark
abstract: LEAD: The dollar tumbled yesterday, breaking though the 1.50 level against the German mark and ending at its lowest level since the mark was created 42 years ago.

headline: Net Off 39% at Tribune Co.
abstract: The Tribune Company said today that its third-quarter net income declined 39 percent because of operating losses at its Canadian paper mills and The Daily News in New York.   The company said net income fell to $38.2 million, or 52 cents a share, from $62.7 million, or 81 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year. Revenues slipped five-tenths of 1 percent, to $588 million, from $590.7 million a year earlier.   Newspaper operating profit fell 15 percent in the quarter, to $48.4 million, from $56.7 million last year, because of losses at The Daily News. The company attributed the losses at The Daily News to weak economic conditions in the New York market and a "burdensome cost structure" that is the subject of labor negotiations.    Profits for the rest of the newspaper group, which includes The Chicago Tribune and The Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel, were down slightly, the company said.   For the third quarter, the company's Quebec and Ontario Paper Company reported a loss of $8.3 million, compared with a profit of $15.2 million last year. Strikes by paper workers shut down the Quebec newsprint mill for 31 days and the Ontario mill for 47 days.    Beside its newspapers and newsprint operations, the Chicago-based company is engaged in broadcasting and entertainment production. The Tribune Company's stock gained 75 cents today, to $35.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Guatemalans Face a Divisive Runoff Election
abstract: A newspaper publisher and an evangelical Christian who caught the rising tide of national discontent appeared today to be headed into a runoff election that threatens to aggravate religious factionalism here, according to returns from the presidential election held Sunday.    After trailing since the polls closed Sunday, the publisher, Jorge Carpio Nicolle, took a narrow lead today. Projections by his party, the National Center Union, gave him a slight advantage, a margin smaller than previously projected. No candidate was close to reaching 50 percent of the vote, which was necessary to avoid a runoff, scheduled for Jan. 6.

headline: Anticipating Jitters, Not Jingling
abstract: Store executives across the nation, anticipating a disappointing Christmas season beginning Friday, have already cut back on merchandise and held big sales. But a few, seeing a glimmer of hope in their early November sales, say the situation is so uncertain that results could end up being much better than predicted.   Many stores, having looked hard at the stuttering sales of recent months, are not taking any chances. To try to seize control early, chains ranging from Nordstrom to Sears and from Saks to Woolworth have in recent weeks reduced the number of items they keep in stock and cut their non-sales staffs.

headline: Foote, Cone & Belding Has 24% Quarterly Gain
