abstract: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc. of Chicago reported yesterday that third-quarter net income rose 24 percent, to $3.1 million, or 30 cents a share, from $2.5 million, or 25 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Revenues rose 10.9 percent, to $86.3 million, from $77.8 million in 1989.    "The earnings came in on target or maybe a tad better," said Greg Ostroff, vice president and industry analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York. "It's apparent that the fourth quarter will be up, but not enough to offset the weaknesses they had in the first half of the year."   Mr. Ostroff cited Foote, Cone's direct marketing firms as the weak links, rather than its advertising agency business.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, said its Bank of America unit had agreed to acquire the deposits and some of the assets of the Los Angeles-based Southwest Federal Savings Association from the Resolution Trust Corporation. Bank of America said it would acquire about $616 million in deposits and about $350 million in residential mortgage and consumer loans. * Blockbuster Entertainment Corp., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said it would buy Erols Inc., a videocassette rental and sales chain, for about $40 million in cash. * Canadian Pacific Hotels Corp., a unit of Canadian Pacific Ltd., Montreal, a holding company, said it had bought Methotels Inc., Phoenix, an operator of hotels, from Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., for an undisclosed amount. * Consolidated National Corp., Washington, an insurance holding company with a 22.5 percent stake in First Executive Corp., Los Angeles, a holding company, said its talks on ways to help reorganize First Executive were at a standstill. * B. F. Goodrich Co., Akron, Ohio, a maker of plastics and specialty chemicals, said it would form a joint venture with Norsk Hydro A.S., Oslo, a maker of fertilizers and oil and gas products, to provide specialized compounds to the European market. * Heritage Media Corp., Dallas, a television and radio company, said that it had completed the acquisition of Pop Radio Corp., an in-store radio network, and added that it would incorporate Pop Radio into its wholly owned subsidiary Actmedia, an in-store marketing company. Terms were not disclosed. * Liberty Financial Services Inc., Boston, a financial services company, formed a new unit called Liberty Distributors, Inc. through the combination of its existing units Pamco Group, Encino, Calif., a marketer of annuities and mutual funds through banks, and Liberty Securities Corp., Boston. * Trinova Corp., Maumee, Ohio, a supplier of power and motion control products, said its Vickers Inc. subsidiary, Troy, Mich., a maker of hydraulic equipment, had sold the businesses of its Statesville, N.C., and Hof, Germany operations to subsidiaries of Garphyttan Industrier A.B., Norsburg, Sweden, for undisclosed terms. * Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Co., Danbury, Conn., purchased the Triton surfactant and alkylphenol business unit from Rohm & Haas Co., Philadelphia, a maker of chemicals and plastics, for an undisclosed amount. * Varian Associates, Palo Alto, Calif., a maker of electron tubes and devices, said it would sell several of its non-core operations to DKP Electronics Inc., a privte company, for undisclosed terms.

headline: Group Says Press Freedom Is Declining in Britain
abstract: LEAD: An international human rights organization said in a report today that the Government had dramatically eroded press freedom in Britain over the last year and greatly increased its powers of censorship.

headline: Newspaper to Cut Staff
abstract: The Daily News in Los Angeles will lay off 4 percent of its workers in a cost-cutting move, its publisher, David J. Auger, said last week. The newspaper, based in the San Fernando Valley, employs about 1,200, indicating that about 48 employees will be let go. The Daily News has offered a voluntary early retirement plan to some employees, Mr. Auger said. He attributed the layoffs to the economic downturn that has hurt newspapers across the country.

headline: No Headline
abstract: LEAD: They came for him at night, the young man said, summoning him from the street. The three men wore black masks and long black wigs; one wore police trousers. They beat him up, he said.

headline: Pacific Telesis Quits Real Estate
abstract: The Pacific Telesis Group announced yesterday that it was leaving the real estate business and would take a $60 million after-tax charge against its fourth-quarter earnings to offset expected losses on property sales.   The decision is the latest recognition of losses by a regional Bell company that diversified into industries very different from the provision of local telephone service, only to find that its new investments were far more vulnerable to an economic slowdown.

headline: Consumer Prices Up by Modest 0.3%
abstract: Consumer prices rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in November, less than half the torrid oil-driven pace set during the three months immediately after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Labor Department figures showed today.    The slowdown reflected both moderation in energy prices, which benefited from diplomatic efforts to solve the crisis instead of threats of force, and a general weakness in the economy. That weakness has tended to put downward pressure on the prices of some items while preventing higher prices for energy.   When food and energy are excluded, the Consumer Price Index rose by the same three-tenths of 1 percent as when these volatile items are included. The rise in so-called core inflation has now been three-tenths of 1 percent for three straight months.  Strange Behavior for Housing     While the November increase was about as expected, many analysts had braced for an unpleasant surprise since the largest element of the price index, housing, has been behaving strangely of late and because last week's report on prices at the producer level was worse than expected.

headline: Wanted: A Kindler, Gentler Germany
abstract: THE world needs a stable, civil united Germany and the Federal elections on December 2 may tell the world if it will get one. But already Chancellor Helmut Kohl's main challenger, Oskar Lafontaine of the German Social Democrats, has said that if he wins, he will reduce immigration and asylum rights. Granted, a united Germany can only handle so many new arrivals added to the 16 million poor eastern Germans now folded into the West. But as the rise in racial attacks, Jewish cemetary desecrations and neo-Nazi activity attests, unification has already made some people more aware of themselves as Germans and less tolerant of those who are not. Government policies restricting rights for foreigners will reinforce this view. Chancellor Kohl and his party, the Christian Democratic Union, is in favor of restricting immigration except to foreigners of German ancestry.   Economic pressures may not undermine democracy in Germany. But they could increase German nationalism and xenophobia. With most layoffs in eastern Germany still to come and with unemployed easterners expected to migrate west, economic pressure for all Germans seems near. According to Government estimates, in the eastern German farming sector alone, unemployment could approach 750,000. And in the public sector -- as the old bureaucracy is swept away -- unemployment could reach 500,000. According to one estimate joblessness in the united Germany could reach six million -- about 16 percent.

headline: A Bankruptcy Wizard's Coups
abstract: In the weeks when Donald J. Trump was fighting to keep his prize casino out of a messy bankruptcy, one participant in the talks got under his skin like no other: a soft-spoken but stubborn investment banker named Wilbur L. Ross Jr., with an owlish face and dimpled chin.    Meet a troubled company's worst nightmare. After a decade of excess, American companies are paying the price of too much debt, and Mr. Ross has become one of the busiest financial engineers on Wall Street by helping to pick up the pieces. As the head of corporate finance at Rothschild Inc. he has built a lucrative specialty offering advice to securities holders of distressed companies like Mr. Trump's Taj Mahal -- often offending his adversaries along the way by playing the bully.

headline: With Mideast Travel Down, El Al Is Looking to Its Roots
abstract: Travel to Israel dropped substantially after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August and the killing of 21 Palestinians at a Jerusalem mosque by Israeli soldiers earlier this month.    Daniel Multer, the director of marketing and promotion for the Israeli Ministry of Tourism, said his Government had "basically shelved our advertising for the time being."

headline: Market Place;   Rating Wines As Investments
abstract: LEAD: INVESTING in wine has always been a bit like investing in art or classic cars: While there is a potential for huge returns, most participants are driven as much by passion as the profit motive. That is just as well, given the anything-but-sure nature of the investment.

headline: Dole Cautious on U.S. Role in Gulf Combat
abstract: Senator Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, said today that putting the Emir of Kuwait back on his throne was not "worth one American life, as far as I am concerned."   Appearing on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Senator Dole said the American people "want to make certain that President Bush has done everything, pursued every avenue, for peace before the firing starts."

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Borden Inc., New York, named Judy Barker vice president of social responsibility.

headline: BRITISH WARNINGS TO IRAQIS ON WAR
abstract: With expectation growing here that the United States is preparing for an attack against Iraqi forces in Kuwait as early as December, the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, warned President Saddam Hussein today, "Time is ticking on."   Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher also met today with King Hussein of Jordan in Geneva and told him that she could not rule out force to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, British officials said.

headline: Pope Endorses Statement on Anti-Semitism
abstract: Meeting with an international delegation from Jewish organizations in the Vatican, Pope John Paul II endorsed a statement yesterday drawn up three months ago acknowledging that some aspects of Catholic teaching and practice had fostered anti-Semitism and outlining plans for combating its re-emergence in Eastern Europe.   The Pope called for implementation of the conclusions reached by Jewish and Roman Catholic representatives at a conference in September in Czechoslovakia.

headline: Former Bonn Chief Forecasts His Party Will Lose Election
abstract: Former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is under heavy fire from his Social Democratic party after he predicted in a newspaper interview that the party's candidate in national elections next month, Oskar Lafontaine, would lose, adding, "He deserves it, too."    In the interview, published last week in the Rotterdam daily Algemeen Dagblad, Mr. Schmidt said Mr. Lafontaine, the party's candidate to challenge Chancellor Helmut Kohl, would be defeated.

headline: In Turkey, Iraqi Deserters Tell of Brutality in Kuwait
abstract: For a month now, 130 Iraqi Army deserters and civilian refugees have been holed up in this eastern Turkish city, where they tell of having left behind troops demoralized by meager food rations and terrorized by threats of hanging.    Some who were sent to Kuwait in the early days of the Iraqi invasion say they saw summary hangings of soldiers and the rape of young women in the streets. A few admit that they themselves had joined in the plunder of gold and cash from Kuwaiti houses, but insist that they had no choice but to take part.

headline: Loss Posted By Texas Instruments
abstract: LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc., one of the nation's largest makers of computer memory chips, said today that it lost $7 million in the third quarter, compared with a profit of $65 million, or 67 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Revenue rose 7 percent, to $1.68 billion from $1.57 billion.

headline: Steady Trade Deficit Seen
abstract: The Bush Administration predicted today in a report to Congress that the United States trade deficit would remain steady even though Americans are paying sharply more for imported oil.   Prepared by the Treasury Department as a requirement of the 1988 trade law, the report also indicated that a further decline in the value of the dollar was not needed to improve the nation's trade balance.   It predicted "a sustaining of the progress" made in reducing the current account deficit, which is the broadest measure of trade and includes investment flows.   The deficit has dropped from a peak of $162 billion in 1987 to $129 billion in 1988 and $110 billion in 1989. In the first six months of 1990, it ran at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $87 billion.   International Monetary Fund forecasts indicate that the deficit will remain below $100 billion next year, despite the run-up in oil prices, the report said. But it noted that the standoff in the Persian Gulf between the United States and Iraq made predictions more uncertain than usual.

headline: Your Money;   Taxes Complicate 'Junk Bond' Loss
abstract: LEAD: With the pounding the ''junk bond'' market has taken this year, many investors now hold high-yield, high-risk securities that are worth far less than they paid for them. And in the fourth quarter, a paper loss always raises the question of whether to sell in order to lower taxable income, and, if one still likes the holding, of whether to invest the proceeds in a similar but not identical security.

headline: Administration Backs Revamping Of Banking and Securities System
abstract: The Bush Administration threw its weight behind a broad reorganization of the commercial banking and securities industries today. It would permit banks and securities firms to merge and would remove barriers to interstate banking.    In a speech before the Securities Industry Association in Boca Raton, Fla., Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady sought to reassure critics of the approach, saying the Administration package would include strong "firewalls" between banking and non-banking arms of a company to guard against overextension of the sort that led to bank collapses in the Great Depression. Substantial Restrictions     Since then, banks have operated under substantial restrictions imposed by the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which limits their ability to underwrite and trade securities. In addition, the McFadden Act of 1927 limits their ability to open branches across state lines.

headline: Rig Count Off in Week
abstract: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped by 28 last week, to a total of 1,151, the toolmaker Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The count a year ago was 1,079 rigs. Baker Hughes has kept the rig count, a widely watched index of drilling activity, since 1940.

headline: GUATEMALA BALLOT MARKS WATERSHED
abstract: Barring a collapse brought about by the wave of political violence now afflicting Guatemala, the general elections on Sunday and the inauguration of a President in January should mark a democratic watershed: the first transfer of power from one elected civilian to another in the country's history.    That would be a significant step for the United States-backed effort to end a tradition of military dictatorship and build a working democratic system.

headline: Toyota Plant Is Expected For Kentucky
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation is expected to end months of speculation on Tuesday by announcing that it will build another automobile assembly plant near its existing factory in Georgetown, Ky.    Toyota needs the additional production capacity to meet rising demand for its vehicles in the United States. In the last year, Toyota's American sales have risen 13.7 percent.

headline: Producer Prices Post 1.1% Jump
abstract: Prices at the producer level, a prominent inflation gauge, jumped more than expected in October as oil prices continued to escalate, but economists generally took the numbers in stride.   The advance in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods was a high 1.1 percent, the third consecutive month with a rise above 1 percent. Economists noted, however, that the Labor Department's report today showed no change in producer prices when energy and food, which are subject to big gyrations, were excluded.

headline: Mortgage Woes Rise At Citicorp
abstract: Delinquent mortgages at Citicorp, the nation's largest home lender, increased substantially in the quarter ended Sept. 30, with much of the rise coming from the economically depressed Northeast.   The rise in mortgage loan delinquencies at Citicorp is a reminder, bankers and analysts said, that defaults and losses are likely to increase for most kinds of bank loans as the economy weakens. In the last year, while Citicorp, which operates Citibank, the nation's largest bank, and many other banking companies have been hurt by heavy losses on commercial real estate loans, mortgage loan portfolios have fared much better.  Report to the S.E.C.    But the new Citicorp data, included in a quarterly report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed that problems with home mortgage loans had risen, though they remained much less frequent than those with commercial real estate loans. Citicorp is also the nation's largest bank lender for commercial real estate.

headline: PREMIER OF INDIA MEETS SIKH LEADER
abstract: Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, looking for a political formula for containing a spreading separatist movement in Punjab, met tonight with an increasingly radical Sikh political leader who believes he can serve as a bridge to armed militants.   The Punjabi leader, Simranjit Singh Mann, is the spokesman for several major factions of the only nonviolent political movement with any influence left in Punjab State, the Sikhs' Akali Party. About 3,800 people have died in violence in the state this year in connection with a campaign for more autonomy or independence.

headline: Profit at Nike Is 58% Higher
abstract: Nike Inc. said today that its second-quarter earnings were up 58 percent from the corresponding period of last year.   Citing strong sales of basketball shoes and women's products, the footwear company said it earned $58.1 million, or 77 cents a share, for the three months ended on Nov. 30. That compared with $36.8 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Inventories Rose 0.5% In September
abstract: Business inventories grew five-tenths of 1 percent in September while sales suffered their biggest decline in five months, the Government said today, leading some analysts to express concern that the situation could lead to further production cuts and job losses.    "It's consistent with the idea that the economy is sliding into a recession and growth will be negative in the fourth quarter," said Evelina Tainer, an economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. She noted that industrial production in October had already dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent, its sharpest cutback in nine months.

headline: Fearful Auto Dealers Cut Back on Orders
abstract: Acting on fear that a recession is beginning, American automobile dealers are cutting back orders for new vehicles, and that is leading to widespread shutdowns of assembly plants.   William Carroll, a spokesman for the Ford Motor Company, said recent retail sales had been slightly ahead of the weak sales in the 30-day period a year earlier. But they were not strong enough to encourage dealers to place more orders with the manufacturer, he said.

headline: Homes for First-Time Buyers; Subsidies Help Staten Island Project
abstract: In the face of a regional slump in the construction of houses for first-time buyers, a development group on Staten Island is pressing ahead with the first phase of what is planned as a 586-unit condominium town house complex in the Concord section of the North Shore. The site is roughly a mile from the entrance to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.   The $75 million project, called Celebration at Rainbow Hill, has signed 90 contracts since marketing began in April. There are 150 town houses in the first phase, with two- and three-bedroom units ranging in size from 1,000 to 1,750 square feet and priced at $111,900 to $160,000. The monthly maintenance fee is $50.

headline: Protecting Balloons at 120,000 Feet
abstract: LEAD: rrHigh-altitude scientific balloons, viewed as low-tech cousins of rockets, are undergoing major technical changes as they are called upon to perform more difficult tasks in a hostile environment.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * Bozell International has signed an exclusive partnership agreement with Tass, the official Soviet press agency, to support each other's public relations, advertising and marketing interests.

headline: Times Weekly's Plans
abstract: LEAD: The New York Times announced two programs yesterday to broaden the audience for its Large Type Weekly. Random House Inc. the nation's largest publisher of general-interest books, will market its new large-print publications with The Times. Eschenbach Optik of America, a distributor of products for the visually impaired, will become The Times's agent in the ophthalmic market and provide subscription information in the offices of eye-care professionals.

headline: G.M. Unit Delays Closing of Plant
abstract: LEAD: General Motors of Canada Ltd. said it would extend production at its Scarborough, Ontario, van plant for about a year. The plant, which employs about 2,500 people, was to shut down in August 1992, and production was to be transferred to G.M.'s Truck and Bus Group plant in Flint, Mich.

headline: Uncertainty Seen Testing Nerves
abstract: Credit market participants are beginning to express a rising sense of unease about the Persian Gulf and the Soviet Union.   With the holidays, trading activity this week will probably be sporadic at best. But after the relative serenity of December, the first two weeks of January will probably be a period that tests the nerves of both traders and investors.

headline: Japan's Trade Surplus Falls
abstract: LEAD: Rising imports and overseas tourism helped slash Japan's trade and services surplus by 72.5 percent in August from the corresponding month last year, the Finance Ministry said today.

headline: Eastern Leaders at Summit Warn Against New Divisions in Europe
abstract: Eastern European leaders at the 34-nation summit meeting here warned today of a threat to stability if the ideological separation of Europe is replaced by an economic and social divide.    Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland was among those expressing such concerns. "Our common future may be darkened by the sinister clouds of the resurging conflicts of bygone days," he told the leaders attending the meeting, "unless the split into a rich and a poor Europe, an 'A' class and a 'B' class Europe, is overcome."  A 'Welfare Wall'     While announcing plans to seek the formal dissolution of the six-nation Warsaw Pact, Hungary's Prime Minister, Jozsef Antall, cautioned Western European leaders that "a new Welfare Wall may arise in the place of the Iron Curtain, which has now been removed."

headline: '91 Trial Seen In VCR Case
abstract: The case of an American videocassette recorder company that contends that Japanese companies conspired to sqeeze it out of the consumer electronics business will go to trial next year, a lawyer for the American company said today.    Joseph M. Alioto, who represents the company, Go-Video Inc. of Mesa, Ariz., said the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco this week denied a motion by Japanese videocassette makers to dismiss the case. The ruling permits a trial date to be set for early next year, Mr. Alioto said.

headline: Gold Prices Plummet Again On Mine Companies' Woes
abstract: LEAD: Gold prices dropped again yesterday, with the latest burst of selling attributed largely to mining companies that are selling future bullion output because of their increasing inability to obtain bank financing.

headline: At Least 19 U.S. Sailors Die As Ferry Sinks Near Israel
abstract: At least 19 American sailors drowned early this morning off the Israeli port of Haifa when a ferry carrying them back to the aircraft carrier Saratoga from a holiday shore leave capsized and sank.    The accident took place shortly after midnight when a strong wave hit the ferry about half a mile offshore in the Mediterranean Sea. The craft, carrying 102 Saratoga crew members, sank quickly just a few yards from the aircraft carrier in rough waters 65 feet deep, a United States Navy spokesman said tonight.

headline: Fuel Stocks For Winter Called Good
abstract: LEAD: Supplies of all fuels except propane are likely to be adequate this winter, but prices for both home-heating oil and gasoline are likely to rise significantly, according to experts at a conference here on the winter fuel outlook.

headline: U.S. Warns of Possible Terrorist Attack on a Ship
abstract: The State Department issued an unusually explicit warning tonight of a possible terrorist attack against a passenger ship in the eastern Mediterranean, saying that "such an operation may be undertaken at any time."   Although the department has issued a number of advisories of terrorist dangers since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the American military buildup in Saudi Arabia, this one was the most direct and detailed.

headline: Japanese Banks Plan Merger
abstract: Under pressure from rising interest rates and the prospect of more deregulation, two of Japan's mid-size banks, the Kyowa Bank and the Saitama Bank, said tonight that they would merge next year.    The merger is the first since Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank announced a combination last year that created the world's second-largest banking institution. Today's merger, while not as large, seems likely to spur further consolidation among the "city" banks that make up the core of Japan's commercial banking business.    The new bank will be Japan's eighth largest. At a news conference tonight, officials from both Kyowa and Saitama said they planned a 50-50 merger, probably by April 1, 1991.    At the end of last March, Kyowa Bank ranked 10th in Japan with 11.9 trillion yen in deposits, or more than $93.7 billion. Saitama Bank ranked 11th, with 11.2 trillion yen, or $88.18 billion, on deposit.    Both banks have seen their profits decline dramatically in recent months, largely because of lower returns in fund management. The Kyowa Bank has been particularly aggressive in shifting its emphasis away from large companies to small ones. It has also been trying to attract individual accounts, which are usually highly profitable in Japan.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Amrep Corp., New York, a real estate company, has completed the sale of its water and sewer utility systems serving Rio Rancho, N.M., to a subsidiary of GWC Corp., Claymont, Del., a water utility, for $40 million. * Applebee's International Inc. said it expected to report a gain on the sale of its St. Louis restaurant interests to a new franchisee, Apple Partners Ltd. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. * Chiles Offshore Corp. has completed the purchase of a jackup drilling rig from Manhattan Maritime Corp. for $23 million. * Ethyl Corp., Richmond, a chemicals and pharmaceuticals company, has completed the sale of its wholly owned subsidiary, Hardwicke Chemical Co., to MTM P.L.C., Cleveland, England, for $112 million. * General Electric Co. said it received a series of contracts to supply 10 gas turbine generators, associated spare parts and services to Israel Electric Corp. for $200 million. * IMO Industries, Lawrenceville, N.J., a maker of analytical and optical instruments, has acquired Optic-Electronic Corp., Garland, Tex., a producer of electro-optic components and systems, for about $39 million. * Loews Corp., New York, a hotel and tobacco concern, has bought an additional $25 million worth of stock in Champion International Corp., raising its stake in the paper-products company to 12.07 percent from 10.9 percent. * New England Critical Care Inc. agreed to acquire Care Plus Inc. in an exchange of 0.775 of a share of New England Critical for each Care Plus share. Care Plus has about 6.1 million shares outstanding and New England Critical about 12.3 million. Both companies are involved in the alternative site health-care industry. * Tokheim Corp., Fort Wayne, Ind., a maker of service station gasoline pumps, said it would close its assembly plant in Newbern, Tenn., to reduce manufacturing costs and become more competitive. Operations at the Tennessee plant, which employs 308 people, will be consolidated into its fabrication and machining plant in Fort Wayne by the end of summer of 1991. The Newbern plant will be sold.

headline: A Push to Curb Lung Disease
abstract: The American Lung Association hopes that smokers who make New Year's resolutions to quit will get some inspiration from a fish.   The organization has begun a public service campaign that uses a live carp as a stand-in for people with chronic lung disease. In one spot, the fish struggles for breath in a body of polluted water. In another it gasps on land while an announcer says: "Deprive us of air for a short time and we suffer. Take it away and we die."   The spots were created by JMCT/Health, the health-care services unit of Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, New York. "We felt the fish theme was a graphic way to communicate what it is like to have lung disease," said Stephen Kling, president and creative director of the agency. "The fish concept offers a simple yet powerful theme which can be used thoughout the yearlong campaign."

headline: Italy Sees Hidden Hand Reviving Moro Case
abstract: LEAD: The letter was a voice from the grave: ''I have been killed three times - through insufficient protection, through refusal to negotiate, through inconclusive politics.''

headline: Wishing Pollution Were Unmade in Taiwan
abstract: Two plastic bottles and an aluminum can hang out to dry on her porch, and a tall stack of waste papers are piled neatly on a desk, as Mary M. L. Chen does battle against one of Taiwan's most daunting challenges in its entry to the industrialized world: pollution.    For the last two decades, all the energy of this island's people was devoted to economic progress, and now that Taipei is among the most prosperous cities in Asia, people are beginning to realize that for all their wealth they still cannot buy a decent sunset.People like Miss Chen, director of the Homemakers' Union, are trying to preach a cleaner way of living, but she admits that often her words cannot make it through the jungle of sounds that also makes Taipei one of the noisiest cities in Asia.

headline: Soviets Jail Man for Anti-Semitic Threats
abstract: LEAD: Ruling under a new law and in the face of hecklers, a Soviet court ordered two years in jail today for a leader of Pamyat, a Russian nationalist group that disrupted a public meeting here last January with anti-Semitic threats.

headline: TALES OF HORROR IN INDIA'S UNREST
abstract: In a small, empty room on the edge of this silent, terror-stricken village in northern India lie the broken bangles, abandoned caps and shoes of children who suffocated when a Hindu mob set fire to their home, testimony to the brutality that is sweeping towns and cities of India's north, west and south.    About 300 people have been killed in the riots and 12 cities are under curfews in those regions. More than 3,000 people have been detained in connection with the violence.

headline: China, Reassessing Its Foes, Views Japan Warily
abstract: Japanese proposals to send troops to the Persian Gulf and a territorial dispute about some uninhabited islands are stirring concern here that Japan could emerge in the coming years as China's primary military threat.    The old fears that the Soviet Union might invade China are easing, and few people cast the United States as a military threat. But Japan and China are longtime rivals, and the octogenarians who run China still have vivid memories of the brutal "War of Resistance Against Japan" from 1937 to 1945."Japan's dispatching of troops abroad is a very sensitive issue both in its own country and abroad," the official New China News Agency reported on Saturday, quoting an unidentified "leading official" of the Foreign Ministry.

headline: Manila Journal; A Land Where Tinsel Lies in Tatters
abstract: There seems to be less Christmas spirit and simple pleasure in Roman Catholic Manila this year.   Most of the lights that used to adorn major streets like Roxas Boulevard have not been put up this year. The Mayor of Manila, Gemiliano C. Lopez Jr., has even been criticized for trying to brighten up the trees along Roxas with capiz shell lanterns, with some suggesting that energy is too expensive now for such fripperies, even at Christmas.

headline: Buenos Aires Journal; An Army Revolt One Day, an Invasion the Next
abstract: On the morning this week that President Bush awoke in Buenos Aires, a local newspaper carried a front-page cartoon showing a crowd of tall men in dark glasses surrounding an almost invisible Mr. Bush, protecting him from the slight figure of President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina.    The dialogue went this way: "Mr. President, there's a guy here who says he's the President of the natives. Has a Latin aspect, is between five and six feet tall and weighs about 130 pounds."

headline: Thatcher Loyalist Chosen as Successor; Finance Official Beats 2 Rivals in Tory Vote
abstract: John Major was selected as the next Prime Minister of Britain tonight after his two rivals in the Conservative Party leadership contest withdrew and conceded that he could best unite their divided ranks before the next elections.   On Wednesday morning, when Queen Elizabeth II asks the 47-year-old Mr. Major to form a new government, he will become the youngest Prime Minister of this century and the first leader of a major European power with no memory of World War II.

headline: A New Test Of Buffett's Reputation
abstract: JUST when oil prices started to fall last week, the United States Government began talking tough and hinting of a possible military action to liberate Kuwait, pushing crude quotes higher again. And as the week ended, a deal to raise taxes significantly seemed to be near.   With actions like that, one could conclude that the Government wants a recession. And, from President Bush's perspective, why not? The 1981-82 recession cost the Republicans some Congressional seats but it paved the way for an economic recovery that made Ronald Reagan the most popular President in a generation.

headline: U.N. Secretary General's Man For Refugee Post Withdraws
abstract: A senior Indian official at the United Nations today withdrew his bid to take command of the agency protecting the world's 15 million refugees after encountering stiff opposition from the United States and other Western aid-giving countries.    In a bitterly worded letter, Virendra Dayal, who runs the executive office of Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, said he is no longer a candidate to fill the vacant post of United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, for which the Secretary General himself had proposed him.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Adam Opel A.G., the German unit of General Motors Corp., said it would decide soon whether to build a new car plant in the eastern German city of Eisenach. * Bell Canada, Toronto, said it would cuts its long-distance rates for business users. The move would mean forgoing revenues of an estimated $772 million in the four years beginning in 1992. * Citizens Utilities Co., Stamford, Conn., completed the acquisition of Louisiana General Services Inc., Harvey, La., a gas company, through a stock swap. * Freeport-McMoran Inc., New Orleans, a minerals and energy company, said it would buy back more than 7.5 million in common shares at $34.75 each. The seller is Fund American Cos. * James River Corp., Richmond, a paper-products company, has completed the sale of its mill in West Linn, Ore., to Simpson Paper Co., Seattle. Terms were not disclosed. * Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H., an aircraft and military unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., said it would cut 1,400 jobs from its worldwide work force of 22,300. * Midsouth Corp., Jackson, Miss., a railroad holding company, said its board would review an offer of $6.60 a share from Illinois Central Corp., Chicago, another railroad holding company. * PWA Corp., Calgary, Alberta, an air carrier, said it would proceed with its sale of eight Airbus Industrie 310 jets worth $568 million to a unit of Lavalin Industries. * Portman Cos., Atlanta, which owns the Peachtree Center office complex, said the debt restructuring plan of the architect John C. Portman Jr. had been approved by lenders. * Western Gas Resources Inc., Denver, said it would buy Amoco Corp.'s Edgewood Gas Processing Plant in Tyler, Tex., and related production. The purchase, for $36 million, would be made through the Western Gas processor subsidiary.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: S.&P. Is Reviewing Rating On Macy's $2.5 Billion Debt
abstract: The speculative-grade rating of subordinated debt issued by R. H. Macy & Company is under review with the possibility of a further downgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.    The action affects about $2.5 billion of CCC+ rated subordinated debt and reflects Macy's continuing weak retail operations in the context of the company's highly leveraged capital structure, the agency said.

headline: India Gets $450 Million Loan for Gulf Hardship
abstract: The International Monetary Fund has agreed to loan India $400 million to $450 million to address an economic crisis caused by rising oil prices and shortages after the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait, a top Indian finance official said today.   But the release of the funds depends on a formal application by the new minority Government of Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, who in the past has been a sharp critic of international lending institutions and multinational corporations. The impending decision is likely to reflect the economic thinking of Mr. Shekhar, whose views may now be tempered by harsh economic reality and a balance of payments crisis, aides said.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday  None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales . . .November Friday  Inventories . . . Oct. Producer Prices . . . Nov. Industrial Production . . . Nov. Capacity Utilization . . . Nov.

headline: Goldman Lifts Bonuses For Staff Below Partner
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Company told its work force yesterday that the firm was slightly increasing annual percentage bonuses for 1990 for all employees below the partner level, but cautioned that future compensation might not be as generous.   In a memorandum to employees, the firm said that the year-end bonuses would be 23 percent of annual compensation, compared with 22 percent last year. While the increase is small, any improvement, given the current market environment, is considered good.

headline: New Babylon Is Stalled By a Modern Upheaval
abstract: LEAD: More than 2,500 years ago, a fabulous city rose here on a bend in the Euphrates River. Under King Nebuchadnezzar, Babylon and its hanging gardens became as fabled, and as much a seat of imperial power, as Rome became later.

headline: Talking Deals; Satellite TV's Appeal to Comsat
abstract: WHEN the Communications Satellite Corporation bought a majority stake in the Denver Nuggets basketball team, a lot of people wondered why. Now, as the company contemplates investing $100 million in a new satellite television venture, the answer seems clear.    Robert J. Wussler, president of Comsat Video Enterprises and formerly the second-in-command at Turner Broadcasting System Inc., wants do with satellites what his former boss, Ted Turner, did with cable television. Mr. Turner, who owns the Atlanta Braves baseball team and Atlanta Hawks basketball team, has used his franchises as a cornerstone for sports programming over the TBS and Turner Network Television cable channels.

headline: James River's About To Invent Itself Again
abstract: DON'T call the James River Corporation a paper company when Bob Williams is around. Never mind that its nearly $6 billion in sales derive almost exclusively from paper products. Never mind that only paper analysts cover the company. Never mind that for a long time Mr. Williams was awfully proud that James River, which he co-founded 21 years ago, has grown to be one of the world's largest paper companies.    None of that matters to Robert C. Williams, who last month took over the chief executive's slot from Brenton S. Halsey, the other co-founder. James River, Mr. Williams hastens to point out every time he hears the dreaded P-word, is a consumer-products company, with its future tied to such branded products as Northern bathroom tissue, Brawny towels and Dixie paper plates and to the bags and boxes surrounding Kellogg cereals and Frito Lay potato chips.

headline: Confusion Grows as Soviets Get More Laws
abstract: The question of who is in charge of the growing state of confusion in the Soviet Union became murkier today as the national and Russian Parliaments adopted conflicting claims to sovereignty over the other's laws.   The separate actions were taken in the name of easing the public's deepening dismay over the erosion of law and order in the nation. But the additional laws only fed the sense of confusion.

headline: Home Equity Loans Back $500 Million Bank Offering
abstract: A $500 million issue of securities backed by home equity loans from the Shawmut National Corporation was priced yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   The securities are being offered through Shawmut National 1990-A Home Equity Credit Line Trust, a unit of the Shawmut National Corporation, a bank holding company based in Hartford.

headline: The 1st Amendment Is Safe at Prodigy
abstract: "I'm thinking of killing myself. Which is less painful: hanging or slashing my wrists?"   "My neighbor, William, embezzled $10,000 from his company and is still stealing to this day."   "Little girls in tight jeans and T-shirts are a real turn-on to guys like me. Write to me at P.O. Box. . . ."

headline: FORUM; The Saudis' Gulf-Crisis Windfall
abstract: On Oct. 31, M. A. Adelman, professor emeritus of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, presented written testimony on oil price volatility to the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs. Mr. Adelman, a leading petroleum economist, wrote that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, including Saudi Arabia, have been following a short-term profit-maximizing strategy by raising prices as high as the market will bear.   In a Forum article last Sunday, Prince Abdulaziz Salman Al-Saud, an adviser to the oil minister of Saudi Arabia, disagreed with Mr. Adelman's assertions. What follows is Mr. Adelman's rebuttal of that article.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 18: MONDAY Baxter Intl Inc Crane Co First Intst Bancorp Genuine Parts Co Hormel Geo A & Co PHH Corp TUESDAY BRE Pptys Inc Briggs & Stratton Corp Collins Foods Intl Consolidated Rail Corp HARSCO Corp  Hughes Supply Inc Ohio Edison Co Public SVC Enterprise Grp Utd Telecommun Inc(MO) Wells Fargo & Co WEDNESDAY Baltimore Bancorp Bowater Inc City Natl (Beverly Hills) Crystal Brands Inc Fleet/Norstar Finl Group Florida East Coast Inds Inc Marsh & McLennan Cos Inc Northrop Corp FRIDAY Pacific Telesis Group

headline: Profits of Big Board Firms Down 98% in First Nine Months
abstract: Reflecting the intense recession that has struck Wall Street, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the earnings of a broad sector of its membership collapsed in the first nine months of this year, falling by 98 percent.    The Big Board's report on 334 member firms is the most striking evidence yet that the difficulties that have spread across Wall Street since the market crash of 1987 have grown much more significant. The decline has grown even steeper this year with the deterioration of the big-fee investment banking business, as well as the dwindling volume on the national stock exchanges.

headline: Ad Magazine Sale Reported
abstract: The Act Three Publishing Company sold Marketing & Media Decisions magazine to Affiliated Publications for an undisclosed amount, people at Act Three said yesterday.   Act Three Publishing, which is owned by the television producer Norman Lear's Act Three Communications Company, has been for sale for several months.    Affiliated, which owns The Boston Globe, The Hollywood Reporter and Billboard and Adweek magazines, had been in discussions with Mr. Lear's company about buying its entire publishing group. But Affiliated decided that it only wanted Marketing & Media Decisions, a profitable monthly for advertising executives.    "The magazine as it exists will no longer exist after the December issue," the staff member said. "It will be a weekly news magazine like Adweek."    Marketing & Media Decisions is almost 25 years old. It remained unclear whether Act Three planned to sell its other publications, which include Channels for the television industry and The Marketer.

headline: 28 Workers Depart New York Telephone
abstract: The New York Telephone Company said yesterday that 23 employees in its buildings department had been dismissed and that 5 more had resigned before they could be terminated, after an investigation into payments and gifts from vendors.   Twenty-eight other workers who accepted small gifts and did not actively collude with vendors will receive various other penalties, said Richard A. Jalkut, the executive vice president and chief operating officer. The measures will range from letters of reprimand to one-time pay reductions of $4,000 or more.    The latest disciplinary actions are in addition to 15 buildings department employees who were previously disclosed as having resigned, retired or been dismissed in the last 16 months.   New York Telephone now plans to investigate about 20 more employees from the department who took early retirement in May under a special program, Mr. Jalkut said. Although their pensions are shielded by law from the company's disciplinary proceedings, their annual bonuses, payable early next year, could be reduced or eliminated if improprieties are found, he said.   Gerald McKelvey, a spokesman for the office of Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau, said that a fraud investigation into the buildings department and its vendors continued and that criminal indictments were possible.   Virtually all of the employees disciplined or being investigated are low-level managers, typically construction foremen and engineers, Mr. Jalkut said. All are in the department's New York City office, he said.    The New York City office of the buildings department has 225 to 250 managers. "Up to half of them let us down in a big way," Mr. Jalkut said.   New York Telephone said the 28 employees who left the company this week had accepted cash and gifts totaling $48,000, while the others "accepted gifts such as liquor or gift certificates during the holiday season."   John Nobile, a buildings department engineer, was indicted on June 12 on 22 counts of bid rigging, accepting bribes, theft and tax evasion. He was accused of accepting nearly $600,000 from five companies in exchange for awarding them overpriced contracts. Mr. Nobile and a contractor indicted with him have pleaded not guilty. No trial date has been set.   Mr. Jalkut said the 28 employees leaving the company had colluded with vendors and accepted substantial gifts of cash, liquor or gift certificates, activities violating the company's business code. In exchange, he said, the employees stored vendors' tools, allowed vendors to park vehicles on company property and in some cases steered contracts that did not require bidding to such vendors.    The other 28 employees accepted holiday gifts but do not appear to have done favors, Mr. Jalkut said.

headline: Recruiters' New Obstacle: War Fear
abstract: The Navy's Recruiter of the Year finds his skills being put to the test as he tries to enlist recruits who fear they may be shipped off to the Middle East and to war.    "If you join up, how do you know if you're coming back?" said Daniel Freeman, 17 years old, a junior at Aviation High School in Long Island City, who stood in a knot of students who listened to the recruiter, Petty Officer 1st Class Willie Barnhill.

headline: Return of $30 Million Sought From Ex-Chief of Centrust
abstract: Federal regulators today ordered David L. Paul, a former savings and loan executive from Miami, to return more than $30 million that they say he spent on an opulent life style using the money of depositors in Centrust Savings Bank, which is now bankrupt.    Recounting his $29 million art collection and Centrust's grandly designed 47-story office tower, complete with 24-karat gold-leaf ceilings and gold-plated toilet pipes, lawyers at the Office of Thrift Supervision said that, as the head of Centrust, Mr. Paul had recklessly disregarded regulations and used millions of dollars' worth of Government-insured deposits for his own personal benefit.

headline: Market Place; Investors Flocking to Stock Funds
abstract: This year is shaping up as the worst one in a decade for the stock market, but mutual fund investors have responded by buying shares in stock funds at a record pace.   Mutual fund sponsors said yesterday that stock funds continued to draw in cash this month, while the stock market had its best month in half a year. "It looks like we will have a strong windup to the year, despite the Middle East and all the uncertainty," said Hank Schmelzer of New England Securities.

headline: Panama Uncovers Plot to Topple President
abstract: LEAD: Panama's Government said today it had uncovered evidence of a plot to topple President Guillermo Endara that was to start with a takeover by rebel police units of the northwestern province of Chiriqui.

headline: Avon Is Asked To Buy Shares
abstract: Chartwell Associates, an alliance of investors dissatisfied with the stock market performance of Avon Products Inc., recommended today that Avon repurchase $500 million of its common or preferred shares to enhance shareholder value.   Chartwell made the proposal in a letter to James E. Preston, Avon's chairman. The letter was contained in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.   In October, Chartwell resigned from a special Avon committee that is examining ways to increase the company's stock price. Chartwell said the New York-based beauty products company was not seriously interested in enhancing shareholder value. It then hired Lehman Brothers to come up with proposals for Avon.   Chartwell, which controls 26.2 percent of Avon's common shares outstanding and 19.8 percent of the voting shares, also recommended in its letter that Avon explore raising its dividend, consider selling subsidiaries and rethink its plan to sell a portion of its Avon Japan business.   A spokesman for Avon said that the Chartwell proposal contained "nothing new." He said Avon's committee would present its recommendations to the board in January.   Avon's shares slipped 37.5 cents today, to $27, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Iraq Warns It Might Delay Soviet Workers' Departure
abstract: LEAD: Iraq warned the Soviet Union today that it could delay the departure of some of the 5,000 Soviet citizens still in Iraq, in effect making them hostages, if Moscow supplied the United States with information about Iraq's Soviet-supplied weapons and defense abilities.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Palazzetti, a New York-based furniture designer, to Weiss, Whitten Inc., New York, with a budget of more than $1 million.

headline: Quarter Bank Profits Off 20% to 25%, F.D.I.C. Says
abstract: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that the profits of the banking industry for the third quarter were down 20 to 25 percent from the second-quarter earnings of $5.3 billion but were significantly better than had been expected.    The figures for the quarter ended Sept. 30 also compare favorably with the corresponding period last year, when the industry posted its first loss in two years, said L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C., in an interview today.

headline: Economic Index Hits 8-Year Low
abstract: Hit hard by lower production and a decline in new orders, the nation's manufacturing economy slowed in November to the lowest level since the recession of the early 1980's, a survey of purchasing managers has found.    The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its index of economic activity fell to 41.3 percent, the weakest showing since November 1982, when the index stood at 39.2 percent. In October, the index was at 43.3 percent.

headline: Dow Declines 20.55 Points, to 2,593.81
abstract: After trading sharply lower, stocks regained some ground yesterday to close with a moderate loss after President Bush in a 2:30 P.M. news conference kept up the pressure on Iraq to get out of Kuwait by Jan. 15.    The market had fallen sharply early in the day in the face of what one Boston investment officer called "a lot of warlike talk" from other world leaders. A larger-than-expected figure on the Producer Price Index, dampening the likelihood of further interest rate cuts, also depressed stocks.

headline: 40 Killed in Muslim-Hindu Clash As Politician's Arrest Is Protested
abstract: More than 40 people were killed and more than 150 wounded today in fighting between Hindus and Muslims as Hindu revivalists and a right-wing party led a nationwide strike to protest the arrest of the party's president.    The detention of the right-wing party politician, Lal Kishen Advani, which came in the middle of his national campaign to build a Hindu temple on a site where a Muslim shrine now stands, has thrown parliamentary leadership into doubt and society into turmoil.

headline: As Airlines Stumble, Rivals Circle
abstract: If the combination of high jet-fuel prices and low-paying passengers persists through the winter, the unrelenting consolidation in the airline industry that pushed Continental Airlines into bankruptcy will claim other weakened carriers, several analysts said yesterday.   "It's a Darwinian situation," said Timothy Pettee, transportation analyst at Alliance Capital Management, a money management firm in New York. "The strong shall survive and the strong will pick off what's left of the weak airlines. There will be more bankruptcies."

headline: Political Warfare in Japan
abstract: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has been battered by domestic criticism of his proposal to send Japanese troops to the Persian Gulf. Page A10.

headline: MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Miscellany
abstract: * Ammirati & Puris has opened offices in Atlanta and Chicago to service its BMW account. The Atlanta office will be headed by Woody Thompson; Frank Stier will head the Chicago branch.

headline: Plan to Share Data on Drexel Is Reported
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing to provide Federal savings regulators with information from its four-year investigation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., people directly involved in the case said yesterday.   The action by the commission is intended to enhance the ability of two Federal agencies to file claims against Drexel. The agencies are the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the insurer of bank and savings institution deposits, and the Resolution Trust Corporation, the manager of the savings industry bailout.

headline: Tech Notes; When Even a Mouse Is Too Big
abstract: MANY personal computers and software programs require the use of a pointing device to move the cursor -- a "mouse." But a mouse needs a tabletop to navigate on, and most substitutes, like trackballs, are bulky. For the new generation of very small portable computers, or "notebooks," a better solution was needed. Home Row Inc.'s answer is to turn the "J" key into a pointing device, activated by pressing the computer's control key. In effect, the key becomes a miniature joystick that can move in any direction. The cursor's speed is determined by how hard the key is pressed. The left hand can press the F, D, and S keys to give the commands on the traditional mouse buttons. Home Row, based in Clackamas, Oreg., has licensed its technology to a number of computer makers. The first products are due this year.

headline: Iraq's Seesaw Diplomacy: Threats and Entreaties
abstract: LEAD: Saddam Hussein is sending decidedly mixed political signals about his intentions toward Kuwait, thus causing Arab and Western moods and expectations to shift and complicating efforts by the United States and its allies to forge a coherent strategy for getting Iraqi forces out of Kuwait.

headline: Puerto Rico Bank Merger
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday approved the merger of Banco Popular de Puerto Rico and the BanPonce Corporation.    The merger, which both banking companies agreed to in October, 1989, will result in the largest banking company in Puerto Rico with assets of about $9 billion and 165 branches. The new holding company will be known as BanPonce Corporation, and the combined banks will be called Banco Popular de Puerto Rico.    As part of the Fed's approval, the companies are required to divest some branches in Puerto Rico with deposits of about $90 million.

headline: Valdice Prison Blues a Bit Happier Now
abstract: In a concrete workshop hall in the maximum-security prison here, inmates in blue cotton prison pants and jackets recently cheered enthusiastically as a leading Czech country-western singer performed such favorites as the Czech-language version of Johnny Cash's "Folsom Prison Blues."    The concert, the third at the Valdice prison since last November's "velvet revolution," was a reflection of efforts to improve prison conditions undertaken by the Government of President Vaclav Havel, the playwright and former dissident who himself spent long periods in such prisons, though not this one, under Communist rule.

headline: CIT Note Offering Totals $100 Million
abstract: CIT Group Holdings Inc., a subsidiary of the Manufacturers Hamover Corporation, is offering $100 million in notes due 1994 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   The notes have an 8 5/8 percent coupon and are priced at 100, to yield investors 133 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.    Noncallable by CIT, the notes are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. CS First Boston+

headline: Penguin to Raise Prices Next Year by 4/ a Book
abstract: LEAD: Penguin USA said yesterday that it would raise prices next year on all its mass market books, but by just 4 cents a book. Books that now cost $3.95 will be priced at $3.99; $4.95 books will be $4.99, and so on.

headline: PANAMA RESISTING MOVE TO CLEAN UP BANKING SYSTEM
abstract: American officials are encountering unusually stiff opposition from Panamanian Government aides and businessmen in efforts to crack the shell of secrecy, and presumed illegality, surrounding Panama's multibillion dollar international banking trade.   When United States troops invaded Panama 10 months ago and deposed the leadership of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, American officials felt that they would get cooperation and information on banking activity, including illegal money-laundering, much of it related to drug trafficking.

headline: Bank Inquiry In Australia
abstract: LEAD: Australia's Treasurer, Paul Keating, sharply criticized the country's banking industry today, saying banks were trying to recoup losses from bad loans by squeezing customers with high interest rates.

headline: Bush Assails Israeli Lack of 'Restraint'
abstract: LEAD: President Bush rebuked Israel today for not acting ''with more restraint'' in quelling Palestinian unrest in Jerusalem on Monday.

headline: And Now the Hard Part: Making Hussein Give In
abstract: LEAD: Eleven weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait, Administration officials still appear determined to confront President Saddam Hussein, but they are discovering just how difficult their policy is to sustain and showing some signs of anxiety about how the crisis will be resolved.

headline: S.&P. Lifts Rating on Paper And Jet Lessor's Senior Debt
abstract: The rating of $1.4 billion in senior debt and commercial paper issued by the International Lease Finance Corporation has been raised, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.   The company is the second-largest operating lessor of commercial jet aircraft to domestic and foreign airlines, behind the GPA Group Ltd.    The rating upgrade reflects the improved financial outlook, expected lower borrowing costs and a planned equity contribution of $200 million over the next several years from the corporation's new parent, American International Group Inc.   Standard & Poor's said while the obligations of International Lease were not guaranteed by American International, the added equity by American International helped to offset relatively high leverage caused by rapi expansion.    The senior unsecured debt is raised to A+, from A-, and the commercial paper rating is increased to A-1, from A-2.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Bausch & Lomb Rochester, a maker of contact lenses, named Alexander Izzard and Manuel Sosa vice presidents.

headline: Business Diary/October 7-12
abstract: LEAD:    THE ECONOMY       After a Week of Negotiations, the Budget Gap Narrows       After topsy-turvy budget negotiations all week, Congress and the White House narrowed their differences. Higher gasoline taxes seem inevitable; lower capital gains tax and steeper tax rates for the rich, improbable. Another truth emerged: The cost of financing the deficit will balloon before the Government can meet its debt-reduction goal of $500 billion.

headline: Nation's Image Worries Argentines
abstract: As the last of the Argentine Army rebels were being loaded onto trucks after giving up Monday, a nearby group of civilians began to chant, "Paredon! Paredon!" meaning that they should be lined up before a wall and shot.    Such disgust with the fourth army rebellion in less than four years was almost generalized across Argentine society today as people endorsed the tough handling of the uprising by President Carlos Saul Menem and fretted about how the revolt might damage Argentina's standing with the world.

headline: Oil Output Rise Barred in Texas
abstract: LEAD: The Texas Railroad Commission voted 2 to 1 today against raising oil production in the East Texas field by 8,000 barrels, to 15,000 barrels a day. A commissioner said the extra oil was not needed despite the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: Taking Aim At Troops' Taste Buds
abstract: As thousands of American troops stream into Saudi Arabia, American packaged-goods companies are providing them with a little bit of home.   For dinner, Land O'Frost Inc., a packager of diet foods in Lansing, Ill., is shipping non-dietetic ham that does not need refrigeration. For dessert in the desert, Hershey Foods Corporation is providing chocolate bars that do not melt in triple-digit Saudi temperatures. And when the searing day trails off to a nippy desert night, the troops can sip Campbell's chicken noodle soup.

headline: First Boston Fills Post
abstract: Tom Sexton, the head of the First Boston Corporation's mortgage product group, will head the firm's fixed-income sales and trading operation, First Boston said yesterday. Last month, First Boston's senior executives asked for the resignations of two of the operation's top executives, E. Craig Coats, a managing director and Ronald M. Stuart, also a managing director. William Voute, the firm's vice chairman, left after his chief lieutenants were asked to resign. Mr. Sexton joined First Boston in 1980 as a managing director of municipal sales and trading. In 1988, he was named head of the firm's mortgage product group.

headline: All About/Smelling Good; Two Crucial Days In Scent Peddling
abstract: EVERY holiday season, the fragrance industry gets nervous. With more than 50 percent of annual sales taking place in the weeks before Christmas -- most in the last two days -- fragrance companies are like children wondering how bountiful their holiday will be.     With more than 800 fragrances on the United States market and a notoriously fickle public, the companies seldom experience the blissful state their products are meant to induce. The industry always seems hyperactive, introducing an average of 60 new products a year. And in the past 18 months, many industry giants have found themselves with new owners or altered fortunes. This holiday season is the first in more than 25 years that Avon Products Inc., the perennial leader in women's fragrances, has not been No. 1.

headline: Cape Canaveral's Need to Renovate
abstract: In the shadow of the latest Delta rocket awaiting liftoff here, an obsolete computer reads data the old-fashioned way, from a paper tape punched with holes. When the computer needs spare parts, engineers here must sometimes rummage for them in electronics surplus stores in Orlando.   "We have to keep the museum operating," said Dan Pinney, an engineer who has worked on all 200 of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's Delta launchings.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER, 24, 1990
abstract: The Economy    The Defense Department has been paying high prices to charter vessels and book space aboard freighters to support the military buildup in the Persian Gulf. Ship brokers, freight agents and shipping executives agree that higher prices have meant more profits for shipowners. But they defend the surge in rates, saying that the deployment has sharply increased worldwide demand for shipping and that the Pentagon has made special demands.  [ Page 1. ]  International    Japan's Finance Ministry has begun an investigation into whether Japanese brokerage houses intimidated two companies into canceling an agreement to issue bonds through Salomon Brothers. Confirmation of the investigation appears to be an acknowledgement of a discriminatory practice that the ministry has long said does not exist.  [ 29. ]   The economy of Alsace is booming, a transformation of France's smallest region that is startling compared with the plight of its neighbor, Lorraine, which remains a classic rust belt.  [ 34. ]  Companies    Some Drexel employees are still receiving more than $1 million a year, even as Wall Street salaries continue to collapse. The firm, which declared bankruptcy on May 29, now has a skeletal work force of 292. Of those, 29 executives are each receiving more than $250,000 a year, and two traders are each receiving $1.45 million a year, according to internal documents.  [ 29. ]   If T.W.A. and Pan Am can reach a deal to merge, airline industry executives and analysts say the resulting company will have enviable routes but will face formidable problems.  [ 29. ]   Next Inc.'s highly automated California factory is a model for improving American competitiveness, many experts say. But the ambitious manufacturing experiment may be wasted unless Next's second generation of computers gains wider acceptance.  [ 29. ]  The Media Business    For almost the entire television industry, 1990 was the worst year ever, marked by loss of momentum, loss of market share and loss of money. Bill Carter: Television.  [ 29. ]   In a further sign of the pessimism of advertising executives, WPP Group said it would not pay a previously announced interim dividend to shareholders. The reaction of investors was sharp and negative. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ 29. ]   Sol Stein is making a remarkable comeback as a publisher three years after Stein & Day went into bankruptcy. Now he is publishing not books but computer software programs.  [ 32. ]   American Photographer is now American Photo, a general-interest photography magazine loosely modeled on Photo, a French magazine that is also part of the Hachette family.  [ 32. ]   The BBC's decision to stop publishing The Listener, its 61-year-old weekly television, radio and literary journal, demonstrates the corporation's increasing attention to the bottom line.  [ 32. ]   MTM Entertainment may soon be sold by TVS, British newspaper reports said. MTM, which was responsible for hits like "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" and "Hill Street Blues," has had trouble creating successful new shows.  [ 33. ]  Today's Columns    The S.E.C. is preparing an overhaul of regulations and laws governing mutual funds. The move has set the industry against bankers, pension funds and insurance companies, who all fear a regulatory overhaul. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law.  [ 30. ]   It is the Wall Street bears who are now buying corporate jets. The success of short-sellers has not gone unnoticed by money managers, who have turned from their bullish ways and started short-selling funds to cash in on a stream of bad news. Market Place.  [ 31. ]   Credit market participants are beginning to express rising unease about the Persian Gulf and the Soviet Union. After the relative serenity of December, the first two weeks of January will probably test the nerves of traders and investors. Credit Markets.  [ 31. ]

headline: Decision-Making Setup Revamped by Du Pont
abstract: LEAD: A management structure that lasted almost a century was demolished last week by Edgar S. Woolard Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, when he abolished the exective committee as the company's crucial decision-making entity.

headline: National Parties of the Right Take Lead in Yugoslav Voting
abstract: Nationalist political parties appeared today to have won a sweeping victory over the ruling Communists in parliamentary elections held Sunday in the central Yugoslav Republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina.    With about 20 percent of the vote counted, ballot tallies show the main Muslim, Serb and Croat political parties with commanding leads.   If the present trend continues, the Bosnian voters have also delivered a severe setback to the Reform Party of Yugoslavia's Prime Minister, Ante Markovic.

headline: Europe's Ban on U.S. Meat Is Threatening Trade Talks
abstract: A European ban on practically all imports of American meat has angered United States officials, brought threats of reprisal and caused a general scratching of heads here.    The dispute comes as the European Community and Washington are locked in battle over billions of dollars of farm subsidies, which the United States has pressed to reduce sharply.

headline: Trash Hauler In Settlement
abstract: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest trash hauler, has agreed to pay several customers $19.5 million to settle price-fixing accusations.   The settlements applied to civil cases in Toledo, Ohio; Memphis; Jacksonville, Orlando, and Dade and Broward Counties, Fla.; Phoenix; Atlanta; Rochester; three counties in Southern California, and several counties in North Jersey.    "Our decision was made to avoid certain protracted and costly litigation," William J. Plunkett, a company spokesman, said Monday.    The suit was brought by a group of customers led by Cumberland Farms Inc., a Canton, Mass., convenience store operator. Waste Management said the settlement had received preliminary approval in Federal District Court in Pennsylvania.   The plaintiffs agreed to abandon all other claims against Waste Management.   Since 1987, Waste Management subsidiaries have pleaded guilty to Federal criminal price-fixing charges in California and Ohio, with fines totaling $2.5 million.

headline: SPY SATELLITE AIM IS TO TRACK IRAQ
abstract: LEAD: The next space shuttle mission will carry aloft an 11-ton spy satellite meant to peer down on Iraqi troops and military gear involved in the Persian Gulf crisis, an industry journal reported yesterday.

headline: Accounts
abstract: *OlympusCorporation, Woodbury, L.I., has put its $12.5 million consumer account into review. The incumbent, Lowe & Partners, will participate. * Pillsbury Co., Minneapolis, a unit of Grand Metropolitan Inc., to Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, for its Toaster Strudel pastry product, with a budget of $5 million.

headline: P.R. Firm Sees Its Future on European TV
abstract: Western Europe has given American television viewers the refinement of "Masterpiece Theater." In return, the United States may be poised to give Europeans a peculiarly American broadcast innovation: the plug.   In a report scheduled to be released next week, Edelman Public Relations Worldwide says the increasing opportunities for product placements on European news and entertainment programs herld a "new era for consumer marketers," especially when combined with new opportunities to sponsor programs and televised cultural and sporting events.

headline: Gannett Unit Rejects Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Gannett Foundation said today that it had rejected a $540 million bid from the Gannett Company to buy its 10 percent block of the company's stock.

headline: Indian Premier Has a Problem: He's Seen as Gandhi's Shadow
abstract: Six weeks after he took power in a sudden realignment of political parties, Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar is having a hard time convincing Indians that his Government is more than a front for the Congress Party of Rajiv Gandhi. Mr. Gandhi's party, defeated at the polls in 1989, seems to be returning to power through the back door.    Mr. Shekhar, whose hastily assembled party, the Janata Dal-Socialist, says it has about 60 seats in the 525-seat lower house of Parliament, is candid about his situation. He is in power only because Mr. Gandhi, with 195 seats, chose to support him rather than return as Prime Minister himself after the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh lost a vote of confidence in November and the President decided not to call new elections.

headline: Rwanda Invaders Said to Gain Ground
abstract: LEAD: A refugee army of more than 1,000 fighters belonging to the Tutsi tribe has advanced more than 25 miles into the Central African nation of Rwanda and cut off the Rwandan Army from vital fuel and ammunition depots, Administration officials said today.

headline: Prices of Treasury Securities Ease
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly, and interest rates moved up a bit in light trading yesterday, as dealers awaited this morning's release of November employment data.    "It's a very quiet market," said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. "Caution and profit taking are the watchwords of the day. The market has come a long way, and there is a big number on Friday. At this point people are unwilling to make purchases."

headline: Foreign Flavor for Publishing Leadership
abstract: Whatever else the 1990's bring for book publishing, they are already shaping up as the decade of the foreign-born executive. The appointment last week of Harold Evans, a native of Britain, as president and publisher of Random House is only the latest example.   Earlier this year, Alberto Vitale, who was born in Italy and spent part of his childhood in Egypt, became chief executive of Random House Inc. When Harold Miller retired last spring as chief executive at the Houghton Mifflin Company, he was succeeded by Nader F. Darehshori, who was a teacher in his native Iran before joining the Boston publisher.

headline: Japanese Markets Rise With the Yen
abstract: Japan's financial markets, battered in recent months by rising interest rates and the leap in oil prices, have received a lift from an unlikely source: a sharp appreciation in the value of the yen.   The rosier sentiment here in reaction to the resurgent yen indicates how much the Japanese have altered their economy since 1985, when the leading industrial nations began a conscious effort to push the dollar lower to ease America's yawning trade deficit. At that time, Japanese companies complained loudly as the yen soared and their products became more expensive overseas, reducing the exports on which the economy thrived.   But today, the markets have focused not on the negative impact a rising yen might have on exports, but on two big benefits: It has reduced Japan's bill for imported oil, which must be paid in dollars, providing considerable relief from soaring world energy prices in the wake of the crisis in the Persian Gulf, and it has permitted interest rates here to fall after a damaging yearlong surge.  Bond Yield Drops    The dollar has declined from 150 yen in mid-July to as low as 124.40 last Thursday in New York, a 17 percent tumble. Buffeted by fears of a recession and the budget crisis in Washington, the dollar, although up slightly the last two days to close at 126.02 today in New York, is edging toward its record low of 120.45, reached in January 1988.   The yield on Japan's benchmark 10-year Government bond, meanwhile, has plummeted from 8.7 percent a month ago to 7.75 percent today, as the stronger yen has slightly reduced concerns about inflation. There is talk now that commercial banks may reduce their key long-term prime lending rate after steep increases in recent months.   That has revived the deeply troubled stock market, which has been through a severe slide, largely because of the higher cost of borrowing. The Nikkei stock average closed today at 25,070.86, up 2.4 percent, or 589.37 points. That still represents a 36 percent tumble from the beginning of the year, but it is also a steep increase from its low last month of nearly 20,000.   "You don't hear Japanese companies crying out the way they did when the dollar fell before," added Yoshihisa Kitai, aneconomist at the Long Term Credit Bank. "Japanese companies have already restructured their businesses to deal with this, and now you are seeing the result."   Until a few years ago, the weak yen had been a big source of economic strength for Japan, encouraging foreign buyers to purchase Japanese goods.   Concern About the Dollar    For the last few years, though, the Government has encouraged industries to cultivate the domestic market and invest heavily to increase productivity and to move more plants overseas.   Japanese Government officials are thus sanguine about the yen's strength, worrying only that it might rise too fast and disrupt the markets. "It is very interesting and telling that we hear very few complaints about the exchange rate," said a senior Government economic official. "It reflects the fact that companies have adapted."   Government and industry officials in Japan are more worried by the what the falling dollar signals about the United States. Many people blame the battle in Washington over the Federal budget and fears of a looming recession for an erosion of confidence in the American economy and American policy makers.   The message is that these officials have fewer concerns about their home market. Manufacturers have moved a significant portion of their factories overseas to avoid the impact of currency swings.
