Toyota, for instance, announced it was building a second auto plant in the United States, just one in a wave of such moves.   The Government has also shown some success in waking up the Japanese consumer and creating a boom at home that has eased further the reliance on exports. Retail sales have been expanding at a nearly double-digit rate this year, for instance. And a record level of capital investment by Japanese companies is providing a big impetus for economic growth.   On top of that, the dollar's tumble has offset part of the huge increase in crude oil prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August.   "If the dollar falls to 110 yen, then you could begin to see some problems, but most companies have already achieved the ability to deal well with the dollar at 120 yen," said Susumu Kato, the chief economist for Goldman Sachs (Japan).

headline: Audit Panel Is Seeking Tough Rule
abstract: The chief rule-making body of the accounting industry agreed late Tuesday to propose a requirement that companies give shareholders more up-to-the-minute information about their worth. The move has upset some banks and other financial institutions, which say the task is too daunting.   The proposal, supported by all seven members of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, would require companies to disclose in footnotes in their financial statements the market value of many assets and liabilities that are now merely shown at their original cost.

headline: Effort to Block MCA Deal Fails
abstract: A judge refused to delay a Japanese company's $6.6 billion buyout of MCA Inc.   Go-Video Inc., a Scottsdale, Ariz., distributor of dual-deck videocassette recorders, filed an antitrust action on Dec. 6, contending that the buyout of MCA by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company violates United States antitrust laws.

headline: Japan Securities Firms Post Big Drop in Profits
abstract: The Big Four securities houses, which enjoy a cartel-like dominance over the financial markets here, today reported severe declines in their earnings for the first half of the fiscal year, when a plunge in the markets hit nearly every line of business.   The pretax earnings of each firm were slashed more than 50 percent in the six months ended Sept. 30, as share prices plunged, volume slowed to a trickle and underwriting activity nearly halted.

headline: Alaska Oil Spending To Increase
abstract: LEAD: The companies that own Alaska's giant Prudhoe Bay oilfield said today that they would spend $1.1 billion on new equipment to slow the decline in North Slope oil production.

headline: Business and Health; Unscrupulous Medical Insurers
abstract: MINING an unprotected gap between Federal and state insurance regulations, unscrupulous operators have sold virtually worthless health-care policies to dozens of small-business groups desperate for low-cost coverage. Government officials say hundreds of thousands of workers and their families have been saddled with tens of millions of dollars in unpaid medical bills.    After the Federal indictments last week of a group in North Carolina charged with selling worthless health insurance, Federal and state officials urged prospective buyers to be wary of bargain-priced offers. Buyers should determine what group is ultimately responsible for paying medical bills and ask state insurance officials if that group is an authorized insurer.

headline: Powell Tells British U.S. Still Has Nerve To Oppose the Iraqis
abstract: Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told America's strongest European supporters in the Persian Gulf crisis today that President Bush, the Congress and the people of the United States had not lost their nerve.   "The only acceptable outcome is total withdrawal of Iraqi forces from all of Kuwait," he told a group of British generals, scholars and policy makers, assuring them that war, if it came, would be "as quick and decisive as possible."

headline: A Cable TV Company Promotes Its Image
abstract: LEAD: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS Inc., the nation's largest operator of cable television systems, has turned to Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, for a warmly lit, feel-good campaign intended to improve its standing with the public. The ads will begin later this month on all the company's cable systems and on broadcast stations in 24 states.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Up By 13.24%
abstract: LEAD: Tokyo stocks posted their biggest single-day gains today, with the key Nikkei index up 13.24 percent The 225-stock average almost regained the nearly 15 percent it had lost over the previous five trading days.

headline: FORUM;  Don't Count on a Mild Recession
abstract: LEAD: As you may recall, the economy was supposed to be landing softly just about now. Most analysts, including myself, had been forecasting for some time a period of modest growth late this year and on into next, with more robust activity resuming by mid-1991.

headline: Last U.S. Flight of Hostages, Envoy Aboard, Gets to West
abstract: The last United States-sponsored evacuation flight out of Iraq and occupied Kuwait arrived here tonight, carrying the United States Ambassador to Kuwait and 31 other Americans.   The Ambassador, W. Nathaniel Howell, and a four-member staff ended a four-month holdout at the embassy compound in Kuwait City this morning and boarded the chartered Iraq Airways flight, which stopped in Baghdad before flying on to Frankfurt.

headline: Argentine Union Leader Blunt About Payoffs
abstract: A labor leader's recent public admission that he saw nothing wrong with taking his cut from business deals has caused embarrassment even in this country where payoffs and other corruption are considered common practice.    Luis Barrionuevo, a leader of the restaurant workers' union who also directs a social benefits fund for all trade unions, said in a radio interview that he had "made a lot of money" by channeling union business to lawyers and accountants, who, in turn, paid him and other union leaders. Mr. Barrionuevo made the comment in the process of claiming he had never "put the hand in the cookie jar" because this availability of money "from the other side" made it unnecessary for union leaders to enrich themselves at union expense.

headline: Singapore Recruiting
abstract: LEAD: A group of employers in Singapore, seeking to ease a shortage of skilled workers, will send recruiters abroad next spring to interview Singapore natives and other Asians studying in British and North American universities. Officials estimate that up to 80,000 workers are needed to supplement Singapore's work force of 1.2 million.

headline: Kuwait Asks U.N. to Preserve Pre-Invasion Population List
abstract: Kuwait's Government in exile is seeking United Nations help in preserving records listing the nation's population before it was invaded by Iraq, Kuwaiti diplomats say.    The Government-in-exile also hopes to use the United Nations to focus world attention on Iraqi atrocities and on the more 1,000 Kuwaiti fighters believed to have been captured during the invasion, whom Iraq refuses to recognize as prisoners of war.

headline: Paper Maker Posts Decline
abstract: LEAD: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that its third-quarter profits dropped 46.6 percent as its interest expense soared and its building products business weakened.

headline: Iraq Allows Some Hostages to Phone Families
abstract: The State Department said today that at least 21 American families had received telephone calls over the weekend from relatives detained in Iraq. It declared that instead of simply permitting the hostages to speak with their families, the Iraqis should free them.   "Consistent with other reports we have received, many detainees said they were losing weight, that the food was poor and that with the approach of winter they were frequently cold," said a State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher. "Others expressed concern that the medication they were using was running out."

headline: Citicorp Planning to Close 9 Real Estate Lending Units
abstract: Following through with its previously announced plans to reduce expenses and cut back its real estate lending, Citicorp is closing 9 of the 16 commercial real estate lending offices it has in the United States, a spokesman for the banking company said yesterday.    The number of jobs lost in the move was not disclosed. Citicorp officials have said they plan to cut more than 2,000 jobs, mostly in the corporate and commercial real estate lending activities in the global banking group, which handles corporate finance in North America, Japan and Europe.

headline: Your Money;   Retirement Funds: Strategy Review
abstract: LEAD: For people who have followed prudent financial advice for years, saving for retirement in tax-deferred accounts, a question arises: When should the money be withdrawn? In today's tax climate, experts who once favored keeping money in I.R.A.'s and 401(k) and Keogh plans as long as possible are beginning to favor earlier withdrawals.

headline: Article 399690 -- No Title
abstract: The Tucson Airport Authority in Arizona tentatively priced three series of $19.2 million in airport revenue bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.    Yields in the Series A bonds include 6.05 percent for an issue due in 1995, 6.55 percent for an issue due in 2000 and 7.05 percent for one due in 2020.    In the Series B bonds, which for some investors is subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax, yields include 6.30 percent for an issue due in 1995, 6.80 percent for bonds due in 2000, 7.30 percent for another due in 2015 and 7.40 percent for an issue due in 2020. The proceeds will finance land purchases for future airport development.    The Series B portion of the financing is a taxable municipal bond due in 2020 and priced to yield 9.50 percent.   Underwriters said the bonds were insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation and, as a result, were rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Your Own Account; Decision Time for Benefits
abstract: IN the last few years, changes in employee benefit plans have shifted more of the cost to employees -- and more of the burden for figuring out how to use them. To wring the most value from your plan next year, you've got to make some decisions by Jan. 1.  "It's never been more hectic in the benefits area," said Douglas J. Carey, partner in the New York office of Hewitt Associates, employee benefits consultants. "You can't assume that what you did last year is O.K. because your company probably changed the plan." Companies are faced with the need to cut costs and medical care is a prime target. Congress, with its new tax law, has cut back on tax-deductible items. So whatever savings you can realize in benefits -- in straight cash or in tax savings -- are valuable indeed.

headline: Shares in NCR Continue to Fall
abstract: The stock of the NCR Corporation fell for the third session in a row as traders said they were worried that A.T.& T.'s bid for the computer company might take longer than initially expected. NCR fell $1.375 yesterday, to $89.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. A.T.& T. was down 37.5 cents, to $29.50.   Last week, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company began a $90-a-share, or $6.12 billion, cash offer NCR. Charles E. Exley Jr., NCR's chairman, has said the Dayton, Ohio, company wants to remain independent, though he said NCR would consider an offer of $125 a share. The Reuters news agency reported the European Commission would review the proposed takeover to determine if it would harm competition in European Community markets.

headline: Bertelsmann Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: Bertelsmann A. G., the German media giant, has acquired the top book publisher in former East Germany, the company said today.

headline: Callable Bonds For Farm Credit
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday priced $100 million in callable consolidated systemwide bonds, due 1993, through Lehman Brothers.

headline: Syndication Post at Times
abstract: John C. Brewer has been named president of The New York Times Syndication Sales Corporation, which markets The New York Times News Service and distributes syndicated material.    Mr. Brewer, who is 43 years old, became executive vice president of the syndicate last January. In his new position he succeeds Karl Horwitz, who will become president of international sales and operations, based in Paris. The moves, effective Jan. 1, were announced by Katherine P. Darrow, president of the Broadcasting/ Information Services Group of The New York Times Company.    Mr. Brewer joined The Times in March 1988 as executive editor of the news service after a 19-year career with The Associated Press.   Mr. Horwitz, 54, took over direction of the syndicate's Paris office in January 1990 and since has overseen a reorganization of international operations. He has been with The Times since 1959 and has been president of the syndicate since 1986.    The Times syndicate distributes feature packages, columns, book serializations and magazine excerpts to more than 2,000 publications throughout the world. The Times news service transmits news and feature articles, photographs and graphics to some 600 publications and broadcast stations in more than 50 countries.

headline: World's Markets Post Hefty Losses in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Battered by higher oil prices and a weakening global economy, the world's major stock markets finished their worst quarter since 1974 on Friday.

headline: Mourning Soviet Reform
abstract: If the First Congress of People's Deputies, a year and a half ago, was a baptism of infant democracy and an exorcism of Stalinist demons, the fourth Congress, which ended on Thursday night, was a wake.    With desperate noise and little cheer, it marked not only the passing of this year of sunken spirits, but in the minds of many participants, the end of the period of great advances.

headline: U.S. Will Interview Dancers Of Cambodia on Defecting
abstract: LEAD: The State Department said today that it had demanded that a group of Cambodian dancers on tour in the United States be interviewed by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to determine if more of them may want to defect.

headline: The Gorbachev Era Up to Now: Five Explosive Years
abstract: March 1985: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is named to succeed Konstantin U. Chernenko as Soviet leader and outlines an urgent agenda to improve the economy. At 54, he is the youngest man to take charge of the Soviet Union since Stalin, who was 45.    April 1985: Mr. Gorbachev emphasizes the need to reshape the economy and reduce rigidity in the Soviet system, in a process known as perestroika.    July 1985: The Gorbachev Politburo removes the veteran Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, and names him to the largely ceremonial Soviet presidency. Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who had been the Communist Party leader of the Georgian republic, replaces him.    March 1986: A Communist Party congress approves a resolution calling for "truly revolutionary changes" in the economy.   January 1987: The Communist Party Central Committee approves Mr. Gorbachev's plan to give voters a choice of candidates in local elections.   October 1987: Boris N. Yeltsin, the Moscow party leader and a favorite of those advocating swifter change, attacks Yegor K. Ligachev, a conservative who is the No. 2 party leader. Mr. Yeltsin is forced out of his party posts.   November 1987: On the 70th anniversary of the Russian Revolution, Mr. Gorbachev sharply criticizes Stalin, helping to legitimize criticism of other organs of repression and loosening censorship.    March 1989: In the first free elections since 1917, scores of party officials suffer humiliating defeats in races for the new national legislature, the Congress of People's Deputies.    July 1989: With Kremlin leaders openly alarmed that the Communist Party is losing control, Mr. Gorbachev calls for a sweeping purge of party ranks to replace conservatives at all levels.   November 1989: In an apparent effort to mollify conservatives, Mr. Gorbachev publishes a manifesto insisting that Marxism will be revived in the Soviet Union, and under the leadership of the party. He describes his goal as "humane socialism."   December 1989: The Communist Party in Lithuania, the most independence-minded of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, breaks with Moscow. Mr. Gorbachev denounces the move.   January 1990: Mr. Gorbachev meets Lithuanian Communist Party leaders and says he understands motivation behind their vote to break away from Moscow and will not attempt to undo it. But later, he demands that Lithuania pay $33 billion in compensation if the republic breaks away. Political dissidents from across country meet in Moscow to openly challenge party dominance, and ethnic violence in Azerbaijan adds to the impression of events spinning out of control.   February 1990: Over the fierce objections of hard-liners, the Communist Party Central Committee adopts Mr. Gorbachev's plan to end the constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power held by the Communist Party and recommends creation of a powerful Western-style presidency and a Cabinet form of government.   March 1990: In elections in the Soviet republics, independent pro-democracy groups achieve major gains in the Russian, Ukrainian and Byelorussian republics and outright control of local governments in Moscow, Leningrad and other cities. The Lithuanian parliament declares that the annexation of the republic by the Soviet Union in 1940 is null and void. Mr. Gorbachev is elected by the Soviet Parliament to the new executive presidency with powers he says he needs to prevent nation from economic collapse and ethnic crisis.    July 1990: At a Communist Party congress the conservative Mr. Ligachev denounces five years of "blind radicalism" by Mr. Gorbachev. He is greeted by thunderous applause, but later loses an election for the No. 2 post in the reorganized Politburo. On Mr. Gorbachev's other flank, Mr. Yeltsin, who has rebounded from his 1987 disgrace to become leader of the Russian republic and Mr. Gorbachev's chief rival, walks out of the congress and quits the Communist Party to express dismay with the pace of change.   September 1990: Soviet farmers produce the most bountiful crop in the nation's history, but a decaying transportation network and regional hoarding translate into worsening shortages on grocery shelves.    December 1990: Western governments, though conceding there is no imminent danger of famine, rush to provide food aid to the Soviet Union as a sign of political support for Mr. Gorbachev. The Congress of People's Deputies convenes to approve Mr. Gorbachev's plan for revamping the Government to give him greater powers and to debate the concept of a new union treaty that would adjust the balance of powers between Moscow and the republics. Mr. Shevardnadze resigns, asserting that reactionaries are pushing the country toward dictatorship.

headline: Mandela's Group Begins a Recruiting Drive
abstract: A middle-aged white couple recently walked into the old Arthur Murray dance studio for a rehearsal and found the last waltz saved for the African National Congress.    Since their previous visit, the premises had been rented to the Congress for its regional headquarters in the Eastern Cape. The dancers were urged to rehearse in what remained of the ballroom, disregarding the militant slogans and political bustle.

headline: Ford-Volkswagen Plan for Portugal
abstract: The Ford Motor Company and Volkswagen A.G. are negotiating to jointly produce a new multipurpose vehicle in Portugal, the president of Ford of Europe said. Lindsey Halstead said a final decision on the $2.5 billion project depended on continuing economic feasibility studies by the car makers, as well as support from the European Community.    Mr. Halstead and Paul Weber, Volkswagen's director for foreign investment, met today with the Portuguese Prime Minister, Anibal Cavaco Silva.

headline: Zygo Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. SEEKS TO AVOID U.N. VETO ON ISRAEL
abstract: For the third time since the Persian Gulf crisis began four months ago, the Bush Administration is trying to avoid using its veto in Israel's defense Thursday when the United Nations Security Council is expected to vote on a new resolution criticizing Israel's treatment of Palestinians in territories it has occupied.    All last month, when the United States held the rotating presidency of the Security Council, American diplomats worked to prevent a vote on the resolution because it did not want to embarrass its Arab allies in the gulf by vetoing the measure before the Council had agreed to authorize the use of force to expel Iraq from Kuwait if necessary after Jan. 15.

headline: Taiwan Envoys Seeking Access on Mainland
abstract: Taiwan legislators are slipping into mainland China these days, touting their political influence in hopes of meeting with the highest-ranking Chinese leaders possible, and carrying back messages they believe will play a role in the quiet diplomacy that is taking place across the Taiwan Strait.   The visits are only one way that the barriers between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland are breaking down -- not so dramatically as the destruction of the Berlin wall, but with scarcely less significance for this region.The four-decade ban by Taiwan on official contacts with mainland Chinese authorities is eroding, under the pressure of the legislators' visits and as well as joint meetings on repatriation of illegal immigrants from the mainland. Last month, Red Cross officials from Taiwan and China met secretly on Quemoy, an island administered by Taiwan off the coast of southern China, to negotiate repatriation of Chinese refugees who had fled to Taiwan. The news came out after the talks ended.

headline: People
abstract: * Lisa von Drehle and Janine K. Davis have been appointed vice presidents of J. Walter Thompson, Chicago. * John Parlato and Walt Hampton Jr. have been named senior vice presidents and creative directors at W. B. Doner & Company. * Timothy Scott has been promoted to a management representative at DDB Needham, Chicago. * Thomas W. Eley has been named vice president of business development for the Gannett Outdoor Group, New York. * Mitchell Hershey joined Wexler, McCarron & Roth Advertising, Pompano Beach, Fla., as a senior vice president of marketing and business development.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allwaste Inc., Houston, an environmental services provider, appointed R. L. Nelson Jr. president, replacing Clayton K. Trier, who resigned. * American Savings Bank, White Plains, said William Lillis, the president, chief executive and a director, would retire at the end of October 1991. * Ameritrust Corp., Cleveland, a bank holding company, promoted Larry D. Peterson to chief executive officer of its Indiana Corp. and Ameritrust National Bank divisions. * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, the drug concern, appointed Thomas D. McCann vice president of public affairs. * California Energy Co., San Francisco, a developer of power plants, named Harvey Brush chief operating officer. * Frank & Son Inc., Conway, S.C., a furniture manufacturer, appointed Geroge E. Sanderson president and chief executive officer, Derek R. Williams vice president, George H. Sanderson treasurer and Cecile S. Gough secretary. * Hartmarx Corp., Chicago, a manufacturer of clothing, promoted Homi B. Patel to president of its men's apparel group. * Pizza Hut Inc., Wichita, Kan., a subsidiary of Pepsico Inc., New York, appointed Randy Barnes president of its international division. * Warner-Lambert Co., Morris Plains, N.J., a diversified company, named Joseph E. Smith and John F. Walsh executive vice presidents.

headline: Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk Journal;   Chekhov Among Outcasts: An Island Remembers
abstract: LEAD: ''Arrived in good condition. Send telegrams to Chekhov.''

headline: Wheeling Steel Reorganization
abstract: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation hopes to conclude a reorganization of its debts and emerge from bankruptcy court protection on Dec. 20. Parties to the reorganization, now in its sixth year, will soon receive ballots and documents related to the proposed settlement.    Under a tentative timetable, voting on the reorganization plan will conclude on Nov. 27. A court hearing to confirm will take place on Dec. 6 and Judge Warren Bentz will probably approve it by Dec. 10, a Wheeling-Pittsburgh spokesman, Ray Johnson, said. When the case concludes, more than $700 million in claims against Wheeling-Pittsburgh will have been settled.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Promoting Reservists' Job Security
abstract: LEAD: REACTING to the crisis in the Middle East, Ross Roy Advertising in Detroit has created a public service campaign that urges the employers of the nearly 50,000 military reservists who have been called into active service to ''Be a hero - give your employees the freedom to protect ours.''

headline: 5 Senators Agree on Futures Trading
abstract: LEAD: After two months of negotiations, five key Senators agreed to a compromise proposal today that would allow the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to retain control over futures trading but give the Federal Reserve Board authority to set margins on trades.

headline: The Tables Have Turned on Gambling
abstract: The cards slapped down on the baize blackjack tables in mind-numbing regularity. The roulette wheels spun, and the slots chattered incessantly, occasionally coughing up cups full of winnings, mostly just eating up dreams. Down at the Copacabana, Barry Manilow was singing. Billboards promised that Joan Rivers would be coming to Caesars. Outside, the air was brittle and the ocean waves were choppy. At Boardwalk Roger's Famous Hot Dogs, hot dogs twirled on their heating rollers, but only one customer came.   A middle-aged man with chiseled features and a thin mustache climbed out of his seat at one of the blackjack tables at Bally's. He gave a wave of disgust. A short-skirted hostess asked him if there was anything he would like. He said, "How about some more chips? They busted me."

headline: Former Communists in Serbia Win Majority in Parliamentary Vote
abstract: Serbia's renamed Communists won overwhelmingly the first free vote in the republic in five decades, taking 194 seats in its 250-seat parliament, according to final official results today.    Serbia, the largest republic, and Montenegro, the smallest, were the only two of Yugoslavia's six republics to elect Communist governments. In the four other regions, center-right or nationalist parties triumphed, and the results in Serbia and Montenegro threaten to push Yugoslavia one step closer to disintegration.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Pakistani Vows to Step Up Nuclear Program
abstract: The new Prime Minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, said today that he would accelerate the country's nuclear energy program, calling it "imperative" to reduce oil dependency and meet the growing needs of the industrial sector.    He stressed, however, that the stepped-up effort would be devoted exclusively to peaceful ends and that he was "against the destructive use of atomic power."

headline: Investor Pursues DeSoto Takeover
abstract: The New York investor William Spier said he was still interested in acquiring DeSoto Inc. and would be willing to raise his offer for the detergent maker by $1 a share, to $5.25. Mr. Spier, chairman of the Sutton Holding Corporation, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he wanted to continue a merger offer he made for DeSoto earlier this month.

headline: Icahn Group to Urge USX Sale of Steel Unit
abstract: The New York corporate raider Carl C. Icahn disclosed today that he had formed a new shareholder committee to press for the rapid sale or spinoff of the USX Corporation's steel business.   Mr. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, is the largest shareholder in USX, with 13.3 percent. He said that although USX had recently taken steps that could lead to a sale of the company, he was still worried that its management was reluctant to part with the business.

headline: A Company Gives Up on New York
abstract: THE budget agreement that is now working its way toward enactment is a good one. It will not achieve all that is claimed for it, but it will make substantial cuts in the deficit that are real. The tax increases and some of the entitlement cuts will be locked into substantive law, and, barring a shooting war in the Persian Gulf, future defense spending is likely to be less than what the budget agreement promises.   We Americans are finally facing up, if only partially, to correcting a decade of public and private profligacy, during which the country borrowed massively at home and abroad to finance a consumption boom. As a nation we now save and invest only 3 percent of our national income. Our economic future depends on raising national saving, mainly through getting rid of the Federal budget deficit and ultimately turning it into a surplus. The budget agreement is a major step in that direction.

headline: Profit Slips 2.6% at Du Pont
abstract: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company today reported a 2.6 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings, with increases in its petroleum operations offset by slower growth in the company's chemicals businesses.   The company reported net income of $533 million in the quarter, down from $547 million a year earlier. Earnings per share were flat at 79 cents and reflected the lower number of shares this year because of a stock-buyback program.   Revenues for the quarter were up 15.6 percent, at $9.93 billion, compared with $8.59 billion in 1989.   "Third-quarter results reflect strong performance from our petroleum operations," Du Pont's chairman, Edgar S. Woolard Jr., said. "At the same time, earnings in several of our chemical businesses continued to be adversely affected by the slowdown in the U.S. economy."   Du Pont said the improvement in petroleum earnings was partly a result of higher oil prices, which soared after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The company said 70 percent of the overall improvement was a result of operations overseas, where there was a strong demand for petroleum products and greater efficiency at the company's refineries.   Du Pont also said its quarterly results included gains of 8 cents a share from the sale of an interest in a North Sea oil property and an instrument systems business.   The company's shares were unchanged today at $34.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Berlin Arrests 4, Alleging $328 Million in Swindles
abstract: LEAD: The German authorities have arrested four people they say are connected with a major series of swindles that have cheated the Bonn Government out of at least $328 million since July, a Government prosecutor announced today.

headline: 10 U.S. Sailors Die in Shipboard Accident in Gulf; Marine Is Also Killed
abstract: Eleven American servicemen in the Persian Gulf region were killed today in two accidents, raising the death toll in the American military deployment there to 43.   A ruptured valve spewed superheated steam into the boiler room of the amphibious assault ship Iwo Jima near Bahrain today, killing 10 sailors; and a marine was killed and three others injured when their vehicle overturned in nighttime maneuvers in the Saudi Arabian desert.

headline: Phone Theft At NASA
abstract: Computer hackers have stolen $12 million worth of telephone service from the Johnson Space Center, according to a report published today in The Houston Chronicle. Hundreds of people have used the system over at least two years, the paper said.    "It's the biggest one I've ever heard of, and certainly the longest-running one I've ever heard of," said Jim Black, a detective, computer crime unit coordinator of the Los Angeles Police Department and leading authority on telecommunications theft. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration could not precisely determine the loss, Steve Nesbitt, a spokesman, said. The $12 million figure was calculated from costs of similar break-ins described by law enforcement agents specializing in computer crime.   Mr. Nesbitt said the service was stolen in two ways -- by using a long-distance credit card number and by gaining access to NASA's lines in the Federal Telephone System. The card fraud was discovered by A.T.&T. when use of the number exceeded typical patterns. The number has been deactivated, Mr. Nesbitt said.    On Nov. 17, it was reported that computer hackers and others had stolen phone service worth millions through the Houston offices of the Drug Enforcement Administration.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Rise 11.6% on Big Board
abstract: LEAD: The latest figure is equivalent to nine-tenths of 1 percent of the total shares listed on the Big Board.      Amex Short Sales Also at Record High

headline: Allies Leave Jordan 'Out of the Loop'
abstract: Jordan's growing isolation is perhaps best reflected in a small notice that appeared today in The Jordan Times: the German airline Lufthansa has announced that it will stop all flights to and from Amman by the end of January.   Lufthansa was the fifth airline to suspend flights to what only a year ago was a major Mideast hub, joining British Airways, Swissair, Alitalia and KLM. Of the major international carriers, only Air France still flies here, but businessmen say it, too, will soon suspend service.

headline: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall
abstract: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the week that ended yesterday.   The Chase Manhattan Bank said its customers were still attracted to the shorter maturities, those of less than a year, because of the uncertainty of the times.

headline: Transport Secretary Given A Dismal Report by Airlines
abstract: Samuel K. Skinner, the Secretary of Transportation, concluded two days of talks with top airline executives yesterday aimed at assessing the damage caused by higher fuel costs and is now considering ways to aid the faltering industry, said a senior agency official who spoke on the condition he not be identified.    The executives, representing most major airlines, gave Mr. Skinner a dismal prognosis for the coming months, mainly because of sharply higher jet-fuel prices and softening demand for air travel.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Milken Sentence    Michael Milken's lawyers could not have determined that he would be sentenced to a prison term as long as 10 years. Based on information compiled by the U.S. Attorney's office in Manhattan, the term fell outside the boundaries of any of the more than 75 sentences handed down against white-collar criminals on Wall Street in the last decade.  [ Page D1. ]   Judge Kimba Wood said in her sentencing that she wanted to send a message. Whether they view Mr. Milken as a hero, a villain or a scapegoat, a variety of people contacted afterward said the judge's message came through loud and clear.  [ D4. ] The Economy    What began as a small promotion by American Airlines to an exclusive group of customers has escalated into a nationwide giveaway. The nation's large airlines are offering free tickets to the traveling companions of all comers, delighting passengers but cutting into industry profits and infuriating travel agents.  [ A1. ]   The Bush Administration has drafted an ambitious plan for expanding highway construction, broadening the network of major national roads, providing incentives to reduce congestion and allowing states to charge tolls on more highways.  [ A1. ] Companies    Two of the world's biggest deal makers are behaving as if mergers had not fallen by nearly half and that the "junk bond" market had not collapsed. Forstmann Little and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts are trying to persuade pension funds and other big investors to replenish their coffers so they can buy more companies.  [ D1. ]   Brooks Brothers has stuck with tradition, in the clothes it sells and how it sells them, even though its sales have slumped.  [ D1. ]   Suspects in the abduction of John F. Grundhofer, chief executive of First Bank System in Minneapolis, include disgruntled former employees and rejected borrowers. He was released after two hours.  [ A33. ]   The Miami City Commission has approved an ordinance requiring the police to report drug arrests to employers.  [ B21. ] International    One of Italy's industrial titans resigned unexpectedly as chairman of Ferruzzi Finanziaria, the country's second-largest private company. Raul Gardini, who has been emboiled in a dispute with a state-owned energy company, said he would leave the business world for "ideological reasons."  [ D1. ]   A new airport going up in western Japan has become the focus of an angry dispute between the U.S. and Japan over the failure of an American-German venture to win a big contract.  [ D1. ]   Argentina's privatization program took a big step forward with the transfer of control of the national airline, Aerolineas Argentinas, to a group led by Iberia, the Spanish carrier.  [ D1. ] Markets    Britain's markets closed virtually unchanged, although they rose sharply after Margaret Thatcher announced she would resign as Prime Minister. Most other European trading was subdued. U.S. markets were closed for the Thanksgiving holiday.  [ D6. ] Today's Columns    Bankers fear that unless a banking crisis is prevented, the economic slowdown could become the most severe postwar recession. The Treasury Secretary urges banks to keep lending, and the Fed insists it is well aware of the dangers of a banking crisis and has plans for dealing with one. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene.  [ D2. ]   The sputtering recreational vehicle industry needs a vacation. Slumping demand has forced companies to close plants and slash earnings projections. Market Place.  [ D6. ]   Ayer has created a public service campaign about the homeless that has failed to attract a sponsor. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D5. ]

headline: German Communists Admit Funds Shift
abstract: Leaders of the former East German Communist Party confessed today that party officials had illegally transferred $70 million to Moscow. Two senior officials were arrested in connection with the incident, the Berlin authorities said.   The confession and arrests came after the party leader, Gregor Gysi, made a one-day visit to Moscow during which he received assurances from Soviet Communist Party officials that the money transfer was not made at the Soviets' request, as the German Communists had said.

headline: Will the Children Really Be Helped?
abstract: LEAD: As the World Summit for Children ended here tonight, diplomats and public-health experts were asking whether the conference would produce tangible benefits for children, as its sponsors hoped.

headline: G.M. to Export Cars to Yugoslavia
abstract: The General Motors Corporation will begin exporting a small number of Chevrolet, Pontiac and Cadillac cars to Yugoslavia beginning early next year, the auto maker said. The initial order is for 450 1991 Chevrolet Corsica, Cadillac Sedan DeVille and Pontiac Grand Prix and Bonneville cars. The order was to be signed on Friday in a ceremony at G.M. headquarters here.    G.M. also has agreements to establish vehicle and component assembly operations in other Eastern Euopean countries, including Hungary, Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union and the former East Germany. The Yugoslavian-bound cars will go to Y.K., a vehicle distributor located in Sarajevo. "Our target is to sell 1,000 vehicles next year from the Sarajevo dealership," said Y.K. president's, Sead Dizdarevic.

headline: It's Glam! It's Fab! It's a Rave!
abstract: Gene and Robert Pressman are like brothers from different planets.   Gene, long haired and laid back, preferring jeans and blazer to a suit, went to film school and worked as a go-fer in Hollywood before bringing women's fashion to the family business, Barneys New York. Robert, at 36, is three years' Gene's junior; he is close cropped and buttoned down, has an M.B.A. and runs the financial side of the company. In an era of retail retrenchment, it may be just this mix -- innovative fashion merchandiser and sober financier -- coupled with rich Japanese backers that will make Barneys fly as other retailers flounder. While in malls and on Main Street fashion industry executives are struggling just to survive, the Pressmans have been thinking: the world.
