headline: SPY FOR BONN SAYS HE'S DOUBLE AGENT
abstract: LEAD: A senior West German counterintelligence officer who used to run East German double agents has confessed to being a double agent himself, the Federal Prosecutor's Office announced today.

headline: Fair Play for Disaffected Men
abstract: To the Editor:   Admittedly, I was amused by the letter from Robin Shectman ("Take My Husband . . . Please," Nov. 4) describing a husband-disposing, man-procuring chain letter scheme. And I appreciate the wry, witty spirit of her plan to "bring relief to tired, discontented women" encouraging them to trade their own "s.o.b." and a postage stamp for 16,748 men, some of whom "are dandies." Yet I can't help but wonder what might have happened if her letter had been written by a man describing a chain letter to "bored, disgruntled men." Imagine it urged them to "ship off the old bag" to the name at the top of the list in anticipation of receiving thousands of women, some of whom "are real honeys!" If such a letter ever saw print, picture the torrents of reader protests, peer criticism and media pontification.   The humor displayed in Ms. Shectman's chain letter is a healthy and honest expression of the unfulfillment and frustration with personal relationships that many women experience. But such emotions are not limited to women. How refreshing it would be if men were freer to humorously (and publicly) express their disaffections with women without fear of being labeled Neanderthals. KENNETH DIAMOND  New York, Nov. 6

headline: Israeli and Intruder Killed in Jordan Border Clash
abstract: An Israeli soldier and an Arab gunman were killed in a firefight in the Israeli-occupied West Bank early this morning when troops battled armed infiltrators from Jordan, the army said.   Elsewhere today, the army reported that a Palestinian man stabbed and killed an Israeli guard at a West Bank military prison, and in Jerusalem, the police arrested seven supporters of Rabbi Meir Kahane on suspicion of inciting violence at the rabbi's funeral on Wednesday. Four Palestinians and two policemen were injured in rioting at the funeral.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: The assets of the nation's 533 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.11 billion, to $427.90 billion, in the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assests of the 162 institutional funds decreased by $627.6 million, to $111.47 billion. Assets of the 267 general-purpose funds were down by $226.3 million, to $150.41 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds decreased by $251.9 million, to $166.02 billion, the institute said.

headline: UAL Financing Short of Goal
abstract: LEAD: An effort by United Airlines' unions to get banks to pledge much more than the amount needed to finance their bid to buy the UAL Corporation has fallen short of the goal, a banking official said yesterday.

headline: Japan Loans To China
abstract: Japan announced Friday that it was resuming a development loan program for China that has been frozen since the brutal suppression of pro-democracy protests in Beijing last year.   Japan will make available up to $283 million to China for seven projects "to contribute to economic stability and to promote the economic modernization efforts of the country," the Foreign Ministry said.   It said in a statement that Japan's Ambassador to China, Hiroshi Hashimoto, and Qi Huaiyuan, a Chinese Foreign Ministry official, had exchanged a memorandum of understanding on the plan.   The money is part of a five-year package of development loans to China totaling $6.28 billion.    In July, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu promised to resume the loans gradually. Other industrialized democracies have also been gradually easing sanctions on China in recent months.   The terms of the loans to China include an annual interest rate of 2.5 percent and a 30-year repayment period. Japan will not require that Japanese companies be involved in the programs.

headline: Merrill Lynch Net Up; Schwab Has Big Gain
abstract: LEAD: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest broker, yesterday reported a 12.4 percent rise in its third- quarter earnings from last year. The company said, however, that the Middle East crisis and ''inconclusive Federal budget deliberations'' led to declines in investment banking activity and retail commissions.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Engineer Is Selected For Top Post at Hercules
abstract: Thomas L. Gossage, a chemical engineer who joined Hercules Inc. two years ago to run the company's core specialty chemicals business, will become its chairman and chief executive on Jan. 1, the company said. He replaces David S. Hollingsworth, 62 years old, who announced in July that he would retire at the end of the year.   Mr. Gossage, 56, will oversee the eclectic mix of businesses at Hercules, which range from resins, fragrances and food additives to electronic products and aerospace technology. The company, based in Wilmington, Del, had total sales of $3.09 billion in 1989.   The biggest challenge facing Mr. Gossage "is taking leadership of a company as diverse as Hercules is," said Ted Semegran, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York.   Mr. Gossage, a senior vice president and president of the Hercules Aqualon subsidiary, said he did not plan any shifts in strategy. But he added, "We've had some difficulty delivering our financial results, and we need to move the crediblity of the company back up to an acceptable level."   Hercules took a pretax charge against earnings of $323 million last year to cover cost overruns on its Titan 4 solid-fuel booster rocket.  Analysts say that the future of Hercules depends heavily on the success of the Titan 4 program, which has absorbed most of the company's $1 billion investment in aerospace technology.   The chairman-elect acknowledged that he had limited experience managing the crucial aerospace business at Hercules, but said that he planned to get more involved. Mr. Gossage said a new management team has "their arms wrapped around that business, and they know what needs to be done."   Before joining Hercules in 1988, Mr. Gossage worked for 26 years at the Monsanto Company. A native of Nashville, Mr. Gossage recieved B.S. and M.S. degrees in chemical engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology.   He and his wife live in Wilmington.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Inc., Lyndhurst, N.J., to Mullen of Wenham, Mass., with a budget of $5 million. * Budget Rent a Car Corp., Chicago, to W. B. Doner, Baltimore, with undisclosed billings.

headline: What's in a Name? For Some Publishers, Celebrity Novels
abstract: LEAD: The celebrity memoir is a staple of publishing, and some publishers are now getting ready to bet millions of dollars that the public will also buy novels by celebrities, even those that are actually written by other people.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE DEAL FOR MCA    MCA agreed to be acquired by Matsushita. The deal, valued at $6.13 billion in cash, will be the largest purchase ever of an American company by a Japanese company.  [ Page D1. ]    Matsushita appears to have raised political concerns by refusing to say that it would not interfere with the content of MCA's movies, records or books.  [ D1. ]     The F.C.C.'s chairman said the MCA deal could give a boost to efforts by the television networks to gain more freedom to own the shows they broadcast and perhaps to own film studios as well.  [ D6. ]  The MCA deal is likely to change Hollywood, and it almost certainly will not be the last transaction to do so.  [ D7. ]     MCA has not strayed far from its core business of movies and television.  [ D7. ]  An MCA subsidiary, G. P. Putnam's Sons, has seen its revenues surge eightfold since it was acquired in 1975.  [ D7. ]     Only a few small investment firms will be dividing up $30 million to $100 million in fees from the MCA acquisition.  [ D7. ]     Just what is a television station worth in the New York market? That question will soon be answered when WWOR-TV is spun off by MCA. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D8. ] THE ECONOMY    Freer world trade has outgrown the rules written for it, and trade negotiators are now trying to bridge wide gaps.  [ A1. ]     The growing backlash against state and local tax increases has created a patchwork of thousands of special-purpose taxes.  [ A1. ]     The former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said five Senators should have steered clear of Charles H. Keating Jr. when he sought their help.  [ A20. ]  Neil Bush served on the board of a Silverado Savings affiliate that helped a Denver homebuilder evade securities laws, according to Federal documents.  [ D2. ]     The Delaware Supreme Court affirmed the right of Fred M. Kirby 2d to oust three siblings from a foundation board.  [ D4. ]     The vacancy rate for Manhattan retail space is rising sharply and may exceed 10 percent by the end of the year.  [ B1. ] COMPANIES    Prodigy Services has issued guidelines restricting some uses of its electronic-mail computer service.  [ D1. ]     Toyota is expected announce that it will build another assembly plant near its existing factory in Kentucky.  [ D4. ]     Motorola has begun volume shipments of its most advanced microprocessor, the 68040, after months of delays.  [ D4. ] .      The Alexander's department store chain stopped advertising in The Daily News.  [ B5. ] INTERNATIONAL    A large Japanese developer is involved in what could be one of the largest bankruptcies in postwar Japan.  [ D1. ] MARKETS    Crude oil prices rose amid increasing worries about the Middle East. Oil gained $1.05 a barrel to close at $32.95.  [ D1. ]     The stock market reversed its early losses. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 5.94 points to close at 2,533.17,  [ D8. ]  Treasury bond prices made a strong turnaround.  [ D19. ]  The dollar advanced moderately and gold also gained.  [ D20. ]     Grain and soybean futures prices fell broadly as hopes for new sales of American crops to the Soviet Union faded.  [ D20. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS    The outlook for the toy industry is good, says John W. Ammerman, chief executive of Mattel. Talking Business.  [ D2. ]     Drenttel Doyle Partners won the $5 million account for Ellen Tracy's new line of clothing by demonstrating that it could create more than advertising. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D21. ]

headline: Sex Asks Its Due at Vatican Synod on Priests
abstract: LEAD: Despite admonitions from church leaders that the topic was out of bounds, the troublesome theme of sex and the priesthood has insistently emerged in the first days of a monthlong synod of Roman Catholic bishops that began here this week.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: A report on the Business Diary page last Sunday referred incorrectly to the quarterly dividend at the Travelers Corporation. Travelers recently announced a cut in its dividend to 40 cents a share from 60, but did not eliminate it.

headline: Britain Sees Gulf Blockade Deadline
abstract: LEAD: The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said today that the American-led forces arrayed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf would have to decide ''in a matter of weeks'' whether economic sanctions should give way to war to force President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to pull his troops out of Kuwait.

headline: A Foreign Flag for A.T.&T.?
abstract: American Telephone and Telegraph may operate cable-laying ships under foreign flags in order to pay their crews lower wages. Page D1.

headline: Dow Plunges 44.31 as Trading Picks Up
abstract: Strong war talk from Margaret Thatcher pushed oil prices sharply higher yesterday and sent stock prices sharply lower.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been falling a bit by noon, began dropping even faster when traders received word that the British Prime Minister had threatened to use force against Saddam Hussein.

headline: National Party Wins New Zealand Vote; Improved U.S. Ties Sought
abstract: Jim Bolger, a conservative who has pledged to patch up relations with the United States, easily captured the Prime Minister's job today as his National Party won by a landslide in national elections.   The party capitalized on a faltering economy to end six years of rule by the Labor Party in this South Pacific nation of 3.5 million people.

headline: Berlin, the Capital, Fears for Future
abstract: Nearly a month after unification, this sprawling city of more than three million people is still struggling to become the united Germany's capital in more than name alone.   The problem arises because the treaty uniting the Germanys declared Berlin the capital, but ruled that only the all-German legislature that will be elected in December could decide where to locate the ministries and bureaucrats. No decision is expected before the spring.

headline: PAKISTANIS SEEING FEW HOPES IN VOTE
abstract: LEAD: In the Murree Hills northeast of here, villagers have hoisted banners with a blunt message for candidates campaigning for elections next week. Roughly translated, the handmade signs say, ''Bring us water and electricity before you ask for our votes.''

headline: S.& L.'s Seek State Charters
abstract: From New Jersey to Texas to California, savings and loan institutions are trying to get state laws enacted that would allow them to convert into savings banks. Federal regulators say this is an attempt to evade strict new Federal rules -- laws that the savings institutions say are so onerous they can no longer do business under them.   The battle is being played out in state legislatures and in Congress, where a bill has been introduced to halt these "charter flips." Three states -- Illinois, Indiana and Louisiana -- have enacted measures to permit the conversions and at least a dozen other states are considering similar action. In addition, such flips have been taking place in four other states, including New York, where current laws permit the change. 'Attempts to Evade Reforms'     "These efforts are blatant attempts to evade the reforms enacted by Congress," said Timothy Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates savings and loans. "I am greatly disturbed by the growing phenomenon of S.& L.'s attempting to circumvent the requirements of Congress simply by changing the form of their charter to become state savings banks."

headline: The Media Business;   Wider Reach Granted for 'Wireless Cable'
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission moved today to give more channels and more power to ''wireless cable'' companies, which broadcast programs on microwave frequencies and are trying to become low-cost rivals to cable television systems.

headline: Trump Move Is Reported
abstract: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump, the New York developer and casino operator, are preparing bankruptcy papers for the Trump Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City in case such a filing is necessary, people close to the Trump Organization said yesterday.    News that the bankruptcy papers were being prepared by Willkie Farr & Gallagher did not surprise lawyers and bankers familiar with the Trump situation; nor did it surprise representatives of the bondholders who are negotiating with the Trump Organization.    Mr. Trump faces a $47.3 million interest payment on Nov. 15 on $675 million of high-yield "junk bonds" sold to finish the Taj Mahal. He has been negotiating with bondholders to reduce his debt burden, offering them equity in the casino. No agreement has been reached.    "It's more or less a week's work to get the papers together, so it wouldn't surprise me at all if they were preparing the papers at this point," said Wilbur Ross, a senior managing director at Rothschild Inc., which represents the majority of bondholders. "I don't think it tells you anything about their intentions."    Mr. Trump will have a 30-day grace period after the Nov. 15th deadline to make the Taj payments.

headline: Treasury to Sell 3-Month and 6-Month Bills
abstract: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to today's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.    By late Friday the outstanding three-month and six-month bills were bid at 7.09 percent and 7.03 percent, respectively.    Among Government agency financings this week is tomorrow's $500 million debenture offering by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation through a 25-member dealer selling group. The three-year Freddie Mac debentures are callable at a price of par after one year.    The following fixed-income issues are scheduled this week: TAXABLE ONE DAY DURING THE WEEK Columbus Southern Power Co., 750,000 shares of $100 preferred stock, NR/Baa-2/BBB-. Salomon Brothers.  ICI Financial Corp., $300 million in notes, due in 2000, (guaranteed by Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C), NR/Aa-3/AA-. Goldman, Sachs & Co.  North Shore Gas Co., $25 million in first mortgage adjustable rate bonds, due in 2020. Edward D. Jones & Co. Source: McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc.   Ratings: MCM/Moody's/Standard & Poor's. TAX-EXEMPT MONDAY Nassau County, L.I., $60.3 million in notes. Competitive.  New York State Housing Finance Agency, $80 million in service contract obligation revenue bonds. Bear, Stearns & Co. TENTATIVE OFFERINGS THIS WEEK New Jersey Health Care Facilities Authority, $65 million in debt securities for Saint Elizabeth Hospital. Dillon, Read & Co.  New Jersey Health Care Facilities Authority, $55 million in debt securities for the Medical Center of Ocean County. Ryan, Beck & Co.  New York City, $1.3 billion in tax revenue anticipation notes. Lehman Brothers.

headline: World Leaders Endorse Plan To Improve Lives of Children
abstract: LEAD: Leaders from more than 70 nations came together here today in an extraordinary show of concern for the world's poorest children. They adopted a declaration and a plan of action committing them to drastically improving the lives of those children.

headline: Gorbachev's Economic Plan Approved
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev won an overwhelming parliamentary mandate today for his plan to transform the destitute Soviet state from a Communist to a market economy.

headline: Telephone Services: A Growing Form of 'Foreign Aid'
abstract: LEAD: Americans who make international telephone calls are paying extra to subsidize foreign countries' postal rates, local phone service, even schools and armies.

headline: Excerpts From Remarks by Webster and Baker on Embargo's Drain on Iraq
abstract: Following are excerpts from remarks by William H. Webster, Director of Central Intelligence, before the House Armed Services Committee today, and from Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, as recorded by The New York Times:  WEBSTER STATEMENT     Despite mounting disruptions and hardships resulting from sanctions, Saddam apparently believes that he can outlast international resolve to maintain sanctions. We see no indication that Saddam is concerned at this point that domestic discontent is growing to levels that may threaten his regime or that problems resulting from the sanctions are causing him to rethink his policy on Kuwait. The Iraqi people have experienced considerable deprivation in the past. Given the brutal nature of the Iraqi security services, the population is not likely to oppose Saddam openly. Our judgment has been, and continues to be, that there is no assurance or guarantee that economic hardships will compel Saddam to change his policies or lead to internal unrest that would threaten his regime. . . .

headline: Head of Hogan Systems Named Equimark Chief
abstract: Gary W. Fiedler has been named chairman and chief executive of the Equimark Corporation, the Pittsburgh-based bank holding company.   Mr. Fiedler, who is 46, has been for three years chairman and chief executive of Hogan Systems Inc., a Dallas-based supplier of technology services to banks. He previously held executive positions at the Mellon Bank, the Wells Fargo Bank and First Interstate Bancorp.

headline: Manerplaw Journal; In Burmese Jungle, Rebel Fortress Awaits Attack
abstract: The Karen, one of the largest of the dozen ethnic minorities of Myanmar, have been digging bunkers into the steep, forested, malarial hills that protect Manerplaw, the headquarters camp for insurgents fighting the Burmese military Government.    The dry season is almost here, when a 40-year-old war with the Burmese Army begins again. But after an effective campaign by the Burmese military last year, when numerous insurgent camps along the Thai-Burmese border were overrun in very heavy fighting, the Karen commander, Gen. Bo Mya, freely admits that Manerplaw is the most obvious target for this year's offensive.

headline: Man in the News; The Grandmaster of Polish Politics: Lech Walesa
abstract: Lech Walesa has a double chin, streaks of gray in his mustache, and a new wardrobe of natty shirts and ties, but in the important ways the 47-year-old electrician who won Poland's first direct presidential elections has changed little since he burst into prominence a decade ago.     Mr. Walesa remains Poland's Everyman, a rough-hewn worker of peasant stock whose political instincts make him the grandmaster of Polish politics, able to think three or four moves ahead of rivals.

headline: JET HITS A SCHOOL IN ITALY, KILLING 12
abstract: A burning military jet crashed into a classroom at a suburban high school today, killing 12 students, officials said. Many survivors jumped from windows, engulfed in heavy smoke, and were injured.   The pilot of the Italian Air Force jet had been trying to land his burning craft in fields near the school, Gen. Carlo Brandini, an Air Force spokesman, said. The pilot bailed out minutes before the crash.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.81   7.87   8.75        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.12   7.16   7.78        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.13   7.11   7.62        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.51   8.47   7.90        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.83   8.77   7.92        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.92   9.85   9.10        MUNICIPAL BONDS*   7.73   7.72   7.40       *Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Market Place; Toy Stocks Weak At Crucial Season
abstract: THE toy industry has been surprisingly resistant to hard times. Past recessions proved that parents will give up a lot of things before they will disappoint their children on Christmas.    Nonetheless, the stock market seems largely to be ignoring past trends and focusing more on bleak expectations for the economy and the evaporation of consumer confidence. A number of toy industry stocks are trading close to their 52-week lows.    And there are indeed some indications that this Christmas season may run counter to past trends. Cautious retailers, wary of being left with shelves of unbought goods, are keeping inventories low on all items, including toys. And fewer people are visiting shopping malls. "What the stocks are saying is, 'There might be somewhat more cyclicality here than meets the eye,' " said Steven Eisenberg, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company.     Analysts and toy company executives say that specific products, along with overall economic conditions, help to determine the health of the $13-billion-a-year industry. "A strong product trend can buck an economic trend," Ms. French said.    Gary M. Jacobson, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, said the recession year of 1982 "was a great year for the toy industry." He added, "Parents know what a slowdown is, but kids don't."    B. J. French, a spokeswoman for the Tonka Corporation, agrees. "Even in the recession of the early 1980's," she said, "toy sales seemed to go up."    Nintendo continues to captivate toy buyers, andthe Japanese machines and their accompanying games, made under license by a number of companies, are again expected to be best sellers. Sales of electronic games are projected at $4 billion this year, more than 20 percent of all toy sales. Still, analysts say the video craze may finally be peaking, a result of boredom and saturation.   In any case, American toy makers largely missed the video boom. Mattel Inc., for instance, was preoccupied with financial problems several years ago and was unable to develop competitive video products. It has since found a way to take advantage of the craze with its Power Glove, which slips over a player's hand, replacing the stick control.    Hasbro Inc. spent millions of dollars developing Nemo, its own electronic video game, but never brought it out.    Going forward, any decline in video games' popularity should free a lot of dollars for other items, to the benefit of traditional toy makers like Hasbro and Mattel.   The Barbie doll by Mattel is experiencing strong sales, and large dolls are also selling well. "You are seeing emotional items doing better," said Mr. Jacobson of Kidder, Peabody. Sales are strong again for Cabbage Patch dolls, which have belonged to Hasbro since it acquired Coleco Industries in 1989.    When it comes to individual toy stocks, a mixed picture exists. "I like the two big guys, and I'd avoid everything else," Mr. Jacobson said, referring to Mattel and Hasbro.    Mattel, which has undergone a significant revamping in the last few years, is a favorite of analysts. Its stock price has nearly tripled in two years. Barbie accounted for about half of the company's 1989 sales of $1.23 billion, analysts say. Mattel's stock closed at $19.125 yesterday, down 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.    Analysts cite Hasbro as a model of diversification, which makes it less dependent on the hit products that typically drive the industry. Nonetheless, investors want the company to develop a substitute for its flagging G.I. Joe and Transformer lines. A share of Hasbro closed at $15 yesterday, up 75 cents on the American Stock Exchange.    Heavy debts or concerns about management have caused analysts to steer away from other companies. "Tonka is at a critical state," Mr. Jacobson said, citing the company's indebtedness, a result of its 1987 acquisition of Kenner Parker.     Lewis Galoob Toys Inc., which makes miniature vehicles known as Micro Machines, is out of favor for its inability to develop a core line of products to sustain the company between hits.    In the short term, toy sales should benefit from changing demographics, Mr. Jacobson said, noting that last year there were nearly four million births in the United States, the most in 30 years. Plenty of money will be spent on these children of the baby-boom generation, he said, because there are more two-income households, more affluent grandparents, and more divorces, which often lead to each parent's spending heavily on toys.    But Mr. Jacobson also says that children are growing up faster and tend to quit playing with toys at a younger age. "Twenty years ago, 12-year-old kids played with dolls and cars," he wrote in a recent report. "Today they are most likely interested in CD's, movies and the opposite sex."

headline: 4 Billion Loss Seen by F.D.I.C.
abstract: The nation's senior bank regulator said today that the Federal fund that insures deposits would probably lose $4 billion or more this year.   The prediction, by L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, appeared to be another sign of the deterioration of the bank insurance system. It came less than three months after he had said that the fund would probably lose about $3 billion, a revision that itself was only a few months old. A loss of $4 billion for the year would put the fund at about $9 billion, only about $7 billion of which is readily available in cash.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * FCB/Telecom, the television programming division of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., and Channel America, are establishing a programming collaborative for designing new projects and overseeing programming activities. Terms were undisclosed.

headline: Europe Stalls On Farm Policy
abstract: LEAD: The European Community today failed for the second time this week to endorse a plan designed to break a deadlock with the United States over farm-subsidy policy.

headline: Iraqis Capture 3 French Soldiers And Return Them to Diplomats
abstract: Three French soldiers stationed in Saudi Arabia were captured by Iraqi forces earlier this week near the Saudi border with Iraq and have been turned over to the French Embassy in Baghdad, the French Government said today.   The soldiers were the first foreign troops, excluding Kuwaitis, to be captured by the Iraqis during the military standoff in the Persian Gulf.

headline: 15,000 Reservists Are Called to Active Duty
abstract: The Army and Marine Corps today ordered more than 15,000 reservists to report for active duty to support the gulf force opposing Iraq.   The Army said it was ordering 14,006 National Guard and Army Reserve members from 35 states to active duty. More than 12,000 more, the Army said, would be called up within days, including the first combat reserve units to be activated in the Persian Gulf crisis.   The Marine Corps called up 1,086 combat reserves, including 109 members of Company B of the Fourth Tank Battalion in Yakima, Wash., which will report for duty with the Second Tank Battalion at the Marine combat training center at Twentynine Palms, Calif.   The Marines are also activating 324 members of the Eighth Tank Battalion in Rochester for duty with the Second Marine Expeditionary Force.   The Second Tank Battalion and the Second Marine Expeditionary Force are active-duty units that are scheduled to be deployed in the gulf.   The Army did not say how many of its reservists would be sent to the Middle East.    The total number of reserves activated from all military services since President Bush first authorized their use for the Persian Gulf operation now totals 50,501.   It is now the largest call to active duty for American citizen-soldiers since the Berlin crisis in 1961, when about 150,000 reserves were activated.

headline: Chess
abstract: The 21st annual North American Computer Chess Championship ended in a tie for first place between Deep Thought and Mephisto, each having scored 4-1 in the five-round tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel Nov. 11-14.   Deep Thought was developed by Thomas Anantharaman, Peter Jensen, Murray Campbell, Feng-hsiung Hsu and Andreas Nowatzyk at Carnegie Mellon University and is now at I.B.M.'s T.J. Watson Research Center. Mephisto was developed by Richard Lang of Hegener & Glaser in Munich, Germany.

headline: Market Place; A Costly Citicorp Move To Win Over Investors
abstract: In another sign of investor concern over the safety of investments in many major banks, Citicorp said yesterday that it would pay an unprecedentedly high rate on an important part of the capital it needs. The move will raise the company's costs substantially.   In agreeing to pay a dividend rate of 12.5 percent on a $100 million issue of preferred stock, the nation's largest banking company accepted a rate that is far higher than the dividend it was legally required to pay. The move was aimed at bolstering investor confidence, but it led to another drop in the company's stock price, to an eight-year low.

headline: Newsstands Dwindle, But Some Still Thrive
abstract: Magazine publishers nervously monitoring the decline in newsstand sales across the country might be cheered by a visit to the Healy News Store in this tiny New England town.    People drive from as far as Massachusetts to buy the 3,000 different magazines stocked by Steve Davis, the manager and son-in-law of the owner, Freeman Healy. In 1962 Mr. Healy and his brother, Richard, bought the business, which had been run by one family for more than half a century at a time when newsstands and paper routes were an essential part of the American way of life.

headline: MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;  Pro Bono
abstract: * March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation, White Plains, to Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss, for a nationwide campaign that will begin May 1991.

headline: AIDS in Africa: Experts Study Role of Promiscuous Sex in the Epidemic
abstract: LEAD: When a man here talks about going to ''le deuxieme bureau,'' the second office, he means he is going to visit a mistress, perhaps at a place like the Hotel Bikoumou. It is one of the many small hotels that have prospered in this capital by renting rooms for two hours at a time.

headline: An Anti-Theft Specialist Bolsters Its Top Ranks
abstract: The Knogo Corporation, which makes electronic devices to stop thieves and shoplifters, has beefed up its management with the goal of doubling sales volume within three years.    The company, based in Hauppauge, L.I., announced earlier this week that Arthur J. Minasy, 65, who founded Knogo in 1966, was yielding the posts of president and chief operating officer to Thomas A. Nicolette.

headline: The Soot Is History. Victoria Should Visit Now.
abstract: Hard hit by the collapse of the steel industry in the 1980's, the 19th-century industrial powerhouse long known as Britain's second city is enjoying a renaissance as a convention and cultural center.   What has pulled it up by its bootstraps is a partnership of local government and industry, with the City Council, dominated by the Labor Party, spending money on projects intended to attract service industries and the affluent, educated people who work in them.

headline: Prices Rise as Commodities Fall
abstract: Another big drop in the price of basic commodities gave impetus to the credit markets yesterday. Prices of Treasury securities rose, and interest rates fell in generally thin trading.    Most of the gain was relegated to long-term notes and bonds, which are more susceptible to shifts in inflation expectations than shorter-term issues.

headline: American Airlines Agrees to Buy London-U.S. Routes From T.W.A.
abstract: Trans World Airlines agreed yesterday to sell its six routes between the United States and London to American Airlines for $445 million -- the latest sign that the country's strongest airlines are taking advantage of the troubles of their weaker rivals to acquire lucrative international routes.   T.W.A.'s chairman, Carl C. Icahn, quickly made clear his plans for that money, immediately renewing his attempt to acquire Pan American World Airways.

headline: Citicorp Earnings Drop 38%
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, announced a 38 percent decline in its earnings for the third quarter yesterday, with strong profits in consumer banking but large losses in real estate lending.

headline: Nynex Sells Unit Linked To Inquiry
abstract: The Nynex Corporation said late yesterday that it had sold the small computer software development subsidiary whose activities resulted in Nynex's indictment by a Federal grand jury on May 30.   The grand jury in Washington accused Nynex of criminal contempt involving a 1982 consent decree that broke up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The indictment charged that the Nynex software subsidiary, the Telco Research Corporation, had violated a provision of the consent decree banning the seven regional Bell companies from creating computerized information and then sending it over phone lines.   Nynex denies wrongdoing, and no trial date has been set.  No Price Disclosed     Nynex said yesterday that it had sold the 124-employee division, which is reportedly losing money and is deeply in debt, to three Telco Research officers for an undisclosed price. The sale of the Nashville-based subsidiary will not affect the pending indictment, and resulted only from Nynex's decision to focus on other businesses, said Carol Fessler, a Nynex spokeswoman.

headline: De Maiziere Accused of Ties to East's Secret Police
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government said today that it was investigating whether Lothar de Maiziere, East Germany's last leader and now a member of Mr. Kohl's Cabinet, worked for the East's secret police, or Stasi.   Mr. de Maiziere denied the allegation.

headline: Phillips Petroleum In Note Offering
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla., is offering $300 million in notes due in 1997 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.   The noncallable issue carries an interest rate of 9.50 percent and is priced at 99.646 to yield 9.57 percent, or about 130 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Underwriters said the issue was rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Market Place; Big Fleer Holders Decide to Cash In
abstract: DETERMINING how long a fad will last is never easy, but the people who control the Fleer Corporation, which has seen its sales and profits soar on the boom in baseball card sales, have evidently decided to cash in as soon as they can.   Less than six months after the company went public, and only 16 months after the controlling shareholders bought Fleer in a phenomenally successful leveraged buyout, the largest insiders are planning a stock offering to enable them to take out far more money than they put into the company, while leaving themselves firmly in control.

headline: Islamic Politics Drive Away Allies of the Sudan
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, came here not long ago for what was supposed to be a celebration of his Sudanese neighbors' decision to adopt, in part, his political system.   Instead, Colonel Qaddafi delivered a frosty lecture to the Islamic fundamentalist junta last month about the folly of mixing religion and politics. Surprisingly, Colonel Qaddafi became the instant hero of the Sudanese underground opposition.

headline: Upbeat European View
abstract: Trade ministers from the European Community's 13 nations tried today to put a positive cast on the continuing negotiations to break the impasse on farm subsidies.   Renato Ruggiero, Italy's trade minister, who presided at today's meeting, said, "Success is possible in all 15 subjects of the Uruguay Round," including farm subsidies.    After months of deadlock, the European Community last week approved a negotiating position on farm subsidies that fell far short of the sharp cuts sought by the United States, Canada and other food-exporting nations, including Australia, Argentina and Brazil. The Europeans, who have long had a policy of subsidizing small farmers because of their political strength, finally agreed to consider a 30 percent cut in subsidies covering a 10-year period retroactive to 1986.    The big producers, including the United States, want reductions of 75 percent in price supports and 90 percent in export subsidies over 10 years beginning in 1991. Japan, where small farmers are also a potent political force, is the only major country taking the European side.    Mr. Ruggiero reiterated the community's position that its negotiating position had room for change. "We have never said it is a take-it-or-leave-it offer," he said.   France has said a 30 percent cut in subsidies is probably the limit it can hope to sell to restive farmers. Peter Lilley, Britain's trade minister, said today in a clear reference to France that some countries had done a disservice to the community by indicating the negotiating position was a final offer.

headline: Teledyne Net Plunges 79%
abstract: LEAD: Teledyne Inc. said today that its third-quarter earnings plunged 79 percent as slowdowns in the military, aviation and electronics industries affected its sales.

headline: New Publisher Named in Shift At Turbulent Random House
abstract: One of the most prestigious positions in New York's high-profile book world changed hands yesterday, and the interlocking personalities involved in the switch sent the industry spinning.   Capping a year of turbulence at Random House, Joni Evans was replaced as publisher of the country's largest issuer of general-interest books, known for putting out the works of Norman Mailer, William Styron and James Michener. She was succeeded by Harold Evans, editor in chief of the Conde Nast Traveler magazine, who is no relation to Miss Evans.

headline: Marines on the Edge Are Trained, Ready And Mostly Young
abstract: With occasional talk of death, grimly realistic chemical warfare drills and the explosion of 81-millimeter mortars being zeroed in, the Second Battalion of the Seventh Marines is palpably preparing for war in its third month here in the Saudi desert.    Although no one knows if the time for killing and dying will come soon, or even come at all, the young men here and their more grizzled noncoms and officers seem to have drawn their conclusion from the news that there will be no rotation home and that as many as 200,000 reinforcements are on the way to join them.

headline: Standard Brands Plans by Latshaw
abstract: LEAD: The Kansas City investor John Latshaw, who controls 15 percent of the Standard Brands Paint Company, said he intends to explore ''one or more of several courses of action'' to increase the value of the Torrance, Calif., paint and home-decorating store chain. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr.

headline: Soybean Meal to Soviets
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 205,000 metric tons of United States soybean meal under a long-term grain agreement, the Agriculture Department said Friday. It was the second meal order last week, with 150,000 tons announced Wednesday. Officials said both orders are for delivery through Dec.

headline: S.& L. Sues Executives Of Drexel
abstract: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association yesterday filed a multi-billion-dollar lawsuit against a number of the current and former senior executives with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., contending that they were responsible for the huge losses in Columbia's portfolio of high-yield "junk bonds."   The suit, which names Michael R. Milken, the former head of Drexel's junk bond division, other executives and hundreds of investment partnerships that included Drexel employees, portrays the junk bond market as driven by fraud and Columbia as one of a number of victims.   In the allegations included in the suit filed in Los Angeles, Columbia contends that Mr. Milken and other Drexel executives used a series of more than 500 investment partnerships, as well as other means, to create the fictitious appearance of a true market in junk bonds.  Billions of Dollars Invested    As a result, they contend that Columbia invested in billions of dollars of debt securities it otherwise would not have purchased.    A spokesman for Drexel said that the firm had not seen the new suit, and could not yet comment for the executives.    A spokesman for Mr. Milken denied the allegations in a statement. "Columbia and its attorneys have invented a revolutionary new legal strategy -- having a plaintiff plead insanity" the statement said. "Columbia's 'let's blame Milken' approach is a transparent attempt to ignore facts and rewrite history." The statement concludes by saying that the suit is without merit.    Columbia had been one of the biggest purchasers of junk bonds from Drexel, and its former chairman, Thomas Spiegel, who resigned last year, was a close associate of Mr. Milken.  Protection From Creditors    The suit comes one month after Columbia filed a similar $4.5 billion claim against Drexel with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York. Drexel filed for protection from its creditors earlier this year.    Primarily as a result of its junk bond losses, Columbia is insolvent and appears on the brink of being seized by Federal regulators.    If Columbia is successful in its suit, it would bode poorly for much of Wall Street. Numerous investment banks underwrote junk bonds in the 1980's and some continue to try to do so today, and if a plaintiff successfully argues that the market in the 1980's was fraudulent, these firms would be potentially exposed to liability.   In its claim, Columbia says that in 1982 it was "ill equipped" to handle the new authority that was granted to the savings and loan industry by Congress to invest in corporate securities, including junk bonds. "Consequently, Columbia was susceptible to unscrupulous salesmen," the complaint says.

headline: U.S. Moves to Help Cold War Rival Much as It Aided World War II Foes
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union, who were mortal enemies for many decades, are now partners in the Persian Gulf, and today's symbolic embrace between the two at a Rose Garden ceremony suggests that they are starting to practice difficult new roles as allies.    "Not allies yet -- that's turning the clock ahead too fast," said Stephen F. Cohen of Princeton University, a leading student of Soviet politics. "Allies don't have 30,000 nuclear weapons pointed at each other. But our mutual oppostion to Saddam Hussein gives us a chance to be allies for this episode at least, and to see if our partnership can survive the strain of deciding whether there will be war or not."

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Billa-Heute, a food store chain in Austria, to Dr. Puttner & BSB, Austria, a unit of Backer Spielvogel Worldwide, New York, with a budget of $8 million to $10 million. * San-J International, a soy sauce-producing subsidiary of San Jirushi Corp., Kuwana, Japan, to Earle Palmer Brown, Richmond, for its industrial and food-service accounts. The agency's Atlanta office picked up CNET, Atlanta, a credit card processing company owned by the National Data Corp. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: House Panel Approves More Funds for Bailout
abstract: After more than a week of bickering between lawmakers and the Bush Administration, the House Banking Committee today approved spending an additional $10 billion through February to continue the bailout of the savings and loan industry.   The authorization, approved by voice vote, came after disagreements between the committee chairman, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady that have centered less on the substance of the financing than on its politics, coming so near Election Day, Nov. 6.

headline: The Starch Goes Out of the Dollar
abstract: Reality caught up with the dollar this holiday week. The American currency surged before Christmas to the 1.51 level against the German mark. Last week, it jumped to 1.54 against the mark and 136 against the yen. Although still quite weak, the dollar was showing signs of strength not seen for months. But on Thursday the Government reported that orders for durable goods had fallen 10.5 percent in November. And on Friday, it was reported that the index of leading economic indicators had declined for the fifth month in a row, dropping 1.2 percent in November. These recession signals knocked the dollar down sharply to -- 1.4936 marks and 134.85 yen -- and put it back on the downward track most forecasters expect it to continue on.               Last   Prior   Year       Week   Week   Ago              Japanese Yen   134.85   135.55   143.85       per Dollar       German Mark   1.4936   1.5289   1.6950       per Dollar       Canadian Dollar   1.1598   1.1600   1.1588       per U.S. Dollar       British Pound   1.9275   1.8860   1.6105       U.S. Dollar per British Pound       Gold   $393.00   $381.25   $403.00       Republic National Bank       Currency: Friday NY Close

headline: JVC and MCA in Venture
abstract: LEAD: The Victor Company of Japan, known as JVC, said today that it would create a new record company with the music division of MCA, the United States entertainment giant.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * Rowland Worldwide Inc., the public relations unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. has acquired Dyson Communications, a Swiss-based public relations consulting firm. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Ex-Aide Held in G.M. Theft
abstract: The authorities arrested a former photo technician for the General Motors Corporation today on charges that he tried to get the auto maker to pay $75,000 for stolen confidential photographs of G.M. cars.   Gregory Charles Hooper, 36 years old, of Royal Oak, Mich., was charged with mail fraud in a complaint filed by the United States Attorney's office, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said. He was released on bond.   The F.B.I. began an investigation on June 16 after receiving a complaint from G.M. that some photographs of cars it was working on were appearing in magazines. Mr. Hooper reportedly tried to obtain $75,000 from G.M. for the return of the photographs, the F.B.I. said in a statement.   In November 1989, G.M. offered a $30,000 reward for information relating to what the auto maker suspected was the theft of photographs from its design studio after photographs of its new Saturn car began appearing in automotive magazines. A G.M. spokesman said today the $30,000 had not been paid.   Mr. Hooper faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine if found guilty.

headline: Market Place;   Profitable Increase in Selling Stocks Short
abstract: A sign of the times is that it is the Wall Street bears who are now buying corporate jets. Feshbach Brothers, based in Palo Alto, Calif., the country's largest short-seller, recently paid nearly $11 million for a Challenger 601A jet, according to Grant's Interest Rate Observer.   The Feshbachs may need the jet to visit a lot more clients a lot faster these days, since they are racking up strong returns on their main short-selling partnership -- the $550 million Southgate Partners. They now have almost $1 billion in various funds, up several hundred million dollars this year.

headline: Closing at Preston
abstract: LEAD: The Preston Corporation said it would close its Reeves Transportation Company and Pioneer Transportation Systems Inc. units and take a related $17 million charge in its third quarter. The company said the units would not accept any new business after Wednesday but would honor existing arrangements.

headline: Why Not a Free Ukraine?
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Ex-Opposition Chief In Bulgaria Admits Role as an Informer
abstract: The man who resigned on Sunday as leader of Bulgaria's major anti-Communist opposition coalition acknowledged today that he had worked as a police informer under the deposed hard-line Marxist government.   The opposition figure, Peter Beron, who had been chief of the 16-party Union of Democratic Forces, was reacting to charges that he and 70 other parliamentarians collaborated with the police under the toppled Communist leadership.

headline: Mead Is Cutting Capital Spending
abstract: The Mead Corporation said its board had approved plans to reduce 1991 capital spending by 30 percent and put into effect other cost-reduction measures within the forest-products company. Capital expenditures will be reduced to $350 million from a previously planned level of $500 million, company officials said.   In addition, the company's Mead Imaging division will be repositioned to limit financial exposure in the color-imaging business, and corporate cost-reduction steps that include an early-retirement program and a salary freeze for higher-paid employees will be put into effect. Mead officials expect savings of about $33 million, or 50 cents a share, in 1991.

headline: Book on Morocco's King Strains French Ties
abstract: France's normally close relations with Morocco have soured over a new French book that accuses King Hassan II of systematic human rights violations.    Moroccan officials assert that the French Government has helped organize a defamation campaign against the King because the writer of the book has been interviewed several times on Government-owned French television and radio stations.   French officials say they were merely allowing the broadcasters to exercise freedom of the press. Butsome Moroccans argue that the French Government was blithely letting state-owned broadcasters criticize the King as a means of pursuing France's policy of getting African nations, including Morocco, to improve their human rights performance.

headline: President for Tektronix Hired From Honeywell
abstract: Tektronix Inc., a maker of test and measurement products, said yesterday that it had hired Jerome J. Meyer from Honeywell Inc. to be its new president and chief executive.    Mr. Meyer, 52, has been president of Honeywell's industrial business, based in Minneapolis. At his new job, in Beaverton, Ore., Mr. Meyer will take over from an interim management team that has been trimming the company's operations and succeeding in returning the concern to profitability.

headline: Lotus Settles Copyright Case
abstract: LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation said today that it had reached an out-of-court settlement with Paperback Software International and Stephenson Software Ltd. for the violation of Lotus's copyrights on its 1-2-3 spreadsheet software.      Paperback agreed to pay

headline: Kel Journal; In Torn Kashmir, Frontier Is Aflame Once More
abstract: In the treacherous mountain terrain along the disputed border between Pakistani and Indian Kashmir, life would be tough enough without war. On precipitous slopes and pocket-sized meadows, rural families raise their crops and animals in isolation at altitudes that demand a mountain climber's skills.   But war of one kind or another is never far away. Almost every day, groups of exhausted, hungry exiles from Indian Kashmir straggle out of mountain passes and give themselves up to villagers or Pakistani soldiers. They come to escape from Indian troops trying to put down an independence movement with a heavy show of force -- or to be trained to go back and keep the Kashmiri fight alive.

headline: Sony, Apple Negotiating Laptop Deal
abstract: LEAD: In a change in its manufacturing strategy, Apple Computer Inc. has entered negotiations with the Sony Corporation for Sony to produce an inexpensive notebook-computer version of the Macintosh, senior Sony officials said.

headline: BUSH PUTS TALKS 'ON HOLD' TILL IRAQ ACCEPTS HIS DATES
abstract: President Bush said today that the direct talks he has proposed to Iraq would be "on hold" until President Saddam Hussein agreed to receive Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d no later than Jan. 3.   Mr. Bush's remarks at a White House news conference, along with statements by Iraqi officials that they want the meeting held on Jan. 12, suggest that what is at issue is not so much conflicting schedules as conflicting strategies.

headline: Rwandans Report Killings of Suspected Rebel Sympathizers
abstract: LEAD: Rwandan peasants accused of supporting a rebel invasion force have been massacred by Government troops and members of the majority Hutu tribe, villagers fleeing to Uganda said today.

headline: Apartheid a Sin, Clergy Conference Says
abstract: A watershed five-day conference of 80 black and white church denominations in South Africa ended today by formally condemning apartheid as a sin and supporting restitution for its victims.    "Some of us are not in full accord with everything said in this conference," the final declaration said, "but on this we are all agreed, namely the unequivocal rejection of apartheid as a sin."

headline: New York Joins Suit for Baby Formula Royalties
abstract: In a legal action that lawyers said was the first of its kind by a state, the New York Attorney General's office said yesterday that it had joined patent lawsuits seeking royalties from the makers of infant formulas.   New York and Dr. Gerald E. Gaull, a former researcher with a state institute, argue that infant formula products made by the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, Wyeth Laboratories and other companies infringe a patent awarded to Dr. Gaull in 1981 when he worked for the state.

headline: Treasury Bond Auction Ends Well
abstract: The last, most speculative leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions went smoothly yesterday, as credit market participants bought $10.75 billion in 30-year bonds.    Worries about the auction and continued jitters about the Middle East helped to push down prices before the sale, and the decline was sufficient to spur demand for the securities.

headline: Blacks Say Castro Fails to Deliver Equality
abstract: To walk a few city blocks here is to see why for many black Cubans a revolution that has staked a claim to social equality for all has fallen short of its promise.    In the narrow warrens of Old Havana, the overcrowded and rundown site of this city's first colonial settlements, mostly black Cubans can be seen chatting in drab work clothes on doorsteps or playing ball in the streets.

headline: Commodities Trader Starts His Own Firm
abstract: LEAD: Gene D. Donney, former president and chief executive of Elders Futures Inc., a commodity futures trading company, has set up his own commodities research and portfolio management firm and claims a unique status for it.

headline: Seoul Ousts 2 Top Aides For Spying on Civilians
abstract: LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo dismissed his Defense Minister and head of military counterintelligence today following allegations that the armed forces have been illegally spying on prominent civilians.

headline: Georgia-Pacific Ends Joint Effort
abstract: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said it had scrapped plans for a $484 million venture here with a German company, as well as plans for a tissue-making plant. Before Georgia-Pacific took over the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation earlier this year, M D Papier G.m.b.H. of Munich and Great Northern had applied for an environmental permit for a lightweight coated groundwood paper mill in Millinocket.    Georgia-Pacific, based in Atlanta, also said it would team up with Bowater Inc., a paper manufacturer in Darien, Conn., to develop long-term economic strategies for mills and woodlands in the Millinocket area. Georgia-Pacific, with $10 billion in sales last year, is the nation's largest forest-products company.

headline: U.S. PLANS TO VACATE EMBASSY IN KUWAIT
abstract: The Bush Administration announced today that it would vacate the American Embassy in Kuwait once all Americans wishing to leave that country have been allowed to do so by the Iraqi authorities.   The State Department said the decision to remove all personnel from the embassy, which had been maintained as a symbol of defiance against the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait, was prompted by purely technical considerations.   On the day that Iraq's National Assembly gave pro forma approval to a decision by President Saddam Hussein to permit all foreigners to leave Iraq and Kuwait, it seemed that all American hostages would choose to leave Kuwait. And with the legitimate Kuwaiti Government having set up temporary home in Taif, Saudi Arabia, the embassy no longer served any purpose, the department said.     In Baghdad today, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq said he thought all the foreign hostages prevented from leaving Iraq and Kuwait could receive exit visas and leave the country in a "few days."  [ Page A6. ]

headline: Chiat/Day/Mojo Wins Nutrasweet Account
abstract: Chiat/Day/Mojo has won a creative shoot-out with some of the industry's top agencies. It has been awarded the account for Nutrasweet brand sweetener, which has billings of about $50 million.   The account had been at Ogilvy & Mather, which will continue to handle the advertising for Nutrasweet outside the United States and for the company's Equal brand sweetener.    The victory could not come at a better time for Chiat/Day. The agency's New York office has been shaken by account-defections this year, losing about $100 million in billings.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Church & Dwight Co., Princeton, N.J., a maker of sodium products and detergents, said its board had authorized the intermittent buyback of up to a million additional common shares. * Cooper Cos., Palo Alto, Calif., which develops optometric products, has acquired substantially all of the assets of Spectra Pharmaceutical Services Inc., Hanover, Mass., a maker of ophthalmic drugs. Terms were not disclosed. * FPL Group Inc., the holding company for Florida Power and Light Co., Miami, said it would write down its investment in its insurance unit, Colonial Penn Group Inc., and three other non-utility subsidiaries. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, said its new Saturn cars officially went on sale yesterday. G.M. will also temporarily close plants in Michigan and Indiana because of low demand for its light trucks. Nearly 10,000 workers will be affected. The shutdowns take effect Monday. * Ivaco Inc., Montreal, a maker of steel and other products, has closed its sale of all outstanding shares of Niagra Lockport Quebec Industries Inc. and Niagra Lockport Industries Inc. The sale was to units of BTR P.L.C., London, a maker of industrial and energy products, for $85 million. * Maytag Corp., Newton, Iowa, has named William R. Foust, senior vice president of human resources, as managing director of its Hoover unit in Britain. He succeeds Anthony Williamson. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, said KLM Royal Dutch Airlines had taken options on five more MD-11 aircraft. Earlier this year, KLM took firm orders on 10 MD-11 aircraft for about $1.3 billion. * Pit Stop Auto Centers Inc., Oklahoma City, said its board had rejected a proposal by Grease Monkey Holding Corp., Denver, an operator of auto-lubricator services, to acquire Pit Stop in a stock swap. * Tambrands Inc., Lake Success, L.I., a maker of personal-care products, will sell its headquarters to Astoria Federal Savings Bank. No terms were disclosed. Tambrands will remain in Lake Success until it moves to a new headquarters in Westchester County next year. * Tosco Corp., Santa Monica, Calif., a petroleum products company, said its board had authorized the acquisition of up to an additional two million common share equivalents from time to time. * Turkish Airlines, Istanbul, will lease 10 new Boeing Co. 737-400's. The airline will obtain the aircraft under long-term lease-purchase arrangements from two leasing companies, GPA Group Ltd. of Ireland and International Lease Finance Corp., Beverly Hills, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * The Home Furnishings Council has signed Kathie Lee Gifford as a spokeswoman for its multimillion-dollar national advertising campaign, which is handled by Baron & Zaretsky, New York.   * Rowland Worldwide Inc., the public relations unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., London, is opening offices in Salzburg and Vienna. Harald Ronacher has been named managing director of the Salzburg operation, and Dr. Christoph Bruckner will head the Vienna office.

headline: New $5 Million Account To McElligott Wright
abstract: McElligott Wright Morrison White, an agency so new that the paint has  barely dried on its Minneapolis office door, picked up its first big piece of business, a cellular-communications product that bills $5 million, increasing the agency's billings to about $10 million.   The new account is from Universal Cellular Inc., of Anaheim, Calif., for a cellular product that has not been identified. The agency has won two smaller accounts since Tom McElligott jumped ship at Chiat Day/Mojo after only a year and started anew with three partners.    "The famous name of McElligott has made it easy to get started," said Claire Canavan, a partner and director of finance and planning at the agency. "The minute we announced our formation, prospective clients started calling."    Ms. Canavan said the agency was looking for some accounts for national consumer products to build a reputation for producing television commercials. Mr. McElligott is well-known for producing witty print ads.

headline: Snubbed, Hamstrung, but Ever So Diplomatic: He's Castro's Invisible Man
abstract: Jose Antonio Arbesu is Fidel's man in Washington.    In a capital where politics and society mix as easily as wine spritzers, Mr. Arbesu, the Chief of the Cuban Interests Section, is so discreet he is the invisible diplomat. He will not identify his friends, nor the members of Congress and academics he meets. To do so, he said, would violate their confidence. He won't give out the address of his upscale Chevy Chase, Md., home because, as he put it, "some citizens of the neighborhood might be angered by my presence."

headline: Slovaks Want an Open Marriage, Not Divorce
abstract: A year after they ousted their former Communist rulers, many people in this eastern region of Czechoslovakia are striving to shed what they view as another oppressor: the Czechs.   After months of negotiations, the Parliament in Prague this month approved an agreement according broad powers to the Slovak republic. But the accord appeared to be only a milestone on a longer trail, as the major parties in Slovakia pursue constitutional changes to give the republic broad political and economic autonomy.

headline: Japan's Trade Surplus Falls
abstract: LEAD: Robust domestic demand and higher oil prices helped to trim Japan's bulging trade surplus in September, the Government said today.

headline: Senators Urge Bush to Lift Vietnam Embargo
abstract: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and seven other Democratic and Republican Senators have written to President Bush requesting the lifting of the 15-year-old trade embargo on Vietnam.   The letter comes at a time when the Administration is slowly building relations with Vietnam, having recently opened talks with Hanoi to help resolve the Cambodian civil war and reinvigorating joint efforts to identify and return American servicemen still unaccounted for from the Vietnam War.Two weeks ago, the Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, became the first Vietnamese official of Cabinet rank to visit Washington since the war.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Beech Aircraft Corp., Wichita, Kan., said it would slow production of some models and stop hiring new workers. * Chase Manhattan Corp., New York, said it would cut costs by 20 percent in its Asian banking operations by the end of the year, partly through layoffs. * Consolidated Rail Corp., Philadelphia, requested binding arbitration to settle its dispute with the Delaware & Hudson Railway over 15 miles of Conrail's track in upstate New York. * Integrated Resources Inc., New York, a real estate, investment and insurance concern, received approval from Federal Bankruptcy Court to sell stock in its American Property Investors subsidiary to an entity controlled by Carl Icahn for $44 million. * Loral Corp., New York, a maker of electronic systems, has completed its acquisition of Ford Motor Co.'s Ford Aerospace unit for $715 million. * Ogden Corp., New York, an environmental services company that owns 68 percent of the shares of ERC Environmental and Energy Services Co., Fairfax, Va., an engineering company, has offered to buy the remaining stake in the company for $14.75 a share. * Poughkeepsie Savings Bank, Poughkeepsie, N.Y., will sell its banking operations in South Carolina to Republic National Bank, a unit of Resource Bancshares Corp., Columbia, S.C., for undisclosed terms. It is selling its North Carolina deposits for undisclosed terms to Robeson Savings Bank, Lumberton, N.C. * D. S. Revco Inc., Twinsburg, Ohio, a chain of discount drugstores, said a Federal Bankruptcy Court has denied its motion to extend past Oct. 31 its deadline to file a reorganization plan. * Summit Bancorporation, Summit, N.J., said its subsidiary banks would purchase two retail banking branch offices in New Jersey from Anchor Savings Bank FSB, Hewlett, L.I. Terms were not disclosed. * Sutton Holding Corp. said it would make an offer for the remaining detergent business of DeSoto Inc., Des Plaines, Ill., a maker of chemical coatings and specialty products.

headline: Israelis Kill an Arab Attacker
abstract: The police today shot and killed a Palestinian woman after she tried to stab a policeman near Jerusalem's walled Old City, police and radio reports said. The policeman was not hurt because he was wearing a flak jacket, which became mandatory for police patrols in East Jerusalem after a series of stabbing attacks by Palestinians. The attacks began after the killing in October of at least 17 Palestinians by the Israel police near Al Aksa Mosque. The incident today began when policemen questioned three Palestinians at the East Jerusalem bus station, the Israeli radio said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;  TV Campaign Spoofs Gum Ad
abstract: LEAD: Ads for N.B.A. Hoop Cards will break into television with a team of dentists when the basketball season starts in late October.
