headline: Changes at the Top Of Aubrey G. Lanston
abstract: LEAD: Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a Government securities brokerage house, announced yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, John B. Ford, plans to retire at the end of the year and that he will be succeeded by Richard M. Kelly.

headline: Bush, in Mexican Visit, Radiates Amity
abstract: Forgoing complex trade talks for cowboy boots and box seats at a rodeo, President Bush came to call on President Carlos Salinas de Gortari today in a visit intended to jump-start Mexican-American relations with a show of unabashed political friendship.    Striding around this dusty northern town like another of the Texas neighbors who have so shaped its character, Mr. Bush spent less than two hours in discussions with Mr. Salinas on the first day of a scheduled two-day state visit.

headline: Australian TV Job Cuts
abstract: The troubled Australian television network Channel Seven announced on Monday that it would cut 100 jobs and freeze executive salaries for two years. The dismissals occurred at the network's stations in Sydney, Melbourne, Perth and Brisbane. They are Channel Seven's first large-scale cutbacks since receivers were appointed a year ago for Qintex Australia Ltd., the operator of Channel Seven.

headline: Arab Nations to Ease Stand on Israel
abstract: Arab countries have said they are ready to end the efforts they have made since 1982 to expel Israel from the United Nations. But in return, they want the General Assembly to declare that Israel's delegation does not represent territories occupied after the 1967 war.   Lebanon's representative, Khalil Makkawi, who is chairman of the Arab Group at the United Nations this month, said there was a consensus in favor of such a change of tactics at this year's General Assembly after a meeting of the group Monday. He added that the Arabs will now "try to sell it" to other countries.

headline: Chase to Consider Ties To Non-Bank Partners
abstract: The president of the Chase Manhattan Corporation said today that he would consider joint business ventures or mergers with industrial companies as a way for Chase to "bust out" of its traditional banking business.    "The financial services industry is broader than banking," said Thomas G. Labrecque, who will become chairman of Chase at the end of the month. He said many of Chase's businesses could be candidates for joint ventures or some other kind of merger with other companies including industrial companies.

headline: Attack on Leftist Campaign Rally Leaves 5 Haitians Dead, 54 Hurt
abstract: Five people were shot to death and at least 54 wounded tonight by unknown assailants after a presidential campaign rally near here for a radical priest, witnesses said.   The violence in Petionville, seven miles outside Port-au-Prince, the capital, occurred during a 10-minute blackout about 7:30 P.M., a few minutes after the end of a rally for the priest, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Radio Metropole and witnesses said.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Chubb Corp., Warren, N.J., an insurance holding company, appointed Theresa M. Stone senior vice president. * Credence Systems Corp., Fremont, Calif., named James T. Healy senior vice president of corporate marketing and a general manager. * Digital Equipment Corp., Maynard, Mass., appointed William C. Hanson vice president of logistics and Robert B. Palmer vice president of manufacturing. * Earth's Best Inc., Middlebury, Vt., a baby food producer, appointed Roger L. Wagner president and chief executive, succeeding Robert Swanson, who is chairman. * McDATA Corp., Broomfield, Colo., named Mary E. Coleman vice president of marketing.

headline: Clarke to Be Renamed as Comptroller
abstract: President Bush decided today to reappoint Robert L. Clarke as the nation's top regulator of nationally chartered banks, taking the advice of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady over the objection of the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu.    The nomination of Mr. Clarke as Comptroller of the Currency had been recommended weeks ago by Mr. Brady. It had been considered a foregone conclusion, especially since the office is a division of the Treasury Department, until Mr. Sununu stepped in earlier this month. He raised concerns that tough regulation of the banking community was contributing to the current credit crunch, reflecting views he had heard from bankers in New England.

headline: When to Threaten Iraq?
abstract: To critics who ask why the United States should not wait a year or more to see if economic sanctions force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, Administration officials say they have valid reasons for threatening a war this winter.    President Bush's decision last week to nearly double the American military force in the Persian Gulf and to cancel troop-rotation plans, they say, was based on the assumption that only the threat of early war can persuade President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw his forces from Kuwait.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Accel International Corp., Dublin, Ohio, an insurance holding company, named William B. Johnson vice president of claims.

headline: Short Sales Outstanding Post Increase of 3.6% on Nasdaq
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported an increase of slightly more than 3.6 percent in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended on Nov. 15.    A total of 304 million shares were held short and not yet covered in mid-November, it said, compared with a total of 293.3 million in the period that ended in mid-October. The November figure, an increase of 10.7 million shares, represents short selling in 2,284 stocks; in October, the short selling was spread among 2,298 issues.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: MAJOR TO BE IN U.S. FOR TOP MEETINGS
abstract: Prime Minister John Major will fly to Washington on Thursday on a mission aimed mostly at establishing his identity in a country where his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, was universally recognized, aides at 10 Downing Street say.    By the time he heads back to London on Saturday morning, the 47-year-old Mr. Major will have appeared on all the Friday network television breakfast programs, met with Vice President Dan Quayle, had lunch with Republican and Democratic lawmakers on Capitol Hill and spent the night conferring with President Bush at Camp David.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Fall Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Share prices in Tokyo extended their sharp declines in the early afternoon today, with the Nikkei average falling through 20,000 for the first time since February 1987. Brokers blamed the heavy losses on last-ditch selling by individuals unloading margin positions.

headline: NS Group Grows
abstract: LEAD: NS Group Inc., a maker of specialty steel products, acquired $96 million in steel assets from Babcock & Wilcox and PMAC Ltd. The purchase includes operations in Koppel and Ambridge, Pa. The company said the acquisition was being financed by PMAC and a $100 million credit line from the General Electric Company's GE Capital unit.

headline: Berlin City Government Fails
abstract: The city's coalition government collapsed today in a dispute over a police crackdown on hundreds of leftist squatters.   The environmentalist Green Party said it was bolting the two-party coalition led by Mayor Walter Momper, a Social Democrat. The Greens say they were outraged by the police crackdown, which has resulted in more than 260 injuries and about 450 arrests since Monday.

headline: Tokyo Journal; The Days of Wine and $115 Melons: It's Gift Time
abstract: A senior Finance Ministry official recently installed four refrigerators at home, the better to receive an onslaught of hams, smoked salmon, musk melons and selected beers from around the world as end-of-the-year gifts.   Taking a different approach, Katsuko Umezawa, a housewife, said she resorted this year to storing the arriving boxes of fruit at her home in an alcove reserved for a Buddhist shrine to her late father. "I had to apologize to my mother and promise they'd be gone by January," she said.

headline: For Investors Who Waited, Few New Benefits
abstract: Having counted on Congress to heed President Bush's call to restore capital gains to favor under the tax code, many investors are likely to feel they were instead dealt a loss in the deficit reduction legislation approved on Saturday. Now, they must decide how to make the best of the situation in year-end tax planning.    "A lot of people put off selling and got killed by the market," said David A. Berenson, national director of tax policy for Ernst & Young in Washington. "They walked into an economic loss because they waited."

headline: Union Bids for UAL Rejected by Directors
abstract: LEAD: An audacious and persistent drive by three unions to buy the UAL Corporation apparently ended yesterday when the company's board turned down two offers because they did not have financing and were lower than an offer the directors had accepted in the spring.

headline: Mubarak Urges Alliance With Syrians and Saudis
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak today urged the creation of a new Arab alliance grouping Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia as "a foundation to serve the Arab people," as Arab nations drew diplomatic lines in response to Washington's latest initiative on the Persian Gulf crisis.   The United States has proposed talks with Iraq to urge it to pull out of Kuwait by Jan. 15 or face war with the United States and its allies gathered in Saudi Arabia.

headline: China's No. 2 Didn't Invoke Jack Kennedy
abstract: LEAD: If Dan Quayle ever gets annoyed at the jokes made about him, he should hear what is said about China's Vice President.

headline: Prosecution Brief Accuses Milken
abstract: Government prosecutors argued in a memorandum released yesterday that the pre-sentencing hearing of Michael R. Milken established that the former financier had "committed serious crimes" in addition to those he has admitted.    The memorandum said the evidence showed that Mr. Milken, who pleaded guilty to six felonies in April, engaged in repeated criminal activity as part of the way he did business.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, appointed Peter S. Sealey senior vice president. * ICF Inc., an environmental consulting subsidiary of American Capital and Research Corp., Fairfax, Va., named Marilyn Block vice president. * JSB Financial Inc., Lynbrook, L.I., a bank holding company, promoted Edward P. Henson to president, succeeding Joseph J. Blaine, who becomes vice chairman. * Litton Industries, Beverly Hills, Calif., a provider of advanced electronic and military systems, promoted David W. Danjczek to vice president of international business. * M/A-Com Inc., a producer of radio frequency, microwave and millimeter wave semiconductors, appointed Jacqueline D. Arthur vice president and treasurer. * MCA Inc., Universal City, Calif., named Robert Blattner vice president. * National City Corp., Cleveland, a bank holding company, appointed Jeffrey D. Kelly senior vice president. * Simon & Schuster, a subsidiary of Paramount Communications Inc., New York, named Peter J. Boni president of its software and information services division and L. William Black president of its business information publishing division. Both divisions are in the company's professional information group. * Storage Technology Corp., Louisville, Colo., which produces computer peripheral equipment, named David E. Lacey corporate vice president. * Thrifty Drug Stores, a unit of Thrifty Corp., Los Angeles, appointed Robert B. Glass executive vice president.

headline: PRETORIA OFFERS MODEL FOR FUTURE
abstract: The South African Government today unveiled some of its proposed mechanisms for a new constitution that would extend political rights to the disenfranchised black majority.    A report prepared by a committee of the President's Council, which advises Mr. de Klerk on policy matters, proposed a two-chamber Parliament and a constitutional bill of rights as a starting point for the negotiations that the President has proposed with black leaders.

headline: Patents; New Artificial Heart Uses Elliptical Shape
abstract: Researchers at the University of Utah have patented a new, egg-shaped artificial heart. It is said to be smaller than but just as powerful as the Jarvik-7 heart, which was used in a number of patients during the 1980's but was largely discontinued in the last year.    In its simplest form, the device would be powered from outside the patient's body and used as a temporary substitute heart until a compatible human organ became available for transplant. But the inventors also said they believed the design could be applied to a more advanced heart that would be suitable for permanent implant.

headline: G.N.P. Up By 1.8% in 3d Quarter
abstract: The Government today reported an increase in the gross national product that was hailed by the Bush Administration but labeled by some economists as misleading or even masking an economy in recession.    The Commerce Department said the economy grew at a 1.8 percent annual rate during the July-September quarter, somewhat faster than most analysts had expected and well above the expansion rate of four-tenths of 1 percent posted during the spring.

headline: Route Shifts Challenge British Air
abstract: From the way Sir Colin Marshall, chief executive of British Airways, talks about the New York Giants and their chances of making it to the Super Bowl, it is obvious that he is still attached to America, where he spent 11 years.   But not all of his thoughts of the United States are so pleasant these days. He is very much concerned about the pending deals by American Airlines to buy seven routes between the United States and London from ailing Trans World Airlines and by United Airlines to buy five others from teetering Pan American World Airways.

headline: Morocco's Call for Arab Meeting On the Gulf Has Diplomats Astir
abstract: The call by King Hassan II of Morocco for an emergency Arab summit meeting to avert a war in the Persian Gulf has set off a flurry of diplomatic contacts, including the dispatch of an Iraqi envoy to the Moroccan capital, but Arab reaction to the appeal has been extremely cautious.   Only the Sudan, Mauritania and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, readily expressed willingness to attend such a session, which the King proposed on Sunday. But even Mr. Arafat, who arrived here today from Baghdad, told associates privately that he was skeptical that such a gathering would produce the much hoped for "Arab solution" to the gulf crisis, which is now more than three months old.

headline: Market Place; '89 Stock Winners Still on Top in '90
abstract: If 1990 was a year when it was best not to own stocks, it was also a year when those who did own them were well advised to stay with the winners of 1989.   The old reliable consumer growth stocks, the ones that make products everyone buys, again led the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average, as they did in 1989. Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola and Philip Morris were the top three stocks in 1990, as they were the year before.

headline: Curfew and Traffic Bans Set In Temple Dispute in India
abstract: Local officials tonight barred all traffic from roads leading to a site in northern India that is attracting Hindu fundamentalists intent on moving a Muslim mosque and beginning construction of a Hindu temple in its place by next Tuesday.    As the deadline set by the Hindu nationalists approached, local officials also imposed an indefinite curfew on the hillside town of Ayodhya, situated 750 miles southeast of here in the populous state of Uttar Pradesh, and on the nearby larger city of Faizabad. The controversy over the temple is threatening to topple the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh.

headline: Parent of First Boston Plans To Buy Firm's Bridge Loans
abstract: CS Holdings, the parent of the First Boston Corporation, has decided to step up to the plate to help bail the investment banking firm out of one of its thorniest financial problems.    An executive with CS Holdings who would discuss the issue only if he was not identified said yesterday that the company was planning to purchase as much as 44 percent of First Boston's outstanding bridge loans, a statement that was greeted by a number of senior officials at the firm with surprise.

headline: SLOVENES TO VOTE ON INDEPENDENCE
abstract: Although the plebiscite on Slovenian independence from Yugoslavia will be held on Sunday, Government officials here and people on the street are confident that they already know the results.    "Of course, of course, I'll vote for independence," said 80-year-old Justi Pletersky as she shopped for Christmas today. "We all will." Like most Slovenes, she sees her vote as simply an affirmation of her Slovene identity.

headline: FRANCE INCREASES ITS FORCES IN GULF
abstract: France's Defense Minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, said today that his nation would send about 4,000 reinforcements to Saudi Arabia, raising the number of French troops there to about 10,000 men.    Confirming a report that first appeared in Le Monde, Mr. Chevenement said the decision to increase France's force was a direct result of the United Nations resolution sanctioning the use of force if Iraq does not withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15.

headline: The Pedestrian Sneaker Makes a Comeback
abstract: LEAD: They are advertisements with a wink. A playful young mother lies on her back and balances her giggling tot on her ankles and feet, which are clad in plain white canvas sneakers. The caption: ''Keds introduces weightlifting shoes.''

headline: SAUDI OIL EXPORTS RISE TO NEW HIGH, ERASING SHORTAGE
abstract: Saudi Arabia's oil production surpassed 8.2 million barrels a day this week and is expected to rise to 8.5 million barrels early next year, the highest level in nine years, the Saudi Oil Minister, Hisham Nazer, said in an interview today.   The rise in Saudi production, along with increases by other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries like the United Arab Emirates, Libya, Nigeria and Iran, means that the loss of an estimated four million barrels a day from Kuwait and Iraq as a result of the United Nations economic embargo has already been made up.

headline: People
abstract: * Laurie Irwin and Jan Johnson have been named vice presidents of J. Walter Thompson, Chicago. * Gary Andrews has joined Grey Advertising, New York, as senior vice president and management representative, and Karen Harris has become senior vice president and media director. Alan Braunstein has joined as vice president and associate creative director. * Stephanie George has been appointed advertising director of W Magazine, a Fairchild publication.

headline: Rig Count Dips in Week
abstract: The number of working rigs in the United States dropped by 20 last week, to a total of 1,124, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The decline, attributed partly to bad weather, followed several weeks of increases that had taken the total to its highest level since Dec. 28, 1987. The count a year ago was 1,045, the Houston-based tool maker said. The count represents the number of rigs exploring for oil.

headline: Report on U.S. Contract Bias
abstract: Tougher rules and more diligent oversight are needed to prevent favoritism in the awarding of Federal computer contracts, a House committee says in a report that accuses the Navy of bias in favor of I.B.M.   The report by the Government Operations Committee, to be released on Monday, details "a tangled web of agency and contractor abuse, improprieties and illegalities," said Representative John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the panel.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * UJB Financial Corp., Princeton, N.J., to Linett & Harrison, Springfield, N.J., with a budget of more than $5 million. * Wordstar International Inc., San Francisco, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, with billings of about $2 million.

headline: Hawkish Coalition Is Forming
abstract: As President Bush prepares for talks with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq, an unusual coalition of liberal Democrats and moderate-to-conservative Republicans is urging the Administration to make the elimination of Iraq's weapons ability an explicit goal of American policy in the Persian Gulf.   The group, which calls itself the Committee for Peace and Security in the Gulf, has scheduled a news conference on Monday where it plans to argue that the United States should be willing to use force if necessary to see that Iraq's chemical, biological and potential nuclear weapons ability is dismantled or destroyed.

headline: Marxist Universities In Germany Protest Kohl Housecleaning
abstract: Three months after the Germans celebrated their national unity with a holiday, teachers and students at universities in what used to be Communist East Germany fear for the future.    Hundreds of professors and students packed into the big Humboldt University in eastern Berlin on Friday to protest steps by Government officials who are moving to sweep out remnants of Marxist scholarship. The universities are fighting back, with charges of western German patronizing that they say is hindering a self-purification process.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: The assets of the nation's 525 money market mutual funds increased by $2.94 billion, to $418.33 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 162 institutional funds increased by $1.27 billion, to $104.22 billion. The assets of the 259 general-purpose funds were up by $1.06 billion, to $148.79 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds rose $608.5 million, to $165.33 billion, the institute said.

headline: Commercial Credit
abstract: The Commercial Credit Corporation, a subsidiary of Primerica Holdings Inc., yesterday priced $150 million in notes due in Dec. 1, 1992, through Morgan Stanley & Company. Underwriters said the 8.875 percent notes were priced at 100, or about 137.5 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The noncallable notes are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * Chemical Banking Corp., New York, made three promotions to executive vice president: Frank Lourenso, for its middle market group; Alan M. Silberstein, for its consumer banking group, and Thomas Jacob, for its national consumer services group.

headline: Cutting the Computer Wire Snarl
abstract: Swarming under floors, above ceilings and through elevator shafts of virtually every modern office building are hundreds and thousands of wires and cables. Forming bunches as thick as a fat man's waist near the center of each floor, they fan out across offices to telephones, answering machines, lamps and computers.    But as more machines crowd the nation's desks, this snarl of wiring threatens to throttle some companies' ability to rearrange staff and departments. To eliminate the newest and fastest-growing family of wires -- the ones connecting computers -- electronics and computer companies have begun introducing products to link computers with light, radio and microwave signals.

headline: 2 Office Chains Plan Merger
abstract: Office Club, an office- supply chain, agreed to be acquired by Office Depot Inc. in a stock swap valued at $137.8 million.   Office Depot, based in Boca Raton, Fla, has 121 stores in the Southeast, Midwest and Texas and is expected to have $630 million in sales in 1990.

headline: Setting Deadlines Is Risky, Particularly Those You Can't Meet
abstract: Deadlines can be treacherous things for the people who set them as well as the people who are called upon to meet them.   The truth of that maxim was demonstrated again this week when Lieut. Gen. Calvin A. H. Waller, the deputy commander of United States forces in Saudi Arabia, said that all the elements of his team would not be in place by Jan. 15, the deadline set by the United Nations for President Saddam Hussein to pull out of Kuwait or face expulsion by force.

headline: Japan's Vehicle Exports
abstract: Japan's vehicle exports fell 4.9 percent in September from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today. The companies exported 509,155 cars, trucks and buses in September, the association said. Exports to the United States and the European Community fell, reflecting increased output from factories abroad. The auto makers shipped 134,827 units to Europe in September, up 2.8 percent from a year earlier. But exports to the 12 members of the European Community were down 7.4 percent, to 88,392 units. Exports to the United States totaled 207,762 units, down 12.7 percent.

headline: Tokyo Stocks In Biggest One-Day Rise
abstract: LEAD: Reports of an easing in Persian Gulf tensions and intervention by the Government sent the stock market here exploding upward on Tuesday for its largest one-day gain, a 13.2 percent increase on the Nikkei average.

headline: Five Big Drug Companies Show Strong Income Gains
abstract: LEAD: Riding high in the face of economic weaknesses that have reduced profits in other industries, five major pharmaceutical companies reported strong gains in quarterly earnings yesterday.

headline: Japan's Chief Said to Scold Aide for Slur Against Blacks
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan gave his new Justice Minister a stern warning for a racial slur against American blacks but will not demand his resignation, the Foreign Ministry's spokesman said today.

headline: 450 to 500 Face T.W.A. Layoffs
abstract: LEAD: In yet another sign of troubled times in the airline industry, Trans World Airlines Inc. said today that it was laying off between 450 and 500 staff and might cut some flights.      A T.W.A. spokesman, Donald

headline: Fund Yields Are Mixed
abstract: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were mixed for the fifth consecutive week ended yesterday, as tax-exempt funds rose and taxable funds held steady.    Money fund managers said the year-end seasonal factors that normally affect short-term interest rates were dissipating, and that they expect the usual softening of short-term rates in January.

headline: U.S.-Canada Stock Plan
abstract: LEAD: In a first step toward developing a cross-border securities market, the Securities and Exchange Commission today approved for comment a revised plan to make it easier for Canadian companies to sell stock to United States investors and vice versa.

headline: Guinness to Buy Largest Brewer in Spain
abstract: Guinness P.L.C. announced plans today to buy the largest brewer in the fast-growing Spanish market for $1.02 billion. Analysts said the deal reflected the growing interest of multinational beverage companies in regional European brewers.   Guinness, the London-based beverage giant, said it had agreed to buy La Cruz del Campo S.A., based in Seville, which holds 22 percent of the Spanish beer market and is the country's fastest-growing and most profitable brewer. The acquisition would be the second biggest for Guinness, after its $4.1 billion purchase in 1986 of the Distillers Company, a spirits concern.

headline: Profits Up at Bristol-Myers
abstract: LEAD: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it had record sales and earnings in the three months that ended on Sept. 30.

headline: Inquiry in South Africa Inconclusive
abstract: A judicial commission that spent six months investigating clandestine operations by special units of the army and police said today that it could not prove that they had systematically murdered and terrorized opponents of apartheid.    Justice Louis Harms, who headed the investigation, was appointed by President F. W. de Klerk in response to calls by anti-apartheid and human rights groups for a full-scale and impartial investigation into the activities of police assassination squads, which anti-apartheid campaigners have long contended were responsible for the deaths of some opponents of the Government.

headline: G.M. Sees Growth In Middle East
abstract: General Motors says it is optimistic about sales in the Middle East -- especially since Chevys have earned a reputation here as speedy getaway cars. The Chevrolet Caprice sedan has acquired a "good reputation for getting people out of Iraq," said Terry Indge, G.M.'s director for the Middle East.   Despite the loss of a rich market in Kuwait, G.M. expects improved business this year and next, he said. G.M. anticipates selling 40,000 vehicles in the Middle East this year, compared with about 36,000 last year. It sees sales improving another 10 percent in 1991, according to Mr. Indge. G.M. relies on the Caprice, which sells for about $24,000 in Saudi Arabia, and the Chevrolet/GMC Suburban utility vehicle for about 80 percent of its sales in the region, he said.

headline: All About/Cruise Lines; A Deluge of Growth in the Floating Vacation Market
abstract: EVERY Sunday, newspaper travel advertisements bring a reminder that cruise ships have armed themselves for competitive battle. For example, seven-day cruises to the Caribbean that normally cost $1,800 are discounted to $1,000, airfare included. Those who shop around can pay as little as $700.   And more is on order. This year, 13 ships with 11,000 berths are being added to the cruise line fleet operating primarily out of North America, expanding capacity by 15 percent. The largest, Carnival Cruise Lines's Fantasy, has 2,025 berths -- more than many of the old ocean liners and all but the largest hotels.

headline: Hard Tests Seen for British Despite European Linkup
abstract: LEAD: Although the British pound jumped and the London stock market soared in response to Britain's formal entry into the European Monetary System, some economists warned yesterday that the euphoria might not be long-lived and that the British economy still faced difficult tests.

headline: Pennzoil Raises Stake In Chevron to 9.4%
abstract: The Pennzoil Company said today that it had bought $90 million worth of shares in the Chevron Corporation since Dec. 3, increasing its stake in Chevron to 9.4 percent, from 9.1 percent.    The purchases, made in the open market at an average price of $69.75 a share, increased Pennzoil's total investment in Chevron to $2.2 billion.

headline: Hamburg Journal; A Plucky Countess Braves the Ghosts of Prussia
abstract: When she recalls the home of her youth, Marion Countess Donhoff, whose 81 years stretch from privileged days as a daughter of aristocracy to editing and publishing one of Germany's most influential newspapers, passes into a dream world.    "I had the intention of never going back there," said the daughter of Germans who settled in East Prussia in the 17th century, and whose life has seen Germany shrink from a vast Eastern empire to a rather middle-sized country in the center of Europe. "Because it was a terribly beautiful place, a very beautiful manor, from a wonderful period, and I didn't want to see all of that destroyed and gone."

headline: Treasuries Inch Up in Light Day
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher, and interest rates inched lower, in quiet trading yesterday, as credit market participants shrugged off a big drop in the price of leading commodities, including oil.

headline: Times Co. Magazines Introducing an Option
abstract: The Magazine Group of The New York Times Company is introducing an option for advertisers to make tailor-made ad purchases in the various publications of its women's magazine division.    The Hearst Corporation and Time Warner Inc. have similar plans for their magazine groups, and Murdoch Magazines announced Tuesday that it had started a group advertising sales program that offers cash rebates for some advertisers based on the number of pages and titles used.    The Times's plan, called Action Plus, offers an opportunity for advertisers to customize ad placements in Family Circle, McCall's, Child or Decorating Remodeling in combination with any single-topic publications that come out at various times of the year. The plan will provide the type of discounts normally available only when advertisers buy space in an entire group of magazines and will also allow for joint marketing partnerships and group promotions.    Advertisers will be able to choose which magazine or combination of magazines they want to appear in, rather than buy into every magazine in the group. The Times Company's Magazine Group said it would also offer joint programs in its sports and leisure division.    "We will be creating a whole new generation of marketing partnerships and efficiencies in advertising buys," said Charles H. Townsend, president and chief operating officer of Family Circle.

headline: Soviet Aide Who Met the Iraqis Talks in Washington About Gulf
abstract: LEAD: A senior Soviet official who recently met with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq discussed the Persian Gulf crisis with top American officials today, but offered no indication that he had brought a new proposal for ending Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.

headline: BMW, the Motorcycle, Gears Up for a Big Run
abstract: LEAD: TURNING attention to its neglected stepchild, BMW is trying to pep up its motorcycle division by hiring a new advertising agency, raising ad expenditures tenfold and adding cheaper entry-level vehicles to its high-performance line. With new management from Germany in place, the company's American division is introducing a new ad campaign later this month by Burkhardt & Christy Advertising Inc.

headline: Business and Health; The Squeeze On Drugstores
abstract: ALTHOUGH few doctors make house calls, many drugstores still deliver prescriptions to the homes of elderly customers. Scrambling to retain customer loyalty in the highly competitive retail pharmacy business, many drugstores specialize in advice and services. Eighty-five percent have also purchased computer systems that cost $10,000 and up, and some even have satellite links to keep supplies and insurers' payments flowing.    The McKesson Corporation's PCS pharmacy card unit, for example, operates a national electronic claims-processing network. An identification card with a magnetic stripe is passed like a credit card through a $200 device, which quickly tells the druggist what the customer's health plan pays for. The bill goes electronically to a data processing center in Scottsdale, Ariz., which pays the pharmacies every two weeks.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: The Economy    The Federal Reserve will probably lower its discount rate as part of its next step to ease credit conditions. Fed officials said a consistent monetary policy would require a reduction of the discount rate, which has remained at 7 percent for almost two years, if the Federal funds rate continues to move lower.  [ Page D1. ]   Analysts believe that the Fed can rescue the economy, but that it will need to push down interest rates by at least a full percentage point, much further than currently forecast. Credit Markets.  [ D7. ]   A debate has begun among banking regulators over accounting standards that could have a profound effect on banks and on the Government's effort to clean up the savings and loan debacle.  [ D2. ] Companies    Hollywood is on a spending spree, with studios paying unprecedented prices for scripts, stars, directors and other talent required to produce feature films.  [ D1. ] International   Mexico will sell control of its telephone company for $1.76 billion to a consortium composed of Grupo Carso of Mexico, Southwestern Bell and France Telecom.  [ D1. ]   Czechoslovakia chose Volkswagen to be a partner with the Skoda automobile company in a deal that could be worth as much as $5.3 billion over 10 years.  [ D1. ]   Feuding managers and workers at a Prague factory agree on only one thing: capitalism is needed not only to save their company but also to save them from each other.  [ D1. ]   There could be a painful return to the trade warfare that aggravated the crises of the 1930's if the European Community does not eventually compromise on farm trade. News analysis.  [ D5. ]   Pressures are growing for radical changes in Deutsche Bundespost, Germany's supplier of telephone and postal services.  [ D8. ]   Japan appears to have bent to the wishes of big companies and failed to raise real estate holding taxes.  [ D8. ] The Media Business    Several Fox stations are giving programs like NBC's "Today" a run for the advertisers' money with local early-morning news programs. Fox executives see a potential for selling national advertising for what would effectively be a network of programs.  [ D1. ]   The Daily News of New York is still hemorrhaging money, so there is an air of suspense about what might happen tomorrow at the board meeting of the newspaper's corporate parent, the Tribune Company.  [ B1. ]   Disney is seeking to prop up sagging sales for reruns of television programs and wants the Government to help by significantly expanding the market for the shows.  [ D9. ]   One of the fastest-growing French publications is an offbeat four-page newspaper that looks like a cross between USA Today and a coloring book.  [ D9. ]   The publishing sales conference is part strategy session and part pep rally. Its purpose is to introduce the sales force to what could be the next best sellers. Publishing.  [ D9. ]   Mattel is using coupons to promote its toys. The campaign is being conducted in association with Coca-Cola, Mastercard, K Mart and Toys "R" Us. Advertising.  [ D10. ] Today's Columns    The legal community has been split over the fairness of sentencing Michael R. Milken to 10 years in prison. But many arguments in the debate appear to be based on misconceptions. Business and the Law.  [ D2. ]   Phibro is offering an instrument that enables investors to speculate on the price of oil in 1995. Market Place.  [ D6. ]

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent       July-Sept   Change       1990   From '89              American West Airlines   (22,000,000)      --        Chevron Corp.   403,000,000   -   3.4        Cummins Engine Co.   (33,700,000)      --        Fort Howard Corp.   (20,400,000)      --        Midway Airlines Inc.   (18,700,000)      --        Monsanto Co.   74,000,000   -   41.3        Pacific Telecom Inc.   18,500,000   -   19.2        Williams Cos.   (15,300,000)      --         See accompanying notes for special items.   (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

headline: Fed Panel Favored Easing At Meeting in Early October
abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers agreed in early October to ease interest rates if a Federal budget-cutting agreement was reached and to permit further easing if economic conditions warranted, records released today showed.   Four weeks after the Oct. 2 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal funds rate dropped to 7.75 percent from 8 percent as the Bush Administration and Congress agreed to a deficit-reduction package.

headline: Saks Head Gets Post At Bergdorf
abstract: In a shift of executives in the top realm of American fashion retailing, Burton Tansky, the president of Saks Fifth Avenue, has been named vice chairman of Bergdorf Goodman and will become chairman and chief executive of the high-fashion retailer in early 1992.   He will take over at Bergdorf when Ira Neimark, who holds those posts now, resigns on Jan. 31, 1992, at the end of his contract.

headline: Shifts in Deposit Insurance Weighed
abstract: The Bush Administration is exploring a wide array of ways to alter the Federal program that insures bank deposits, including basing the premiums paid by banks to the insurance program upon their financial health, Treasury officials and senior regulators said today.   The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's Bank Insurance Fund, which is at its lowest level since its creation 56 years ago, is under considerable financial strain. Some experts have predicted that the onset of a severe recession could make it insolvent, leading to a taxpayer bailout of the industry.

headline: Iraqi Rates Chances Of a War at '50-50'
abstract: In his first public remarks since President Bush offered to hold direct talks, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said in an interview that the chances of war or peace in the Gulf were "fifty-fifty."     Article, page A12.

headline: Gorbachev's Five Years: Era of Tumult and Change
abstract: March 1985: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is named to succeed the late Konstantin U. Chernenko as Soviet leader and outlines an urgent agenda to improve the economy.   April 1985: Mr. Gorbachev elevates three new members to the Politburo: Viktor M. Chebrikov, head of the K.G.B.; Yegor K. Ligachev, chief of party appointments, and Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, manager of the Soviet economy. Mr. Gorbachev emphasizes the need to reshape the economy and reduce rigidity in the Soviet system, in a process known as perestroika.    July 1985: The Gorbachev Politburo removes the veteran Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, and names him to the prestigious but largely ceremonial Soviet presidency. Eduard A. Shevardnadze, Communist Party leader in the Georgian Republic, replaces him.    March 1986: At the behest of Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Ryzhkov, the 27th Communist Party Congress approves a resolution calling for "truly revolutionary changes" in the economy.    January 1987: The Central Committee approves Mr. Gorbachev's plan to give voters a choice of candidates in local elections. It also approves Mr. Gorbachev's proposals for greater flexibility in elections within the ruling party, where the real authority lies.    October 1987: The Moscow party leader, Boris N. Yeltsin, attacks Mr. Ligachev, the No. 2 party leader. Mr. Yeltsin announces his resignation as Moscow party leader and is later dropped from the Politburo. Mr. Yeltsin later regains status as a legislator in the new Parliament, and then leader of the Russian Republic.    June 1988: In a speech to the first special Communist Party conference since 1941, Mr. Gorbachev declares that an overhaul of the system is imperative.    March 1989: In the first free elections since 1917, scores of party officials suffer humiliating defeats in races for the new national legislature, the Congress of People's Deputies.    July 1989: With Kremlin leaders openly alarmed that the Communist Party is losing control, Mr. Gorbachev calls for a sweeping purge to replace conservatives at all levels.   November 1989: In a manifesto insisting that Marxism will be retained in the Soviet Union, Mr. Gorbachev describes his goal as "humane socialism."   December 1989: The Communist Party in Lithuania breaks with Moscow. Mr. Gorbachev denounces the move.    January 1990: Mr. Gorbachev demands that Lithuania pay $33 billion in compensation if the republic breaks away. Political dissidents from across country meet in Moscow to openly challenge party dominance, and ethnic violence in Azerbaijan adds to impression of events spinning out of control.   February 1990: As the Communist Party Central Committee meets, 100,000 people rally in Moscow to demand democratic change. Mr. Gorbachev calls on the party to accept rival political organizations and urges the most sweeping internal reorganization since Lenin, including more power for himself. Parliament votes to end the monopoly on power held by the party for over 70 years and recommend creation of a powerful Western-style presidency and a Cabinet form of government.    March 1990: In elections in the Soviet republics, independent pro-democracy groups achieve major gains in the Russian, Ukrainian and Byelorussian republics and outright control of local governments in Moscow, Leningrad and other cities. The Lithuanian Parliament elects the first non-Communist premier of a Soviet republic, then votes to have Lithuania secede from the Soviet Union and recover the independence lost in 1940. Mr. Gorbachev is elected by the Soviet Parliament to a new executive presidency with powers he says he needs to prevent economic collapse and ethnic crisis from overwhelming the nation.    July 1990: Mr. Yeltsin, leader of the Russian republic and Mr. Gorbachev's chief rival, walks out of the Congress and quits the Communist Party.   November 1990: Mr. Gorbachev dismisses Mr. Ryzhkov and announces that executive power will be wielded by himself and the presidents of the 15 republics.

headline: Losses Widen at S.& L.'s
abstract: Despite the Government's crash program to close failed savings and loans, losses at the surviving solvent institutions more than doubled in the third quarter, compared with the previous quarter, regulators said today.    Timothy Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, said the decline was a result of the slumping real estate market.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * American Capital and Research Corp., Farifax, Va., an environmental consulting company, named Marilyn F. Meigs vice president and director of government relations for its ICF Kaiser Engineers subsidiary.

headline: Army Limits Night Maneuvers in Effort to Prevent Accidents in Gulf
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to stem the growing number of accidents in the Persian Gulf, the Army has put new restrictions on night operations by Army helicopters, the Pentagon said today.

headline: Sallie Mae Sets Note Offering
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $150 million in notes due Dec. 18, 1995, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.   The notes carry a coupon of 8.19 percent and are priced at 100, to yield about 28 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The notes are noncallable for two years.    Sallie Mae, a Government-chartered, privately owned corporation, sells debt securities to investors to raise funds for the purchase of student loans from financial institutions.

headline: In Qatar, Forgotten U.S. Warriors Wait
abstract: They are the forgotten 1,000.   There have been no nightly news photos of these members of the United States armed forces, and no television interviews about their mission, living conditions and morale. Unlike the Americans in Saudi Arabia, who have been the focus of lavish attention, these men and women have had virtually no visitors from the states.

headline: Premier Survives Censure Vote in Paris
abstract: The Socialist Government of Prime Minister Michel Rocard survived a no-confidence vote in the National Assembly tonight by five votes.    The Communist Party joined with conservatives and centrists in the attempt to bring down the 30-month-old Government over its decision to pass a 1.1 percent social security tax.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Dentsu Burson-Marsteller, New York, opened an office in Brussels. * Pace Communications Group and Tromson Monroe, both WPP Group companies, have merged. Most of the staff will move into the Pace offices. Mario Trombone, chief executive officer of Tromson Monroe, will become a consultant.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: LEAD: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Court Denies Bhutto Respite From Trial
abstract: LEAD: Benazir Bhutto's legal defense team failed today to persuade the judge of a special tribunal to postpone hearings on corruption charges against the former Prime Minister until after national elections on Oct. 24 so that she could concentrate on her political campaign.

headline: Smoot-Hawley's Role in the Depression
abstract: To the Editor:   Smoot and Hawley did not raise tariffs in the Depression, ("Consumers Aren't Buying the Bad News," Dec. 2). The Smoot-Hawley legislation came first. It triggered the crash of 1929 and along with Hoover's tax increases of 1932 caused the Depression. JUDE WANNISKY  Morristown, N.Y., Dec. 3
