abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                  Oct. 19   Oct. 12   Oct. 20        1990   1990   1989        Gasoline production, daily   6.9   7.1   6.8        Distillate production, daily   2.9   2.9   2.7        Gasoline stocks   222.6   225.9   223.9        Distillate stocks   136.9   135.9   120.0        Crude imports, daily   4.8   5.0   5.2        Product imports, daily   1.6   1.3   2.0        Crude stocks   340.4   343.3   336.5        Crude production, daily   7.1   7.1   7.4        Refinery utilization (%)   83.3   85.8   85.4       Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: U.N. Postpones Vote On Resolution on Israel
abstract: The United Nations Security Council postponed a vote on a Middle East resolution again today, at the request of the Soviet Union.   The Soviets asked for the postponement to give Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze time to discuss the problem with the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, at a meeting planned for Friday in Turkey.   Exactly what Mr. Shevardnadze will propose to Mr. Arafat remains unclear. But most Security Council members want to change the draft resolution to avoid an American veto, which would embarrass Washington's Arab allies in the gulf crisis by giving President Saddam Hussein of Iraq more ammunition in his campaign to portray them as the friends of Israel's protector.    The postponement until Monday is the third the Council has agreed to in the last week, as the United States struggles to modify the draft resolution to avoid vetoing it.   A majority of Council members appear ready to vote for the draft, which extends more United Nations protection to Palestinians in the occupied territories, defined as including Jerusalem, as well as endorsing the idea of an international peace conference to resolve the Arab-Israeli dispute.   Supporters of the resolution argue that the Security Council cannot credibly punish Iraq for annexing Kuwait while ignoring Israel's continued occupation of Arab lands.

headline: China's Premier Sees Progress on Cambodia
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Li Peng said today that significant progress had been made in reaching a political settlement in Cambodia and that Beijing was ready to repair ties gradually with Vietnam.

headline: Northeast Utilities
abstract: LEAD: A judge struck down state approval for Northeast Utilities to issue $500 million in bonds to help pay for its $2.3 billion takeover of the bankrupt Public Service Company of New Hampshire, owner of the Seabrook nuclear plant. Merrimack County Superior Court Judge Kenneth McHugh said approval of the bonds by the state's Industrial Development Authority, Gov.

headline: Ford Reports 78.7% Decline In Earnings
abstract: The Ford Motor Company turned in its worst quarterly performance since the 1982 recession, it said yesterday, a 78.7 percent drop in third-quarter profit caused by weak automotive business and by a $44.6 million loss at First Nationwide, its savings and loan subsidiary.    Ford's worldwide automotive business was hit by a variety of problems: costly incentives in the United States, production losses in Europe and anti-inflation measures in South America.

headline: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes This Week
abstract: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed on Wednesday by an auction of two-year notes. On Thursday the Treasury postponed a planned auction of 52-week bills and on Friday held an auction of 69-day cash management bills.    By late Friday the rate for the three-month bill was 7.23 percent; for six-month bills it was 7.19 percent. With no when-issued trading in two-year notes, investors followed the outstanding issue as an indicator. The two-year note traded at a price to yield 7.82 percent.    The following fixed-income issues are scheduled this week: TAXABLE WEDNESDAY GTE Northwest Inc., $75 million in first mortgage bonds, due 2030, A+/Aa-3/AA-. Competitive. ONE DAY DURING THE WEEK Apache Corp., $150 million in convertible subordinated debentures, due 2000. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. First Interstate Automobile Trust 1990-1, about $623 million in certificates backed by auto loan assets, NR/ Aaa/ AAA. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Source: McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc. Ratings: MCM/Moody's/Standard & Poor's. TAX-EXEMPT TUESDAY Los Angeles, $80 million in revenue bonds. Competitive. WEDNESDAY Texas Public Finance Authority, $138.4 million in general obligation bonds. Competitive. TENTATIVE OFFERINGS THIS WEEK California State Public Works Board, $315 million in lease revenue bonds for Regents, University of California (various University of California). J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. Connecticut, $75 million in general obligation capital apprecialtion bonds (College Savings Plan). Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Geo. L. Smith 2d Georgia World Congress Authority, $200 million in revenue bonds (Domed Stadium Project). Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

headline: Moves Urged In Trade Talks
abstract: The head of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said today that after four years of hard bargaining, the talks were in a crisis, and he urged ministers who will meet at the final session in Brussels next week to reach early compromises.   "The round is in a crisis, and the negotiators have to get out of this crisis in the first hours and days in Brussels," GATT's Director General, Arthur Dunkel, said.   President Bush, during his visit to Mexico, also appealed for a successful conclusion of the talks.   Delegates to the trade talks wound up their work in Geneva late Monday, agreeing on a 391- page package of draft texts and comments to send to the ministers. But despite their efforts, many differences stand in the way of a final agreement by the 107 countries.

headline: Growth Rate Of Consumer Debt Slows
abstract: Growth in consumer credit slowed to a seasonally adjusted $1.47 billion in October, the Federal Reserve reported today. Analysts said it was another sign of a weakening economy.   "That is minuscule, a very, very small increase," said Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group, a Washington management consulting firm. "It mostly reflects that we have a real softening in the kinds of purchases that people usually use credit for -- cars, furniture, appliances."

headline: Criminal Inquiry on Plane
abstract: The Federal Government is conducting a criminal inquiry into excessive payments on the Navy's secret A-12 attack plane, the Defense Department told Congress on Monday.   The department's inspector general, Susan Crawford, made the disclosure during questioning at the first House Armed Services Committee hearing on the secret Stealth aircraft and the controversy surrounding the six-year-old program.

headline: Business Diary/December 2-7
abstract: COMPANIES Phones, Computers and Price  Lawsuits, rebuffs and a hostile bid might not seem like the stuff of courtship, but multibillion-dollar corporations don't conduct their romances like everyone else. The NCR Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest computer maker, rejected the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's takeover offer of $6 billion, or $90 a share. A.T.& T., whose own efforts to market computers have been costly disgraces, desires NCR so ardently that it offered a 60 percent premium over the stock's previous price. NCR initially resorted to the "Garbo defense." Said NCR's chairman and chief executive, Charles E. Exley Jr., "We want to be left alone." Then his board members decided they would rather be left wealthy, and offered to negotiate at $125 a share. Whereupon A.T.& T. turned its $90 bid into a hostile offer. Analysts treated all the hubub as tactical -- a prelude, said Jack Grubman of PaineWebber, to a friendly deal for at least $100 a share. "A.T.& T. wants to get this done in the nicest, most friendly way possible," he said. "It's just a matter of price." Bankrupt, Again  For Continental Airlines, bankruptcy is becoming the continuation of business by other means. The nation's fifth-largest airline filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday while assuring passengers and travel agents that it would continue to do business as usual. The last time the airline filed for bankruptcy was in 1983, in the grip of a strike, and it resumed operating at a fraction of its former size. Continental's current problems are the huge debts created by Frank Lorenzo, the former chairman, and the high oil prices that have accompanied the Mideast crisis. "I think the creditors understand that this bankruptcy is substantially different," said Thomas Longman, an analyst at Bear Stearns. "I don't see any reason to think they will be out of business." It helps that under Hollis L. Harris, the current chairman, Continental has taught cabin attendants to treat passengers better than the baggage. Talley's Tally  From corporate headquarters in Phoenix came word that Talley Industries Inc. would eliminate its quarterly 12 1/2-cent dividend. From the board meeting in Miami came word that the dividend would be paid. Turns out that the company's clever administrators had written press releases to suit every possible board decision. Fortunately for stockholders, the Miami announcement was right. Yes, There Will Be a Macy's  R.H. Macy & Company took out a full-page advertisement last week to say it can survive the Christmas season without "miracles on 34th Street." "We expect it to be slow and we are prepared for it," wrote Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive. Macy's is bowed under $5 billion in debt and mounting losses. The ad, in Women's Wear Daily, might have worried the very suppliers and creditors it was supposed to reassure. In the movie, "Miracle on 34th Street," after all, a headline-conscious Macy's executive says he believes in Santa Claus. Fed Helps Banks to a Hold  You can't just tell bankers to make more loans. You have to offer them money. After months of urging the banks to stoke the economy by loosening credit, the Federal Reserve Board on Tuesday came up with an incentive. The Fed eliminated a requirement that banks hold in reserves 3 percent of their corporate certificates of deposit. The action frees about $13 billion for new lending, and is expected to increase bank profits by about $1 billion a year, mostly at the largest institutions. Bank stocks jumped from dismal levels to merely low, as some industry analysts upgraded their recommendations from sell to hold. Sandoz Cuts a Price, a Bit  No blood, no drug. That had been the Sandoz Pharmaceutical Corporation's profitable slogan. The company forced schizophrenia victims to buy a blood-monitoring rig that pushed the cost of treatment with the drug clozapine to $8,944 a year. Many Federal and state hospitals ruled the drug out instead of paying such a price. Under pressure from Congress and advocates for the mentally ill, the Swiss-owned company has agreed to sell the drug alone, cutting the price to about $5,000 in the United States. That's still much higher than the government-controlled prices of $2,500 in Germany and $1,000 in Britain.    INTERNATIONAL   Japan's Mideast Role  One Japanese export unlikely to grow is aid to the American-led military effort in the Middle East. Although Japan buys a higher portion of its oil from the Middle East than the United States does, Japanese leaders only reluctantly raised their contribution, from $1 billion to $4 billion -- "microscopic," considering the size of the Japanese economy, former Commerce Secretary Peter G. Peterson, chairman of the Blackstone Group investment bank, recently told the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry in New York. Shuzo Muramoto, former president of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, said in New York last week that Japan already gives more foreign aid than the United States, and added, "Japanese resources are not as abundant as you may think." But Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, told the Japan Society of one other reason the Japanese were unlikely to raise their support for American forces in the Middle East: the troops are already there. "Make sure the next time military peace keeping is undertaken by the United States, we get our commitments before we go in," he advised. Vietnam's Sorry Economic State  As Vietnam begs for foreign aid, United States officials ponder whether to end their economic blockade. C. Peter Timmer, a Harvard economist, said that the Vietnamese dong is worth so little that dollars are the accepted medium of exchange. The 5,000 dong note, the nation's largest, is worth less than a dollar. Vietnam's leaders published a plan last week to save the economy from socialist strangulation by turning to free markets. They aim to cut the annual inflation rate from 50 percent to 10 percent by 1995 and double income per person to about $200 and increase exports fivefold by the year 2000. "We are still among the poorest nations of the world," the plan says. Jane Werner, an associate research scholar at Columbia University, expects that steps toward normalization of relations with the United States next year will help Vietnam compensate for the loss of Soviet aid. Several American companies want Vietnamese business. British Airways Reaches Out  British Airways is finding its way from England to Europe without the help of the channel tunnel. The company said last week that it wants to join German investors in forming a new Berlin-based airline that will give Lufthansa more competition. It already has asked the European Commission's approval for sharing ownership of the Belgian airline, Sabena, with Dutch and Belgian partners. And, farther east, it seeks to start Air Russia in Moscow. Once a dreary Government-owned airline, British Airways has transformed itself since its 1987 privatization into an ambitious international competitor. THE ECONOMY   Jobs Down, Unemployment Up  The nation is losing jobs far more rapidly than economists or Federal officials had feared. Friday's reported decline of 450,000 civilian jobs caused many economists to abandon their hopes for only a mild recession. The November unemployment rate rose two-tenths of 1 percent to 5.9 percent. In the view of Allen Sinai, the Boston Company's chief economist, the latest figures "suggest the cumulative, downward spiral that the Federal Reserve chairman said was not in evidence." The Federal Reserve eased on Friday, and several banks lowered their prime lending rate from 10 to 9 3/4 percent. An Abrupt Halt in Trade Talks  European leaders faced with 30,000 rampaging farmers on one side and renewed trade barriers on the other have decided that sharpened pitchforks can do them more harm. The European Community refused last week to meet American demands for deep reductions in farm subsidies. Crucial trade talks in Brussels then came to a halt after four years of delicate preparation. Negotiators hope the talks will resume next year. The Plunge in Purchasing  The last time purchasing managers were so pessimistic, the nation was caught in the recession of the early 1980's. An index based on a survey of the nation's industrial purchasing managers fell to 41.3 percent in November, down from 43.3 percent the month before. Roseanne M. Cahn, an economist at First Boston, said that the index has already fallen below the level typical of a mild recession. "I think it will go lower," she added. "The weakness feeds on itself." In Brief  Retailers reported slower holiday sales than last year. Sears, risking an intensified price war, announced that its everyday low prices would become lower still, with the usual after-Christmas reductions coming before. As prospects for avoiding a Middle East war improved, oil prices fell $2.27 a barrel to $26.58 last week. Economists said that lower oil prices would only gradually help pull the nation from a recession.

headline: Revenue Bonds For Illinois Project
abstract: LEAD: The Village of Hoffman Estates in Cook and Kane Counties in Illinois has tentatively priced $111.5 million in tax-increment revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Several Issues in This Week's U.S. Sales
abstract: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week consists of a record supply of Government securities for sale, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. And for the remainder of the week the Treasury will be busy with its quarterly refunding, consisting of three- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.    There will also be an auction of 161-day cash management bills on the same day the 30-year bond is sold.    By late Friday the three- and 10-year notes were trading on a when-issued basis at prices to yield 7.84 percent and 8.55 percent, respectively. The long-term 30-year bond was offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.69 percent. In the bill market, the outstanding three- and six-month bills were bid at 7.09 percent and 7.05 percent, respectively.   New Government agency issues expected this week include a $850 million, two-part sale of callable debentures by the Federal National Mortgage Association. Fannie Mae interest rates will be announced tomorrow for the $400 million in five-year debentures callable in 1993, and for the $450 million of 30-year debentures callable in 1995.    The Student Loan Marketing Association today plans to price $650 million in floating-rate notes due May 9, through various securities dealers. The Sallie Mae notes will be priced at a spread to the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill, with the interest rates adjusted the day after each weekly Treasury bill auction.    The following fixed-income issues are scheduled this week:  TAXABLE ONE DAY DURING THE WEEK Household International Inc., $5 million in $10 depository preferred shares, NR/A-3/A-. Blunt, Ellis & Loewi Inc. Source: McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc. Ratings: MCM/Moody's/Standard & Poor's. TAX-EXEMPT  WEDNESDAY Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Maryland, $70 million in general obligation bonds. Competitive. TENTATIVE OFFERINGS THIS WEEK Boston, $170 million in revenue bonds for Boston City Hospital. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Chicago, $200 million in Chicago-O'Hare International Airport special facilities revenue bonds (American Airlines). Goldman, Sachs & Co. Connecticut Health and Education Facilities Authority, $124.7 million in Yale-New Haven Hospital debt securities. Goldman, Sachs. New Hampshire, $50 million in general obligation bonds for the College Saving program. Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Trimble County, Ky., $100 million in pollution control revenue bonds for Louisville Gas and Electric. Goldman, Sachs.

headline: Loser in Ivory Coast to Challenge Election
abstract: The opposition presidential candidate in the Ivory Coast, Laurent Gbagbo, said today that he would ask the West African nation's Supreme Court to overturn election results that he says were rigged by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny.   The Interior Ministry announced that Mr. Houphouet-Boigny, 85 years old and the nation's leader for 30 years, won Sunday's election with 81.67 percent of the votes cast. It was the country's first contested presidential election.

headline: Suit Says TRW Cheated Air Force
abstract: A whistleblower's lawsuit is accusing TRW Inc.'s space and military division of inflating bids and double-billing the Air Force on classified contracts. Frank M. Breene, a retired TRW acquisitions manager, said in a $20 million Federal lawsuit that TRW violated the False Claims Act by submitting false bids and falsely allocating costs from 1982 to 1990.   Julian Levine, a spokesman for Cleveland-based TRW, said the lawsuit was "frivolous and totally without merit." The division based in Redondo Beach, Calif., works on several highly classified projects.

headline: Israel Warns Against a Gulf Retreat
abstract: Israel warned the United States and its Western allies today not to stray from what it views as America's original Persian Gulf goals -- forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and dismantling President Saddam Hussein's military threat.    Addressing the possibility that American talks with Iraq might lead to a negotiated settlement of the gulf crisis that would leave Iraq's military unharmed, Foreign Minister David Levy warned against "a situation in which all the Western armies will leave the gulf and Saddam Hussein will emerge with certain advantages."

headline: Romania Decides to Dismiss Officials in Weak Industries
abstract: LEAD: The Government has decided to fire thousands of managers of failing state-owned industries, Economics Minister Eugen Dijmarescu said today.

headline: Patents; A Hand-Held Computer
abstract: For Bowling Statistics For bowlers who want to keep detailed statistical breakdowns on their performance, an inventor in Baltimore obtained a patent this week for a hand-held computerized scorekeeper that can store and analyze data from a year's worth of games.    Invented by James P. Cullen, who operates a small import business, the scorekeeper was designed in part just to simplify the often confusing job of adding up multiple strikes and spares. Resembling an ordinary pocket calculator, it features a small screen containing the 10 frames on a standard bowling scoresheet and a microprocessor programmed with rules for both tenpins and duckpins. The inventor said the device could keep track of up to five bowlers at once.

headline: Ford Curbs Customer Rebates
abstract: In a significant shift in marketing, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would stop offering cash rebates to buyers of most of its vehicles starting on Tuesday. Instead, discounts will be given to dealers for the next two and a half months, allowing them to choose whether to provide cash payments to buyers or use the price break in other ways.   Ford executives said the company was halting most customer rebates, at least temporarily, because they had not proved effective in raising sales in what is currently a soft market for vehicles. Ford will continue rebates on five, mostly small models.

headline: Economic Scene; A 'Happy Ending' In Gulf Is Doubted
abstract: THE greatest uncertainty hanging over the economy and the financial markets is whether the confrontation in the Persian Gulf will end in war or peace. Markets got a shot in the arm this week when President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accepted President Bush's proposal for discussions in Washington and Baghdad with their respective chief foreign officers. And yesterday word came that Mr. Hussein said he would allow all hostages to leave Iraq and Kuwait.   However, the end game of this affair is tricky -- and could take a lot longer than the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations resolutions calling for full Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, restoration of the Kuwaiti Government and release of all hostages. President Hussein will doubtless seek to escape from some of those terms.

headline: Life Insurers Jolted By Sharp Downturn In Real Estate Value
abstract: LEAD: With real estate values going downhill and banks nationwide struggling to avoid being buried in the slide, anxieties are focusing on another group of lenders: life insurance companies.

headline: After Court Rebuke, Refac Hints at a Retreat on Suits
abstract: LEAD: In the wake of a stinging rebuke from a Federal appeals court here, the Refac Technology Development Corporation signaled a retreat today in its efforts to sue thousands of companies over patent infringement.

headline: Senators Reach Agreement To End Cable TV Impasse
abstract: LEAD: Legislation to regulate the cable television industry, considered all but dead when it was blocked on the Senate floor two weeks ago, may be resurrected with a last-minute deal reached today.

headline: MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Accounts
abstract: * Round Tables Pizza Inc., San Francisco, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, with a budget between $6 million and $8 million. * Automatic Data Processing Inc., Roseland, N.J., to Lowe & Partners, New York, and to Lowe Direct for direct marketing. Billings were not disclosed. * Bankers Trust, New York, to Caroline Jones Advertising, New York, with undetermined billings. * Metromedia/ITT Long Distance, Secaucus, N.J., to the Richards Group, Dallas, with undisclosed billings. * Riddell Activewear, New York, a unit of USA Classic Inc., New York, to Goldsmith/Jeffrey, New York, with a budget of $3 million. * Callitheke Importers Ltd., a subsidairy of Paddington Corp., Fort Lee, N.J., to Grace & Rothschild Advertising, for its Aqua Libra sparkling herbal fruit drink account, with a budget between $2 million and $3 million. * Dunham Shoe Co., Brattleboro, Vt., to Doyle Advertising and Design Group, Boston, with a budget of $1.5 million. * Allied-Lyons P.L.C., London, a food and drink company, to Zenith, London, the media unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., for media buying, with a budget of $:45 million, or nearly $88 million. The creative end of the account will still be handled by various British agencies. * National Foods Inc., New York, to HDM, New York, for the Hebrew National account. Billings are $3 million. * Cub Foods, Stillwater, Minn., a subsidiary of Super Valu Stores Inc., Eden Prairie, Minn., to Cliff Freeman and Partners, New York, with an undisclosed budget. * Continental Cargo, the freight division of Continental Airlines, to Taylor Brown Smith & Perrault, Houston, with undisclosed billings. * Sonoma Mission Inn & Spa, Sonoma, Calif., a subsidiary of Rahn Property, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Norcal Waste Systems Inc., San Francisco, to Muhlhauer & Young, San Francisco. Billings have not been determined. * Bausch & Lomb Inc., Rochester to Arnell/Bickford Associates, New York, for advertising and corporate redesigning, with a budget between $1 million and $2 million. * Bata Shoe Organization, New York, to Partners & Shevack, New York, with billings of $2 million.

headline: B. P. Asset Sale For $217 Million
abstract: LEAD: The British Petroleum Company agreed to sell the companies holding its exploration and production interests in New Zealand to Fletcher Challenge Ltd. for about $217 million. The company said the interests included an 18.75 percent stake in the offshore Maui field and a 37.5 percent ownership in the onshore Kapuni field.

headline: Financing Of UAL Bid Hits Snag
abstract: LEAD: The unions seeking to buy the parent of United Airlines said yesterday that they had failed to persuade enough banks to finance their bid, forcing them to present a bid with less cash than the $2 billion they had sought.

headline: Rationale Behind Milken Sentence
abstract: SINCE Michael R. Milken was sentenced last month, the legal community has been split over the fairness of the decision. But like several aspects of the criminal case, many arguments in the debate are based on misconceptions.    In giving Mr. Milken 10 years in prison, Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood has been criticized and praised for what has widely been seen as an attempt to put pressure on the former financier to cooperate with Government investigations.

headline: A Promotion At The Times
abstract: LEAD: The appointment of James A. Cutie as vice president for marketing at The New York Times has been announced by Lance R. Primis, president and general manager of the newspaper.

headline: The U.S. Claim Against Drexel
abstract: THERE is an old joke about a man who said he had sold his dog for $100,000. Well, actually, he explained when pressed, it wasn't for cash. "I got two $50,000 cats in trade."   In essence, that is like some of the transactions that the Government cited yesterday in asserting a multibillion-dollar claim against the bankrupt Drexel Burnham Lambert Group. The Government said that such transactions enabled the participants to report large and phony profits, and then to take that money out of savings associations that were destined to fail, leaving the Government holding the bag.

headline: Dublin Journal; New President Sees a 'New Ireland'; Could She Be a Startling Beginning?
abstract: President Mary Robinson's sharpest political weapon may be the power of being there.   President Robinson, Ireland's first woman to hold that office, was elected last month as the candidate of the small, leftist Labor Party. The 46-year-old human rights lawyer began her run for the presidency as a 100-to-1 outsider.

headline: Back to Basic Trading?
abstract: Since the announcement of my impending role at the New York Stock Exchange, I have been meeting with a cross section of people involved in and affected by equities investment and trading. What I have heard can be summed up in a word: Dissatisfaction.   People are dissatisfied with how the industry has performed -- and not just because the market has turned down. They see that the focus of the industry has changed to include diverse activities. As clients, they are not convinced that those activities are in their best interests.

headline: Market Place; Some Fast Profits In British Utilities
abstract: AMID a blaze of publicity and some resentment, one of the last big British privatizations took effect yesterday. Those lucky enough to buy shares in 12 regional electric utilities at the initial offering prices showed substantial profits, but part of those gains faded later in the day.    The selling was the climax of a huge campaign to sell the shares to individual British investors, who were given preference in buying and discounts on their utility bills if they bought shares. But for practical and logistical reasons, many individuals were unable to seize the quick profits available when the shares began trading yesterday.

headline: Rival Shiite Groups in Lebanon Agree to a Truce
abstract: Rival Shiite Muslim factions that have been battling for three years for control of southern Lebanon agreed today to a cease-fire and said they would allow army troops to be deployed in a region near Israel.    The two factions, the mainstream Shiite Muslim militia Amal and the Party of God, its pro-Iranian rival, said they would free all prisoners and normalize their relations under the agreement, reached under the auspices of their backers, Syria and Iran.

headline: European Community Office In Athens Struck by Missiles
abstract: Two antitank missiles crashed into the European Community's offices in downtown Athens late today, causing damage and slightly injuring two passers-by, the police said.   No group immediately claimed responsibility, but when the offices were bombed a year ago the Revolutionary Popular Struggle, a leftist group, said it was responsible.   The regional police chief, Simeon Papadogiorgos, said today's explosion was caused by two antitank missiles.   A spokesman at police headquarters did not say whether there were employees in the office at the time or whether the usual police guards were at the building's entrance. Two women at a nearby bus stop were slightly injured by flying glass, the spokesman said.   Greece's most notorious urban guerrilla group, November 17, has used antitank missiles in the past in an attack on a United States-based multinational corporation and on a Greek shipowner. The group is opposed to Greece's membership in the European Community and NATO and to the American military presence in Greece.

headline: U.S. and Saudi Forces Hold Exercise Near Kuwait
abstract: The United States and Saudi Arabia carried out an amphibious landing exercise in northeastern Saudi Arabia today that involves about 1,000 marines, 16 warships and more than 1,100 aircraft, including virtually all the American warplanes in the Persian Gulf region.    The six-day training maneuver, known as Imminent Thunder, is by far the largest and most ambitious of three amphibious landing drills that American forces have conducted since they were sent to the gulf. Two smaller exercises were carried out in Oman.

headline: Russian Sees Hussein and Is Hopeful
abstract: LEAD: An envoy of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union said today that he was more hopeful of a peaceful settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis after two days of talks with President Saddam Hussein and other Iraqi leaders.

headline: Hussein Won't Order Pullout Unless Imperiled, C.I.A. Says
abstract: William H. Webster, Director of Central Intelligence, said today that United States intelligence experts had concluded that President Saddam Hussein will not withdraw Iraqi troops from Kuwait until he is convinced he is "in peril of immediate military attack."   Mr. Webster's statement, which is similar to those made recently by other Administration officials, came in an interview with The Washington Post.   Mr. Webster said that President Hussein is expected to try to stretch out the Persian Gulf crisis until the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for the withdrawal of Iraqi troops, and that the Iraqi President would continue to believe he can succeed "until the first shell is lobbed over him."

headline: Arab Countries in the Middle: Leverage With the Adversaries Is Growing
abstract: The Arab countries that have expressed opposition to the United States military presence in the Persian Gulf as well as Iraq's invasion of Kuwait are likely to play an enhanced diplomatic role in the weeks ahead as Washington and its allies in the gulf crisis edge closer to war with Iraq, Arab officials and Western diplomats in the Middle East and North Africa say.    While Western diplomats say they believe that the Soviet Union, which has sent three high-level diplomatic missions to Baghdad since the Aug. 2 invasion, can best convince President Saddam Hussein that the anti-Iraq alliance is prepared to use military force, those officials say the Arab countries that have taken a more neutral position in the conflict -- among them Algeria, Jordan, and Yemen -- are best placed to persuade Mr. Hussein that war will be futile and have devastating consequences for his country and the region.

headline: Army Warnings Won't Stop Bush If War Is Needed, U.S. Aides Say
abstract: Warnings from some military commanders that American troops will not be ready for action by Jan. 15 will not constrain President Bush from ordering military action if he thinks it is necessary, senior Administration officials said today.   The White House was aware of the military's concerns about readiness when it agreed at the United Nations to a resolution fixing a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait or face the use of force by the American-led military coalition, the officials said.

headline: A Yugoslav Republic Holds a Contested Election
abstract: Voters in the central Yugoslav republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina cast ballots today in the first multiparty parliamentary elections here in more than half a century.    The results of the voting will officially end 45 years of one-party rule in the republic, whose Communist regime was once reputed to be the harshest in Yugoslavia, and its outcome will likely be of importance to the future cohesion of Yugoslavia.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: Pakistani Election: Will the Result Be More Political Uncertainty?
abstract: In an election that could create more political uncertainties than it resolves, Pakistani voters are being asked on Wednesday to give their verdict on the dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto in August.    Voting takes place from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. here, with final results not expected until Thursday Eastern time.

headline: Where All That Gas Goes: Drivers' Thirst for Power
abstract: The United States' dependence on Persian Gulf oil can be explained in part by a tale of two Chevys.   The two 1990 Chevrolet Corsicas look alike and have identical legroom, headroom and trunk space. The difference is in the engines: one takes the car from a standstill to 60 miles an hour in less than 10 seconds and travels 22 miles on a gallon of gasoline. The other takes about four seconds longer to reach 60 miles an hour, but gets five more miles to the gallon.

headline: New Chief Is Optimistic At Alliant Techsystems
abstract: Toby G. Warson is off and running as president and chief executive of a new public company that makes ammunition and other military products -- just as the nation's military spending flattens out.    But Mr. Warson, who heads Alliant Techsystems Inc., which until recently was part of Honeywell Inc., said he was optimistic about the business.

headline: New Twist in Pickens Fight
abstract: A long, bitter and sometimes comic battle for control between T. Boone Pickens and the Koito Manufacturing Company took another indecisive twist today when Mr. Pickens disclosed that he had bought Koito stock with a loan from a well-known speculator. But Mr. Pickens, the corporate raider from Texas, refused to reveal any terms of their financial relationship.    Mr. Pickens made the disclosure in response to a change in Japanese law that forces large shareholders to provide information on their stakes, intentions and financing.

headline: Bulgarian Premier's Backers and Foes Clash
abstract: About 30,000 demonstrators rallied to back Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov today, one day after he narrowly survived a no-confidence vote. Opponents of his Socialist Government blocked a main boulevard in protest.   Some fights broke out between Government supporters and opponents, but hundreds of police officers intervened to prevent serious clashes.

headline: INDIA READY TO BAR HINDU MOVE TODAY
abstract: The besieged state Uttar Pradesh is all but sealed off from the rest of India tonight as a state government loyal to Prime Minister V. P. Singh tries to prevent a disputed mosque from being overrun Tuesday by 10,000 militant Hindus determined to build a temple on the site.   Mr. Singh's determination to stop the campaign, which is pulling up from the depth of India a religious fervor that modern leaders had hoped was a thing of the past, has put the Prime Minister's political future in jeopardy.

headline: Maker of Schizophrenia Drug Bows to Pressure to Cut Cost
abstract: In the latest example of a drug maker bowing to pressure from Congress and the public over high-priced medicines, a Swiss-owned company has decided to make a sharp cut in the cost of treatment with a drug that helps thousands of schizophrenia patients. The treatment has been rejected by many Federal and state hospitals because of its steep price.    The company, the Sandoz Pharmaceutical Corporation, has charged $8,944 for a year's supply of clozapine, but that includes a blood-monitoring system that the company insisted was necessary because of possible dangerous side effects.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Alloy Computer Products Inc., Framingham, Mass., appointed Herbert Shanzer president and chief executive, replacing Richard G. Meise for reasons that the company did not specify. * Alpharel Inc., Camarillo, Calif., a software supplier, named Neil Lynch vice president of sales and marketing. * American Corporate Funding Ltd., New York, a merchant banking subsidiary of Canadian Corporate Funding Ltd., Toronto, appointed Ronald O. Drake president. * American West Airlines, Phoenix, named John W. Timmons to the newly created position of vice president of government affairs. * Business Resources Inc., The Plains, Va., an executive search and management consulting firm, appointed Barbara J. Steinem executive vice president. * Equimark Corp., Pittsburgh, a bank holding company, named Joseph J. Whiteside executive vice president and chief financial officer, replacing Michael Jehle, who resigned. * Intelogic Trace Inc., San Antonio, a computer-maintenance concern, appointed Susan A. Mravca vice president of national accounts. * Irving Forest Products Inc., Greenwich, Conn., named Darryl M. Wharton vice president and manager of newsprint sales. * Seagram Co., Montreal, appointed Jack M. Cooper vice president and chief operating officer of its worldwide information systems and services unit in New York. * Walt Disney Co., Burbank, Calif., named John Skipper vice president of magazine publishing. Disney, Walt

headline: Navistar Expands Mexico Truck Pact
abstract: The Navistar International Corporation said it had more than tripled its stake in Mexico's largest truck builder, Dina Camiones, to 17 percent, and agreed to supply Dina with as many as 5,000 diesel engines annually. The supply agreement "stabilizes the current production levels" at Navistar's Melrose Park engine plant outside Chicago, but it does not guarantee against layoffs, a spokesman, William H. Greenhill, said.   Navistar, based in Chicago, is North America's largest manufacturer of medium and heavy trucks. It did not disclose financial terms of the agreement. Navistar previously owned 5 percent of Dina, a private corporation created in 1989 as the Mexican Government denationalized segments of the automotive industry.

headline: Planes and Reservists In Gulf to Be Increased
abstract: The Pentagon said today that it was sending more F-15 Eagle fighter jets to the Persian Gulf area, and the Army announced more callups of National Guard and Reserve personnel.   Elements of the 36th Tactical Fighter Wing at Bitburg, Germany, will be deployed to the Middle East starting on Dec. 28, the Pentagon said. It did not say how many planes would go, but a tactical fighter wing normally includes about 70 aircraft.   The Air Force has recently disclosed deployments of a variety of additional aircraft to the gulf, including F-117A "Stealth" fighter-bombers, F-111 medium-range bombers, A-10 tank killers and OA-10 observation planes.   The F-15's from Bitburg will give the United States greater air-to-air combat capability in the event of war with Iraq. The aircraft are armed with Sidewinder and Sparrow missiles and a 20-millimeter Gatling gun.   An undisclosed number of F-15's were sent to the gulf in August from the First Tactical Fighter Wing at Langley Air Force Base, Va., and from the Fourth Tactical Fighter Wing at Seymour Johnson Air Force Base, N.C.   In its announcement, the Army said it had ordered 1,457 members of National Guard and Reserve units in 20 states to active duty to support services including cargo transport, medical service and civil affairs.   The Army callups brought to 120,281 the number of reservists called to active duty in all four services.

headline: In Korea Talks, Still a Gulf of Distrust
abstract: Three months ago, North and South Korea began a series of high-level talks, cautious but hopeful about airing their differences politely and reducing tensions that have kept them in a state of hostility since the Korean War ended in 1953.     But as the third round of discussions adjourn today, the gulf of suspicion between Seoul and Pyongyang seemed as wide as ever, perhaps even wider, with each nation accusing the other of using the talks for subversion instead of understanding.

headline: U.S. AND MOSCOW SEEK ANGOLA UNIT
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union, taking part directly in Angola's peace talks for the first time, have indicated their willingness to police a potential cease-fire and elections to end the 15-year civil war, American, Soviet and Angolan officials said today.

headline: Soldiers Have Some Beefs for the Boss
abstract: LEAD: The men of the headquarters supply platoon of the Second Squadron of the Army's Fourth Cavalry Regiment had a few things they wanted to get off their chests.

headline: Hostages Mark Thanksgiving
abstract: Whether they ate turkey or tuna, Americans trappede in Iraq and Kuwait tried to celebrate the holiday despite the threat of war. Page A16.

headline: Text of Resolution On the Palestinians
abstract: Following are the texts of the resolution adopted today by the Security Council on protecting Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories and the statement by the Council President backing a Middle East peace conference: Resolution 681  THE SECURITY COUNCIL,    REAFFIRMING the obligations of Members States under the United Nations Charter,    REAFFIRMING FURTHER the principle of the inadmissibility of the acquisition of territory by war set forth in Security Council resolution 242 (1967),    HAVING RECEIVED the report of the Secretary General submitted in accordance with Security Council resolution 672 (1990) on ways and means for insuring the safety and protection of the Palestinian civilians under Israeli occupation and in particular taking note of paragraphs 20-26 therein (S/21919),    TAKING NOTE of the interest of the Secretary General to visit and send his envoy to pursue his initiative with the Israeli authorities, as indicated in paragraph 22 of the report of the Secretary General (S/21919), and of their recent invitation extended to him,    GRAVELY CONCERNED at the dangerous deterioration of the situation in all the Palestinian territories occupied by Israel since 1967, including Jerusalem, and at the violence and rising tension in Israel,    TAKING INTO CONSIDERATION the statement made by the President of the Security Council on 20 December, 1990 concerning the method and approach for a comprehensive, just and lasting peace in the Arab-Israeli conflict,    RECALLING its Resolutions 607 (1988), 608 (1988), 636 (1989) and 641 (1989) and alarmed by the decision of the Government of Israel to deport four Palestinians from the occupied territories in contravention of its obligations under the Fourth Geneva Convention,    1. EXPRESSES its appreciation to the Secretary General for his report contained in document S/21919;    2. EXPRESSES its grave concern over the rejection by Israel of Security Council resolutions 672 (1990) and 673 (1990);    3. DEPLORES the decision by the Government of Israel, the occupying power, to resume deportations of Palestinian civilians in the occupied territories;    4. URGES the Government of Israel to accept de jure applicability of the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 to all the territories occupied by Israel since 1967, and to abide scrupulously by the provisions of the said Convention;    5. CALLS ON the high contracting parties to the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 to insure respect by Israel, the occupying power, for its obligations under the Fourth Geneva Convention in accordance with Article 1;    6. REQUESTS the Secretary General in cooperation with the International Committee of the Red Cross to develop further the idea from the report of the Secretary General (S/21919) of convening a meeting of the high contracting parties to the Fourth Geneva Convention and to discuss possible measures that might be taken by them under the Convention and for this purpose to invite these parties to submit their views on how the idea could contribute to the goals of the Convention as well as on other relevant matters and to report to the Council;    7. REQUESTS the Secretary General to monitor and observe the situation regarding Palestinian civilians under Israeli occupation, making new efforts in this regard on an urgent basis, and to utilize and designate or draw upon the United Nations and other personnel and resources present there in the area and elsewhere needed to accomplish this task and to keep the Security Council regularly informed;    8. REQUESTS further the Secretary General to submit a first progress report to the Security Council by the first week of March 1991, and every four months thereafter and decides to remain seized of the matter as necessary. Council President's Statement  The members of the Security Council reaffirm their determination to support an active negotiating process in which all relevant parties should participate leading to a comprehensive, just and lasting peace to the Arab-Israeli conflict through negotiations which should be based on Resolutions 242 (1967) and 338 (1973) of the Security Council and which should take into account the right to security of all states in the region, including Israel, and the legitimate political rights of the Palestinian people.    In this context they agree that an international conference, at an appropriate time, properly structured, should facilitate efforts to achieve a negotiated settlement and lasting peace in the Arab-Israeli conflict.    However, the members of the Council are of the view that there is not unanimity as to when would be the appropriate time for such a conference.    In the view of the members of the Council, the Arab-Israeli conflict is important and unique and must be addressed independently, on its own merits.

headline: Bache Settlement Seen On Big Board Charges
abstract: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. has decided to settle charges stemming from a series of cases under investigation by the New York Stock Exchange, according to an internal memorandum from the firm.    One charge is that the firm sold $218 million worth of securities it was required to hold for customers and used the proceeds in other transactions. Prudential-Bache was censured by the Securities and Exchange Commission for that act last October. In that case the firm was censured for numerous violations of securities laws governing accounting procedures and operational controls but paid no fine.

headline: Crimean Tatars Return as Squatters, Taking Advantage of Current Chaos
abstract: Rooted in memories dark as the earth itself, the Crimean Tatars have been returning home as squatters 100,000 strong from Stalin's brutal exile, building stone huts all over the Yalta hills and beyond in a measure of the creative space that can be clawed paradoxically from the current Soviet chaos.    "In 1944 we were given 10 minutes to pack and be trucked out of here to the railroad by the Red Army, and so we began our road of death," said Ivas Mustafayev, a 55-year-old Tatar, gesturing to this land of his birth from a jerry-built Tatar fortress of bunkhouse and barbed wire here in a tobacco field that has been seized from the local state farm.

headline: Wider Corruption Found, New York Telephone Says
abstract: The president of New York Telephone yesterday described a broader problem of corruption in the company's buildings department than had been previously indicated.    Prosecutors in Manhattan have uncovered evidence of widespread abuses at the division, and more criminal indictments may result, Frederic V. Salerno, the president, said in an interview.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                  Nov. 9   Nov. 2   Nov. 10        1990   1990   1989        Gasoline production, daily   6.9   6.8   6.8        Distillate production, daily   2.9   2.9   3.0        Gasoline stocks   218.6   221.2   218.3        Distillate stocks   135.8   138.2   122.4        Crude imports, daily   4.8   5.9   5.9        Product imports, daily   2.2   1.6   1.8        Crude stocks   345.4   344.5   347.1        Crude production, daily   7.2   7.2   7.5        Refinery utilization (%)   82.7   84.5   85.4       Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: New Digital Computer Uses Standard Design
abstract: LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation plans to introduce a computer for small businesses today that contains the latest-generation Intel Corporation 486 microprocessor.

headline: Taiwan Investor Plans Chemical Plant in China
abstract: Prime Minister Li Peng is personally overseeing a proposal by Taiwan's richest industrialist to build a $7 billion petrochemical complex in China, an investment that could provide a lift to this country's hard-line leaders and its coastal economy.    The deal, if concluded, would be by far the largest single foreign investment in China. It would also represent a major challenge to Taiwan's Government, which is trying to regulate the flow of Taiwanese investment to mainland China.

headline: Some Advice To the Jobless On Wall St.
abstract: AS waves of dismissals continue on Wall Street, out-of-work analysts, brokers and investment bankers should expect keener competition as they seek new jobs, says Jan A. Cris of the Cris Group, a management recruiting firm.   "Today it is not enough just to mail out a few resumes, tell a few friends, contact a few recruiters," Ms. Cris said at a recent luncheon of the New York Society of Security Analysts. "There are a variety of other resources."

headline: Business and the Law; Prepackaging A Bankruptcy
abstract: AS more overleveraged companies admit that they cannot make the interest payments on high-yield securities they issued in the 1980's, they face the prospect of long, bitter and costly bankruptcy proceedings. Some troubled corporations are trying to cut both the time and the expense of bankruptcy reorganization by taking an approach known as the prepackaged bankruptcy.    In a prepackaged bankruptcy, the debtors and certain required majorities of each class of creditors and equity holders accept a reorganization plan before the company files for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. In such an instance, the company's management gives the bankruptcy judge a full plan that needs only the court's approval. This prepackaged plan generally results in a controlled and speedy reorganization, rather than the lengthy, expensive and treacherously unpredictable process that often follows a Chapter 11 filing.

headline: Citicorp's Reserves Stir Unease
abstract: As Federal bank examiners near the end of Citicorp's annual checkup, analysts and investors are wondering how badly the nation's largest banking company has been hurt by real estate problems and other kinds of bad loans.    Citicorp officials have acknowledged that loan losses are increasing, but have denied that the problems are so large that they would require adding billions of dollars to the company's loan-loss reserves, a move many analysts have predicted.

headline: British Telecom, I.B.M. Hold Talks
abstract: British Telecommunications P.L.C. and I.B.M. said they were holding talks but declined to comment on whether they were negotiating a partnership to sell communications and information services. The Financial Times reported this week that such a partnership was under negotiation.   British Telecom said it was "developing a strategy to provide global network services to major multinational organizations," and that it was "naturally talking to major companies such as I.B.M." The International Business Machines Corporation has been holding periodic talks with British Telecom on a variety of issues, an I.B.M. spokesman said, adding that I.B.M. does not plan to enter the telephone service business.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * BSN S.A., Paris, to TBWA Frankfurt, for its Dannon yogurt and dessert business, with a budget of $10 million. The account was previously handled by Saatchi & Saatchi. * Kiddie Products Inc., Avon, Mass., to Mullen, Wenham, Mass., for its First Years baby product account. * Dugan/Farley Communications Associates Inc., Upper Saddle River, N.J., resigned Glenbrook Laboratories, a division of Sterling Drug Inc. The agency, which worked with the company for 17 years, handled various Bayer Aspirin accounts.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Skytel Corp., a subsidiary of Mobile Telecommunication Technologies Corp., Jackson, Miss., established a $30 million revolving line of credit and term loan with Chemical Bank and the New York branch of Credit Lyonnais. Common Stock  * Broadcast International Inc., Salt Lake City, is offering 1.78 million common shares at $7.50 a share through William Blair & Co. * Western Oceanic Inc., a subsidiary of the Western Company of North America, Houston, is withdrawing from a proposed initial public offering of 6 million common shares, citing unfavorable market conditions. Ratings  * ACF Industries, a subsidiary of Icahn & Co. based in Earth City, Mo., had the rating of its equipment trust certificates lowered to Ba-3, from Ba-2, by Moody's Investors Service, which also reduced the rating on senior debentures to B-2, from Ba-3.  * Midlantic Corp., Edison, N.J., had its senior debt rating and the senior rating of its Midlantic Bank unit lowered to BB-, from BBB-, by Standard & Poor's.

headline: U.S. Unlikely to Use Force to Resupply Embassy
abstract: A United Nations effort to arrange for the resupply of the American and British Embassies in Kuwait has stalled, but Administration officials say they are not likely to use military force to restock the missions with food and other supplies.   A week after President Bush expressed anger at Iraqi isolation of the embassy and at least one aide floated a number of military contingency plans to deliver food, Administration officials said keeping the embassy open was a less important objective than giving the trade embargo against Iraq more time to take hold.

headline: Soviet Army Surrenders a Towering Symbol of Its Victory in Berlin
abstract: For decades, the stern soldier's presence gripped the center of Berlin, his sculptured glare cast out across the Brandenburg Gate, his broad stride unbroken even as the ranks of the Soviet soldiers still based in Germany falter.    But today the towering statue of a Soviet infantryman, the chief monument to the victorious Red Army on the soil of what used to be the Western sector of Berlin, was handed over to the former enemy for safekeeping.

headline: Black Hole in Television;   Nielsen's 'People Meter' Has Engendered A Revolution by Showing a Fall in Viewers
abstract: LEAD: Like Galileo's observation that the earth revolves around the sun, the A. C. Nielsen Company's report of an unexpectedly sharp drop in the national television audience last winter has altered the accepted view of reality. And like the telescope Galileo used, a new instrument - the ''people meter'' - provided the new information.

headline: Mandela Tells Blacks to Intensify Campaign
abstract: Nelson Mandela has urged supporters to "intensify the struggle" against white minority rule, using "legitimate peaceful means" like protest marches, strikes and consumer boycotts.    His remarks, delivered on Sunday at a rally in the Indian community of Lenasia near Johanneburg, underscored the aggressive course upon which the African National Congress has embarked against the Government in promoting destabilizing mass action while it prepares for negotiations on the future of South Africa.

headline: A Marine General Speaks To Troops of an Offensive
abstract: A senior American military commander here told his troops today that it is now possible that they will launch an offensive against Iraq in the months ahead.   The statement, by Maj. Gen. Robert M. Johnston of the Marines, a leading member of the American command in Saudi Arabia, was repeated by other senior officers today as they reacted to President Bush's decision to send at least 150,000 reinforcements to Saudi Arabia "to provide an adequate offensive military option" if economic sanctions against Iraq are deemed insufficient.

headline: Leningrad Mayor, in U.S., Seeks Economic Tie
abstract: The Mayor of Leningrad met today with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d; the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and the Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell, seeking "new forms of economic relations" between the United States and the Soviet Union.    He also had a chance to exchange a handshake and brief greeting with President Bush.

headline: No Headline
abstract: LEAD: A united Germany's first Ambassador to Israel presented his credentials to President Chaim Herzog today and assured Israelis they had nothing to fear from his country's unification. Otto von der Gablentz, 60 years old, is the first Ambassador accredited to a foreign country since the two Germanys were unified on Oct.

headline: U.S. Urges Britain to Ease Bid for Reparations by Iraq
abstract: LEAD: The United States is urging Britain to tone down a resolution it plans to introduce in the Security Council that would require Iraq to pay compensation for damage resulting from the invasion of Kuwait, diplomats say. They say Washington fears that the third world would demand similar action against Israel for its occupation of land claimed by

headline: Rates Fall as Fed Becomes Focus
abstract: LEAD: Long-term interest rates fell sharply and Treasury bond prices rose yesterday, in reaction to several positive developments, including the 11-hour agreement to cut the Federal budget deficit announced on Sunday.

headline: G.M. CUTS OUTPUT IN THE LATEST SIGN OF ECONOMIC SLUMP
abstract: The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest industrial company, said today that it was sharply cutting back its production for the rest of the year because of the weakening American economy.   The cutbacks reflect the company's pessimistic outlook for American car and truck sales, which General Motors said had been made worse by the economic uncertainty since the Persian Gulf crisis began and dwindling consumer confidence.

headline: Oil Company Campaigns Attracting Some Criticism
abstract: OIL companies like Texaco Inc. and the Amoco Corporation are running advertising urging consumers to conserve oil, but some marketing and oil industry executives said these campaigns were not likely to create much good will for their sponsors.   The message of the campaigns is to use less gas, home heating oil and electricity. But some marketing experts and oil industry executives said the oil companies were wasting their time and money if their goal was to change consumer behavior.

headline: Police and Tax Protesters Clash in London
abstract: LEAD: At least 9 people were injured and 91 arrested today when violence broke out during protests here against Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's unpopular new local tax.

headline: Patents; A Powdered Mouthwash With Fizz
abstract: An entrepreneur and a dentist in Houston have patented a way to prepare mouthwashes and medicines like cough syrup in powder form, capable of dissolving in water or fizzing into action when popped into the mouth.    The new preparations are said to be more convenient than their liquid counterparts because they can be carried more compactly.

headline: MINIMUM-TAX PROVISIONS EXPECTED TO SNARE MANY
abstract: Many taxpayers who have not had to worry about the alternative minimum tax may find themselves trapped by it in future years as a result of the deficit-reduction package approved by Congress on Saturday, tax professionals warn.   The provision is the tax code's variation on "good cop-bad cop": People who have managed to give themselves too favorable a tax situation under the regular rules, through various deductions or by income that is given preferential treatment, must pay taxes under an alternative, more stringent set of rules.

headline: Amoco's Profits Rise 57.7%; Surge Reflects Asset Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that its quarterly earnings rose 57.7 percent from the 1989 period. The profit surge reflected an unusual gain of $149 million derived from the sale by Amoco of its refining and marketing company in Britain, not sharply higher crude oil prices. Operating profits fell.

headline: Language Bill Weighed as Slovak Separatists Rally
abstract: Demonstrators shouted for a separate Slovak state today as thousands poured into the streets and squares around Parliament for rallies held by opposing groups.    The meetings were called as the Slovak National Council, the legislature of this constituent republic, prepared to vote on Thursday on a bill to make Slovak the only official language and force the population of 600,000 thnic Hungarians to use only Slovak in dealing with the authorities.

headline: Deficit Up In October
abstract: The Federal Government opened the 1991 fiscal year with a $31.5 billion deficit in October, the Treasury Department said today.    The monthly budget gap was 21 percent higher than the $26.1 billion deficit of October 1989. The increase reflects the buildup of United States forces in the Persian Gulf and the rising cost of savings and loan industry bailout.    Military spending, at $24.1 billion, was up $4.9 billion, or 26 percent, from a year earlier.   Spending by the Resolution Trust Corporation to clean up bankrupt savings and loan associations was 10.7 billion, up 36 percent from $7.9 billion a year earlier.    Despite the five-year $500 billion deficit-reduction plan adopted by Congress last month, the Bush Administration has already conceded that the 1991 deficit will set a record.    In remarks last week, Richard G. Darman, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said he expected a 1991 budget gap of $250 billion to $300 billion, more if a shooting war breaks out with Iraq.    Red ink in 1990 totaled $220.4 billion, just short of the record deficit of 221.2 billion in 1986.    Government revenues in October totaled $78.7 billion, up 15 percent from a yearl earlier, while spending amounted to $110.2 billion, up 17 percent.

headline: Consortium To Buy Intel Computer
abstract: A consortium of 14 United States research institutions led by the California Institute of Technology is scheduled to announce today that it will purchase a custom-designed supercomputer from the Intel Corporation to help solve a series of scientific "grand challenges."   The project, known as the Concurrent Supercomputing Consortium, is one of the most significant endorsements to date of a style of computing known as parallel processing, which chains together many processors and breaks up problems to solve them more quickly.

headline: CONCEDING A CRISIS, GORBACHEV VOWS TO SHIFT LEADERS
abstract: Conceding that his country was paralyzed by political stalemate and sinking deeper into economic crisis, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today promised a shake-up of Government and military leaders to win back diminishing public support.    But the Soviet leader, who was summoned by Parliament to give an emergency report on the state of the union, rejected demands that he form a coalition government with non-Communists and insisted that the constituent Soviet republics accept a new union treaty preserving the country's federal structure.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9.5-10   9.5-10   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   6.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   10.00   7.25   9.37        3-MO.
