headline: BUSINESS DIARY/Dec. 9-14, 1990
abstract: INTERNATIONAL After 15 Years, Washington Looks to Moscow's Hunger  The question is, will Western aid for the Soviet Union furnish a down payment on economic progress, or a drunken, delirious banquet likely to end in deeper despair? Russian citizens and American scholars wonder. President Bush last week approved $1 billion in Federal credits for the Soviet Union, lifting a 15-year ban on such aid with the goal of easing Soviet food shortages. The United States rejected European calls for full Soviet membership in the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, saying the Soviets should receive only Special Association status pending further economic reforms. Many Soviets feel the kindest deed they can do for foreigners bringing money and supplies is to warn that their fellow Russians are cheats, profiteers and thieves. Using the K.G.B. to police food distribution is hardly reassuring. The K.G.B. officer trying to sell his high-crested hat to tourists one day is unlikely to to keep his hands off Western goodies the next. Dyed-in-the-Wood Gorbachev  Under the skin, deep inside, is Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev really another Brezhnev? A Khrushchev? A Stalin, or Lenin, perhaps? Moscow souvenir-hunters can count up the implications of the nesting wooden dolls of Soviet leaders sold along the Arbat, the pedestrian mall. They are a 1990's version of the traditional    matrushka    dolls, which, in Brezhnev's and Stalin's times, invariably depicted maidens, soldiers and other politically safe subjects. The doll vendors are evidently taking advantage of Mr. Gorbachev's encouragement of free markets, hawking Gorby dolls for $20 (hundreds of rubles).   Mexico's Telephone Sale For many Mexicans, a long-distance or international call means a trip to the Telmex office, an hour's wait and charges equal to a day's salary. Last week, the Mexican Government said it would sell Telefonos de Mexico for $1.76 billion to a group that has agreed to bring a donkey-and-cart system into the airline era. The sale, to Grupo Carso of Mexico, the Southwestern Bell Corporation and France Telecom is the latest sign of the country's willingness to accept American investment, according to Sidney Weintraub, a professor at the University of Texas Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs. He added that the United States is meanwhile becoming more hesitant about the free flow of goods and money across its southern border. "I find that role-reversal ironic," he said.  Post-Hammer Occidental  Maybe Armand Hammer kept going for all those years partly to frustrate the traders who always bid up Occidental Petroleum on rumors of his demise. He died on Monday at the age of 92, the day before his planned bar mitzvah. The stock jumped 1 7/8 to 22 5/8 on Tuesday. Dr. Hammer was long the Soviet Union's favorite capitalist; tour guides at the Lenin Museum in Moscow point out the small statue, a gift from Dr. Hammer, that still sits on Lenin's desk. At Occidental, Dr. Hammer ran his own command economy, purging top aides and spending company funds on an art museum to house his collection, no matter what other stockholders said. Analysts expect Dr. Hammer's patient successor, Ray R. Irani, to introduce perestroika, possibly selling the company's 51 percent interest in IBP Inc., a major meat packer, as well as coal and natural gas operations, to concentrate on chemicals and oil. In Brief  Eastern Airlines might still be falsifying its maintenance records, according to a court document released last week. Eastern and several employees were indicted by a Federal grand jury in July on charges of falsely recording repairs.  The strong German mark, it would seem, buys more in the United States. The largest German utility, RWE A.G., agreed on Thursday to pay $590 million for the Vista Chemical Company. The offer, $55 a share, was more than double the previous day's closing price of $25.    THE ECONOMY   Spreading Recession  The worst monthly decline in industrial production since 1982 confirmed the views of many economists that the current recession is unlikely to be mild. Output fell 1.7 percent last month, with automobile production especally weak. "Almost every sector is declining now," said Lawrence Krohn, an economist at Shearson Lehman. He expects production declines to moderate but continue for several months. Not to worry about November's five-tenths of 1 percent rise in producer prices, he added. "Anyone who looks for an acceleration of inflation given this depressed environment will be mistaken," he said. New England Bailout  The Bush Administration placed more than $1 billion in Treasury deposits in the ailing Bank of New England this year just as worried depositors were withdrawing billions. Treasury officials denied that the bank had receieved special aid. But the Senate Banking Committee and the General Accounting Office have opened their own inquiries. Retail sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent in November -- no surprise to the store managers who are resorting to pre-Christmas sales. COMPANIES   CBS Dumps the Cash  The implosion of CBS Inc. continues. It was a premier television network with record and magazine businesses besides; then, a network with a huge pile of cash; soon, just a network with lagging profits and a smaller pile of cash. CBS offered on Thursday to buy back about 44 percent of its stock for $190 a share, using about two-thirds of its $3 billion in cash. The immediate cause was the need for the heirs of William S. Paley, the company's founder, to pay estate taxes. But some analysts said the company's president, Laurence A. Tisch, could find no better use for the cash. Or maybe, some said, Larry the Liquidator wants to trim the company down so it can be acquired in one easily digested bite. Mr. Tisch was greeted as a white knight when he invested in CBS in 1986. Now, some there question his colors. Equitable Passes the Hat  That man in front of a midtown Manhattan skyscraper ringing a bell and seeking contributions might be from the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. The needy insurance company announced last week that it plans to raise about $500 million by offering stock to the public. Like most other major life insurers, Equitable has been a mutual company, owned by its policyholders. Losses on "junk bonds" and real estate have forced the company to raise capital. Analysts expect other impoverished insurers to follow Equitable's examples. Power Over Cable?  Communities would have more power to limit the cost of cable television service under new rules the Federal Communications Commission proposed last week. The measures could be enacted as early as the spring. An Animated Separation  Call off the caterers. Cancel the hall. Mickey Mouse and Miss Piggie have broken off their engagement because their families just can't get along. The Walt Disney Company said on Thursday that it has abandoned its planned acquisition of Henson Associates Inc. and its Muppets. After Jim Henson, the Muppets' creator, died in May, some industry executives say, his five children became rather piggy themselves, refusing to reduce their $100 million-plus asking price. Disney maintained that buying Henson Associates without Henson was like buying Kermit the Tadpole. Kerkorian Targets Chrysler  With the Chrysler Corporation smelling like carrion in the desert, sooner or later a vulture was bound to appear. On Friday, Kirk Kerkorian, the takeover artist who rules his own arid kingdom of Las Vegas casinos and hotels, emerged as the owner of 9.8 percent of Chrysler's shares, which cost him $277 million. The Chrysler board did its best on Friday to make the company unappetizing, offering to sell new shares at less than market value if anyone acquires more than 10 percent of its stock. Some analysts say Chrysler is so weak that, to avoid falling prey to an enemy, it needs to sell out to a wealthy, protective friend. NCR Spurns A.T.&T.  NCR and A.T.& T. are taking their public battle to the stockholders. The NCR Corporation board unanimously rejected a $90-a-share buyout offer last week from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. NCR chairman Charles E. Exley Jr. plans to visit major institutional investors so as to urge them to keep their stock out of A.T.& T.'s hands. The telephone company, for its part, has threatened a proxy fight against the NCR board.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Ciatti Inc., Minneapolis, an operator of Italian restaurants, appointed Christopher L. Collier vice president and chief financial officer. * Davox Corp., Billerica, Mass., which produces computer-aided communications systems, named Lawrence Doherty vice president of finance and chief financial officer. * Donnelly Corp., Holland, Mich., a producer of rear-view mirrors and digital products, named John W. Carter, Donald G. Auch and Cleon C. Morgan vice presidents. * Murdoch Magazines Distribution, a division of Murdoch Magazines, New York, appointed John Robert Amann vice president of single-copy sales. * Playtex Family Products Corp., Stamford, Conn., promoted Calvin J. Gauss to president. * Poughkeepsie Savings Bank, Poughkeepsie, N.Y., named Christoph Schmidt president, replacing Michael Feeks, who resigned. * Raymond James & Associates, a subsidiary of Raymond James Financial Inc., St. Petersburg, Fla., named Thomas S. Franke president and chief operating officer. * Saks Fifth Avenue, New York, a division of Investcorp Bahrain, named Ann Keenes senior vice president of direct marketing. * Southwestern Bell Corp., St. Louis, promoted Donald E. Kiernan to senior vice president of finance and treasurer. * Zacks & Perrier Inc., New York, a media and staged-events producing company, appointed James F. Ryan president and chief executive.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE ECONOMY   Delinquent mortgages at Citicorp increased substantially in the third quarter to 3.6 percent of the dollar amount or loans, up from 3 percent at June 30, with much of the rise coming from the economically depressed Northeast.  [ Page D1. ]   Home building plunged 6 percent in October, the Commerce Department said, extending the longest slide on record and putting starts at their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession.  [ D1. ]   Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged bankers and Government regulators to make loans more readily available.  [ D1. ]   Americans consume 40 percent of the world's gasoline, even though they make up only 4 percent of the world's population.  [ A1. ]   Michael R. Milken is to be sentenced today on six felony charges to which he pleaded guilty. He faces a maximum of 28 years in prison, but legal experts generally predict 2 to 10 years. Whatever sentence Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood hands down, the experts say, controversy will follow.  [ D1. ]   Store executives across the nation, foreseeing a disappointing Christmas season, are cutting back on merchandise and holding sales. But a few see hope in their early November sales.  [ D1. ]   An aide to Senator John McCain testified that she warned the Arizona Republican that his colleague, Senator Dennis DeConcini, was seeking to press Mr. McCain into improper negotiations with regulators on behalf of a savings unit executive.  [ B8. ] MARKETS    The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 35.15 points, to 2530.20, as Boeing led blue chip stocks sharply downward.  [ D1. ]   Oil prices fell sharply as traders concluded that a military confrontation with Iraq was unlikely anytime soon.  [ D6. ]   The dollar rose against most major currencies, particularly the British pound.  [ D17. ]  Grain prices skidded on the Chicago Board of Trade, in the absence of a food aid plan for Moscow.  [ D17. ]   Prices of Treasury securities rose, and interest rates fell in thin trading in response to a 3.29-point drop in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 leading commodity prices to 223.15, its lowest level since July 1989.  [ D16. ]  Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mostly lower.  [ D20. ] COMPANIES    Mollie Raab, the wife of Genentech's president and chief executive, G. Kirk Raab, was fined $162,400 by the S.E.C. in settlement of an insider trading case.  [ D2. ]   JMB Realty confirmed reports that it would slow its pace of buying and developing shopping centers and office buildings.  [ D4. ]   CBS will cut program payments to its affiliated stations by 20 percent, the network said, saving about $30 million a year.  [ D4. ]   The Daily News announced that it was filing civil suits against 11 individual strikers, who, it said, have hurt newspaper sales.  [ B2. ] BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY    Electronics and computer companies are introducing products to link computers with light, radio and microwave signals, to lessen the snarl of wiring in offices.  [ D9. ]   The aluminum can is now taking on the market for noncarbonated beverages and foods, as well as carbonated beverages.  [ D9. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS    Redirecting the products of Europe's farm subsidies from competitive world markets to Soviet tables might solve both the trade and Soviet food problems. Peter Passell: Economic Scene.  [ D2. ]   Zenith Electronics may be running out of time to carry off a strategy to become a technology pioneer. Market Place.  [ D10. ]   The stock of London-based WPP Group tumbled on news that the company expected profits to be less than the $216 million that had been forecast by analysts. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D7. ]

headline: Mary Kay May Sell Part of Avon Stake
abstract: The Mary Kay Corporation, one of three partners in an investment group holding a sizable stake in Avon Products Inc., said it might have to sell a portion of its Avon holdings. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mary Kay said it was involved in a tax dispute with the Internal Revenue Service.   Mary Kay said the dispute might cause a subsidiary to liquidate a portion of its holdings in Avon. That subsidiary, Argonaut Partners L.P., is a member of Chartwell Associates, an investment group that holds a 19.8 percent stake in Avon. Other members of Chartwell include the Gordon P. Getty Family Trust and the Fisher real estate family of New York.

headline: 6 Corsican Villas Blown Up
abstract: Small gas bombs blew apart six vacation villas under construction on Saturday and a nationalist terrorist group claimed responsibility, the police said today. There were no casualties. The villas, in a tourist complex in Poggio-Mezanna near this northern Corsican city, were destroyed on Saturday night in separate blasts, along with two cars bearing Italian license plates, the police said. Eleven villas were destroyed on Friday in a similar incident near Calvi, also in northern Corsica.

headline: Libya Said to Expel Palestinian Guerrillas
abstract: Abul Abbas, who directed the Achille Lauro ship hijacking five years ago, said today that Libya had expelled 145 members of his group, a wing of the Palestine Liberation Front, and closed down four training camps.   Mr. Abbas said the move was a surprise. He said the ejection was unjustified and urged Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to reopen the camps and the group's offices. The Government in Tripoli has not given an explanation for its action, he said.    Reports began to surface about a week ago that Libya had expelled the Palestinians.    Arab diplomats in Baghdad said the United States had asked King Hassan of Morocco and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to press Colonel Qaddafi to eject the group. Pressure to remove Mr. Abbas increased after his group raided an Israeli beach in May, an action that led to a break in contacts between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization, with which Mr. Abbas's group is affiliated.    Colonel Qaddafi is believed to want Libya's removal from the United States State Department's list of countries supporting terrorism.

headline: Stake in Shawmut Acquired by Tisch
abstract: Laurence A. Tisch, the chief executive of CBS Inc. and the chairman of the Loews Corporation, has acquired a 5 percent stake in the Shawmut National Corporation, one of New England's largest banking companies, for $33.2 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Tisch said that he had acquired the Shawmut shares as an investment.   Mr. Tisch and members of his family have been buying the stock of several bank holding companies. Shawmut said it was pleased with the Tisch investment. Mr. Tisch acquired his 3.8 million Shawmut shares for an average price of $8.66. Shawmut's shares fell 37.5 cents today, to $5.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Illness Leads to Switch At Panhandle Eastern
abstract: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation, which operates one of the nation's largest natural gas pipeline systems, said yesterday that its chairman, president and chief executive, Philip J. Burguieres, had resigned for health reasons and been succeeded by Dennis R. Hendrix.   The Houston-based company declined to describe the medical problem of the company's 47-year-old leader. But a spokesman, James W. Hart Jr., said it was not life-threatening and that when it was resolved Mr. Burguieres planned to get back into the business world, but not at Panhandle.

headline: German Rail Workers to End Strike
abstract: Striking rail workers in eastern Germany agreed to return to work today, after the Government agreed to consider their demands for higher pay and job security.   Officials of the unions and railroad management announced agreement late Wednesday after more than six hours of talks, thus ending a brief but bitter labor conflict that sent ripples of disquiet through eastern Germany only days before national elections scheduled for Sunday.

headline: Chinese Atom-Arms Spying in U.S. Reported
abstract: Chinese intelligence agents succeeded in stealing nuclear-weapons secrets from the Government's Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in the 1980's, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation later conducted a long espionage inquiry into the theft, American intelligence experts said today.   It was unclear whether the investigation, which began about 1986, has been closed, but no one has been charged with wrongdoing.

headline: Bertelsmann Wins MCA
abstract: MCA Inc. said today that its music unit would shift its $100 million overseas distribution business from Time Warner Inc. to the Bertelsmann Music Group of Germany.    The deal hands a large portion of business to Bertelsmann just when MCA officials are discussing a buyout for as much as $8 billion by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan.   The Bertelsmann Music Group, a subsidiary of the giant media company Bertelsmann A.G., operates in 30 countries and owns labels including RCA, Arista, Zoo and Ariola.   The three-year deal calls for Bertelsmann to give MCA $37 million a year in promotion and other support. Officials of the companies said an important part of the partnership would be developing new talent.   The agreement covers the distribution and licensing of MCA, Geffen and GRP records.

headline: Bank Sues Equitable Life
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company sued the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States on Monday, claiming that Equitable failed to meet its financial obligations to a real estate partnership when it forced the partnership into bankruptcy two weeks ago. The bank is seeking $100 million in compensatory damages and $500 million in punitive damages.    Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc., a unit of the life insurance company and general partner of 1515 Broadway Associates L.P., stunned its limited partners when it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for the partnership on Oct. 15. The partnership's sole asset was an office tower at 45th and Broadway.

headline: So It Parks Itself. Where?
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Former Apple Executive Is Named Chief at Covia
abstract: Allan Z. Loren, a data processing expert who tried his hand unsuccessfully in a top sales and marketing post at Apple Computer, has been named president and chief executive of Covia, which operates the Apollo travel reservation system for a number of airlines.   Covia, which is based in Chicago, is 51 percent owned by United Airlines. The other airlines involved are British Airways, USAir, Swissair, KLM, Alitalia and Air Canada. Apollo is the second-largest reserveration system in the airline industry behind Sabre, which is owned by American Airlines.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: The Business Diary column last Sunday misstated the size of Darryl Strawberry's five-year contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers. It is $20.25 million, not $23.5 million.

headline: Pathe Finally Takes Over MGM/UA
abstract: After months of scrambling to find financing for one of the most complex deals in Hollywood's history, the Pathe Communications Corporation today completed its $1.3 billion acquisition of the MGM/UA Communications Corporation.   The deal brought to an end years of attempts by Kirk Kerkorian, the financier who controls MGM/UA, to find a buyer for the film and television studio. And it represented a vindication of sorts for Pathe's chairman, Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian investor, whose ability to raise the money to complete the transaction had been widely doubted in the entertainment industry.

headline: Action Sought On Polly Peck
abstract: A bank has moved to force the troubled British conglomerate Polly Peck International P.L.C. into bankruptcy proceedings, the bankruptcy court said.   The court in London said the National Bank of Canada filed a petition Monday against the food and electronics conglomerate, which is suffering a cash shortage. The petition asks the court to place the company in receivership so that its assets can be liquidated to meet debt payments. A hearing was scheduled for Dec. 12.   Bankers speculated that the bank intended to set out its claims against Polly Peck in the event of a rush by creditors. The hearing falls more than a month before a debt-payment standstill agreement between Polly Peck and its key lenders expires on Nov. 9.   A Polly Peck spokesman declined to comment, and officials at National Bank of Canada's London branch office were not available to comment.   Asil Nadir, Polly Peck's chairman and chief executive, has been visiting Turkey and northern Cyprus in search of financial support. Polly Peck needs about $194 million in short-term financing to get it through its liquidity squeeze, sources have said.

headline: Cuba, Hurt by Falling Soviet Imports, Makes Field Hands of Office Workers
abstract: The Government sent several hundred office workers to plant potatoes and sugar cane last week in the first phase of a program that envisions thousands of urban dwellers working for 21-day shifts in the countryside to increase food production in the face of the severest economic crisis since Fidel Castro took power 32 years ago.    With food imports from Eastern Europe quickly drying up, President Fidel Castro's Government has been forced in recent days to close barren supermarkets and add 28 food items, including fresh and frozen fish, canned meat, pasta and ketchup, to a growing list of rationed goods.

headline: Profits Up at Microsoft and Down at Lotus
abstract: LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation today reported strong gains in revenues and earnings, while the Lotus Development Corporation reported declining earnings on essentially flat sales, which it attributed to upgrading its most popular product.

headline: Delay in Trial of Suspect Accused of War Crimes Has France Astir
abstract: A Government decision that will delay the trial of an aging Frenchman accused of crimes against humanity has stirred a new debate here about France's reluctance to address its role in the deportation of thousands of Jews to Nazi death camps in World War II.   Legal experts say that by assigning the case of Rene Bousquet to a long-moribund Special High Court of the Liberation rather than to an ordinary criminal court, the Prosecutor General's Office may even have insured that he will never be brought to trial.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; New Pic 'N' Save Chief Has Retailing Expertise
abstract: The Pic 'N' Save Corporation, a close-out merchandiser based in Dominguez, Calif., near Los Angeles, said yesterday that it had found the retailing expert it was seeking to serve as president and chief executive. He is Len Williams, a retailing consultant who is a former president of the Caldor and Gold Circle chains.   Peter Willmott, a former chairman of Carson Pirie Scott & Company, was recently named chairman of Pic 'N' Save.

headline: Your Money; Rare Opportunity In the 28% Bracket
abstract: STANLEY BREITBARD, national director of personal financial services for Price Waterhouse in Los Angeles, calculates that some taxpayers who are in the 28 percent bracket this year have a rare opportunity in the next few weeks to make investments that yield double-digit rates of return after taxes, with virtually no risk.   The idea may sound too good to be true, but it is one of the anomalies of the deficit reduction package Congress approved last Saturday. With the top tax rate on ordinary income scheduled to rise to 31 percent in 1991, many tax professionals are recommending that people who are now taxed at 28 percent bring income forward into this year, if possible. That group would include couples with taxable income above $185,730 this year, or $208,690 if they have two dependents, as well as some couples with taxable incomes below $78,400.

headline: NEUTRAL NATIONS LOOKING TO EUROPE
abstract: The end of the cold war and the beginning of a recession have plunged the neutral welfare states of Western Europe into an identity crisis.   Most are nearly falling over themselves to join the European Community in the hope that membership will bring a return to prosperity and a new vision of the future to replace the "Swedish model" of political neutrality between East and West, extensive social-welfare programs and an economy combining capitalism with a sizable public sector.

headline: Bucharest Journal; The Hurdles Are Many, but the Reward Is a Child
abstract: Moved by pictures she had seen of the desperate conditions in Romanian orphanages, Linda Tresgaskis came here from Austin, Tex., for the first time last July to find a year-old child to take home with her.    She recently came through a crash course in the ordeals of Romanian adoption with flying colors -- and a 2-week-old son named Charles Michael.

headline: Merger of Law Shows Seen
abstract: Time Warner Inc. and the Cablevision Systems Corporation are preparing to merge their planned cable channels dealing with the legal profession, people close to both companies said yesterday,   Time Warner has been planning to start a service in 1991 tentatively called The Legal Channel. It is to be run by Steven Brill, founder of The American Lawyer, the magazine in which Time Warner bought a stake last year. The service would cover trials in the 44 states in which television cameras are permitted in the courtroom.    Cablevision is preparing to begin In Court, also a 24-hour trial coverage service, early in 1991. The service is to be produced by a programming subsidiary of Cablevision, of which NBC is a partner.    Once the channels are merged, Mr. Brill would run the venture, the sources said. Neither company would comment.   Larry Gerbrandt, a cable service analyst at Paul Kagan & Associates, said there was a shortage of channel capacity among the cable operators. By combining the efforts of the two services, Mr. Gerbrandt said, it will be easier to become profitable because rival services would not have to battle for potential subscribers.

abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.06   7.31   8.25        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.60   6.61   7.56        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.60   6.59   7.39        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.89   7.79   7.77        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Trading Halted in Italy
abstract: A strike by floor traders protesting a proposed capital gains tax halted stock trading Friday in Italy. Picket lines formed outside the Milan exchange, Italy's largest, and trading was also blocked in Rome and the other small stock exchanges in the country. The union said the strike will continue until at least Wednesday, when a committee of Parliament has agreed to hear the strikers' grievances.

headline: Free Trade Imperils a Free-Trade Zone in Brazil
abstract: Here in the heart of the Amazon, palm trees and tropical decay give way to a unexpected sight: row upon row of shoebox-style factories that churn out millions of radios, television sets, tape recorders, watches and pocket calculators each year.    Brazil's largest manufacturing center after Sao Paulo, Manaus is the boom town that protectionism built. Since a free-trade zone enveloped the city in 1967, Manaus has attracted 600 factories and has quadrupled in population, to 1.3 million people, about two-thirds of the population of Amazonas State.

headline: A Renault Executive Is Taking Over Mack
abstract: LEAD: Mack Trucks Inc., the money-losing heavy-duty diesel truck manufacturer owned by the French auto maker Renault is switching to a French chief executive. Mack, based in Allentown, Pa., announced yesterday that Elios Pascual had been named to the post.

headline: U.S. Envoy to China Regrets His Criticism of Protesters
abstract: The American Ambassador to China, James Lilley, said on Sunday that he regrets calling demonstrators against Chinese human-rights abuses "cowards" and suggesting that one man, a Tibetan, "go back to China and serve China."   Mr. Lilley said the protesters had provoked him with an obscene name.   "It was a mistake," Mr. Lilley said of the incident on Saturday before he addressed a Chinese-American trade conference. "I shouldn't have done it."   He defended his position on human rights in China, noting that he had negotiated the passage to exile of an important Chinese dissident, Fang Lizhi.

headline: Productivity on the Increase But Hours Worked Decline
abstract: The productivity of American workers climbed at the fastest pace in two years during the July-September quarter, but hours worked fell, the Government said today, in a sign that the economic slowdown is forcing businesses to make do with fewer employees.   "The good news is that productivity is up; the bad news is we're in a recession," said Michael K. Evans, a Washington-based economic consultant.

headline: Chairman Holds Key to MCA's Sale
abstract: LEAD: Several years ago, an investment banker, trying to sell the idea of a management buyout of MCA Inc., came to see Lew R. Wasserman, chairman of the $3.5 billion entertainment company.

headline: Swarovski Head's Goal: Lift U.S. Jewelry Sales
abstract: Sherry Baker's first career was as a high school history teacher. "It seems like another person who lived that life," she said yesterday. Some years after teaching, Ms. Baker zigged to the fragrance and cosmetics business; this week she zagged to the jewelry industry, where she was named president and chief operating officer of Swarovski Jewelry Ltd. U.S.    Swarovski, which markets the Savvy and Swarovski jewelry line, is a subsidiary of the Daniel Swarovski Corporation, a 95-year-old company based in Zurich and known for its crystal products.

headline: Machine Tool Orders Decline 4.6%
abstract: Orders for American-made machine tools dipped 4.6 percent in September, from August's rate, according to an industry report to be released today. The decline is the second in as many months.    The report, which is being released by the Association for Manufacturing Technology, a trade association for the machine tool industry, stated that machine tool orders fell to $264.2 million in September, from $276.8 million in August. The September figures represented a 12.7 percent decline from September 1989.

headline: Talking Deals;  Risks in Ventures With the Japanese
abstract: LEAD: AFTER trying for years to break into the supplier network for Japanese auto plants in the United States, Elco Industries finally succeeded by using the same method as a growing number of American auto-parts companies. It found a Japanese partner.

headline: House Democrats Caution Bush on War
abstract: House Democrats adopted a nonbinding policy statement late today declaring that President Bush should not initiate any offensive military action in the Persian Gulf without the formal approval of Congress unless American lives were in immediate danger.   The resolution, adopted on a 177-37 vote after two hours of closed-door debate by the House Democratic Caucus, reflected the views that Democratic leaders in both the House and Senate have repeatedly expressed since Mr. Bush ordered more American troops to the Gulf last month. But it is the most explicit and formal statement to date of the Democratic position.

headline: Neil Bush Assailed By Judge
abstract: An administrative law judge today assailed Neil Bush for what he called "conflicts of interest" and "unsafe or unsound practices" when he was a director of a failed savings and loan and recommended that the President's son be disciplined.   The recommendation, however, was for the mildest disciplinary action that could be imposed. It was nonetheless strongly fought by Mr. Bush, who denied wrongdoing. Mr. Bush could have drawn a recommendation that he be barred permanently from the industry.

headline: Jerusalem as Tinderbox: Fury and Foreboding Prevail
abstract: Soldiers threw up scores of roadblocks at dawn today, barring all Palestinians from entering Israel. Immediately a tense and angry truce fell over the nation and its occupied territories.     Across the forced separation that some here were calling a "Middle Eastern Iron Curtain," Arabs and Jews still seethed. Both sides continued calling for revenge and death after an ugly half week in which three Jews and three Arabs were killed in a rush of assaults and counterattacks.

headline: Eastern,Seeing Gain, Asks $30 Million More From Escrow
abstract: Martin R. Shugrue Jr., the trustee of Eastern Airlines, contending that Eastern's program of offering first-class seats to flyers who pay full coach fare has resulted in strong bookings and better cash flow, is asking the bankruptcy court to let the airline withdraw an additional $30 million from escrow funds to keep operating.   The motion was filed yesterday with Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court. In it, Mr. Shugrue argued that stronger bookings, along with stabilizing fuel prices, could enable Eastern to start generating enough cash from operations by February to avoid having to dip into the escrow funds.   "The dramatic results of the initial weeks of Eastern's first-class marketing program, coupled with a decline in the company's cost of fuel and the success of the liquidity program, signal a watershed in Eastern's chapter 11 case," the motion said.   Eastern's unsecured creditors who heard Mr. Shugrue present the same arguments on Wednesday, however, are skeptical and could oppose further withdrawal from the funds, people familiar with their meeting said.   Judge Lifland set a hearing for Nov. 14 at 3 P.M. The unsecured creditors and the preferred stockholders committee, if they wish, can show cause then why the judge should not authorize the withdrawal of the cash.   Since Mr. Shugure was appointed trustee on April 19, taking control of the airline from Frank Lorenzo, the former chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, the unsecured creditors have generally been supportive of his attempts to revive the carrier.   The court authorized the use of $80 million at the time of his appointment, and in three following orders Eastern management was able to withdraw an additional $150 million.   Mr. Shugrue ran an advertising blitz to win back the business flyer in the summer and to promote the first-class program in the fall. Still, the airline has continued to have deep losses.   The unsecured creditors thus must decide whether to support Mr. Shugrue and approve more withdrawals from escrow fund, or to say no because there would be less left for them if the airline is liquidated.   If the unsecured creditors withdraw their support, then the pressure would grow to shut down the carrier and liquidate it. Two Primary Conditions    In the motion Mr. Shugrue said that there was still $257 million in cash left, which would be enough for him to shut down the carrier. But he said that would not occur.   Mr. Shugrue said that Eastern would need an additional $40 million between mid- and late December. Of that, $24 million would be to pay for aircraft leasing and $10 million would be for cash needs in January.   Mr. Shugrue's optimism, however, is dependent on two major factors -- that Eastern can continue to lure business flyers from Delta and other major carriers and that fuel prices do not begin to rise again.    Since Eastern moved its hub to Atlanta, Delta has become its major competitor. For a time Delta allowed Eastern to undercut its fares, preferring to keep a weaker carrier as a competitor rather than to push Eastern into liqudation and thus enable another major airline to come into Atlanta.    Recently however, Delta has matched Eastern's lower fares with lower coach fares. Selling More Assets    Mr. Shugure argued in the motion that during the first three weeks of the first-class marketing program the number of passenger who paid full coach increased by 4.3 for each flight.   He said that the program generated a lot of cash; adding one passenger paying full coach per flight brings in $4 million more in revenue a month.    He also said that Eastern's fuel costs appeared to have peaked on Oct. 16 when it was paying $1.24 a gallon. By Nov. 2, fuel had dropped 12 cents, to $1.12, he said, adding that every 10-cent drop represents a saving of $5 million a month.   The motion also disclosed that Eastern is in the process of selling more assets. The airline has negotiated an agreement to sell a hangar at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport for $7.5 million, and US Air has offered to buy certain Canadian routes.   The motion also said that Eastern was negotiating with Aeroflot to sell or lease a number of its Lockheed L1011 aircraft to the Soviet airline.

headline: Dividend Halved By Ameritrust
abstract: Expecting a loss for the year, the Ameritrust Corporation said it had halved the dividend on the banking company's common stock. Officials said they resorted to the cut -- the first in the company's 96-year history -- mainly because of problem loans linked to a lagging commercial real estate market.   The Ameritrust board declared a quarterly dividend of 16 cents a common share, down from 32 a share in the third quarter. The dividend is payable on Dec. 10 to stockholders of record on Dec. 3. For the first nine months of 1990, Ameritrust reported a loss of $19 million.

headline: Credit Markets; Treasury Securities Rise in Price
abstract: A plunge in new orders for durable goods during November helped to push up prices of Treasury securities yesterday, as interest rates fell.   The 10.5 percent drop in new orders was at least twice as large as most analysts had forecast. The reported decline accentuated problems currently being experienced in the nation's manufacturing sector.

headline: Macy's Loss Said to Reach $66 Million
abstract: R. H. Macy & Company has told creditors and credit agencies that it had a loss of $66 million in its latest quarter -- a bigger loss than creditors expected and double its $33.1 million loss in the quarter last year, according to a number of creditors and credit agencies.   A Macy spokesman yesterday said the company would not comment on the reports. Macy is expected to report the quarterly loss to the Securities and Exchange Commission in several weeks.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Reebok will be the exclusive athletic footwear and apparel advertiser on CBS network broadcasts of the United States Open Tennis Championships, under a three-year, multimillion-dollar deal.

headline: The National Ends Its Sunday Issue
abstract: Feeling the pressures of a sagging economy, The National, the fledgling sports daily, said yesterday that it would stop publishing a Sunday issue and that it was undergoing some management changes.    The moves raised renewed questions about the long-term prospects for the newspaper, the first attempt at a nationally distributed daily that covers only sports. Since its debut on Jan. 31, The National has grown more slowly than anticipated, and despite some high-priced writing talent its editorial content has drawn a tepid response from some readers.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. is offering $300.1 million in real estate mortgage investment conduit securities through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The offering is backed by 15-year Freddie Mac gold participation certificates, with a coupon of 9 1/2 percent. * MCI Communications Corp., Washington, has filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of about $750 million in subordinated medium-term notes through Merrill Lynch & Co. The offering would be due from nine months to 30 years from the date of issue. Combined with proceeds from an earlier registration, the total value of the offering would be $910 million. * New York State Electric and Gas Co., Ithaca, N.Y., will redeem on Dec. 24 all $75 million outstanding of its first mortgage bonds, 12 1/8 percent series, due 2015. * Philip Morris Cos., New York, is offering $250 million in notes, due in 1994, through Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes, expected to yield 8.80 percent, have an 8 3/4 coupon rate and were priced at 99.825 to yield 96 basis points more than comparable Treasury securities. Noncallable for life, the issue is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's. * Westwood One Inc., Los Angeles, is offering to exchange its 9 percent convertible senior subordinated debentures, due in 2002, for its 6 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2011. Ratings * Glendale Federal Bank's long-term deposit and senior debt ratings have been lowered to Ba-2, from Ba-1, and the subordinated debt rating has been lowered to B-2, from Ba-3, by Moody's. The rating agency also lowered the subordinated debt of GlenFed Inc., the parent of the Glendale, Calif., savings and loan association, to B-3 from B-1.

headline: Nintendo Offers Pact to Designers
abstract: The Nintendo Company, which has strictly controlled the manufacture of games for its video entertainment systems, has offered United States companies that design the games the chance to manufacture them. The Japanese company licenses 53 companies to design games for its systems and manufactures the game cartridges itself in Japan, maintaining exlusive marketing rights.    Lynne Gray, a spokeswoman for Nintendo in Los Angeles, said the company sent a letter to its licensees on Oct. 3 offering to let them manufacture their designs. No one has signed up yet, she said. Ms. Gray said the experimental offer was unrelated to a Federal Trade Commission investigation of Nintendo for possible anti-competitive practices.

headline: REBELS IN CONTROL OF CHAD'S CAPITAL
abstract: Rebel forces under the leadership of Gen. Idris Deby occupied the undefended Chadian capital of Ndjamena today, just 24 hours after President Hissen Habre and his top aides reportedly fled the country to neighboring Cameroon.    General Deby, a tough 37-year-old veteran of Chad's frequent civil wars who broke with President Habre in April of last year, promised to turn the country into a multiparty democracy for the first time since it won independence from France in 1960. The landlocked Central African nation of about 5 million people has been plagued by chronic disorder for three decades.

headline: Zenith Awarded Grant for HDTV
abstract: The Zenith Electronics Corporation received a $1 million grant from Illinois to develop manufacturing processes for high-definition television monitors. The grant from the Illinois Technology Challenge Grant Program will augment Zenith's $50 million commitment to the emerging television technology.    High-definition television, featuring picture clarity like 35mm photographs and sound like that of compact disks, is viewed as the future of the television industry. Zenith, based in this Chicago suburb, is competing with larger and better-financed foreign manufacturers to develop an high-definition system that it hopes will be chosen as the United States standard.

headline: Gillette Warns Of Plant Closing
abstract: The Gillette Company is threatening to close the world's largest razor blade plant if Boston bans ozone-depleting chemicals. The City Council is considering outlawing chemicals that when released into the atmosphere deplete the ozone layer protecting the earth from damaging rays from the sun.   At a hearing on Thursday, Gillette's vice chairman, Joseph E. Mullaney, said that the ban would put the company at a significant competitive disadvantage and that if the bill were adopted, Gillette would close its plant in the South Boston section by January 1992. A statement from the company this morningsoft-pedaled the threat somewhat, saying if the proposed ordinance is approved, Gillette "will make any necessary decisions at that time." Joan Fitzgerald, a Gillette spokeswoman, said the company hoped a compromise wording for the ordinance could be worked out. The Gillette plant employs 3,100 people.

headline: Top Gillette Managers Prepare for Succession
abstract: The Gillette Company, the world's largest maker of razors and blades, said yesterday that Colman M. Mockler, its chairman and chief executive officer since the mid-1970's, will retire at the end of next year as part of a plan to set up an orderly line of succession for senior management.   The succession plan, approved by the board yesterday, realigns Gillette's most senior officers, three of whom are 60 years old, as is Mr. Mockler. And it places Alfred M. Zeien, one of two vice chairmen, in line to succeed Mr. Mockler. It also elevates Robert J. Murray, a 49-year-old executive from Gillette's Braun subsidiary, to a senior officer for Gillette North Atlantic, encompassing the United States and Europe, Gillette's biggest markets.

headline: Fire Guts the Brussels Stock Exchange
abstract: The century-old Brussels stock exchange building was gutted by fire Friday morning, halting trading and throwing the exchange into doubt about changes scheduled to begin on Jan. 1.    Jean Peterbroeck, chairman of the exchange, said that despite the widespread damage the Bourse would try to open for trading on Monday. He said that the Belgian central bank had offered trading space and that the exchange's surviving computers could handle the bids.

headline: U.S. FARMERS COOL TO SOVIET AID DEAL
abstract: President Bush's decision to temporarily lift a ban on lending to the Soviet Union and provide $1 billion in agricultural loans received a less-than-enthusiastic response in the farm community today.    Representatives of farm groups said the President's action, which was intended to help the Soviet Union meet anticipated winter food shortages, was encouraging to the farmers who will benefit from the purchases but over all it was too late, was far less than farmers had hoped and would have no significant impact on farm income.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * CSX Corp., a Richmond-based transportation holding company, is offering $200 million in 9 1/2 percent noncallable notes due 1995 at 99.88, to yield 9.53 percent, or about 140 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, through the First Boston Corporation as lead manager. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The notes are rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P. * Norwest Financial Inc., Des Moines, Iowa, a subsidiary of the Norwest Corp., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $1 billion in debt securities. * Pennzoil Co., a Houston-based oil and gas exploration company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $500 million in debt securities consisting of debentures and notes. * Pioneer Standard Electronics Inc., Cleveland, has privately placed $20 million in senior notes with Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America. Ratings  * Transco Energy Co.'s debt rating is under review by S.& P. with negative implications. The energy holding company is based in Houston.

headline: U.S. Securities Prices Increase
abstract: The credit market rally continued yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell further.    The bulk of the gains were achieved during overseas trading, but the positive momentum generated by the weak November employment data released Friday continued to swirl even after activity shifted to American financial markets.

headline: Commodities Rise Sends Stocks Tumbling
abstract: An unexpected rise in commodities prices yesterday pushed bonds lower and sent stocks tumbling.   By the end of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average had dropped 17.08 points, to 2,485.l5.

headline: Cranberry Crop Down
abstract: The crop of fresh cranberries has dropped 30 percent this year in Massachusetts compared with last year's harvest. The shortage was caused by inclement weather. The December 1989 deep freeze damaged some vines, and an 8-inch, bog-flooding rainfall on Cape Cod and adjacent areas in late July was devastating, leading to rot. Massachusetts is traditionally the nation's biggest cranberry grower, accounting for half the United States crop, but Wisconsin might take over the top spot this year once this year's figures are in.

headline: F.C.C. TV Hearing Set
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that it was still considering a variety of proposals to modify regulations governing the ownership of television programming. The commission said it would hold a hearing on Dec. 14 for further comments on the issue from networks, Hollywood studios and producers and other interested parties. The commission gave no indication of how it might rule on the issue, one of the most important facing the television industry.

headline: Sikh Militants Slay at Least 16 in an Attack on Buses in Punjab
abstract: Sikh militants killed at least 16 people today in attacks on three buses outside the capital of Punjab state, news agencies reported.   United News of India said the buses were ambushed near Paroll village outside Chandigarh, 150 miles north of New Delhi.    United News of India reported that the police chief of Punjab state, K. P. S. Gill, had confirmed 16 deaths and said that several people were wounded.

headline: Brokerage Given Fine
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had fined Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. $750,000 for violating exchange rules.    A fine against the firm had been expected because it decided earlier this month to settle a number of cases without admitting or denying guilt, as is usual in settlements with the Big Board. That decision was disclosed to employees in a memorandum signed by George L. Ball, chairman of Prudential-Bache.    One charge was that the firm sold $218 million worth of securities it was required to hold for customers and used the proceeds in other transactions. Prudential-Bache was censured by the Securities and Exchange Commission for that act last October, but it paid no fine then. Many of the same factual findings are listed in the Big Board's action.    Also, Prudential-Bache was said to have failed to properly supervise an employee in its institutional block-trading business. According to the Big Board complaint, the employee sold stocks near the close of the trading day on an "uptick," which is when the last trade is at a higher price than the one preceeding it.   The exchange said that the trades took place when the firm held shares for its own account and that the trades "had the effect of increasing the value of the firm's overnight inventory."   A spokeswoman for Prudential-Bache said yesterday that the exchange's disciplinary action represented "violation of technical rules."    "We think it important to point out that none of the problems regarded issues involving customers," she said.

headline: Eastern Reports Success With Fares
abstract: LEAD: Eastern Airlines has told its unsecured creditors that its new fares have been a success with business travelers and could enable the troubled carrier to survive, a spokeswoman said. ''The corporate fares are going over very well with business travelers,'' the spokeswoman, Karen Ceremsak, said.

headline: A Bronfman Empire Stumbles
abstract: Peter and Edward Bronfman, the brothers who quietly built Canada's largest corporate empire after being shut out of the Seagram business controlled by their high-profile cousins, are running into problems on a number of fronts.    Among other things, large real estate investments by the complex empire under the Bronfmans' Edper holding company have soured, and the stocks of the main publicly traded Bronfman companies have fallen sharply on the Toronto Stock Exchange. While the two brothers, once known as the "poor" Bronfmans, continue to avoid the limelight, their senior executives have taken a road show to Bay Street, Toronto's financial district, to try to quell growing fears.   The Bronfman empire is so vast -- more than 360 closely intertwined companies with holdings as diverse as the Toronto Blue Jays baseball team, the Labatt breweries, the Noranda natural-resources businesses, the Trilon financial-services companies and the Carena real-estate concerns -- that if it did suffer a serious setback it would have tremendous consequences on Canadian securities markets and on the economy, some analysts say.    "Any trouble that the Edper group runs into would not be good for Canada as a whole," said Richard Lafferty, president of Lafferty, Harwood & Partners, a Montreal-based money manager.    All told, the Bronfman brothers control companies whose assets are valued in the tens of billions of dollars and that produce yearly revenues in the billions.   By some estimates, the more than 40 corporations in the Edper group that are publicly traded account for about 12 percent of the total capitalization of the Toronto exchange.     Investors are worried not only about the losses at some of the companies, which run into the hundreds of millions of dollars, but also about the labyrinthine structure of the holdings, private transactions among the various companies, and the large amounts of debt they carry. Preferred shares in each of the companies are regularly shifted to other affiliated concerns and it is difficult to tell how much leverage some of the companies have.    "It's a pyramid scheme," said Stephen Jarislowsky, president of the Montreal-based Jarislowsky, Fraser & Company, Canada's largest money managers, with more than $11 billion (Canadian) from pension funds and investors under management. He was referring to the flow of cash in the empire, where many of the companies at the top depend on the dividends paid by those at the bottom for most of their cash flow. If dividends are not paid steadily, cash problems spread upward through the group.    "They seem always to be shuffling paper here and there and I don't think any investor with any brains -- except for them -- can make head or tails out of it," said Mr. Jarislowsky, who added that it takes months of number-crunching to understand the value of the Edper assets and precisely how and by whom they are held.    The Bronfman brothers declined to be interviewed, but Edper executives took umbrage at this assessment. "I don't know that pyramid is the right word," said Trevor Eyton, president and chief executive of Brascan Ltd., one of the main holding companies within the Edper group. "We call it top-down financing," he said, acknowledging that it is the bottom-up cash flow in the empire that worries analysts.    Edper Holdings, the group's top holding company, is 54 percent owned by Peter F. Bronfman, 61 years old, and his family. The balance is held by the Pagurian Corporation, which holds the interests of top Edper executives. Edper Enterprises, which falls directly below the top holding company, is 70 percent owned by Edper Holdings and 25 percent by Edward M. Bronfman, 62.  A Family Dispute     Edper, which takes its name from the family trusts set up for the two brothers, was initially financed with cash raised by selling the interests these Bronfmans had in the Seagram Company. Seagram is controlled by Edgar M. Bronfman and his brother, Charles R. Bronfman. Their Toronto cousins were shut out from executive management of the family liquor business because of a rivalry between Samuel Bronfman, the founder of the whiskey dynasty and father of Edgar and Charles, and his brother Allan, father of Edward and Peter.    The Edper companies, and indeed most of Peter and Edward Bronfman's holdings, are run by Jack L. Cockwell, a reticent South African accountant who put together most of the empire and is widely regarded as the financial whiz behind its business deals. Mr. Cockwell, who is vice president and chief operating officer of Brascan, declined to be interviewed for this article. The 49-year-old accountant is highly respected in Canadian business circles for his financial skills as well as his vision, but he remains mysterious and aloof.    But as the Edper companies run into trouble, some Canadian analysts and institutional investors have asked him and other top Edper executives to give the public a better view of the companies' dealings and structure so that their value can be better assessed. (Disclosure requirements for public companies in Canada are markedly less demanding than those in the United States.) According to executives, the Edper group has declined such invitations, and that reluctance continues to fuel concern.  Some Debt Downgraded     "We don't know as analysts how much money they have," said Phillip Wright, who is with McNeil Mantha, a small Toronto firm. He said the companies often mixed cash and securities on their balance sheets without outlining that much of these securities were notes from affiliated companies.   Late last month, major rating agencies downgraded the long-term debt of several interlocked companies, and operating expenses exceed operating income at at least two of the companies in the group. As a result, the stocks of Edper, Hees International Bancorp Inc., Brascan, Carena Development and Bramalea Ltd. have fallen sharply in the last several weeks.    A few weeks ago the real estate arm of the group was battered when news that Bramalea, a subsidiary of Trizec, would take a $115.2 million writedown on third-quarter earnings because of soured Toronto land investments. The charge gave Bramalea, which has spent nearly $1 billion over the last two years to acquire land, a net loss of $68.8 million for the first nine months of this year.  Short on Liquid Assets     Trizec reported last month that its income had fallen 60.2 percent from the corresponding nine-month period in 1989. Trizec holds many highly valuable assets but real estate experts who have worked with the company point out that it is suffering from a lack of liquid assets at a time when real estate values are falling and market financing is scarce.    Beyond the real estate troubles, the Edper group has stumbled in financial services. Royal Trustco Ltd., the group's trust company (whose main business is making residential mortgages) and the largest trust company in Canada, has seen its bottom line and stock price suffer after it made bold forays into the London real estate market and the United States savings and loan markets. Royal Trustco's stock, which has been sliding for four months, is now trading below book value, and earnings potential over the near-term is dim, some analysts said.    And Hees Bancorp Inc., the merchant banking operation, has watched its stock fall because of troubled investments in real estate and natural resources. In addition, the company has had a difficult time drumming up profitable merchant banking deals, said Eric Sprott, head of Toronto-based Sprott Securities.    The Edper group has also garnered unwanted attention from its interests in troubled companies it is trying to turn around, including the BCE Development Corporation, Unicorp Canada, the Enfield Corporation and National Business Systems Inc. Short on Dividend Cash     In its natural resources and mining group, Noranda Inc. is operating at about break-even, hurt by low commodity prices. Noranda is controlled by Brascan Ltd., one of the important holding companies, which is itself facing a $50 million cash shortfall.   Brascan reports paper profits based on its share of the profits of companies like Noranda and John Labatt Ltd., the food and drink company it controls. Even so, Brascan has for many years not had enough cash to pay its dividend commitments and has to borrow to make the payments.    The Edper group has paid very little in taxes for years because the companies and their managers hold their interests in the empire largely through shares of preferred stock. Under Canadian law in force at the time the arrangements were made, companies that held preferred shares in other companies did not pay taxes on dividend income earned through these holdings. Hees, for example, paid only $5.5 million in taxes last year on net income of $248 million.    "They've played a lot with smoke and mirrors and they've done it for years without paying any taxes," said Mr. Lafferty of the money management firm.    While there are some big problems with the Edper group, its resources remain vast, and many Bronfman watchers doubt that the companies will begin to topple -- although isolated assets may have to be sold to raise money.

headline: Farebersviller Journal; Minaret Is Silent, but Has Much to Say to France
abstract: This is a tale of a minaret, two imams and a symbolic franc, of a fanciful architect and a rough stretch of coal country, of France and Islam and a little faith.    The story takes place in this medieval town of 10,000 on a plateau overlooking the coal fields and steel mills of French Lorraine and German Saarland. Its players include a soft-spoken bishop and an industrial giant, a Moroccan, a Tunisian, an Algerian and a Turk, two gaggles of schoolgirls in scarfs and the methodical Muslim who brought them together.

headline: Offer by I.B.M. To Its Holders
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation is offering its shareholders a chance to invest in its I.B.M. Money Market Account, which has been available only to employees, retirees and their families.   The account represents an investment in demand notes, or short-term securities, issued by the I.B.M. Credit Corporation.    For the last five weeks the I.B.M. Money Market Account has paid 7.75 percent, which would mean an effective annual yield of 8.03 percent, if there was no change in the rate. Rates can be changed once a week.   I.B.M. said the account "offers an alternative to bank money market and savings accounts, money market funds and certificates of deposit."   Offering it to shareholders, which it has been doing quietly since early October, also gives the company a new, broader market to tap for its short-term financing needs.

headline: Albanian President to Meet Striking Students
abstract: The Communist President of Albania, Ramiz Alia, agreed today to meet with striking students, a day after the police engaged in fistfights with student demonstrators.   A diplomat in the Albanian capital of Tirana who was reached by telephone said some people had been hurt and many arrested during a rare show of public defiance against the Communist Government on Sunday. It was the first known anti-Communist demonstration by students in Albania.

headline: GUERRILLAS REPORT PACT WITH ANGOLA
abstract: A United States-armed guerrilla organization has reached tentative agreement with the Soviet-backed Government of Angola on a plan to end 15 years of civil war, the rebels' leader, Jonas Savimbi, said today.   At a negotiation session on Thursday sponsored by the United States, the Soviet Union and Portugal, the warring sides agreed to set a date for free elections and then sign a cease-fire agreement, Mr. Savimbi told reporters.   The breakthrough in the tortuous peace efforts follows a series of meetings here this week, including a session between Mr. Savimbi and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union. Mr. Savimbi, who had been vilified by the Kremlin as an anti-Communist menace, also met with President Bush on Thursday. Pressure From U.S. and Moscow     Washington and Moscow have been pressing their allies in Angola to halt the fighting, which has killed more than 300,000 people and left the mineral-rich country in ruin.   The United States has shipped Mr. Savimbi's group, known as Unita, as much as $50 million in weapons each year since 1986; the Soviets have given the Angolan Government as much as $800 million annually, United States officials say.   Under the tentative accord, both countries will stop sending weapons once a cease-fire is signed, American officials said.   Mr. Savimbi said that Unita and the second-ranking official in Angola's governing party, Lopo do Nascimento, had agreed at the highest-level gathering on Thursday that the signing of a cease-fire agreement should be preceded by the setting of a date for free elections.   The two sides agreed that the cease-fire should be guaranteed by international observers, he said, and that outside military assistance would stop once the cease-fire accord was signed.   Mr. Savimbi said there was also agreement that Angola should be governed through a democratic system and that elections should be monitored by international observers. 'No Question' of an Accord     The Angolan Government official, Mr. do Nascimiento, asked for more time to confer with his superiors in Luanda, Mr. Savimbi said. But "there is no question" that the Government will agree in principle, he added.   At a news conference late Thursday, the American, Soviet and Portuguese participants in the talks said "significant progress" had been made but declined to elaborate.   A United States official, speaking on condition of anonymity, today confirmed the gist of Mr. Savimbi's account of the meeting.   "Unita is optimistic that the remaining differences between the two parties can be successfully addressed and that signature of a cease-fire will be possible during the sixth round of negotiations," the official said. The talks are to be held next month in Portugal, the former colonial ruler of Angola.

headline: U.S. Faces a $2 Billion Loss On Unauthorized Iraq Loans
abstract: LEAD: Congressional investigators said today that the Federal Government stood to lose $2 billion because it had guaranteed unauthorized loans to Iraq made by the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank.

headline: The Attraction of Ginnie Mae
abstract: What do you get when you buy a corporate bond fund? Some corporate bonds, of course. But if your fund has been a top performer lately, odds are good that you had a big chunk of mortgage-backed paper like Ginnie Maes, issues of the Government National Mortgage Association.   Historically, corporate bond funds have kept about 11 percent of their portfolios in mortgage-backed paper. But today, that figure is nearly 30 percent for the leading funds, and only about 4 percent for the laggards.

headline: Houston Industries
abstract: LEAD: Houston Industries, an electric utility holding company, adopted an employee stock ownership plan that will buy about 10 million of the company's 128 million shares outstanding. The company said it had adopted the plan to finance its obligations to make matching contributions under an employee savings plan.

headline: U.S. MOVES TO CUT CHEMICALS' SPREAD
abstract: The White House has announced tighter controls to stem the spread of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons while approving long-delayed export licenses for the sale of high-performance computers to China, Brazil and India.    The moves, disclosed on Thursday night, include an Enhanced Proliferation Control Initiative to obtain, among other things, worldwide export controls on 50 chemicals used to manufacture chemical weapons. They were intended chiefly to soften criticism by business of cumbersome procedures governing the export of sensitive goods.

headline: Debentures Priced By Freddie Mac
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, a publicly traded and federally chartered company that provides a continous flow of funds to mortgage lenders, priced $500 million in three-year debentures yesterday through its regular 25-member debenture dealer group.    Freddie Mac said the debentures with a 7.95 percent coupon were offered to investors at a price of 100, to yield about 24 basis points more than Treasury secuities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.   The dealer group said that the debentures are callable by Freddie Mac on or after Nov. 29, 1991, at a price of par, with interest payable semiannually each May 29 and Nov. 29, beginning May 29, 1991.

headline: People
abstract: * The League of Advertising Agencies, New York, has appointed new advisers and consultants. Named as advisers were Douglas J. Wood, legal; Seymour Levenstein, financial, and Ray Heller, credit and collections. The consultants will be: Jeffrey Sussman, public relations; Bill Weiner, media, and Bernard Zuckerman, production.

headline: Political Factions in Israel Pursue A Cure for Paralysis: Soviet Jews
abstract: After six years of divisive political paralysis, the Israeli Government may be dramatically reshaped in the very near future by the coveted votes of more than half a million new Soviet Jewish citizens.   Eager politicians on Israel's embattled left and right are avidly counting the arriving immigrants each month, and each party is claiming the growing pool of new voters for itself. Everyone is acutely aware that enough Soviet immigrants are arriving about every six weeks to elect one member of Parliament.

headline: Iraq's Shadowy Quest for Atom Arms: Tentacles in Four Continents
abstract: Exploiting a web of front companies and secret military alliances on four continents, Iraq has managed to buy much of the hardware and acquire the skill for an assembly line that could produce atomic weapons within the decade, Western law-enforcement and intelligence officials say.    The Iraqi purchasing network worked with virtual impunity for nearly 10 years, using deception and, some critics charge, murder to skirt Western safeguards on nuclear technology. In turn, Iraq's enemies have arrested and killed its agents and tried for years to sabotage the bomb program, with some success.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Padilla Speer Beardsley Inc., Minneapolis, a public relations firm, has expanded its international consulting practice by opening a subsidiary, Padilla Speer Beardsley International, which will be headed by David J. Speer.

headline: One Big Store's Recession Jitters
abstract: LEAD: As an early morning drizzle began falling on the parking lot, William Senn, the manager of the big J. C. Penney store here, began another nervous day of coping with consumer lassitude. He scolded an employee to restore a vanished sale sign in a display window -Who knew how many lost customers that could mean?

headline: Pacific Gas Plans Stock Repurchase
abstract: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company Wednesday authorized the repurchase of up to $750 million in common stock to offset new shares issued through the company's employee stock ownership plan and shareholder dividend reinvestment plan, and thus eliminate a net change in the value of its stock.    The company said the buyback, financed by internally generated money, would take place over the next two and a half years either through open-market purchases or negotiated transactions. This is the second such authorization this year. The first one, in January, was for $500 million. About 19 million shares have been repurchased so far under that authorization.    Pacific Gas has about 418 million common shares outstanding and the latest buyback represents about 7 percent of the total.

headline: Dow Declines 10.64, Ending a Strong Rally
abstract: LEAD: After two days of extremely strong advances, the stock market rally fizzled yesterday.

headline: Millicom in Test
abstract: Millicom Inc., a small New York communications company, announced yesterday that Northern Telecom Ltd., the telecommunications equipment giant based in Toronto, would help it design and conduct tests of a new type of tiny cellular telephone in Houston and Orlando, Fla. The Federal Communications Commission awarded Millicom an experimental license on May 8, setting off a rush by many other companies, including five of the seven regional Bell companies, to obtain permission for similar tests. None of the companies has yet demonstrated a working two-way handset.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M.    SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.    DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.    LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.    SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10:30 A.M.

headline: A Better Way to Reward Quality
abstract: To the Editor:   There is a basic flaw in the administration of the Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Awards described in "The Baldrige Badge of Courage - an Quality" (Oct. 21). The article says awards are limited to two companies in each category. If the purpose of these awards is to upgrade product quality throughout American industry, this limitation defeats that end.   The British have done it much better with their BS 5750 Quality Award, chartered by the Government and administered by the British Standards Institute. Under the BSI program, a company fills out a relatively simple form which covers some two dozen criteria: not only activities directly related to quality assurance, but also other aspects of company operations like management philosophy and employee training.   Applicant companies are inspected onsite. If they pass, they receive the award and can use its symbol in promotional materials and advertising. Recipients must be reinspected periodically to maintain their qualification. A major incentive to qualify is that most companies and the Government now limit purchases to vendors who have proved, through receipt of the award, that their products meet high standards.   The BS 5750 award has now been accepted as the model within all European Community countries for a similar program, designated the ISO 9002 award. It is run by the International Standards Organization for all types of industries. The standards for both the BS 5750 and ISO 9002 awards are strictly enforced, impose no limit on how many companies may qualify. The Baldrige awards, on the other hand, give both a publicity and bottom-line coup to one or two well-heeled companies (its application takes hundreds of hours to complete and requires a hefty accompanying fee) rather than encouraging quality raising at all levels of industry. THEODORE LUSTIG  Morgantown, W. Va., Oct. 26

headline: Ed Woolard Walks Du Pont's Tightrope
abstract: LEAD: A big part of the future of America's largest chemical company can be found on a conveyor belt in an old warehouse here.

headline: Mexico City Journal; Who's Afraid of Trotsky? Not This Russian, Now
abstract: The first time Yuri Paporov got a glimpse of the house where Leon Trotsky died, he barely escaped in time.    Driving with another Soviet diplomat here in the early 1950's, Mr. Paporov took a wrong turn that brought him within a few hundred yards of the walled compound before his apoplectic colleague realized that they were heading straight toward political doom.

headline: Big-City Ambitions at Toys 'R' Us
abstract: The new Toys "R" Us store that will anchor the Herald Center in Manhattan will be the company's first multilevel store in the center of a major city and, if successful, will lead the nation's largest toy seller in an entirely new direction for expansion.   The company, by far the nation's largest toy retailer, with 1990 sales of about $5.7 billion, plans to open the store across 34th Street from Macy's around Nov. 17, in time for the Christmas shopping season. It will occupy 45,000 square feet on three levels: below the street, the ground floor and the mezzanine.

headline: Fiction Pays for Putnam Publishing Unit
abstract: When MCA Inc. bought G. P. Putnam's Sons in 1975, the house was publishing more than 225 hardcover titles a year. Today, Putnam publishes only 70 to 80 books a year, but its revenues are eight times as high.   Indeed, rarely a week goes by when a Putnam book is not on the best-seller lists.

headline: New Hurdle For Mandela; Apartheid Foes Face Divisions on Strategy
abstract: At its first legal conference here in more than 30 years, the African National Congress has confronted gaps of generation and ideology within its ranks that have implications not only for its negotiations with the Government but also for its political future in a post- apartheid South Africa.    The Congress leadership, which during three decades of exile had grown accustomed to dispatching orders from the top down, had to contend with persistent and sharp criticism from angry delegates who have waged their own struggle against the system.

headline: Bond Prices Pushed Up By Job Data
abstract: An unexpectedly large rise in weekly unemployment claims reported yesterday helped to push up prices of Treasury securities and drive down interest rates as traders speculated that the ever-weakening economy would prompt the Federal Reserve Board to move quickly to ease credit again.    The report, released early in the session by the Labor Department, suggested to traders that today's October employment report will be even weaker than people in the market had anticipated.

headline: 2 Grenades Fired in Manila At U.S. Embassy Compound
abstract: Two grenades were fired at the United States Embassy compound today, but only one exploded and no injuries were reported, an embassy spokesman said.   The attack came a day after American and Philippine officials ended the latest round of talks on the future of six United States military bases in the Philippines.   There was no immediate claim of responsibity for the attack, and it was not known if it was linked to the negotiations.   The attack on the embassy compound followed at least 40 bombings in the Manila area since August. Most were believed carried out by renegade soldiers seeking to topple President Corazon C. Aquino.

headline: Reversal of Forces in Gulf: Iraqis Now Set for Defense
abstract: Three months after Iraq invaded Kuwait, military forces numbering at least 900,000 are amassed in the Persian Gulf, with Iraqi troops positioned in a formidable "V" defense and Western and Arab adversaries building up their offensive capabilities.   In early August, Iraq's forces seemed poised for a possible invasion of Saudi Arabia, while the initial American deployment was essentially a small and vulnerable defense.
