Now the roles have changed.

headline: Setting Up an Island in the Soviet Storm
abstract: On a fall Friday, just after Pepsico opened its first two Soviet Pizza Huts, a small yellow Lada puttered up to the curb outside the larger one. Out stepped a slight, middle-aged woman who wired the doors shut. The woman, a sanitary inspector, said Pizza Hut had failed to file all the necessary papers, including venereal disease tests for every employee. "This is the cleanest restaurant in Moscow," protested Andrew Rafalat, Pizza Hut's regional director for the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. She shrugged, but would not relent.   Just days before, American executives and Soviet officials had hailed the restaurants as evidence of a new epoch, the fruit of perestroika. Said Donald M. Kendall, head of Pepsico's executive committee, "We hope that today's opening sends a clear message to the world that Western-Soviet business initiatives can succeed."

headline: Even If Sanctions Are Lifted, Few Will Rush to South Africa
abstract: FORCES now seem to have been set in motion for lifting economic sanctions against South Africa -- a prospect acceptable to a growing number of blacks and whites. The effect this will have on a badly weakened South African economy or on the future of American business there is far less clear.    Events in recent days, if the forces behind them are not reversed, are pointing the way toward lifting the sanctions as early as March, according to a senior United States State Department official.

headline: Market Place;   Heritage Media's Bid for POP Radio
abstract: LEAD: IT takes a gutsy investor to step in and buy a stock just as a takeover seems to be falling apart. Or one who knows more than the public.

headline: Hartford Bank In Revamping
abstract: Society for Savings said today that it would sell about $1.6 billion worth of assets in a restructuring that will result in a $52 million loss for the year and the elimination of 140 jobs.   Society for Savings Bancorp Inc., the bank's parent company, said the bank needed to jettison about $130 million in non- performing commercial real estate loans and other assets to reduce expenses and remain competitive as New England's economy deteriorated.   The bank will also increase its reserve fund to $103.5 million, up from the $49.5 million as of Sept. 30.   Meanwhile, the parent company announced that Elliott Miller would retire as president and chief executive as of Jan. 1 after 12 years as president.   The projected 1990 loss includes a $58.6 million charge for severance payments and other restructuring expenses. The bank expects a fourth- quarter loss of $54.4 million.   The restructuring will take place in three stages in the next 13 months under a plan approved by the parent company's board of directors.

headline: Amoco Gas Platform
abstract: LEAD: The British Government said today that it had ordered Amoco U.K. to improve work supervision on a North Sea gas platform or face criminal prosecution. The action, which was taken on Sept. 17 by the Department of Energy, followed an inspection on the Amoco Alpha platform in the Leman field off the Norfolk coast, the department said.

headline: Liberian Factions Agree to a Cease-Fire
abstract: Leaders of Liberia's main warring factions agreed here today to an immediate cease-fire in their yearlong civil war.    The accord was reached after all-night talks between remnants of the army of the late President Samuel K. Doe, two rebel factions and a five-nation West African peacekeeping force.

headline: Nepal's King Gives Way to Multiparty Democracy
abstract: Seven months after pro-democracy forces toppled Nepal's absolute monarchy and began a difficult process of change, King Birendra has put his official seal on a new Constitution that enshrines multiparty democracy and human rights as hallmarks of the political system.   It took effect Friday morning after a five-minute ceremony at the palace attended by the King and senior officials of the interim Government.

headline: BARRICADE FALLING AS BEIRUT UNIFIES
abstract: On its first day of patrol duty in and around Beirut today, the Lebanese Army acted quickly to tear down a wall of barricades and earth mounds that had stood for 15 years as the green line cutting the city into Muslim and Christian halves.   "From now on our capital is a united city and the definition East Beirut, West Beirut no longer applies," said an army major supervising the engineering work in the demolished downtown area. Emphasizing that a new order has taken hold here, the major, who asked not to be identified, said the lines that had divided the capital since the civil war broke out in 1975 will be eliminated gradually.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Slim-Fast to Sell Itself as 'a Way of Life'
abstract: JUST in time for all of those "today-I'll-start-a-diet" resolutions, the Thompson Medical Company will begin a new series of commercials tomorrow for its Slim-Fast diet aid. The spots are intended to serve as an umbrella campaign for a new line of reduced-calorie foods the company plans to introduce.   The commercials focus on a group of well-proportioned people having a good time at the beach, playing games and, of course, exercising. In one spot, the announcer tells viewers that Slim-Fast is "a way of life."

headline: THE DEAL FOR MCA;
abstract: MCA Inc., one of the nation's largest entertainment companies, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company. The deal, valued at $6.13 billion plus stock in a television station, will be the largest purchase ever of an American company by a Japanese company.    The purchase price is $66 a share in cash and shares in an MCA subsidiary that would own WWOR-TV, the New Jersey-based television station owned by MCA. Analysts yesterday valued the deal at about $69 a share, lower than the $75 or more a share that MCA's chairman, Lew R. Wasserman, had been led to believe he would receive when preliminary talks began in September, one person involved in the talks said.

headline: ComFed Sues Ex-Workers
abstract: LEAD: A Massachusetts savings institution filed a lawsuit today against 34 former employees, contending that widespread misconduct aggravated the financial troubles of the struggling ComFed Savings Bank.

headline: Militant Students in Ukraine Force the Party Into Retreat
abstract: LEAD: A missing force in Soviet politics, student militancy, has coalesced with a vengeance here in the Ukraine, pushing the Communist-dominated Parliament into deep retreat and forcing the nationalist movement to put a more aggressive edge on its agenda.

headline: U.S.-Canada Air Talks
abstract: LEAD: The United States and Canada have agreed to open talks that both nations said would greatly expand and deregulate airline service between the two countries.

headline: Democratic Leaders Divided on China Trade
abstract: LEAD: Democratic leaders in Congress are divided over whether to deny China favorable treatment on trade or to fashion more moderate legislation that may prove acceptable to the Bush Administration.

headline: Whistleblower Details Harassment on S.& L.
abstract: A former Federal examiner recounted today in vivid detail how she was harassed by superiors and ultimately dismissed for raising questions two years ago about the financial condition of a large savings and loan that regulators tried unsuccessfully to take over.   The account of the examiner, Lisa R. Walleri, offered a rare insight into the conflicts facing regulators and was supported today by a stunning admission by the Office of Thrift Supervision. At a Congressional hearing, an official of the agency said an internal review had found "substantial evidence" to support Mrs. Walleri's account and added that she was owed an apology by the Government. Faults Examination

headline: Small Traders Give Polish Economy a Facelift
abstract: LEAD: Off to one side of the towering Stalinist building that is Warsaw's Palace of Culture, a gift made by Moscow in the 1950's as a token of Communist solidarity, huddle hundreds of wooden stalls laden with everything from furs to frying pans.

headline: Technology; A Thirsty California Is Trying Desalination
abstract: FACING a possible fifth year of sustained drought, communities along the California coast are looking to desalinated ocean or bay water as a way to quench their thirst and water their lawns.    While most water districts are only looking at desalination now because alternative sources are dry, advances in technology over the past few years have helped make seawater a competitive source for drinking water. As California's population growth continues to outstrip its water supply, communities are looking beyond the current drought and investigating desalination as a long-term solution.

headline: A.T.&T. in Accounting Pact
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had agreed with Deutsche Bundespost Telekom to reduce accounting rates between the United States and Germany by 17 percent, effective next April.   The accounting rate determines how much phone companies pay one another for handling incoming international calls. Deutsche Bundespost had refused for years to lower its accounting rate.    Many more calls are made to Germany from the United States than in the opposite direction.This has contributed to a growing American trade deficit with Germany, which in turn has drawn increasing criticism from the American Government.   Over the summer the Federal Communications Commission announced that it would try to drive down the cost of international calls by 50 percent over three years.    The F.C.C. said it would do so by obliging American long-distance carriers to negotiate lower accounting rates.

headline: Utility Plans Efficient House
abstract: Southern California Edison will build 20 prototype "houses of the future" in the eastern suburbs of Los Angeles in 1991, the company said. The houses are designed so that water consumption will be reduced by 25 percent, electricity saved and the load factor of the utility's generating equipment increased.    Each house's lighting, heating, air-conditioning and security system will be controlled by a computer that uses touch-screen commands, like an automatic teller machine.

headline: U.S. Output Climbed 0.2% In September
abstract: LEAD: Industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Government reported today, with a 7.5 percent spurt in automobile production masking an underlying manufacturing weakness.

headline: Tech Notes;   Electricity From Wind
abstract: LEAD: With oil prices rising and concern about the environment growing, alternative ways to generate electricity are becoming even more attractive. Now a company in Livermore, Calif., U.S. Windpower Inc., is developing a wind-powered turbine for generating electricity that according to the California Energy Commission will cost 5.3 cents a kilowatt.

headline: In Urals City, the Communist Apparatus Ends but Not the Communist Power
abstract: Until recently, the ornate green building at the corner of Pushkin and Lenin Streets housed an intimidating organization called the Sverdlovsk People's Control Committee.    The committee, part of a nationwide citizens' network run by the Communist Party to inspect the work of government and industrial enterprises, was abolished last summer by the democratic reformers who have swept into office in the Russian Republic.

headline: Sarandi Journal; Land Program: What's Yours Is Mine
abstract: As Juvino Rodrigues de Aquino cleared brush with a sickle, a straining ox team plowed long furrows, slowly opening black soil as rich as chocolate cake.    The scene was pastoral, but in fact the barefoot farmer and his brother were tilling land they had occupied illegally.

headline: Britain Clears TV Merger
abstract: The British Government today cleared the proposed merger of Sky Television, headed by Rupert Murdoch, and British Satellite Broadcasting.   The Trade Secretary, Peter Lilley, said he would not refer the deal to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission.   Sky Television, which had four channels, and British Satellite, which had five, announced the merger agreement early last month.   The renamed five-channel British Sky Broadcasting is 50 percent owned by Mr. Murdoch's News International and 50 percent by British Satellite's existing shareholders: the publishers Pearson P.L.C. and Reed International P.L.C., the entertainment company Granada Group and the French conglomerate Chargeurs S.A.

headline: Managing; Sheepskins With a Corporate Twist
abstract: JAMES W. STERNITZKY, now a nuclear technical review engineer at the Wisconsin Public Service Corporation, took science courses at work in order to get promoted. When he discovered he could apply 33 credits from them toward a nuclear science degree from the University of Maryland, it was an unexpected bonus. "I had figured it would take seven years to get my degree, and it only took five," he said.    Diane M. Jones, an associate planning manager at the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in New Jersey, already has 73 of the 121 credits she needs for a bachelor's degree at Caldwell College. She got three of those credits for taking a four-day A.T.&.T marketing seminar, one of the 75 for-credit courses A.T.&T. offers to employees who want to advance up the corporate ladder. "You learn just as much, even more, in corporate courses, yet they're so much more convenient," said Ms. Jones.

headline: Iraq Tries to Offset U.S. Weapons With Low-Technology Strategies
abstract: Iraqi military commanders are taking steps to offset the technological superiority that will be the United States' major military advantage in any Persian Gulf conflict, American defense and intelligence specialists say.   The experts say the Iraqis are developing low-technology solutions like antiaircraft barrages from infantry that in effect mine the sky against low-flying aircraft, which might otherwise inflict devastating strikes.   The conclusion is the result of a broad review of the Iraqi military in which American analysts have also decided that the passage of time is rapidly degrading Iraqi military ability and some of the advanced weapons in Baghdad's arsenal through maintenance difficulties.

headline: U.S. Seeks Moratorium on Antarctic Minerals
abstract: The United States will seek a legally binding moratorium on mineral development in Antarctica when it meets with other nations next week to consider the continent's future, Bush Administration officials say.    The nations at the meeting are likely to agree on an enforceable prohibition on exploration for and extraction of oil and other minerals from the continent at their forthcoming meeting in Santiago, Chile, the officials said in recent interviews.

headline: Investments Flowing Out of U.S.
abstract: Foreigners are not the only investors moving money out of American financial markets, some economists and portfolio managers say. Increasingly, domestic institutions as well as individual investors are looking at foreign bond markets as preferable alternatives to staying at home.    The trend to move offshore was clear in the first half of the year, when American purchases of foreign securities totaled $18 billion, more than double the amount bought in the first six months of 1989.

headline: Rioting Laborers Disrupt Osaka In Protests over Police Corruption
abstract: LEAD: Police officers fought with rioting workers in this western Japanese city late today as protests over what the workers describe as police corruption entered a fifth day.

headline: At Mrs. Gorbachev's School, Hardy a Communist in Sight
abstract: The question before the 10th-grade history class at Raisa M. Gorbachev's old school was: How many students would like some day to enter the ranks of the Communist Party?   A few of the 34 students giggled. Anyone? No one.

headline: Prudential-Bache Deficit Of $250 Million Expected
abstract: The troubles enveloping Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. are expected to result in a $250 million loss for the year, and the firm's parent has moved in strongly to help stem the tide of red ink.   The Prudential Insurance Company announced its estimate of the loss in its brokerage division yesterday and said it would inject $200 million in new equity capital into the firm. Prudential also said it would assume a number of the assets in Prudential-Bache's portfolio, including those from its merchant banking activities.

headline: With Thatcher Gone, Labor Party Loses Lead in Polls
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's resignation has stunned the opposition Labor Party, erasing its lead in public opinion polls and leaving it with few clearly perceived policy differences with the governing Conservatives.   Public opinion polls that showed Labor 16 percentage points ahead of the Conservatives under Mrs. Thatcher last month now say that it would trail them under any one of the three candidates for the Conservative Party leadership -- Michael Heseltine, Douglas Hurd or John Major -- if a national election were held tomorrow.

headline: Continental Bank Stake of Tisch Up
abstract: LEAD: Laurence A. Tisch and his family have increased their stake in the Continental Bank Corporation to 8.5 percent from 5.6 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Tisch group said it might seek approval of the Federal Reserve Board to acquire more shares of the Chicago-based bank holding company.

headline: Alarmed Soviet Legislators Insist Gorbachev Give an Accounting
abstract: Alarmed by the nation's deepening economic crisis, the Soviet Parliament unexpectedly bolted from its prescribed agenda today and demanded an emergency address on the state of the union from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.    The surprising revolt by the normally passive lawmakers, who described the fears of economic collapse and famine they hear from their constituents, succeeded in forcing Mr. Gorbachev to agree to address them Friday on both the economy and the uncertain shift of government authority across the nation.

headline: Gulf Summit Talks End on a Mixed Note
abstract: The six nations of the Gulf Cooperation Council ended a four-day summit meeting today by warning Iraq that war was the only alternative to its peaceful withdrawal from all of Kuwait.    The council, the Persian Gulf's economic and military cooperation group, held its 11th annual summit meeting in Doha, the capital of Qatar.

headline: ARAFAT OPTIMISTIC ON GULF SOLUTION
abstract: LEAD: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that he was optimistic about prospects for a political solution to the Persian Gulf crisis after his latest talks in Baghdad with President Saddam Hussein.

headline: Recent Rate Policy of Fed
abstract: LEAD: Federal Reserve policy makers decided two weeks after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait to keep interest rates unchanged but to permit lower rates if economic conditions warranted, records released today show.

headline: U.N. GIVES IRAQ UNTIL JAN. 15 TO RETREAT OR FACE FORCE; HUSSEIN SAYS HE WILL FIGHT
abstract: The United Nations Security Council voted 12 to 2 with 1 abstention today to authorize the United States and its allies to expel Iraq from Kuwait by force if President Saddam Hussein does not withdraw his forces by Jan. 15.    Security Council members plan to observe "a pause of good will" until that date by taking no further actions against Iraq and concentrating on diplomatic efforts to promote a peaceful settlement.

headline: GTE Switches To A.T.&T.
abstract: The GTE Corporation announced yesterday that it had replaced Motorola Inc. with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company as its main vendor of cellular telephone system equipment and that it would buy more than $600 million worth of gear from A.T.&T. in the next several years.   The deal is the second setback for Motorola in less than three months. McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's largest cellular phone company, announced on Oct. 3 that it had signed a $250 million contract for L.M. Ericsson of Sweden to replace much of its Motorola equipment.   GTE is expected to become the nation's second-largest cellular company next spring, when it is scheduled to complete its $6 billion acquisition of the Contel Corporation. Shareholders of both companies approved that deal earlier this week.   Motorola said that it has won other large contracts recently, particularly overseas. Motorola and Ericsson dominate the $2 billion worldwide market for cellular systems, but A.T.&T. has been steadily gaining customers.   Shares in A.T.&T. rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $31, on the New York Stock Exchange while Motorola's stock tumbled $2, to $50.50.

headline: Crotone Journal; New U.S. Base: City Boon or NATO Boondoggle?
abstract: Nothing would please him more, Francesco Sottile said, than to have Fiat plunk down a huge plant and start churning out cars in this outpost on the arch of the Italian boot. It would be great if Olivetti were to produce computers here.    But Mr. Sottile, a realist as well as president of Crotone's Small Industries Association, recognizes that none of that is about to happen.

headline: Officials Leave Retail Group
abstract: Fifteen top executives and specialists of the National Retail Federation, the country's largest retail trade association, have chosen to take early retirement and most will not be replaced, the federation said yesterday in New York.   Among those who left are Charles Binder, executive vice president; Mary Ellen McGrory, senior vice president in charge of conferences; John Chay, vice president for management information systems; Vita Giancola, vice president, personnel, and Tomi Block, public relations director.   John J. Schultz, president of the federation's business services division, confirmed the retirements and said the moves had been voluntary.   "Eighteen people in our New York and Washington offices became eligible to take advantage of an early retirement opportunity which resulted when the former National Retail Merchants Association early this year merged with the American Retail Federation," Mr. Schultz said. "The consequent merger of the two organizations' pension plans created more generous pension benefits than they had separately."    Of the 15 who chose to leave, 12 are from the New York business services' office and three are from the government affairs office in Washington. Mr. Schultz said the organization would probably replace only a few of the executives.    The departures come when the association was preparing for its annual convention and trade show in January in New York. As many as 15,000 retail and allied industry executives usually attend the meeting. "We have arranged with a number of those who have left to return on a temporary consultant basis during the convention," Mr. Schultz said.

headline: Indian Parties Urge Cancellation Of Hindu Protests at Mosque Site
abstract: In a rare display of political unity, India's bitterly divided governing and opposition parties today jointly appealed to Hindu fundamentalists to abandon a plan to demonstrate at a disputed religious site in northern India, as the local authorities prepared for a new confrontation.   A spokesman for the Hindu groups tonight rejected the appeal to call off the planned action on Thursday in the city of Ayodhya, where Hindu fundamentalist groups have been seeking to build a temple on the site of a 16th-century mosque. But the spokesman said the demonstration at Ayodhya, in the form of volunteering arrest, would be "absolutely peaceful."

headline: Control Data Unit To Martin Marietta
abstract: LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation will purchase the Control Data Corporation's reconnaissance systems business segment for an undisclosed price, the companies said. The Air Force must approve the transaction.

headline: British Clear Company In 192 Deaths on Ferry
abstract: LEAD: The trial of a British shipping company and seven employees, charged with manslaughter after a Channel ferry capsized and killed 192 people in 1987, ended abruptly today when the judge ruled that the prosecution had failed to produce sufficient evidence.

headline: Report By U.N. On Arabs
abstract: Following are excerpts from the report submitted to the United Nations Security Council by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on the Palestianians in the Israeli-occupied territories:     Palestinians have expressed a profound feeling of vulnerability at all times, whether in the workplace, at school, in places of worship or simply walking down the street. This fear was compounded by their view that there was no recourse to any authority, other than the security forces who were so often responsible for the measures inflicted upon them.   They have stated that they feel unsafe even inside their homes, which were frequently subjected to midnight searches, and during which entire households, including children, were beaten. It was said that arrests during such operations were common. A wide range of collective punishments had, they said, become routine during the past three years, such as curfews, the demolition of homes, administrative detention and the uprooting of trees.   A system of arbitrary and heavy taxation had been imposed, which if not complied with, might lead to the confiscation of personal property and even arrest. Furthermore, the Palestinians have complained bitterly about a number of longstanding Israeli practices: the taking of land, especially for Israeili settlements and the privileged access that these settlements were given to water supplies; the closure for prolonged periods of the universities, and the periodic closure of elementary and high schools, which, in the Palestinian view amounted to a denial of their right to education, and the overall economic exploitation of the territories.   Palestinians emphasized that their distrust of the Israeli occupation authorities -- be they the security forces charged with maintaining law and order or officials of the Civil Administration whose role affected most aspects of their daily lives -- had grown so deep that they felt that only an impartial presence, properly mandated by the United Nations, would be able to provide them with a credible sense of protection.   In this connection, many of them drew attention to the military observers stationed in Jerusalem at the headquarters of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization , and inquired why they could not be assigned to monitor the situation in the occupied territories.   While they expressed appreciation for the humanitarian efforts carried out by representatives of international agencies and voluntary agencies, they were nevertheless deeply frustrated that those organizations were prevented from intervening or unable to intervene more effectively on their behalf. Israeli View of Strife     During the past three years I have had occasion to meet with a number of senior Israeli officials in New York, and have frequently voiced to them my concern about the situation in the occupied territores. In discussions with me, and with members of my staff in the area, the Israeli authorities have maintained that measures such as administrative detentions, curfews and the closure of schools and universities have been carried out in order to restore calm in the territories.   Israel's position has been, and continues to be, that it retains exclusive control over the territories it administers. Furthermore, the Israeli authorities point out that even under the Fourth Geneva Convention it would be for them to maintain law and order in the territories.    According to them, their policy during the past three years has been to put an end to the unrest in the territories which, in their view, is fomented by elements from the outside.   They note that the security forces are adhering to strict regulations determined by the Minister for Defence and that violations of those regulations are punishable. In response to expressions of concern regarding the need for the safety and protection of the Palestinians, the Israeli authorities point out that the many Palestinians who have been killed by other Palestinians should be a matter of equal concern to the international community.    Had it been possible for me to end a mission to the area at the present time, it would have followed up on the discussions begun last summer with the Israeli authorities and the Palestinian leadership. The Israeli authorities indicated at that time that they would be implementing new measures in the territories.    It should be noted that, in the subsequent months, there was a decreased military presence in the occupied territories and a decline in casualties resulting from actions involving the Israeli security forces there. Practical U.N. Steps     Further, there has also been a reopening of certain academic institutions. Nevertheless, the essential facts of the occupation have not changed and the potential for friction and confrontation between Israelis and Palestinians has remained very high, as evidenced by the tragic events of Oct. 8, 1990. The spate of violent attacks that have occurred since then, with more bloodshed on both sides, has generated further mistrust and bitterness.   The issue before us today is what practical steps can, in fact, be taken by the international community to insure the safety and protection of the Palestinian civilians living under Israeli occupation. Clearly, the numerous appeals -- whether by the Security Council, by myself as Secretary General, by individual Member States or by I.C.R.C., which is the custodian of the Geneva Conventions -- to the Israeli authorities to abide by their obligations under the Fourth Geneva Convention have been ineffective.

headline: Solidarity, Shaken by Dark Horse, Is Closing Ranks Behind Walesa
abstract: Staggered by the electoral appeal of Stanislaw Tyminski and uncertain what it portends for the Dec. 9 presidential elections, the leaders of the deeply divided Solidarity movement are closing ranks behind the candidacy of Lech Walesa.   In a recrimination-filled meeting that ended early this morning, the caucus of Solidarity legislators approved a resolution of support for Mr. Walesa, who seemed uncertain how to counter the surge in popularity that carried Mr. Tyminski to a second-place finish in the initial phase of the campaign.

headline: Market Place; Sharper Image Slipping a Bit
abstract: AFTER a few years of sales and earnings setbacks, the Sharper Image, one of specialty retailing's spectacular growth companies of the last decade, is losing some of the edge implied by its name.    The founder, chairman, president and owner of 75 percent of the company, Richard Thalheimer, does not deny it. "I'm on the spot," he said on a recent visit to New York. "I've got to show an earnings increase in the next fiscal year. The bankers are wondering why a company with our fine reputation can't make a profit. So, I find myself forced to take some drastic steps such as cutting overall costs and especially our advertising costs."

headline: Sakharov's Death, a Year Later: Russia Mourns Its Missing Moralist
abstract: A year later, the graveyard earth has settled firm and flat above the remains of Andrei D. Sakharov, leaving his friends in the battered democracy movement still fathoming the loss of the human rights champion who so prodded the Soviet conscience.    Mr. Sakharov's simple grave in a wooded enclave on the southwest edge of the city displays fresh-cut pine, its aroma so elegiacal amid a dusting of snow.

headline: Not the Cheapest Form of Transportation
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: ARIZONA GOVERNOR BACKS DECONCINI
abstract: After two arduous days of testimony by a Federal regulator about pressure from five Senators on behalf of a banking constituent, the Senate Ethics Committee today had a change of pace.   Gov. Rose Mofford of Arizona testified before the committee as a character witness for Senator Dennis DeConcini, attesting to his integrity and to the good he had done for his Arizona constituents.

headline: Article 673090 -- No Title
abstract: Robbers took at least $1 million in gold ingots and cash today from a plane chartered by Brinks Inc., the police said. The plane had just landed at Montreal's Dorval airport on a regular flight from Toronto when the robbers boarded it, said Lieut. Pierre Lebel, a police spokesman. He said they took the gold and the cash and escaped in a truck. The police later found the truck, with a shotgun inside, in the suburb of Saint-Laurent.

headline: Equitable Life Denies Rumors
abstract: Rumors that the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States had missed a debt payment and was near insolvency swept through financial markets yesterday despite strenuous denials by the company.   Currency and bond traders said the rumors asserted that the Equitable, the nation's third-largest life insurer, had failed to make a bond payment and that it would seek bankruptcy protection. The rumors are believed to have begun in the London markets.   The vague rumors tended to focus on recent losses the Equitable has suffered through its guaranteed investment contracts, which are high-yield bond-like obligations the insurance giant sold to institutional investors in the 1980's. Equitable, which has about $44.9 billion in assets, has already suffered a loss of about $1 billion on these contracts.    "The Equitable is in solid financial condition and is going about business as usual," said Joseph J. Melone, president of the life insurance giant.    Yesterday, a deputy superintendent of New York State's insurance agency said the agency knew of no reason to believe that the Equitable cannot meet its commitments to policyholders.

headline: A Site of Ageless Piety and Modern Strife
abstract: LEAD: A 35-acre plateau in the eastern half of the ancient walled city of Jerusalem has been a site of nationalist and religious struggles for more than 20 years.

headline: Another Round on Smoot-Hawley
abstract: To the Editor:   A letter from Jude Wanniski on Dec. 23, contained a historical error. He wrote that "The Smoot-Hawley legislation came first. It triggered the crash of 1929."    Actually, the drastic trade tariffs became law when President Hoover signed Smoot-Hawley on June 17, 1930 -- eight months after the stock market crash of October 1929.  E.H. LEONI  New York, N.Y., Dec. 24

headline: London Journal; Now It's Noblesse Oblige vs. the Trickle-Downers
abstract: The Duke and the Lady are in a working-class struggle, of sorts.   A legal skirmish over whether Britain still has a working class has pitted Lady Porter, Conservative leader of the Westminster City Council and an heiress to the Tesco supermarket fortune, against the Duke of Westminster, the nation's wealthiest man.   The winner -- Lady Porter, who says the working class no longer exists, or the Duke, who says it does -- could be decided next month when Britain's High Court hears each side's arguments. A Fortune of Billions     But some onlookers say the fight is actually a much larger contest in which the free-market principles and enterprise culture of modern-day Thatcherism are squaring off against the old-school noblesse oblige of Britain's patricians.

headline: Northrop Sets Revamping
abstract: The Northrop Corporation said today that it would close a missile manufacturing plant in Newbury Park, Calif., next year and eliminate about 800 jobs in a restructuring that includes reorganizing its electronics businesses.   Military contractors, recognizing that business is slowing because of Federal budget cuts, have been slimming down for some time.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Dime Savings Bank of New York, New York, named C. David Bushley senior vice president and general manager of mortgage banking. * First International Bank, Chula Vista, Calif., appointed Suzanne Baril vice president and manager of its Bankcard department. * First Western Bancorp Inc., New Castle, Pa., named Thomas O'Shane president and chief executive, replacing John Sant, who is retiring. * Jefferson Bancorp Inc., Miami Beach, named Beverly J. Davis vice president of human resources. * K-Tron International Inc., Pitman, N.J., a manufacturer of digital measurement products, appointed Marcel O. Rohr president and chief operating officer. The company treasurer, Ronald G. Larson, added the titles of senior vice president and chief financial officer. * M/A-Com Inc., Burlington, Mass., a producer of electronic components, named Dr. John M. Herman 3d vice president and general manager of its semiconductor division. * Omega Hydrocarbons Ltd., Calgary, Alberta, named Thomas J. Hall chairman and chief executive. His son, Dennis Hall, replaces him as president. * Technology Applications Inc., Alexandria, Va., a professional and technical services company, promoted Lee Cooper to vice president of its applied sciences division. * Vical Inc., San Diego, a biopharmaceutical company, appointed Dr. Dannie H. King executive vice president and chief technical officer. * Wisconsin Toy Co., New York, a subsidiary of Value Merchants Inc., Milwaukee, named Alan Chaikin president and chief operating officer.

headline: Business Diary/November 18-23
abstract: COMPANIES Milken's Exile From the World That Milken Built  He spent tens of millions on his defense, and his lawyers were the very best. But on Wednesday, Michael R. Milken, the most powerful financier of his time, was sentenced to 10 years in prison, to be followed by 3 years of community service. It was the toughest sentence by far for anyone caught in Wall Street's recent scandals, from a judge familiar with the financial community's ways. Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood gave up a lucrative partnership in a New York law firm, specializing in antitrust law, for the relatively modest pay of the bench. She offered Mr. Milken the prospect of a milder sentence if he helped prosecutors snare others, but he is banned from the securities industry for life. Some mourn Mr. Milken's exile, saying that the collapse of the "junk bond" market since he left Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. proves how indispensable he is. But how much are those bonds truly worth if their value depends on the fate of one firm and one man? Accountants Go Under  Laventhol & Horwath ultimately couldn't even balance its own books. The nation's seventh-largest accounting firm asked for bankruptcy protection from creditors on Wednesday -- apparently the largest such filing by a professional services firm. The firm had a negative net worth of $6.9 million as of Oct. 13. It also faces lawsuits seeking nearly $2 billion over its handling of such clients as the P.T.L. ministry and its favorable feasibility studies for real estate projects that would have needed divine intervention to succeed. Those trying to collect from Laventhol at this point might do just as well directing their prayers to Jim and Tammy. Bad Mortgages at Citicorp  How can a bank lose by pumping out plenty of mortgages when the housing market is strong? As long as borrowers provide a fat down payment, why bother pawing through piles of their financial records? Citicorp's latest experience is providing some answers. The company said mortgages delinquent 90 days or more or in foreclosure have risen from 3 to 3.6 percent of dollar volume during the third quarter. Falling home prices, especially in the Northeast, are partly to blame, but Arthur P. Soter, a banking analyst at Morgan Stanley, also points to relaxed lending criteria. The surprise is that it happened at Citicorp, the nation's largest home lender. "This is not some mad dash for growth by an inexperienced, wet-behind-the-ears player," Mr. Soter said. Citicorp has decided to take more care in verifying applicants' income and down-payment sources. But more loans might go sour. As Mr. Soter said, "Problems related to real estate tend to have a fairly long tail." Move Over, Wayne Gretzky The sports world's probable greatest money-earner was laid to rest in an oak coffin a week ago at age 29 in Canada, where he was bred. Northern Dancer's achievements only began with his victories in the 1964 Kentucky Derby -- a track record -- and the Preakness. At stud, he enriched his thoroughbred breed with foals, including 123 stakes winners, that won more than $26 million. His descendants included more than 1,000 stakes winners. Bidding by European breeders and Arab sheiks for his royal bloodline pushed prices for his yearlings past $10 million, and his stud fee to $1 million. "He was a national hero in Canada, along with Wayne Gretzky," the hockey star, said Bernard McCormack, general manager of Winfields Farm near Toronto, where Northern Dancer rests. Wait 'til all the athletes concerned that their multimillion-dollar salaries are lower than someone else's hear about all this. Buyout Funds Reborn  Merger mania still lives. Forstmann Little & Company and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company are having some initial success in raising new buyout funds of $1 billion to $2 billion. CBS Plot Thickens  Maybe CBS should consult a script doctor to straighten out its tortured plot. The network is in the awkward position of telling affiliates about its weaknesses and advertisers about its strengths. CBS executives said last week that they expect a loss this quarter, and they asked affiliated stations to swallow a 20 percent, $30 million cut in payments to carry CBS shows. Instead of planning the usual three-day bash for affiliates in Los Angeles next year, with parties, invitations to spouses and walk-ons by network stars, CBS will hold a sober day-and-a-half meeting in New York in June just for station managers. Laurence A. Tisch, president of CBS, said increased competition for viewers and advertisers is "changing the fundamental economics of network television." CBS is boasting to advertisers, meanwhile, that it will remain the best way to reach a huge audience, with spots on "60 Minutes" likely to have as many viewers as a blanket campaign on cable networks. Air Fare Bonanza  The airlines might fill up their seats with two-fers, but barely have money to go on with the show. In a frenzy to retain market shares, the nation's airlines are offering free companion tickets, most until Feb. 28. "The industry is going to lose a fortune," said Helane Becker, an analyst at Shearson Lehman. With the high cost of fuel, she added, "A couple of airline companies are going to have great difficulty surviving." Buy now, she said, because the deals are unlikely to last into March. THE ECONOMY   Easing Up on Bankers  Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady promised last week to do more for bankers than urging them to be generous with loans. Mr. Brady, sharing the Bush Administration's concern that tight credit is choking the economy, asked regulators last week to go easier in examining bank finances. "Use some judgment," he said. "Don't overreact." Bankers say they need an overhaul of regulations that fragment and restrict their industry, and Mr. Brady promised to recommend new laws by next year. Trading at a Crawl  A power outage halted trading for 94 minutes Friday at the New York Stock Exchange. Business was so sluggish that some said they failed to notice when trading resumed. Oil prices rose $2.12 last week, to $31.90, after President Bush's tough talk in the Middle East. What little other economic news there was last week was discouraging. Initial unemployment claims for the week ended Nov. 10 rose to 488,000, the highest level in seven years. "An ominous sign," Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist of Hongkongbank said.  Economic Justice  The economic slowdown has struck some of the healthiest states the hardest, while leaving weaker states improved. October unemployment figures indicate that even with the auto industry in retreat, Michigan's jobless rate was lower than a year ago, as the agriculture and machinery sectors picked up. In Texas, farm exports and Mexican trade quickened before the jump in oil prices, leaving unemployment just one-tenth of 1 percent higher than New York's. And California, its defense plants and real estate ailing, has a higher jobless rate than the nation's. Fear of Science  Americans continue to shun advanced study in technical fields essential to the nation's economic health. According to a recent survey, only 43 percent of the 933 doctorates in mathematics awarded in the United States in the last academic year went to American citizens -- a record low. Engineering and several other sciences show similar trends. Many foreign students do stay to seek their fortune in the United States. But for top scientists and engineers, it is a scant fortune: a median starting salary for mathematicians of about $32,000, less than many Wall Street M.B.A.'s earn their first six months out. INTERNATIONAL   The Bush Mold in Britain?  Will Great Britain turn to a George Bush, of sorts, for conservatism with a lighter hand? After 11 1/2 years of unwavering right-wing rule under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, her Conservative Party chooses a new leader, and Prime Minister, this week. Michael Heseltine, whose challenge brought about her resignation announcement on Thursday, proffers a renewed role for government in aiding the poor, improving schools and reviving inner cities. But Mrs. Thatcher's resignation also throws the contest open to two members of her Cabinet. Douglas Hurd, the Foreign Secretary, is more pragmaticthan she is -- and, like Mr. Heseltine, more pro-European. Only John Major, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, might closely follow the Thatcher line. A defender of free markets and a critic of a federated Europe, he appears to be Mrs. Thatcher's first choice. Guinness in Spain  When Ernest Hemingway was in Spain, it is said, he liked nothing more than an aged Rioja. Guinness P.L.C. is betting that Spaniards and latter-day Hemingways will switch from sherry and red wine to beer. The London-based company last week announced an agreement to pay $1.02 billion for the Spanish brewer La Cruz del Campo S.A. Cruzcampo has more than a fifth of Spain's beer market, with the fastest growth and strongest profits.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Auto Suture Company U.S.A., a unit of the United States Surgical Corp., Norwalk, Conn., promoted Judith M. Stant to vice president and general manager.

headline: D.M.B.&B. Plans to Create An Agency Network in Asia
abstract: D'ARCY MASIUS BENTON & BOWLES is expected to announce today the creation of a broad network of agencies in Asia.    D.M.B.&B.'s move comes as an increasing number of international agencies are scrambling to establish strong networks in Asia. Many industry executives believe that parts of Asia are fast becoming among the leading areas for advertising growth and will rival Europe within the next few years.

headline: Costly Accounting Rule on Benefits for Retirees Adopted
abstract: In the face of opposition from some of the country's largest companies, the board that makes the nation's accounting rules voted unanimously yesterday to adopt requirements that employers say will slash millions of dollars from their annual earnings.   The seven-member Financial Accounting Standards Board gave final approval to rules requiring companies to subtract from current earnings part of the cost of medical benefits promised to future retirees.

headline: Senate Votes Open Aid For Cambodian Rebels
abstract: LEAD: The Senate today approved $20 million in new American humanitarian aid to Cambodians, an apparent replacement for the previous policy of covert aid to rebels fighting the Vietnamese-backed Government.

headline: Z-Nix Settles Suit Against Microsoft
abstract: The Z-Nix Company, a small personal computer accessory maker, has settled its lawsuit accusing the software giant Microsoft of restraint of trade and breach of contract. Under terms of the settlement, Microsoft will license Z-Nix to use Microsoft's Windows software through 1991. It will then negotiate a renewal with Z-Nix. Neither company disclosed details.   Z-Nix, based in Pomona, makes the computer-control device known as a mouse. It filed the $4.5 million suit in Federal court in Los Angeles last week. The suit contended that Microsoft had unfairly doubled its $27.50-a-copy charge for Windows when Z-Nix wanted to pair the software with its own mouse device.

headline: AQUINO UNTOPPLED, AT LEAST FOR NOW
abstract: LEAD: The political scene in the Philippines is a little bit like California's seismic situation: there are regular tremors, and each rumbling provokes new doubts about if and when ''the big one'' will strike.

headline: Taco Bell Finds Price of Success (59)
abstract: Twice a week, Kendall Williams, a 26-year-old department store clerk, drives to Taco Bell for lunch from his job at a mall here.    "They have fast service, and the price is good," said Mr. Williams, as he handed over $2.66 for a large burrito and a small Pepsi. "I like a change of pace from burgers, and this is a fast way to get Mexican food."

headline: Poll Finds Strong Support for Bush's Goals, but Reluctance to Start a War
abstract: LEAD: Americans overwhelmingly support President Bush's goals in the Persian Gulf, but are not ready to start a war for them, according to a study of public opinion released today.

headline: Standard Register Sets Plant Closings
abstract: Standard Register Inc. said it would close plants in New York, Colorado and Illinois and reduce its work force of about 6,100 people by 5 percent through attrition, early retirement and terminations, John K. Darragh, Standard Register president and chief executive, said in a prepared statement.   He said forms plants in Rochester and Denver and a print center in Peoria, Ill., would be closed. The changes will cost $14 million but will reduce projected annual expenses by $12 million, the company said. It said the plan should be completed by next March 31.

headline: U.S. SAYS ITS TROOPS WON'T BE ROTATED UNTIL CRISIS IS OVER
abstract: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the Pentagon was no longer planning to rotate troops through Saudi Arabia and that the American forces already in the Persian Gulf area or headed there would remain for the duration of the crisis.   Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of the forces in the gulf, and other military leaders had been planning to set up a program for rotating troops in Saudi Arabia every six to eight months. But Mr. Cheney and other Pentagon officials indicated today that those plans have been dropped.

headline: Merrill Lynch Is Expected To Increase Customer Fees
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage firm, plans to tell its brokers today that it will raise some customer fees on Feb. 1, Merrill executives said yesterday.    They said commissions on stock-trade orders valued at more than $5,000 would be increased by 5 percent. The commission on stock trades under $5,000 will not be affected.

headline: U.S. to Send 300 More Planes to Gulf Region, Pentagon Says
abstract: The United States, continuing its military buildup for a possible attack against Iraq after Jan. 15, is sending 300 more planes to the Persian Gulf region in the next several weeks, Pentagon officials said today.    The additional aircraft would increase to about 1,200, from 900, the number of Air Force planes in the region. The Navy and Marines have about 600 to 700 aircraft in the region or on the way, primarily aboard the six aircraft carriers that will be in the area by early next year.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * CMS Energy Corp., Dearborn, Mich., has established a $500 million line of credit with a group of banks led by Union Bank and Citibank. * Dayton Hudson Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $600 million offering of debt securities and warrants. * Eli Lilly & Co. has filed for a shelf offering of up to $500 million in debt securities through Morgan Stanley & Co. * Hurco Companies Inc., Indianapolis, has privately placed $12.5 million in 10.37 percent senior notes with an undisclosed institutional investor.  Common Stock  * Cygnus Therapeutic Systems, Redwood City, Calif., has filed for an initial public offering of three million common shares through Robertson, Stephens & Co. * Enron Oil and Gas Co., Houston, a unit of the Enron Corp., has postponed indefinitely an offering of 4.1 million common shares because of market conditions. * Penn Central Corp.'s board has authorized the buyback of five million common shares at a price of $21 a share in cash. Friday's New York Stock Exchange closing price was $19.50 a share.  Ratings  * Allied-Signal Inc.'s debt rating is under review for possible downgrading by the Standard & Poor's Corp. * McDonnell Douglas Finance Corp.'s long-term debt rating has been lowered to Baa-2, from Baa-1, and its subordinated debt rating to Ba-1, from Baa-3, by Moody's Investors Service. The commercial paper rating was also cut to Prime-3, from Prime-2. The diversified finance company is based in Long Beach, Calif. * Niagara Mohawk Power Corp.'s debt rating is under review for possible upgrading by Moody's. * Pennsylvania Power and Light Co.'s senior secured debt rating has been increased to A, from A-, by S.&P. * Rochester Telephone Corp.'s senior secured debt rating has been lowered to A+, from AA, and senior unsecured debt and preferred stock to A, from AA-, by S.&P. The commercial paper rating was cut to A-1, from A-1+.

headline: Market Place; Real Estate Unit Heads for Risk
abstract: THE Catellus Development Corporation is about to do something that terrifies most real estate companies: trade publicly.    The company, a subsidiary of the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation, will be spun off to Santa Fe shareholders early next month as part of the parent company's effort to fend off takeovers. When the move is completed, Catellus, with about two million acres of developed and undeveloped land and assets valued at more than $3 billion, will be the largest publicly traded real estate company in the country.

headline: Iraq Says U.N. Backing for Use of Force Is 'No Concern to Us'
abstract: Iraq lashed out at the United States today for sponsoring a resolution in the United Nations Security Council to allow the use of military force to oust Iraqi forces from Kuwait, and said it would ignore any deadline set in the resolution.    "Any decision taken by the Security Council under the present U.S. hegemony is of no concern to us," the Government said in a report in the state-run newspaper Al Thawra. "It will not force us to step back or relinquish our national historical rights."

headline: Data Bank/November 18, 1990
abstract: Industrial Production Index   Oct.   Sept.   Aug. Aug.
