headline: Burlington Stake
abstract: The 26,000 employees and managers of Burlington Industries have acquired a majority ownership and voting control of the textile giant. The company established an employee stock ownership plan last year. The latest transaction, which was announced on Tuesday, gives employees and management all of the voting stock and 51 percent of the company's common equity.

headline: Forum; The Collaborative Organization
abstract: FASHIONABLE organizations today are flattening their hierarchies, streamlining operations and using the word "empower" a lot. The most adventurous increasingly rely on information technology to reshape themselves. They buy into the idea that network technologies will let them become lean and mean so they can do more work with fewer people.   Unfortunately, the network to organizational hell is wired with good intentions. Many companies are learning the hard way that their networks are designed in ways that virtually guarantee the waste of money and time.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Wal-Mart Set to Buy Discount Club Chain
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, already the operater of the nation's largest chain of wholesale warehouse clubs, will acquire the Wholesale Club Inc., which operates 27 membership clubs, for $21 a share, or a total of $178 million.   The $18 billion membership warehouse club industry sells discounted merchandise to businessmen and consumers who pay small membership fees. Wholesale Club had sales of $330 million for the first half of its fiscal year, ended Aug. 4.

headline: MENEM'S REFORMS PROVOKE BACKLASH
abstract: LEAD: For a President who likes to duck his bodyguards, drive his own car, frequent the nightspots and soccer stadiums and generally mix with the throngs, the reviews that Carlos Saul Menem gets from the people these days are disquieting.

headline: Report Notes Doubt Over Iraq's Weaponry
abstract: LEAD: Much of Iraq's military equipment may be obsolete by Western standards, but modifications and chemical weapons make it an unpredictable potential foe, Jane's Defense Weekly reported today.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., Zurich, the engineering concern, and Ansaldo S.p.A., an Italian state-owned engineering company, ended their joint venture accords. * Calvary Holdings Inc., New York, which owns about 2 percent of the common shares of Diceon Electronics Inc., Irvine, Calif., started a tender offer for the shares it does not already own at $5.25 a share. * Crane Co., New York, a diversified building concern, sold two of its operating units, Sea-Pac Sales and McAvity, for a total of about $19 million. * Divi Hotels N.V., Ithaca, N.Y., said that Tomdor Ltd. had agreed to purchase the Divi Anchorage Beach Hotel on Antigua for $12 million. * Gradco Systems Inc., Irvine, Calif., a maker of copier sorters, said it had agreed to sell substantially all of the assets of its copier business to its majority-owned subsidiary Gradco (Japan) Inc. * Interco Inc., St. Louis, ended its agreement to sell Sky City Stores Inc. to Sky City Holding Corp., an investor group. No reason was given. * Morgan Keegan Inc., Memphis, said that it had completed the acquisition of substantially all operating assets of Scharff & Jones Inc., an investment firm based in New Orleans. Terms were not disclosed. * Pet Inc., St. Louis, a food products subsidiary of the Whitman Company, said it would close its frozen pie plant in Frankfort, Mich., on Feb. 3. The factory's 115 workers will be offered severance packages.  * Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, Jerusalem, said it had entered into a memorandum of intent with W. R. Grace & Co., New York, the diversified industrial concern, for Teva to purchase Grace's 49.8 percent interest in Tag Pharmaceuticals Inc. for $20 million. * Toyota Motor Corp., Tokyo, said it will begin an experimental four-day workweek at its Japanese auto factories in January. * Woolworth Corp., New York, said that it had opened its first store in what had been East Germany. The site in Halle was occupied by Woolworth's German subsidiary before World War II.

headline: Limited's Founder Sells Some Stock
abstract: Leslie H. Wexner, founder, chairman and president of the Limited Inc., said in a financial statement that he had sold 3.5 million of the retail fashion chain's common shares. Mr. Wexner still retains more than 115.3 million Limited shares, or about 30.3 percent of the common shares outstanding.    In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Wexner said he had sold the shares between Nov. 14 and Nov. 21 at prices ranging from $13.875 to $14.75 each. Executives close to the Limited's founder said he had sold the shares to raise cash for philanthropic activities and to build new homes for himself in Columbus, Ohio, and New York City. The Limited's common stock closed yesterday at 17, up 25 cents, so that at yesterday's value Mr. Wexner's remaining stock is worth about $1.96 billion.

headline: G.E. Contract
abstract: The Air Force has awarded an additional $557 million contract to the General Electric Company for the Navstar Global Positioning System of navigation-data satellites, the Pentagon said. The work on 20 replacement satellites will be done at plants in Princeton and Nutley, N.J. Contracts totaling $99 million will expire at the end of the year, and the new contract is expected to be completed in 1999.

headline: U.S. Asking U.N. Chief to Send His Inquiry Team to Israel Quickly
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration is urging Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations to send a fact-finding mission to Jerusalem soon, despite Israel's objections. In doing so, Washington is trying to head off a possible new campaign to condemn Israel here, an effort that would further deflect attention from the Persian

headline: No Lenin, No Marx and, Just Maybe, No Communist Party in Prague
abstract: LEAD: In his faded jeans and blue, short-sleeved polo shirt sporting a ''Levis'' label, Vasil Mohorita, a tall 38-year-old, looks nothing like his grizzled, somber-suited predecessors.

headline: REVOLUTION BRINGS BANGLADESH HOPE
abstract: After 19 years of independence in which this vulnerable nation has known little else but human tragedy and natural disaster, the capital is alive today with new hopes.    Against long odds and with stunning speed, an eight-day revolution last week not only brought down the eight-year-old military Government of Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, but also did it with the decisive support of the army.

headline: Family Business: Trying to Gain a Brother's Freedom
abstract: Moments before the Iraqi jetliner touched down at Saddam International Airport this afternoon, Bill Stevenson turned to a fellow passenger and explained that he simply could not be concerned for now about the larger issues of international law and national sovereignty, and of the new American role in the Persian Gulf.   "I'm here on family business," he said, gently brushing his right hand back and forth across the cover of his United States passport. "The politics of it don't matter, the governments don't matter. I'm here to find my brother, and to take him home."

headline: Hanover Deal For Deposits Of Goldome
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 13 branches in the New York City area and about $1.6 billion of deposits from Goldome F.S.B., a Buffalo savings bank.    The purchase is the latest example of banks' growing appetites for the consumer deposits of troubled savings institutions. Although banks have generally avoided buying the loans and real estate holdings of savings institions, they have viewed purchases of consumer deposits and branches as an inexpensive way to expand in one of the most profitable parts of the banking business.

headline: D.E.A. Denies Pan Am Bomb Tie
abstract: The Drug Enforcement Administration denied today that it knew of any connection between a Federal drug operation and the 1988 bombing of a Pan American World Airways jet that left 270 people dead.   "D.E.A.'s inquiry has to date revealed no evidence whatsoever to support any of the allegations that a D.E.A. operation was in any way involved in the Pan Am tragedy," the drug agency's administrator, Robert Bonner, said in a statement.

headline: As Soviet Oil Becomes a Trickle, Havel Seeks Gorbachev Meeting
abstract: LEAD: The Czechoslovak Prime Minister met today with the Soviet Ambassador in an effort to resolve a crisis here as new measures were announced to stop panic buying of gasoline.

headline: Bookstores Heed Call on Civil War
abstract: LEAD: After taking public television by storm with the recent series on PBS, the Civil War is now cutting a swath through the nation's bookstores. More than 75 stores nationwide already specialize in Civil War books, but now many general bookstores - including the Doubleday Book Shop on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan - are adding Civil

headline: Coke and Nestle Plan Coffee and Tea Drinks
abstract: Nestle S.A., the world's largest food and coffee company, and the Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink company, said yesterday that they were negotiating a joint venture to make and market coffee and tea drinks under the Nestle Nescafe and Nestea brand names.    The venture would be owned and financed equally by Coca-Cola, which is based in Atlanta, and Nestle, which is based in Vevay, Switzerland. The two companies signed a letter of protocol to negotiate a joint venture. Nestle is the No. 1 coffee company in Europe and ranks No. 3 in the United States coffee market, where its brands include Hills Brothers, MJB and Taster's Choice instant coffee.    The initial investment is expected to total $100 million, the two companies said in a statement.    Nestle and Coca-Cola are especially interested in canned ready-to-drink coffee. Japan has by far the most developed market for such beverages, with annual sales totaling more than $10 billion. Both Nestle and Coke separately offer canned coffee in Japan, although their joint venture will not operate there. Coke's canned coffee in Japan, called Georgia Coffee Original, is presweetened and is usually drunk at room temperature or chilled.    "We believe the ready-to-drink coffee market outside of Japan is basically underdeveloped," said Randal W. Donaldson, a Coke spokesman.   Coke could benefit from the venture by putting Coke canned-coffee formulations under the Nestle trademarks, Mr. Donaldson said; Nestle benefits from access to Coke's distribution network in nearly 170 countries. Exact details of the venture are still to be negotiated.    Industry analysts said the venture had great potential but was unlikely to have much short-term benefit.

headline: MAN IN THE NEWS: John Major; A Tory of Humble Origins
abstract: One measure of the depth of class division in Britain may be the fixation on the "classless society" that John Major, the son of a onetime circus performer and the man who will become Prime Minister on Wednesday, wants to bring about.     Like his patron, Margaret Thatcher, Mr. Major springs from the lower middle class. But unlike her, he does not try to imitate the speech and mannerisms of earlier upper-class Conservative Party leaders with a private school background, people like Winston Churchill, Anthony Eden and Harold Macmillan.

headline: Iraqi Leader's Message To National Assembly
abstract: Following is the text of President Saddam Hussein's message to the Iraqi National Assembly, broadcast on the Baghdad radio and translated by the Federal Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:    In the name of God, the merciful, the compassionate. Mr. National Assembly Speaker, members: Peace be upon you. Under difficult conditions, the strength of the believers' affiliation and loyalty is put to the test. Their action in the service of principles is also put to the test. Iraqis in general, and you among them, have proved that on very dark nights, the spark of faith glows in a much nicer way than on ordinary nights. Adherence to the supreme principles governing the relation between man and his Creator and his duty toward Him, as well as the relation between the Iraqis with all peoples, becomes even stronger in the more difficult circumstances.

headline: Quayle Meets With Saudi Royalty And Seeks More Aid for Military
abstract: Vice President Dan Quayle met with this country's rulers today and said he wanted the Saudis and Kuwait's exiled Government to provide greater financial support to the United States military effort in the Persian Gulf.   "They will have to be making more contributions" because of the likelihood that American troops will remain in the gulf longer than initially anticipated, the Vice President told reporters before his meetings.

headline: Bulgarian Strategy Is Made in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: A group of American experts has taken on the moribund economy of newly democratic Bulgaria and has drawn up a plan for transforming it into a supply-side, free market.

headline: Tearful Walesa Is Sworn In as President
abstract: Lech Walesa, the 47-year-old shipyard electrician and founder of the Solidarity movement, was sworn in as Poland's President today in a day of pageantry that evoked this country's centuries of struggle against dismemberment and domination.    Blinking back tears, Mr. Walesa took the oath of office at noon at the lectern of Parliament and promised to shake this nation of 38 million from "passivity and discouragement."

headline: Under Baghdad's Iron Fist, Hint of Other Opinions
abstract: LEAD: A middle-level Iraqi official picked up his office telephone tonight, listened, and then smiled. Then he turned to a Westerner waiting in the office and gave a thumbs-up sign.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: ECONOMY    New York City's economy has some surprising strength and shows little evidence of irreversible decline. Still, most of the enterprises that built the city face complicated problems.  [ Page A1. ]   Big military contractors seem to be immune to punishment when they cheat the Government. Though many Pentagon suppliers have been convicted of fraud, none have been barred from more Government work.  [ A1. ]   Commodity futures traders say they help the oil industry to cope with price swings. They made their case at the opening here of the annual convention of the American Petroleum Institute.  [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL    The Japanese are giving ground grudgingly in retailing. Small shops are fighting to preserve their domination in the face of challenges from large stores and pressure from the United States.  [ A1. ]   Haagen-Dazs is taking on the land of napoleons and eclairs. Its new French shops are part of a $50 million campaign by the American ice cream maker to expand European sales.  [ D8. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS    The Tribune Company has resisted investment banking logic. The owner of The Daily News has not expanded television business.  [ D1. ]  In its battle with strikers, The News has turned to sidewalk hawkers to sell the paper.  [ B1. ]   All-sports radio stations are considered AM radio's best chance for building a base among males listeners. WFAN in New York is now one of the area's most successful radio stations.  [ D1. ]   Entertainment Weekly is showing new energy and confidence after a shaky debut earlier this year. The magazine has a new design and a new, more mainstream direction.  [ D6. ]   Time Publishing is testing a new magazine on the newsstands. A glossy life-style publication, Martha Stewart Living, will be available today, with a second test planned for the spring.  [ D6. ]   The TV networks seem to have cut the volume of their outcry against new Nielsen findings. Bill Carter: Television.  [ D6. ]   The oldest advertising agency in Japan has been concentrating on its Asian base, but is now opening offices in Eastern Europe and expanding its U.S. operations. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D7. ] COMPANIES    Trans World Airlines has proposed buying Pan Am for $150 million in cash and $300 million in securities.  [ D1. ]   The chairman of Microsoft, William Gates, promises to begin a "crusade" for a new way of using computers. The company wants to increase the range of information accessible from desktop personal computers.  [ D1. ]   Citicorp is trying to sell about $1 billion of convertible preferred shares in a private sale in Europe and the Middle East.  [ D5. ]   The failure of the Freedom National Bank of New York was more than just the demise of another shaky financial institution. It was the end of an idealistic venture begun during the height of the 1960's civil-rights movement.  [ B1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS    Bond market analysts expect the Federal Reserve to approve a quarter-point reduction in the Federal funds rate rate to soften the decline of the nation's economy. Credit Markets.  [ D1. ]   The asbestos cases in the Federal courts has come down to a fight between District Judge Jack B. Weinstein in Brooklyn and the plaintiffs' lawyers. The judge, who is handling the case of many workers in the Navy shipyards, has sought to consolidate litigation and cut legal fees. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law.  [ D2. ]   Catellus Development is about to do something that terrifies most real estate companies: trade publicly. The entity will be spun off by Santa Fe Pacific next month. Market Place.  [ D4. ]

headline: Wall Street; Consumer Driven? Not This Economy
abstract: In one more sign that the hard times are a-changin', the number of new households being formed in the United States had fallen to near-Depression levels    before    the weaker economy became apparent, reports Richard F. Hokenson, a demographer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Fewer new households, of course, is ominous for housing and consumer-goods industries.   One reason for the drop is the declining number of marriages. Another is that more young men are living at home. "I hope this is not a permanent trend," Mr. Hokenson said of the latter, "and I know their parents hope so, as well. But even if it were to reverse -- and it actually shows signs of growing -- it's a very protracted reversal process."

headline: TOLL IN INDIA CLASH AT MOSQUE RISES
abstract: Northern India was relatively quiet today, as Hindu militant organizations and the Government claimed victory in the confrontation Tuesday at a disputed mosque in the holy city of Ayodhya.   The Press Trust of India news agency said the death toll had risen to 56 nationwide, as people died today from wounds sustained over the last few days in demonstrations supporting Hindu militants' efforts to tear down a mosque in Ayodhya and build a temple to the Hindu god Rama, who they believe was born there.

headline: Mistletoe in Beirut Crosses Religious Lines
abstract: Almost every store on Hamra Street, the shopping center of the Muslim part of the Lebanese capital, has mistletoe dangling in the doorway.   "We're selling the mistletoe as fast as we can bring it in," said Samih Daouk, a flower shop owner who says he imports his mistletoe from Europe and Syria. "We sold mistletoe at Christmas in the past, but this year, the demand was overwhelming. Why? Perhaps because Lebanese for once feel that there is a genuine hope for peace.'

headline: American-T.W.A. Deal Faces Inquiry
abstract: The Justice Department said it would review a proposed $625 million deal between T.W.A. and American Airlines to determine whether the sale of international routes and airport plants would violate antitrust laws. The department made its announcement after receiving a request for an antitrust investigation from Senator John C. Danforth, a Republican from Missouri, who opposes the sale. Trans World Airlines Inc. has an important hub at the St. Louis airport.   American has proposed buying all of T.W.A.'s routes from the United States to London and T.W.A.'s takeoff and landing rights at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. The Justice Department said its antitrust division would investigate the plan.

headline: Mutual Funds; The Winners Switched in July
abstract: How could you have made money in mutual funds in 1990? For most stock fund investors, the formula was clear: stay in equities until July, then switch to money market funds for the rest of the year.   Investors who missed the July deadline didn't fare too well. In 1990, the average stock fund dropped 8.2 percent through Dec. 27 while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost only 7.1 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc., which tracks mutual funds. That's a far cry from last year's 23.8 percent stock fund gain and does not even compare well with 1987, when the funds finished up 2.3 percent despite the market crash.

headline: Curbs Are Placed On Coast Savings
abstract: Coast Savings Financial Inc., the parent of the nation's 10th-largest savings institution, said it did not expect to meet a new Government requirement for financial strength and that Federal regulators had placed restrictions on its operations. Coast said bids for 27 branches of its Coast Federal Bank it had put up for sale were lower than expected and that it would not sell its eight branches in central California.    Without the sales, the company said, it expected to fall short of the Government's new requirement for risk-based capital. Analysts had estimated that the sales would bring a gain of about $60 million. Coast, based in Los Angeles, said Federal regulators plan to restrict its ability to increase its liabilities and will require the company to file a plan within 60 days detailing how it plans to meet the capital requirements.

headline: CBS Is Big Loser in the Reds' Series Sweep
abstract: The Oakland Athletics were the visible casualty of the Cincinnati Reds' four-game sweep of the World Series. The invisible casualty was CBS.   Oakland lost four games -- and a lot of pride. CBS could lose its shirt.   Though the size of CBS's losses on the first year of its four-year $1.06 billion baseball contract have yet to be determined, one network sports executive estimated that CBS would be "lucky to lose only $150 million."

headline: Civilian-Troop Clashes Kill 8 in a Soviet City
abstract: Five soldiers and three civilians died in the southern Soviet republic of Uzbekistan over the weekend during several hours of violence touched off by a clash between youths and troops returning from leave, the official press agency Tass said today.   The agency also reported that in the troubled border region between the republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia, four Azerbaijani policemen were killed, three wounded and two reported missing on Sunday. Tass said the policemen had been attacked by Armenian fighters, three of whom were killed and two wounded.   Tass said Interior Ministry troops had been sent today to the scene of the violence, the village of Martunashen in Azerbaijan's Khanlar district northwest of the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region.    In Uzbekistan, the Mayor of Namagan, Erkin Mamakulov, said six soldiers, whom he described as drunken, had been harassing young women passengers on a city bus on Sunday night and demanding that the bus change its route.   A crowd surrounded the bus and began to beat the soldiers, four of whom died, Tass said. More soldiers were sent to the scene, the crowd grew, and a fifth soldier was killed, along with three civilians, the agency said. Twenty-nine soldiers and 22 policemen were injured, some seriously, it said.

headline: Pakistan Is Accused by India Of Shelling Kashmir Border
abstract: LEAD: The Indian Government accused Pakistan today of ''unprovoked and heavy shelling'' on the disputed border in Kashmir.

headline: 2 Ex-Military Chiefs Urge Bush to Delay Gulf War
abstract: Two former Chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff urged the Bush Administration today to postpone military action against Iraq and to give economic sanctions a year or more to work.   "If in fact the sanctions will work in 12 to 18 months instead of six months, the trade-off of avoiding war with its attendant sacrifices and uncertainties would, in my view, be worth it," said Adm. William J. Crowe, who appeared with Gen. David Jones.

headline: Fleet-Norstar To Cut 500 Jobs
abstract: Fleet-Norstar Financial Group plans to cut about 500 jobs by the end of the year, an official of the banking company said today.   The layoffs will be scattered among Fleet's 1,000 offices in 40 states but will primarily affect workers in New England and New York, a bank spokesman, Robert W. Lougee Jr., said.    The cutbacks "range from the top to the bottom of the organization," he said. Some workers have already been notified.   Fleet posted a small profit in the third quarter and has been profitable for the first nine months of the year. The Providence-based bank-holding company attributed most of the layoffs to the recession in the the Northeast.   Other reductions were part of a continuing consolidation since Fleet Financial Group merged with Norstar Bankcorp of Albany in 1988. Shortly after the merger, Fleet-Norstar employed 19,500 people. Today, it employs 18,000, Mr. Lougee said. The work force reduction was expected to save the company about $25 million.

headline: American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
abstract: Akio Tanii  A Cautious Giant Acquires Some Glitz    If Hollywood's top directors were holding auditions for the role of the stereotypical movie studio chief, there is no doubt what they would tell Akio Tanii: Don't call us, we'll call you.     But the stocky, white-haired Mr. Tanii, the president of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, is changing that stereotype quickly. And since last month, when he led Matsushita's $6.13 billion buyout of MCA Inc., and with it Universal Pictures ("Jaws" and "Back to the Future"), it would be hard to find someone in Hollywood who would not jump at the chance to call on Mr. Tanii.   With the deal, Japan's biggest overseas acquisition ever, the Osaka-based Matsushita became the second Japanese electronics giant to buy a studio in hopes that it will create a "synergy" between the company's Panasonic and National hardware and American-made software. No one, including Mr. Tanii, who rose through the company as an engineer, has described just what that synergy is. But once arch-rival Sony bought Columbia Pictures in 1989, it was a virtual certainty that Matsushita would buy a studio.    Now the question is whether Matsushita, known as the most cautious and conservative of Japanese industrial giants, will learn how to survive in the boom-and-bust world of Hollywood. Most experts predict that the company will have a lot of adjustment problems.    In his spare time, Mr. Tanii studies Buddhist statuary at temples around Japan. Asked recently whether he goes to the movies often, he paused for a moment and then said, "Maybe I don't have that much time."

headline: Haitians Overwhelmingly Elect Populist Priest to the Presidency
abstract: The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a priest who campaigned as a champion of the poor, was overwhelmingly elected President in Haiti's first democratic elections on Sunday, according to unofficial preliminary returns from several international election-monitoring groups.    Father Aristide, a 37-year-old Roman Catholic priest, led his nearest rival, Marc L. Bazin, a former World Bank economist, by as much as 30 percentage points.

headline: SHEVARDNADZE STUNS KREMLIN BY QUITTING FOREIGN MINISTRY AND WARNING OF 'DICTATORSHIP'
abstract: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's closest confederate in negotiating an end to the cold war, abruptly resigned today with an impassioned warning that "reactionaries" threatened his country with dictatorship.   "I cannot reconcile myself with what is happening in my country," Mr. Shevardnadze told his stunned audience at the Congress of People's Deputies, adding that he was weary of defending his policies against hard-liners.

headline: American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
abstract: William H. Gates    Microsoft's Payoff   For Persistence   More than anyone in the computer industry, 1990 belonged to William H. Gates, chairman and co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation.    After seven years of unsuccessfully attempting to persuade PC users that his Windows software was the wave of future, Mr. Gates tried a third time this summer. He spent $10 million to introduce Windows 3.0 and managed to convince almost everyone that even if the program is not perfect, it is inevitable.   The 35-year-old entrepreneur's extraordinary success with Windows 3.0 underlined the increasingly vital role that software plays in the computer industry. And Microsoft's position today seems so strong that many industry executives are now convinced that it is Mr. Gates, and not I.B.M., who will set the direction for computing in the 1990's.    Since 1987, Microsoft and I.B.M. had been trying to persuade business customers to abandon their MS-DOS-based computers for the more powerful but untried alternative of a OS/2 operating system, which used I.B.M. hardware and special Microsoft software. But few users moved up.   So in 1990, Mr. Gates decided to improve the lot of the nation's 40 million MS-DOS users by evolution rather than revolution -- and Windows 3.0 was the tool. I.B.M. and I.B.M.-compatible computers may now be operated with a hand-held mouse and on-screen symbols, as is Apple's Macintosh, rather than by typing in commands.   Microsoft's growth has been stunning at a time when most of the computer industry has stagnated. Its profits jumped 47 percent, to $279.2 million.   The Redmond, Wash., billionaire has begun to shed his bespectacled-nerd image. He is building a lake-front home that will have a garage large enough to hold 80 cars, evidence of a passion beyond software.

headline: Interco May Sell Its Converse Unit
abstract: Interco Inc. reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it might be forced to sell its Converse athletic footwear business to ease the debt burden it incurred to avoid a hostile takeover in 1988. The St. Louis-based footwear and furniture maker said it would put Converse up for sale if its plans to sell $140 million in other assets falls short of expectations and its earning and cash flow do not exceed current expectations.    Interco is seeking to complete a restructuring of $1.9 billion in debt. Under its plan, bondholders would receive 95 percent of Interco's common stock in exchange for their bonds. Interco also owns the Florsheim Shoe Company and the Lane and Broyhill furniture companies.

abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.50   7.50   8.25        3-MO. TREAS. headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MONDAY: GATT talks in Brussels to conclude the Uruguay Round, through Dec. 7. * Construction spending for October. * Purchasing managers' survey for November.  TUESDAY: Oral arguments scheduled in New York on temporary order barring Donald Trump from selling his houses. * November auto sales. * October new home sales.  WEDNESDAY: Factory orders for October. * Third-quarter labor productivity and costs. * The Center for Financial Engineering in Development hosts a conference in Washington on the prospects for American business in Vietnam.  THURSDAY: Major retailers report November sales. FRIDAY: Unemployment for November. * Consumer credit for October. * Annual meeting of Carter Hawley Hale.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Abbott Laboratories, Abbott Park, Ill., appointed Joy A. Amundson vice president of corporate hospital marketing. * Consolidated-Tomoka Land Co., Daytona Beach, Fla., a unit of Baker, Fentress & Co., Chicago, named Robert F. Apgar vice president and corporate counsel and Joseph Benedict 3d vice president of government relations. William H. McMunn was named president of the Indigo Development Inc. subsidiary. * Dun & Bradstreet Corp., New York, appointed Ron K. Glover president of North American information services, and Henry P. Holland president and chief operating officer of the software division. Michael A. Choukas was named executive vice president for strategy and business development, and John B. Landry was named executive vice president and chief technical officer * G. L. Hodson & Son Inc., New Hyde Park, L.I., a reinsurance unit of Corroon & Black Corp., New York, appointed Demarest S. Newman executive vice president and assistant national production manager. * Imcera Group Inc., Northbrook, Ill., a producer of human and animal health-care products and specialty chemicals, named William B. Stone vice president and controller, succeeding John F. Sonderegger, who becomes vice president of financial management. * Ionics Inc., Watertown, Mass., manufacturers of water-purification equipment, named Robert J. Halliday vice president of finance and accounting. * Ridgewood Savings Bank, Ridgewood, Queens, appointed Harold A. Jones senior vice president. * Rohr Industries, Chula Vista, Calif., an aerospace company, named Keith D. Gentry vice president of material, replacing Jack Y. Peckenpaugh, who is retiring. * Whitman Corp., Chicago, a holding company, appointed J. Larry Vowell president and chief executive and Richard D. Neece executive vice president of finance and administration of its Hussmann Corp. subsidiary.

headline: U.N. to Weigh Iraqi War Crimes Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: The United States has agreed with the four other permanent members of the Security Council to support a resolution calling for the collection of evidence that war crimes have been committed by Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait.

headline: Britain Pushing Electric Stocks
abstract: LEAD: Britain offered the lure of discounts on electricity bills last week in its campaign to attract buyers for shares in the $9.5 billion sale of 12 state-owned electricity utilities.

headline: Penril Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Unitrode Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tofutti Brands Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SkyWest Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Randers Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Provident American Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FORUM;  How a Corporation Reveals Itself
abstract: LEAD: Products from companies competing globally are becoming similar. That means a company's identity can be the deciding factor for success in the marketplace. From my experience, American managers do not seem to understand this as fully as their European counterparts - even though it was in the United

headline: Raytheon's President Is Elected Chairman
abstract: The Raytheon Company, a maker of air-defense missiles and other military electronics products, yesterday elected its president, Dennis J. Picard, to be chairman and chief executive effective March 1. He succeeds Thomas L. Phillips, who will retire in March after leading the company for 22 years.    Mr. Picard, 58 years old, signed on with Raytheon in 1955, and, like Mr. Phillips, has spent his entire career with the company. Mr. Phillips, 66, joined the company in 1948.    Mr. Picard is being succeeded as president by Max E. Bleck, 63, who is president of the Beech Aircraft Corporation, Raytheon's biggest subsidiary.

headline: New Stock Exchange Is Opened in Shanghai
abstract: Communist authorities opened a new securities exchange today that they hope will help restore Shanghai's role as a financial capital for Asia.    Only 93 transactions were recorded on the first day, but some Chinese economists and business executives think the market could eventually become the cornerstone of a national network of stock and bond markets that would help finance the Government and corporations as well as ease the transition from state ownership to stockholder control.

headline: ASK Computer
abstract: LEAD: Judge William Allen of Delaware Chancery Court reaffirmed his previous decision to allow ASK Computer Systems Inc.'s proposed sale of 30 percent of its stock to the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Electronic Data Systems Corporation. Judge Allen said in a four-page ruling that he had found no persuasive reason to block the deal, intended to help finance ASK's planned acquisition of the Ingres Corporation.

headline: Bank Yields Are Mixed In Week
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were narrowly mixed for the week ended yesterday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; Books Go East and, Maybe, Profits Go West
abstract: FARRAR, STRAUS & GIROUX has long published books by authors from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. But with censorship and other barriers to book publishing toppling in the region, the house recently added what are known as subagents in Berlin and Belgrave, Yugoslavia.    Like many other publishers, Farrar Straus sees great potential in a region of almost 400 million people, a new and potentially rich market, at a time when book companies are feeling squeezed in their established markets. In addition, as foreign publishers are increasingly drawn to the United States for growth, their American counterparts are also aiming to become global companies.

headline: Rwanda Accepts Cease-Fire Plan
abstract: LEAD: President Juvenal Habyarimana of Rwanda said today that he had accepted a Belgian plan calling for neutral troops to supervise a cease-fire between his army and rebels invading from Uganda.

headline: New Magazine Is Announced
abstract: The Association of National Advertisers plans to begin publishing a new trade magazine, The Advertiser, in the spring. The new publication, which will begin as a quarterly, was announced yesterday at the organization's annual meeting in Naples, Fla.   "This is not to be a magazine about advertising but a magazine for advertisers," said DeWitt F. Helm Jr., president of the association. "It will reflect the day-to-day need for hard- edged, practical information," he said. The Advertiser will accept advertising.   Last May, the American Assocation of Advertising Agencies began Agency, a quarterly journal sent to its members.

headline: Yet Another Deadline in the Battle for UAL
abstract: LEAD: Only ''Friday the 13th'' has produced more nasty sequels than the battle over UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines. The airline is faring well, but speculators are suffering as UAL stock careens toward its next deadline - on Tuesday.

headline: Bulgaria's Tottering Government Appears Ready to Resign
abstract: Bulgaria's Prime Minister appeared today to be close to acceding to increasing popular clamor for the resignation of his Government.   Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov's Socialist Government, which has been the target of two weeks of peaceful but noisy street demonstrations, was further staggered by a three-day-old strike that appeared to be gathering momentum throughout Bulgaria.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1990
abstract: The Economy    The leading indicators fell for the fifth month in November, a 1.2 percent drop that suggested no early end to a deepening contraction that now lacks only formal designation as the nation's ninth postwar recession. The latest fall in the index made the five-month drop the lengthiest period of uninterrupted decline since 1984 and the most severe since late 1981.  [ Page 29. ]   The S.E.C. said the nation's stock exchanges generally performed well during two tumultuous days of trading in October 1989, but it found that further measures could be taken to reduce sharp swings in stock prices.  [ 29. ]   Some mutual fund investors are pulling in their horns as the year ends after staying confident for most of 1990. So far the hesitation has not taken the form of a sharp increase in outright redemptions of mutual fund shares, but of a slowing in the pace of new sales, fund managers said.  [ 29. ]   Americas Tower, a skyscraping distress signal in mid-Manhattan that has been frozen for more than a year while its developers battled one another, may finally be completed as a result of a settlement.  [ 28. ]  Companies    Data General is still trying to prove it has a future, and many industry analysts are not optimistic. The company made a clean break with its past this month by forcing out its founder and chairman, Edson de Castro.  [ 29. ]   Great Lakes Bancorp said it would more than double its reserves for loan losses, to more than $23 million from $10.8 million at the end of September.  [ 32. ]   Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel said it would take a $170 million one-time charge against fourth-quarter earnings to adjust for retiree health benefits.  [ 31. ]  International    Enormous swings in the fortunes of economies across the globe have resulted from the jump in oil prices since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Oil-producing countries will be the biggest winners of the standoff, although some experts say they may not fare as well as many presume.  [ 29. ]  Markets    A spurt of selling pushed down prices of Treasury securities, as dealers made final bookkeeping preparations for the end of 1990. The decline came in spite of economic data generally favorable for the fixed-income market.  [ 29. ]   Oil prices rose in thin trading, spurred by rumors of shots fired in the Middle East. Crude rose 56 cents, to $27.57 a barrel. For the week, crude gained $1.65.  [ 31. ]   Stocks were mixed, with the Dow gaining 3.71, to 2,629.21. But the Dow was down three of the four trading days this week, which meant a loss for the week of 4.45.  [ 33. ]   Gold futures prices hit their highest levels in nearly three months, helped by Persian Gulf fears and a weaker dollar. Other precious metals also rose sharply.  [ 38. ]   The dollar fell sharply, with extremely thin trading accentuating the downward move.  [ 38. ]  Today's Columns    People who received a sizable chunk of income this year, like a capital gain, a year-end bonus or a severance check -- and there are a surprising number, experts say -- may well need to pay their state and local taxes on it by Monday to be sure of getting a Federal deduction. Your Money.  [ 30. ]   A "walking distance locator," an electronic street-corner kiosk that provides the equivalent of a Yellow Pages guide for stores and restaurants and other businesses within a 15-minute walk, has been patented by a Boston company. Patents.  [ 30. ]

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Olympus Corp., Woodbury, N.Y., to DDB Needham Worldwide, New York, for its consumer products group. The $12.5 million account was previously handled by Lowe & Partners. * Sterling Motor Cars, Miami, a subsidiary of of the Rover Group, London, to Grace & Rothchild Advertising, New York, with billings of $10 million to $20 million. The incumbent agency was AC&R, New York.

headline: Air Strike on Iraq, the Favored Strategy, Means Big Risks for Both Sides
abstract: An American-led air strike against Iraq the Pentagon's favored strategy if war starts -- would be a complex operation risking thousands of civilian casualties and causing billions of dollars in property damage, Defense Department officials and military analysts say.    Military commanders are pondering an array of strategic options -- from pinpoint laser-guided missile strikes to widespread carpet-bombing -- aimed at destroying scores of Iraqi military and industrial targets, and ultimately forcing Iraqi troops to withdraw from Kuwait.

headline: Ethiopia Wooed as Ally by U.S. in Gulf Crisis
abstract: After more than a decade of being shunned and condemned by the United States for its orthodox Communism and poor record on human rights, Ethiopia now finds itself being courted as an ally by Washington.   The crisis in the Persian Gulf has made Ethiopia, with its long Red Sea coastline, suddenly more important to the West. In the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the Ethiopian President, Mengistu Haile Mariam, has been able to gain additional credibility for the argument he has been addressingto the West in recent years: that Ethiopia, a predominantly Christian nation, is a bulwark against turmoil in the Arab world and the rising tide of Islam.

headline: Treasury Issues Post Small Gain
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher and interest rates dipped in light trading yesterday, as dealers bought some securities on signs that agreement on the Federal budget was imminent.    The generally positive news on the budget outweighed a rise in oil prices.

headline: Alliance Is Formed by Fiat and French Company
abstract: LEAD: Fiat, Italy's largest industrial group, and Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, France's largest electronics group, announced today that they were forming a far-reaching strategic alliance and that C.G.E. would acquire control of Telettra, Fiat's $1.4 billion-a-year telecommunications subsidiary.

headline: Hong Kong Pushes First Direct Vote for Legislature
abstract: LEAD: The Hong Kong Government recently extended its six-week voter registration drive by four more weeks in an attempt to attract more interest in the first direct election of legislators in the British colony's 150-year-old history.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * CRS Sirrine Engineers Inc., a subsidiary of CRSS Inc., Houston, a design and construction company, has been awarded an engineering and construction management contract on a $100 million expansion of Corning Inc.'s optical fiber plant in Wilmington, N.C. * Dana Corp., Toledo, Ohio, a maker of automotive components, formed Tianjin Wix Filter Corp., an equal joint venture with Tianjin Auto Filter Factory in Tianjin, China. * Forest Oil Corp., Bradford, Pa., sold its interest in 107 gas wells in Texas to Conoco Inc., a unit of Du Pont Co., for about $39 million. * Arthur J. Gallagher & Co., Rolling Meadows, Ill., an insurance company, acquired Insurance Underwriters Inc., Bellevue, Wash., for undisclosed terms. * Hannaford Bros. Co., Scarborough, Me., an operator of supermarkets and drugstores, will purchase the Alexander's Supermarkets chain from various entities owned by Robert and Peter Gordon and members of their family. Terms were not disclosed. * ISS-International Service System A.S., a Danish cleaning and security company, agreed to pay 750 million Swedish kronor, or about $135 million, for the cleaning business of Electrolux A.B.'s Environmental Services Group in Denmark, Sweden, Finland and the United States.  * Lotus Development Corp., Cambridge, Mass., a software designer, will ship a Russian version of Lotus 1-2-3 to the Soviet Union by the end of the year. * Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm, a unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., the German car and engine manufacturer, will reduce its work force by 1,400 employees by 1995. * Mitsui O.S.K. Lines Ltd., a Japanese shipping company, acquired a substantial but undisclosed share of Skaarup Shipping Corp., Greenwich, Conn., for undisclosed terms. * Sun Resorts N.V., an operator of resorts in St. Maarten, will acquire the Caribbean resorts and hotels of Divi Hotels N.V., Ithaca, N.Y. Divi shareholders will receive 600,000 Sun Resorts common shares, and holders of Divi's $110 million in outstanding unsecured subordinated debt will receive cash and securities valued at between $35 million and $40 million. * Tyler Corp., Dallas, a maker of construction and industrial products, agreed to acquire the privately held auto parts retailer Forest City Auto Parts for $26 million to $30 million subject to an audit. Forest City operates 51 stores in Illinois, New York, Ohio and Pennsylvania.

headline: The Executive Life; The Enduring Charm Of the Drexel Mystique
abstract: "OH my God!" squealed a woman in her 30's, waiting to get inside a crowded Mexican restaurant called Tequila Willie's near Wall Street. "I can't believe it's you!" she said, turning to embrace the briefcase-carrying woman who had just joined her at the door. "I haven't seen you for so long. Did you end up somewhere?"   "Yes, I thought you knew," the other woman replied. "I'm at a firm in New Jersey."

headline: Russian Republic Backs Private Farm Plan but Rejects Private Sale of Land
abstract: The Russian republic approved a program today to revive the private peasant farm 60 years after Stalin snuffed it out with his collectivization program.   But the Parliament of the republic, which has most of the nation's farmland and much of the current separatist zeal for private enterprise, stopped short of allowing the private sale of land between farmers.

headline: Zavitz Tech reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Waters Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: China Student Candidates, 10 Sad Years Later
abstract: It was a decade ago, on the shady grounds of Beijing University, that the nation's best and brightest undertook one of China's first and most famous experiments in direct elections.   In a free election for the position of "people's deputy" in a town council, three students stepped forward in the fall of 1980 and hustled for votes. The post carried little power, but the race commanded attention because of the vigor of the campaign and because the constituency was Beijing University, the most famous campus in the countryand a training ground for the future leaders of China.

headline: Allied-Signal In Valeo Deal
abstract: LEAD: Valeo, a French car components maker, said it had agreed to sell its brake linings business to Allied-Signal Automotive, part of Allied-Signal Inc., for 385 million francs, or about $106 million, effective Dec. 1. The business consists of two factories - one in the Calvados region of France and the other in Spain near Madrid - and a technical and administrative center near Paris.

headline: Blazing Trenches May Be Iraqi Means of Defense
abstract: Fortifying its military positions in Kuwait, Iraq has dug trenches that might be set afire to defend against an American attack, Administration officials say.    The Iraqi move is one of a series of steps that Baghdad has taken to strengthen its defenses along the Kuwaiti border with Saudi Arabia and along the Kuwaiti coastline, including minefields, barbed wire and sand barriers.

headline: Trimedyne Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GAS PRICE PROTEST CRIPPLES HUNGARY
abstract: Angry taxi drivers and truck drivers blockaded the streets and bridges of Hungary's capital today to protest the government's decision to raise gasoline prices by 65 percent.    Protesters also snarled traffic in dozens of other cities and towns, closed border crossings and brought much of the nation's economy to a standstill.    The protests began on Friday morning when the new gasoline prices took effect, but the Government has vowed not to bow to the protesters' demands to roll back the increases.

headline: Seeking Safety for Federal Cash
abstract: Concern about the safety of money in the Treasury's placement of funds dates back more than a century.    During the financial panic of 1837 there was a run on banks and the Treasury found some of its deposits frozen in state and local banks for a year. In response, Congress passed a law in the 1840's requiring the Treasury to keep its funds only in its own mints and customs houses around the country.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: The Executive Computer column on Nov. 11 misstated the affiliation of Jonathan L. Yarmis, a computer industry analyst. He is with the Gartner Group of Stamford, Conn.

headline: 20 Die in Rebel Assaults in El Salvador
abstract: Hundreds of rebels attacked more than a dozen military positions in El Salvador today. At least 20 people were killed and 46 were wounded, the army said.   The fiercest fighting was in the eastern provincial capitals of San Francisco and Usulutan, where combat lasted more than five hours. Fighting was reported in 7 of the nation's 14 provinces.

headline: N.A.S.D. Ruling on ASK
abstract: LEAD: ASK Computer Systems Inc. said today that it had been advised by the National Association of Securities Dealers that as a condition of its continued listing, the proposed sale of about 5.6 million shares of common stock to the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a General Motors subsidiary, and the Hewlett-Packard

headline: Wave of Political Killings Has Claimed 16 Turks
abstract: LEAD: A wave of political killings has baffled the police and revived bitter memories of extremist street violence that shook Turkey before an army crackdown in 1980.

headline: Business Scene; Chemical Industry Faces Oversupply
abstract: CHEMICAL manufacturers illustrate a troublesome shortcoming of free markets. For three years, they have been expanding operations, even as they worried that their new plants would produce much more than anyone wanted to buy. And, as these plants come on line, their fears are coming true. Chemicals used in the manufacture of hundreds of household items are once again in oversupply.   That hurts. Consumers might soon get a price break on things like drugs, soap, paint and plastic zipper bags, but profits are down at companies like Dow Chemical, Union Carbide and Monsanto, and some new plants are not being opened on schedule. Dow, for example, had planned to open a huge ethylene plant in Freeport, Tex., in 1992 but will wait until 1993. By then, Dow hopes, the demand for ethylene might again exceed the supply.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * TNT Skypak Inc., a division of TNT Ltd., London, an express-mail service company, to Lintas MCM, a direct marketing unit of Lintas USA, New York. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Poles Line Up to Buy Stock
abstract: Poles lined up today at banks to buy shares in the first five state-run companies to be sold to individual shareholders under the country's post-Communist economic program.   Five companies are being privatized in the first round: the Krosno glass works; Kielce, a construction company; Exbud, a textile company in Lodz; Prochnik, a Silesian cable factory, and Tonsil, an audio equipment company.

headline: Associates Corp.'s Notes Yield 8.87%
abstract: LEAD: Associates Corporation of North America, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, is offering $300 million in notes, due in 1993, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Market Place; At Coast Savings, Is the Worst Over?
abstract: COAST SAVINGS FINANCIAL INC., the parent of the nation's 10th-largest savings and loan association, is at a crossroads.    Coast, which has assets of $10.2 billion and 120 branches in California, has been running up big losses for two years. Its capital is badly depleted and barely meets the minimum Federal requirements. Last month it suspended its quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share on common stock.

headline: Gales and Rain Sweep Britain
abstract: Gales and heavy rain swept across Britain today, and thousands of homes were without power. Roads were closed by floods and fallen trees. The police said four people suffered cuts and bruises from falling masonry at the Anglican parish church of Kingston St. Michael near Chippenham in southwestern England. The royal family, led by Queen Elizabeth II, clung to their hats and shivered in the cold when they attended a morning church service in the village of Sandringham 105 miles northeast of London. The Princess of Wales's hat blew off in the churchyard.

headline: Saudis' Quandary: Carrot or the Stick for Iraqis?
abstract: The Saudi Defense Minister's conciliatory-sounding remarks addressed to Iraq this week were the latest sign that Saudi strategists and military officials are trying their best to offer President Saddam Hussein more of a carrot and less of a stick to persuade him to pull his 350,000 troops out of Kuwait.     This approach stems in part from the deep cracks in the Arab world from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and some second thoughts here about the confrontational attitude that Saudi Arabia has adopted toward Jordan, Yemen, the Palestine Liberation Organization and other Arab supporters of Iraq.

headline: Europe Jobless Rate Up
abstract: LEAD: Unemployment in the European Community rose one-tenth of 1 percent, to 8.4 percent, in August from the previous month, the European Community Executive Commission said this week. The rise was the first in the 12-nation trade bloc since February. Overall unemployment in August 1989 was at a rate of 9.2 percent.

headline: Europeans Scoff at Salesmanship
abstract: To the Editor:   Prof. John Philip Jones observed that European advertising is kinder, gentler and more amusing than American advertising ("Why European Ads Are More Amusing," Oct. 7) because Europeans have fewer brands available to them. This, he wrote, has a "deadening" effect on American advertising.   I think there's a deeper underlying cultural reason that explains the difference: the attitude toward salesmanship. Many Europeans distrust salespeople because they don't believe selling is a legitimate career. Most Americans don't see it that way.   The advertising reflects these differences: charming understatement vs. "hard edged and brand specific."   It will be interesting to see which model, Old World or New, sets the tone for advertising in the emerging free-market nations. RICHARD S. SECLOW  Westport, Conn., Oct. 12

headline: Drink-Box Makers Fighting Back
abstract: Faced with one statewide ban and the prospect of others, the companies that make the increasingly popular containers known as drink boxes are moving to counter criticism that the containers cannot easily be recycled.    The airtight boxes, which can preserve liquids for as long as six to nine months without refrigeration and have become a staple for products like Gatorade, Mott's apple juice and Hawaiian Punch, are made of layers of paper, plastic and aluminum. Environmentalists favor packages made of a single material, like aluminum, glass or plastic, over multilayer containers because there are no dissimilar materials to be separated before recycling. And with aluminum and glass, the material can be made again into containers, whereas the recycled drink boxes are put to more limited uses, like plastic lumber.  Wrapping Product in Flag     But in newspaper advertisements, and in pilot recycling programs in Rhode Island and California, the industry producing the boxes, known as aseptic packages, has tried to make the case that they are environmentally benign. The industry has even wrapped its product in the flag, noting that American troops in Saudi Arabia are drinking their milk from such boxes.

headline: 21 South Africans Are Released Under Political-Prisoner Amnesty
abstract: LEAD: The Government released 21 political prisoners today, and the African National Congress, while welcoming the move, responded by insisting that all political prisoners still behind bars be released immediately.

headline: Ex-Official Concedes Lapses in Savings Collapse
abstract: A former senior official responsible for overseeing savings and loans as the industry was collapsing in the late 1980's conceded today that the Government had failed to respond adequately to auditors' concerns about pervasive regulatory problems.   "Surely there is more that could have been done," said the former official, Darrel W. Dochow, who passed auditors' reviews in early 1988 to his superior, M. Danny Wall, the former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

headline: Loss Shown By Cummins In 3d Quarter
abstract: The Cummins Engine Company, citing a sharp decline in demand for its truck engines, said yesterday that it had a third-quarter loss of $33.7 million, compared with a loss of $39.7 million in the corresponding quarter last year.   Cummins, the largest independent maker of diesel engines in the world, said that it expected no improvement in the North American heavy-truck market anytime soon and that it planned to continue to reduce its work force. Painting a grim picture of the future, the company said that truck sales could decline by up to 10 percent next year.

headline: Dividend Meetings

headline: Indian Army Fights Rebels in Assam
abstract: Indian Army troops began a crackdown today against an insurgency in the northeastern state of Assam. In Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar's first decisive political strike in 18 days of office, he ousted the state's government, which is led by a regional party accused of aiding the rebels.   State and Central Government officials here said that search and arrest operations against militants from the United Liberation Front of Assam had begun and that at least 36 militants had been detained. Officials in Assam were quoted as saying that several strongholds of the guerrilla group were attacked and destroyed and that the militans had fired on advancing troops. There were no reports of casualties.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Atlantis Group Inc., Miami, said it had received an offer from management of the companies in its furniture group to buy the unit for $25 million. * Flow International Corp., Kent, Wash., a manufacturer of water-jet and abrasive-jet cutting equipment, said it had ended its efforts to find a buyer for the company. * General Development Corp., Miami, a community development and real estate concern, said its shareholders were not likely to receive any distribution in its pending bankruptcy proceedings. * Harleysville Group Inc., Harleysville, Pa., a holding company, said it had ended talks on the acquisition of Hawkeye-Security Insurance Co., a unit of USLico Corp., and on the sale of its Harleysville Life Insurance Co. to USLico. * Maxwell Communication Corp., London, announced that its independent shareholders had approved the sale of its interests in Quebecor Printing Inc. and Donohue Inc., Quebec, a newsprint and lumber company, to Mirror Group P.L.C.  * May Department Stores Co., St. Louis, said it had completed a spinoff of its wholly owned Venture Stores Inc. discount retail subsidiary by distributing more than 16 million shares of Venture common stock to May shareholders. * McCall Pattern Co., New York, said it had completed its reorganization under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code and had been acquired by an investment group organized by Dimeling, Schreiber & Park, a Philadelphia-based partnership. * Morgan Keegan Inc., Memphis, a brokerage, announced an agreement in principle under which it would acquire substantially all the operating assets of Scharff & Jones, a New Orleans-based brokerage. * Pitney Bowes Inc., Stamford, Conn., says 100 workers at its distribution center will lose their jobs by early December as a result of a decision to close an operation that refurbished used copier equipment. * San Jacinto Savings Association, Houston, a wholly owned subsidiary of Southmark Corp., said that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its 68.8 percent interest in Thousand Trails Inc., Bellevue, Wash., a resort campground concern, and certain assets of American National Corp., Omaha, a bank holding company, to Delta Campground Management Corp. * Union Carbide Corp., Danbury, Conn., formed a joint venture with three partners to build a new plant in Alberta for $350 million.

headline: Sony Discman's Output Doubled
abstract: LEAD: The Sony Corporation has doubled production of its portable CD players for data for the second time in two months to meet strong demand in Japan, a company spokesman said. Sony introduced the Discman, which uses three-inch compact disks, on July 1. Production has been raised to 20,000 players a month.

headline: Bush, on Saudi Visit to Troops, Sees U.N. Acting on Iraq in Week
abstract: The United States, the Soviet Union and France called separately today for new steps soon by the United Nations Security Council to bring about Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. But American officials said that there was still no consensus on the exact shape of a new resolution.    President Bush, who flew to Saudi Arabia from Paris today for a Thanksgiving visit with American troops, said that the Security Council should pass a new resolution against Iraq by Nov. 30, the last day the United States holds the rotating presidency of the Council.

headline: Douglas's Outlook for New Plane
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation reiterated today that it does not expect a significant loss on its contract to develop the Air Force's new C-17 transport plane, despite a new Air Force study that said the company could suffer cost overruns of $600 million.    The Air Force study, disclosed today in an article in The Los Angeles Times, concluded that McDonnell Douglas would not be able to meet the cost ceiling of $6.5 billion on its current contract, which covers all development work and the production of the first six planes.    The study estimated that the company would spend $7.1 billion to complete the contract. The company's Douglas Aircraft division in Long Beach, Calif., is building the C-17 under a fixed price contract, meaning that it must absorb all costs over the $6.5 billion ceiling.    A loss of that magnitude would be a significant blow to the company, which is suffering from declining military budgets at the same time its commercial airliner business is struggling to recover from years of losses.    Don Hanson, a spokesman for Douglas, said the company believed the Air Force study's conclusions were incorrect.    "Our estimate is that our performance on the C-17 contract will be at or near break-even when the contract is completed in 1994," Mr. Hanson said.

headline: Former Papandreou Aide Is Jailed in Scandal
abstract: LEAD: A man who was once a top aide and deputy to former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou was ordered jailed today on charges of involvement in a large-scale financial scandal.

headline: Bush's Move Unlikely to Mean Quick Trade Surge
abstract: President Bush's major step today toward normalizing commercial relations with the Soviet Union will increase American farm exports, but is unlikely in the short term to lead to a big surge in two-way trade.   The two countries will sell each other about $3.6 billion worth of goods this year -- little more than what the United States exchanges with Haiti.

headline: China Offers Cautious Economic Plan
abstract: China's Communist Party Central Committee concluded a major six-day meeting today, after approving a moderate, cautious new blueprint for the 1990's and warning that the next decade could determine the rise or fall of the nation's Communist system.   At the long-awaited meeting, the Central Committee formally approved the five-year plan that is supposed to govern the economy from 1991 to 1995 as well as a broader 10-year "program" for the 1990's. No specific measures or targets were disclosed today, but the party leaders issued a communique acknowleging that the Central Committee had held the meeting and mentioning some elements of the economic plans.

headline: A Boyfriend, a Bank Fraud and Greed Imperil Mexico's Economic Renewal
abstract: LEAD: For more than five years, wealthy clients of Maria del Carmen Badillo shared an amazing secret: annual returns of up to 200 percent on accounts she supervised as a money-market executive at Banco BCH, one of Mexico's major banks.

headline: Abu Simbel Journal;   The Ancient Temples Shine but the People Suffer
abstract: Nearly three decades have passed since the waters of the Nile began to rise here, trapped behind the Aswan High Dam and threatening monuments and people whose history entwines with the onetime land of Kush and the Pharaohs who craved its gold.   Since then, however, the monuments have done better than the people, as they probably were designed to when they were built 3,200 years ago.

headline: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves; Blue-Collar Workers: Industries Fading, But Not the Jobs
abstract: Once the bedrock of New York City's economy, the manufacturing industries that historically provided many blue-collar jobs have been leaving the city for years. Even during the prosperity of the 1980's, the city lost about 150,000 factory jobs.    But to the surprise of some labor economists, blue-collar workers are not disappearing. In fact, despite the lost factory jobs, the overall number of blue-collar workers increased by 140,000 from 1983 to 1989, bringing the total to 740,000 last year. Blue-collar jobs of all types now account for about a fifth of the city's work force.    Still, in a city that has become increasingly dominated by what Mr. Ehrenhalt of the Bureau of Labor Statistics calls knowledge-based industries, many of these blue-collar jobs require more training and more skills than the usual entry-level, industrial jobs. Workers who once might have worked on carburetors are now expected to care for computers and other sophisticated electronic gear.   This problem is a worrisome one in New York City, where already perhaps half a million working-age people are not looking for work, because they are held back by lack of education or skills. Indeed, only 25 percent of the city's young people have jobs or are looking for them, about half the rate of their counterparts in Houston or Los Angeles.    Construction work has been a quick route to the middle class, especially for many people just starting their work lives. But that industry, which had surged in the 1980's real estate boom, is now experiencing a sharp decline that has idled as many as 25 percent of the workers in some trades.    "The more demanding jobs structure and an education system with a 38 percent dropout rate are on a collision course," Mr. Ehrenhalt warned.
