headline: Big Conviction in Recruit Scandal
abstract: LEAD: Hisashi Shinto, once one of Japan's most powerful business figures, was convicted of accepting bribes today in the first big court case to emerge from a scandal that rocked Japan's political world.

headline: Mexicans Hopeful as They Await Bush Today
abstract: Seeking to capitalize on the warmest official American-Mexican relations in recent memory, Mexican authorities prepared for the arrival of President Bush here on Monday for a two-day state visit that is expected to focus largely on trade issues.   The visit, which will be the sixth meeting between President Bush and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, is seen here as a confirmation of the good personal ties between the two leaders, who held their first talks even before Mr. Bush was sworn in as President.That theme has dominated descriptions of the meeting by aides to Mr. Salinas, who has staked much of his personal and political success on his ability to work as an equal with Mr. Bush in improving relations between the two countries.

headline: Market Place; A Way of Betting On a '95 Oil Price
abstract: WHILE the world pays close attention to daily changes in the price of oil, a deeper question for the oil industry and the economy is the long-term outlook for prices. What will a barrel of oil cost in five years, after the Persian Gulf crisis has presumably been resolved and any war damage has been repaired?    A relatively new financial instrument, the Salomon Phibro Oil Trust, represents a sort of popular projection of the 1995 oil price. Four units of the trust represent one barrel of West Texas Intermediate oil -- or, more practically, the price of one barrel -- in September 1995. At that time, Phibro will acquire four million barrels, auction them and split the proceeds among the holders of the 16 million units.

headline: Jordanians Resentful as Tourism and Business Fall
abstract: LEAD: Close by old columns that have soared since Roman times beneath a bowl of sky in this north Jordanian town, two men played slow chess, a policeman watched, half-interested, and Ibrahim Mustafa Smaaly, a vendor, counted his take for the day: three postcards at 50 cents each.

headline: Southwest Airlines Gets Credit Line
abstract: The Southwest Airlines Company announced yesterday that it had completed a new $215 million revolving line of credit with a group of banks led by Texas Commerce Bancshares.   The lending agreement includes a competitive mechanism, through which the participating banks compete against each other on interest rates when the Dallas-based airline draws on the credit line.

headline: 'I'll Miss Her,' Bush Says
abstract: President Bush said today that he would miss Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's friendship and counsel but that he expected to continue working closely with her successor as head of the British Government.   "You know of my high regard for Prime Minister Thatcher," Mr. Bush said after a Thanksgiving visit to American forces in Saudi Arabia. "We will obviously work with the next Prime Minister."    He added: "I would send my best to her at this difficult time. She has been a staunch friend and ally. She's a woman of principle. She stood for what she believed. You always know where she was and what she believed."   Mr. Bush said he was certain that Britain would remain a firm American partner. "But on a personal level I'll miss her because I value her counsel. She has been an outstanding Prime Minister for the United Kingdom and an outstanding friend for the United States."

headline: National Advertisers Elect New Officers
abstract: Philip Guarascio was elected chairman of the Association of National Advertisers yesterday at the group's annual meeting in Naples, Fla.   Mr. Guarascio, who will head the 29-member board of national marketing and advertising executives, is executive director of corporate advertising and marketing at the General Motors Corporation.   L. Ross Love, vice president of advertising for the Procter & Gamble Company, was elected vice chairman. Elected directors were: Richard Costello of General Electric; Charles B. Fruit, Anheuser-Busch; John L. Moorhead, Pepsi-Cola; John O'C. Nugent, Unilever U.S.A., and Janet L. Soderstrom, Visa USA.    Mr. Guarascio, who was vice chairman of the organziation last year, is a specialist in automobile marketing. He begain his career as an assistant media buyer at Benton & Bowles in 1964, where he eventually became senior vice president and director of media management. He is best known for G.M.'s corporate image campaigns and is also responsible for aggressively pushing G.M. into integrated marketing.    "I think that my main objective as chairman is the brilliant execution of an already-strong and substantial plan," Mr. Guarascio said in a telephone interview yesterday. "We want to make sure our membership-retention and programs are more successful and that we bring the A.N.A.'s voice further up the line to more senior levels of management."

headline: 4th-Largest Credit-Card Unit on Sale
abstract: The fourth-largest credit-card business in the country was put up for sale yesterday. Its owner, the largest banking company in Maryland, is raising cash to compensate for heavy losses on commercial real estate loans.    The sale by the MNC Financial Corporation of Baltimore will be an opportunity, analysts predicted, for large industrial companies like the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the General Electric Company to dramatically increase their activity in a business dominated by banks.

headline: Search Is Pressed for Cairo Official's Killers
abstract: LEAD: The search for the killers of the Speaker of Egypt's Parliament continued for a fourth day with hundreds of suspects rounded up today, including Iraqis, Palestinians and Jordanian militants.

headline: Layoffs Set At Morgan Stanley
abstract: Morgan Stanley & Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 50 investment banking jobs, or 6 percent of the 800-member division. It is expected that this round of cuts will be followed by investment banking layoffs at other Wall Street firms.   Similar layoffs have taken place at Paine Webber Inc. and Shearson Lehman. But Morgan Stanley's are significant because of the firm's reputation. It is considered a corporate finance powerhouse and its investment bankers are generally viewed as the elite of Wall Street and were instrumental in arranging some of the biggest deals of the 1980's.

headline: Channel Tunnel City Worries About Job Loss
abstract: Sheila Simpson can distinctly remember the last time Folkestone was in such a state of turmoil.   "I lived here through the Second World War, and we were blitzed from across the Channel," she said. "We were shelled nightly. But even that was nothing compared to what has happened here in the last few years."

headline: Spanish Papers Thrive as Hispanic Market Surges
abstract: LEAD: The Spanish-language newspaper market in the United States seems like a pinata being whacked on all sides by entrepreneurs and media companies. All are eager to reap the profits from the surging Hispanic population, which may reach 30 million by the turn of the century.

headline: ISRAELIS PROMISE NO HELP FOR U.N.
abstract: LEAD: When the United Nations mission arrives in Jerusalem to examine the circumstances surrounding the shooting of 21 Palestinians last week, the Israeli Government will greet it with unbridled hostility.

headline: Japanese Give in Grudgingly On a New Way of Shopping
abstract: A few months ago the Summit supermarket and department store in Nakano, a quiet neighborhood on the west side of Tokyo, posted notices that it would stay open an hour later every evening, until 7 o'clock.    Within hours, the store was mobbed by owners of small shops, who carried protest signs and shouted accusations that Summit was being deceitful. The crowd kept up its protest until the store's management came out to negotiate.

headline: A Proliferation of Claims by Victims of Nazis
abstract: LEAD: After years of dwindling usefulness, Israeli organizations devoted to helping survivors of Nazi crimes win restitution from West Germany are overwhelmed with thousands of claims against the former state of East Germany.

headline: Complaints, but More Power for China Leader
abstract: One of the puzzles of the Chinese political system is that Prime Minister Li Peng seems to gain power along with unpopularity. The more he is mocked and reviled, the more he seems able to consolidate his authority.    There are still rumors that Prime Minister Li will be dismissed, and a Chinese close to disgruntled elements in the leadership says some officials are still pushing for Mr. Li's ouster. But while the situation remains unsettled, Mr. Li seems to feel more secure and self-confident than ever."He's put on a bit of weight, and he seems much more relaxed and contented than he was a year ago," said a foreigner who has periodically met with the Prime Minister.

headline: PRAGUE TO APPEAL FOR AID FROM U.S.
abstract: As flags went up and a workman on Wenceslas Square painted over graffiti saying "Yankees, Get Out of Saudi Arabia," Czechoslovakia prepared today to mark the anniversary of the revolution that toppled Communism by presenting President Bush with an appeal for economic aid.    Mr. Bush is to arrive in the Czechoslovak capital on Saturday to help mark the anniversary, on the first leg of a weeklong trip to Europe and the Middle East. On the eve of the visit, Prague officially renamed its railway station in honor of President Woodrow Wilson, who encouraged an earlier Czechoslovak push for independence.

headline: Europe Can't Heal Britain's Economy
abstract: With a speed astonishing to most Americans, Britain has selected John Major as its new Prime Minister. But changes in Britain's economic policies or in the parlous state of its economy may be much slower in coming.    At the moment, Britain is in the midst of classic stagflation: double-digit inflation, rising unemployment and declining gross national product. And, while Britain's economic forecasters are holding out hope of an orderly recovery, the expectations for that upturn are more often attributed to the natural economic cycle than to any particular policy prescription.   Mr. Major appears likely to reject one popular notion -- that greater economic integration with Europe will somehow smoothly restore Britain's economy to good health. In principle, economic integration is a good thing: classic theory suggests that freer trade should benefit all participants. But economic integration in and of itself is no more likely to cut inflation and increase output in Britain than Massachusetts' could escape its difficulties by unifying with California.   The British fascination with European integration manifests itself in the notion of linking the pound with other European currencies and eventually creating a single currency to supplement or even replace the traditional units of exchange. But such a return to fixed exchange rate policies -- and it was Mr. Major who pushed Mrs. Thatcher into entering the current European exchange rate mechanism -- carries at least as much baggage as benefit.   Because Britain's economy is not competitive with countries like Germany, maintaining the pound's assigned position in the constellation will take high domestic interest rates or direct intervention in foreign exchange markets or both. The first, which amounts to giving the Bundesbank a major voice in British economic policy, almost insures a continued slow domestic economy. That could well prove as politically hazardous for Mr. Major, who must face a general election by June 1992, as it did for Mrs. Thatcher. The latter tactic has been proved in many other countries to be extremely costly and of little efficacy for anything other than correcting short-term imbalances in foreign exchange markets.   When it comes to matters like the poll tax, change will come quickly from Mr. Major -- and the betting is that the tax will be scrapped. Imagine an American leader deciding to abolish the property tax -- which at least bears some relationship to individual wealth -- and to substitute a per capita charge that would not vary regardless of whether one's income was $10,000 or $10 million. It took extraordinary arrogance and insensitivity to believe that such a policy would be politically acceptable. Mr. Major will inevitably move toward raising revenue based on ability to pay.   Peculiarly, Britain's real difficulty is the same root problem Mrs. Thatcher found, albeit to a far lesser degree: an extraordinarily rigid and uncompetitive economy unable to produce goods and services as efficiently as trading partners. Mrs. Thatcher's biggest misjudgment was her belief that five years of monetary discipline would be enough to bring a period of strong economic growth after those policies were relaxed in 1986.   But after relaxation, inflation immediately shot up, to its current peak of more than 10 percent. In response, the Thatcher Government began to increase interest rates in late 1988, ultimately more than doubling the base rate to 15 percent and bringing economic growth to a halt. Now the country is mired in recession. The Confederation of British Industry recently forecast that the economy would contract by 1 percent in 1991. Unemployment is now expected to rise into 1992.   When the British economy was stimulated, the result was not higher domestic output but higher imports and higher inflation. For while productivity jumped in the 1987-88 boomlet, the most recent results on output per head in manufacturing showed only a 0.2 percent increase compared with a year earlier. Meanwhile, average earnings grew by 10.25 percent.   How John Major will address these most important problems remains to be seen. He emphasizes his opposition to inflation and his commitment to a classless society. He surrounds himself with bright young economists like Mervyn King and Gavyn Davies. He emphasizes that he is his own man, not a Thatcher clone or stooge. But success will depend on finding the path to freeing up Britain's economy, not only through strict macroeconomic policies and free markets, but through other avenues like education and training.   It's fine for Britain to welcome Mr. Major as part of a needed change. But it is an economic illusion for Britain to believe that its problems resided with Mrs. Thatcher or the rest of Europe or anywhere but with Britain itself. To proceed on any other foundation risks merely returning Britain to the unappetizing economic state in which Mrs. Thatcher inherited it.

headline: Kodak-Sanofi Venture Talks
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said it was considering forming a joint venture between its Sterling Drug subsidiary and the French drug company Sanofi S.A.    A Kodak spokesman, Paul Allen, confirmed the talks but said they had not progressed to the stage of an agreement.   Kodak acquired Sterling for $5.1 billion in 1987. The company makes Bayer aspirin, Phillips' milk of magnesia, Midol pain relievers and other over-the-counter products. Its best-selling prescription drug is Omnipaque, which highlights body organs during X-rays and CAT scans.   But analysts have said that Sterling has not produced the new drugs or financial returns Kodak expected.   The Wall Street Journal reported that sources close to the talks said an agreement could be reached by the end of the year. Mr. Allen would not comment.   Ronald Nordmann, a securities analyst at Paine Webber, said Sterling's established credibility with doctors in the United States would be important for Sanofi.   Kodak's stock was up 37.5 cents a share today, to $41.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Two Phone Aides Retire
abstract: The New York Telephone Company said yesterday that a former head and a current senior manager of its buildings department had retired after disclosures of widespread wrongdoing by junior managers in the construction and maintenance unit.   The retirements follow New York Telephone's announcement on Thursday that 56 more employees of the department were disciplined this week for accepting cash and other gifts from vendors. This followed the departure of 15 employees from the company in the preceding 16 months for the same reason.

headline: Croatia's Serbs Declare Their Autonomy
abstract: LEAD: In an atmosphere of rising ethnic tension, Serbs in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia today declared the republic's predominantly Serbian-populated counties to be autonomous.

headline: Day by Day Economics As Seen in Reading, Pa.
abstract: Here in this row-house industrial city 50 miles northwest of Philadelphia, evidence of economic malaise abounds, from the closing of Georgia-Pacific's fine-paper plant to a subtle shift in demand toward the cheaper brands of the Bachman Company's snack foods.   Throughout the nation, from automobile factories to dairy farms, businesses and workers are hearing talk of recession and fearing its consequences on their lives. No one place is a perfect microcosm of the United States. But the Reading area reflects both the weaknesses and the partly offsetting strengths of the economically floundering mid-Atlantic region. While its large manufacturing base tends to reflect contraction quickly, Reading's economy as a whole is diverse, and occasional visits here may provide a look at how one city deals with difficult economic times.  Drop in an Important Gauge     Some analysts think recession has already put its clammy grip on Reading and the rest of Berks County. One important gauge is a drop in the amount of electricity used by industry. This proxy for industrial output has trailed 1989 levels in three of the last four months. And the unemployment rate, though below the national average, has climbed one and a half percentage points since September 1989.

headline: Bond Deal Near Completion
abstract: LEAD: Lion Nathan Ltd. of New Zealand said today that it had settled all but the final financing details of its joint venture purchase of Bond Brewing Ltd. The acquisition would make Lion the largest beverage company in Australia and New Zealand.

headline: Atteridgeville Journal; Fighting Apartheid Power by Refusing to Pay for It
abstract: This middle-class black township has discovered what it really means to fight city hall, toppling its municipal council and defying the Transvaal provincial authorities in refusing to pay its bills.   The electricity was turned off on Oct. 15. The Mayor and his councilors resigned under pressure on Nov. 15. And Atteridgeville is now under a night curfew and state of emergency imposed by the Government on Nov. 12.

headline: U.S. Officials Call Arms Package for Saudis Vital
abstract: LEAD: In a departure from earlier explanations for selling weapons to Saudi Arabia, Bush Administration officials said today that a proposed $7.3-billion arms package for Riyadh was vital to a long-term strategy to deter attacks against the Saudis after the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: Bankers Face Increasing Skepticism Among Investors
abstract: The high dividend that Citicorp was forced to pay today on a preferred stock issue served as a reminder that many investors are skeptical about the strength of large banks despite assurances by bankers and regulators that they are solvent.   Bankers gathered here for a meeting of the American Bankers Association noted that data of the Federal Reserve through mid-October show that Citicorp and other large banking companies like Chase and Chemical have not been hit with enough deposit withdrawals to force them to borrow at the Fed's discount window.

headline: Your Money; Products to Help Trim Tax Bills
abstract: A NUMBER of excellent books and computer programs are now available to help taxpayers whittle down their income-tax liabilities. Indeed, studying them can be a profitable way to spend part of a long holiday weekend, for after the first of the year little can be done to reduce 1990 taxes.    In the remaining five weeks of the year, taxpayers can ask a number of questions and act on the answers, which vary with individual circumstances. These are among the questions taxpayers might ask:    *With the top tax bracket going up to 31 percent in 1991, from 28 percent this year, would it be a good idea to accelerate income into 1990?    *Would giving an appreciated asset, like stocks, to charity be advisable? For people not subject to the alternative minimum tax, the full market value is deductible.    *Is more withholding needed to avoid a penalty for underpayment?   *Can more money be put into a tax-deferred retirement account like an employer-sponsored 401(k) plan, or should someone with income from self-employment establish a Keogh plan?    The first step in answering these questions is to organize financial records well, and for people with an I.B.M. or compatible personal computer, the fastest, easiest, least-expensive way to do that is undoubtedly with Quicken, a personal finance program from Intuit. The new Version 4.0 tracks investments, including stocks, bonds, mutual funds, certificates of deposit and collectibles, and provides performance reports, as well as the information on interest, dividends and capital gains needed for Schedule D of the tax return. The program lists for $59.95 and is widely available for about $35.    For more detailed tax strategies, J. K. Lasser's Your 1991 Income Tax Software, which lists for $74.95, includes both the tax book "J. K. Lasser's Your 1991 Income Tax," which has justifiably beenthe best-selling income-tax guide for generations, and a year-end tax planner program. Buyers may send in a coupon to get a free upgrade for the preparation program early next year after the I.R.S. makes available all the forms for filing 1990 returns. People who wait to buy that program will not get the planner. Companion programs for 24 states can be ordered for $29.95. The Lasser program reads Quicken files and allows users to transfer data from them.    The Lasser tax book alone costs $12.95. In addition, "J. K. Lasser's Personal Tax Strategies 1991" by David S. DeJong and Ann Gray Jakabcin (Pocket Books, $4.95, 349 pages) focuses on year-end strategies and begins with a tabular presentation that makes it easy to find the place in the book where one's particular problems and possible solutions are discussed.    Another program that may be valuable for people who want an on-screen expert to guide them is Andrew Tobias's Tax Cut, from Meca Software Inc. It is written by Daniel Caine, a tax lawyer, who provides an easy question-and-answer format for novices, as well as a built-in audit function to check the return. It allows users to transfer data from Meca's very thorough personal finance program, Andrew Tobias's Managing Your Money, as well as Quicken and Lotus 1-2-3. Tax Cut offers side-by-side what-if strategies and lets people who have a"mouse" peripheral device use it. Companion programs for 10 states are available.    People who do not own computers or who are not inclined to such a hands-on approach, but who want enough knowledge for an intelligent discussion with their accountants, can choose from a number of books.   Ernst & Young's "Tax-Saving Strategies 1990-1991" (John Wiley & Sons Inc., $6.95, 229 pages) is a vest-pocket-size book from the accounting firm that can be particularly helpful in making year-end tax decisions. It is a companion to the firm's tax guide, which provides line-by-line instructions for filling out tax returns and which will be published later.    Another valuable book is "Julian Block's Year-Round Tax Strategies for the $40,000-Plus Household" (Prima Publishing, distributed by St. Martin's Press, $12.95, 278 pages). The first chapter is filled with year-end tips, and subsequent chapters consider topics like home sales, marriage and divorce, travel and moving expenses, child- or dependent-care expenses, charitable contributions, investments, audits, Social Security taxes and estate planning. Mr. Block is a lawyer who manages to avoid legalese in favor of concise, clear English.    Price Waterhouse has also lent its name to tax-planning books and has moved from one in recent years to three well-documented books this year: "The Price Waterhouse Personal Tax Adviser," which details year-end and year-round tax strategies; "The Price Waterhouse Investors' Tax Adviser," and "The Price Waterhouse Retirement Planning Adviser." The trilogy is published by Pocket Books at $5.50 each.    "The H & R Block 1991 Income Tax Guide" (Collier Books, a division of Macmillan Publishing, $9.95) is a large-format, 512-page volume with instructions for filling out the 1990 return, as well as timely advice on the new tax law for next year and help in planning year-end strategies. It also offers advice for those affected by economic and global problems, like reservists called up to military duty, union members on strike and people laid off and conducting a job search. Buyers who decide to have their returns professionally prepared can get a refund on the price of the book if Block does the return.

headline: Nuveen Offering Shares in 2 Funds
abstract: To raise $400 million in capital for two new closed-end funds, John Nuveen & Company is making initial public offerings of common stock for the Nuveen New York Investment Quality Municipal Fund Inc. and the Nuveen California Investment Quality Municipal Fund Inc.    The lead manager for both underwritings is Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. The New York fund is issuing 15 million common shares at $15 a share, and the California fund is issuing 11.5 million common shares at $15 a share.   Each fund's objective is to generate income that will be free of Federal, state and, in some cases, city income taxes. Proceeds from the offering will be invested in diversified portfolios of long-term investment-grade municipal bonds.

headline: Earnings Rise 27% At I.B.M.
abstract: LEAD: I.B.M. reported yesterday that its earnings rose nearly 27 percent for the third quarter, but financial analysts said they were concerned about declining international and personal-computer sales.

headline: Former East Germans Vote, And Kohl Is the Big Winner
abstract: LEAD: Voters electing new state legislatures in what used to be East Germany overwhelmingly chose Christian Democrats today, handing Chancellor Helmut Kohl a resounding political victory.

headline: Sigma Upgrades Standard Monitors
abstract: Sigma Designs Inc., a computer peripheral maker based in Fremont, Calif., said yesterday that it would offer special circuitry, designed to reduce electromagnetic field radiation emissions from cathode ray tube-based monitors and display systems, as a standard feature in all of its monitors for I.B.M. PC-compatible and Apple Macintosh systems.    The company has been offering the ircuitry, originally developed in Sweden, as a $200 option with its monitors. In recent years there has been increasing worry about the possible health problems associated with radiation and magnetic fields generated by computer screens. The company said that the circuitry could reduce radiation by as much as a factor of 10.

headline: DID GANGS BENEFIT FROM PAPAL VISIT?
abstract: For five days last month, Pope John Paul II traveled in and around hard-pressed Naples, visiting blighted neighborhoods on a crusade against the Camorra, the local version of the Sicilian Mafia.    Be honest, he excoriated Neapolitan politicians. Be courageous, he urged business leaders. Stand up to gangster threats of violence. "You businessmen must be in the front line in this battle," he said. "Don't give up."

headline: Ashton-Tate Has a Profit
abstract: LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Corporation, a computer software company based in Torrance, Calif, said today that it had returned to profitability after a long string of losses.

headline: Fifth Account Lost by Chiat
abstract: LEAD: Chiat/Day/Mojo in New York suffered another blow Friday when it lost the Royal Caribbean Cruise Ltd. account after a two-month review. This is the agency's fifth major loss this year.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  Crown President Likes Lure of Gold Mining
abstract: The lure of gold exploration today is the same as it was 140 years ago, says Christopher E. Herald, the geologist who is the new president of the Crown Resources Corporation, a gold exploration company based in Denver that prospects in the West and Canada.  "You just don't know when you'll stumble onto something that leads to a gold discovery," Mr. Herald said in a telephone interview from Stanley, Idaho, where the company is examining a potential gold mining site.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  S.E.C. Picks New Chief For Investment Division
abstract: Marianne K. Smythe, who has been serving as the chief of staff to the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was appointed yesterday to head the agency's investment management division.   After working at the S.E.C. for a number of years in the 1970's, Ms. Smythe went to North Carolina to teach law. Finding herself moving back to Washington, Ms. Smythe returned to the agency.

headline: German Link To U.S. Rates
abstract: German unification could raise interest rates in the United States by at least a percentage point after 1992, a Congressional study released today said.   The Congressional Joint Economic Committee, which requested the study, said in a statement that "if Germany finances higher Government spending with higher borrowing, real short-term interest rates are estimated to be a full percentage point higher in the 1990's" in the United States.   The study, by the Congressional Budget Office, projected that the rate increase in the United States could be six-tenths of 1 percent next year, nine-tenths of 1 percent by 1992, 1 percent by 1993 and 1.1 percent by 1994.   The committee said that much of the money the United States borrows comes from the savings of German people. That money helps to cover the Federal budget deficit and to pay for imports. If the German Government borrows more of those savings for its own purposes, interest rates could rise in both countries.

headline: Toyota Effort Seeks to Show How It Cares About the U.S.
abstract: LEAD: IN a move clearly calculated to counteract the recent spate of anti-Japanese advertising, Toyota Motor Corporate Services of North America Inc. has begun an extensive campaign intended to convince Americans that Toyota cares about their country.

headline: New Jersey Endorses Trump's Plan
abstract: Donald J. Trump got approval yesterday from New Jersey regulators for a deal to rescue the Taj Mahal casino, and people close to the Trump Organization said he might surprise the bondholders of another of his Atlantic City casinos, Trump's Castle, by making an $18.4 million payment due today.   The Trump Organization is believed to be sitting on millions in cash from earnings of its various properties. The interest and principal payments of many of these operations were suspended or reduced as part of a bank loan package that rescued the financier last summer.

headline: Judge Orders a Special Hearing for Milken
abstract: LEAD: After almost four years under Government investigation, Michael R. Milken is going to have his day in court - although without the possibility of a full acquittal.

headline: Saudi Curbs on Yemeni Workers Sets Off a Migration
abstract: The Saudi Government has suspended residency privileges for Yemenis working here in response to Yemen's support of Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis and set off a mass migration of at least 350,000 of them in the Last three weeks.   Officials say that by early summer the move could force out an estimated one million Yemenis, a quarter of the expatriate labor force here.

headline: Albania Discusses Abolishing One-Party System
abstract: The Communist Government of Albania has begun discussions with members of a fledgling opposition party on allowing independent political organizations in what has been a one-party country for the last 46 years.   Among the issues is how soon the current election law can be overturned. Only last month, Parliament made Communist Party entities eligible to take part in elections but proscribed any others. Parliament also set national elections for Feb. 10.

headline: World Markets Begin 1991 Pressed by Problems of 1990
abstract: World stock markets begin 1991 facing the threat of a war in the Persian Gulf, recessions or economic slowdowns around the world, and dismal earnings -- the same factors that drove stock markets down sharply in 1990. Yet many market watchers expect a better year than the one ending today.    In 1990, these pressures resulted in a worse year for stocks than even 1987, when stock markets crashed in October.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MONDAY: Veterans Day. Many government offices and banks closed; financial markets open. * Comdex computer show in Las Vegas through Thursday. TUESDAY: Industrial production for October. * I.R.S. auctions the possessions of Mustang Ranch in Reno, Nev.  WEDNESDAY: Retail sales for October. * Sentencing of John Mulheren for stock manipulation.  THURSDAY: Business inventories for October. * Deadline for Donald J. Trump to make a $47 million payment on Taj Mahal bonds.  *Senate Ethics Committee opens a hearing on five Senators who intervened with regulators on behalf of Lincoln Savings.  FRIDAY: Merchandise trade balance for September. * Consumer prices and earnings for October.

headline: RUSSIA CUTS SHARE OF SOVIET BUDGET
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, still reeling from a week of reversals, faced a major new political crisis today after the huge Russian republic voted to slash its payments to the federal budget.    Mr. Gorbachev told the Congress of People's Deputies that the confrontation left the country without a budget four days before the start of the fiscal year and threatened the nation with economic collapse.

headline: Why Cambodia's U.N. Seat Is 'Unattended'
abstract: "Temporarily unattended" is how the leaders of Cambodia's quarreling parties describe their country's empty United Nations seat as this year's General Assembly draws to a close.    "The seat is definitely not vacant, you see," insists Prince Sisowath Sirirath, Cambodia's deputy representative, who is also the personal representative of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of one of the country's four warring factions.
